questions.text: Which of the following has a molecular weight of 30,000, expands the plasma similarly to albumin, generates less hypersensitivity reactions, but needs to be used with care?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Polygeline

  • Polygeline is a polymer of urea and polypeptides derived from degraded gelatin.
  • The mean molecular weight of the polygeline molecules is 35000 with a range of 5000 to 50000. Polygeline is readily excreted in the urine so has a short half-life of about 3-6 hours.
  • This half-life increases in patients with impaired renal function to about 16 hours.
  • Hypersensitivity reactions are fewer compared to other plasma expanders and histamine release has been reported in few cases which may result in hypotension, bronchospasm and skin rash.


Online Reference: Singh A, Ali S, Shetty R. Effectiveness and Safety of Polygeline in Patients with Hypovolemia due to Trauma. J Emerg Trauma Shock. 2017 Jul-Sep;10(3):116-120. doi: 10.4103/JETS.JETS_120_16. PMID: 28855773; PMCID: PMC5566017.

* Audio Reference:

questions.text: Continuous intravenous infusion of medication X was administered at 1.6 mg per minute. The medication has a 640 mL/min clearance rate. What would the drug's steady state plasma concentration be at a 1.8 hour half-life?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (Option 1) 0.002 mg/mL
 
  • Continuous IV infusion of drug = 1.6 mg/min  
  • Clearance rate : 640 ml/min
  • Plasma concentration at 1.8 hours = Infusion rate/ Clearance rate
                                                              = 1.6/ 640
                                                              = 0.0025 mg/ml

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 39.

questions.text: What indicates the storage of drugs in tissues?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Large volume of distribution

Large volume of distribution = high aVd = High distribution and storage of drugs in tissues.

Drugs sequestrated in various tissues are unequally distributed, tend to have larger volume of distribution and longer duration of action. Some may exert local toxicity due to high concentration, e.g. tetracyclines on bone and teeth, chloroquine on retina, streptomycin on vestibular apparatus, emetine on heart and skeletal muscle.

Drugs may also selectively bind to specific intracellular organelle, e.g. tetracycline to mitochondria, chloroquine to nuclei.

* Clinical importance – Dialysis is not effective for drugs with high aVd.

* Examples of such drugs are :
  • Digoxin
  • Benzodiazepines
  • Organophosphates
  • Opioids
Pathological states, e.g. congestive heart failure, uremia, cirrhosis of liver, etc. can alter the aVd of many drugs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 24, 27.

questions.text: A patient receives 200 mg of medication. 75 mg of medicine leaves the body in approximately 90 minutes. How much drug will be left over after 6 hours if the drug follows first-order kinetics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 30.5 mg
 
  • In first-order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time.
  • 75 mg of 200 mg is excreted in 90 minutes -> 75/200 = 0.375 -> eliminated.
  • After 90 minutes; 200 -75 = 125 mg -> remaining.
  • Next 90 minutes (total 180 minutes) = 125 x 0.375 = 46.875 mg -> eliminated ; 125-46.875 = 78.125 mg -> remaining.
  • Next 90 minutes (total 270 minutes) = 78.125 x 0.375 = 29.297 mg -> eliminated ; 78.125-29.297 = 48.828 mg -> remaining
  • Next 90 minutes (total 360 minutes) = 48.828 x 0.375 = 18.310 mg -> eliminated ; 48.828-18.310 = 30.518 mg -> remaining
  • Therefore, after 6 hours, 30.5 mg is remaining.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 38, 40.

questions.text: Which of the following medications induces P-glycoprotein?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Rifampicin

P-glycoprotein (MDR 1) is a pump that causes efflux of absorbed drugs in the intestine and brush border cells of renal epithelia thus Inducing or inhibiting MDR 1 contributes towards their bioavailability and Toxicity profiles. 

*Effects of Rifampicin on MDR 1 (P-gp):
  • ↑ Transcription activity
  • ↑ Expression in duodenum
  • ↑ Expression in primary hepatocyte
  • ↑ Expression in brush border cells in renal epithelium
Option 1, 2 and 3 Drugs are inhibitors of P glycoprotein.

* Drugs that inhibits P-glycoprotein: (CAVE-Q)
  • Cyclosporine
  • Clarithromycin
  • Amiodarone
  • Verapamil
  • Erythromycin
  • Quinidine

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 87.

questions.text: To explore the effects of medicines on intestinal contractility, a guinea pig is dissected and a piece of its intestine is fixed in the modified Dales chamber. Following the addition of material X to the soup, the graph appears as shown. Which of these compounds is most similar to Substance X
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Epinephrine

After receiving drug X, contractility is shown to have decreased on this graph. When acetylcholine acts on M3 receptors, intestinal muscles become more contractile, but epinephrine inhibits contraction. Therefore, it is likely that substance X is epinephrine, a sympathomimetic medication.

In isolated preparations of gut, activation of both α and β receptors produces relaxation. In intact animals and man peristalsis is reduced and sphincters are constricted, but the effects are brief.

Epinephrine ➔ interaction with adrenoceptors ➔ G-protein mediated stimulation of cell membrane bound adenylyl cyclase ➔ increased intracellular cyclic 3',5'AMP ➔ cardiac stimulation, hepatic glycogenolysis, hyperglycemia and gut relaxation etc.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 144.

questions.text: Which class of drugs can only be administered/bought after a prescription from qualified medical practitioners?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Schedule H

Schedule H is a class of prescription drugs in India appearing as an appendix to the Drugs and Cosmetics Rules, 1945. These medications require a prescription from a licensed physician to be acquired over the counter.

Other Important Schedules: -

Schedule X- narcotics and psychotropic drugs 
Schedule G- Includes hormonal medications


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 7.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the Phase 1 clinical trial?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Drug safety

Phase I: Human pharmacology and safety

The emphasis is on safety, tolerability, and to detect any potentially dangerous effects on vital functions, such as precipitous fall/rise in blood pressure or heart rate, arrhythmias, bronchospasm, seizures, kidney/liver damage, etc.
Unpleasant side effects are noted and an attempt is made to observe the pharmacodynamic effects in man. The human pharmacokinetic parameters of the drug are measured for the first time.

Although Dosing, Pharmacodynamics is also being carried out in Phase 1 but most appropriate answer would be Drugs safety.


* Exam points about Drug development:




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 90.

questions.text: What exactly does a drug's low volume of distribution imply?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Does not accumulates in tissues

A low volume of distribution implies that the drug remains confined to the plasma compartment without getting distributed in the body tissues.  

* Audio Explanation:


Vd = Dose of drug(mg)/Concentration of drug in blood(mg/L)


* Factors governing volume of distribution:
 
  • Lipid:Water partition coefficient of the drug
  • pKa value of the drug
  • Degree of plasma protein binding
  • Affinity for different tissues
  • Fat: Lean body mass ratio
  • Disease like CHF, Uremia, cirrhosis

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 23.

questions.text: The odour of shoe polish can be seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Nitrobenzene

Nitrobenzene is an oily yellow-to-yellow-brown liquid that smells like bitter almonds or shoe polish. 
The most frequent exposure occurs in jobs where nitrobenzene is used to make dyes, medications, pesticides, or some kinds of rubber. Exposure can happen through your breath or through physical contact.

Other options: -
1. Mercaptans smell- garlic or smelly feet
2. Lacquer odour- banana smell
3. Paraldehyde odour- pungent like acetic acid

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd edition, Page No 501.

questions.text: Some medications are labeled store in a cool environment only'. At what temperature should these medications be stored?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 8–15 °C

Any temperature below 8 °C, typically between 2 and 8 °C, is considered Cold.
Cool: a temperature range of 8 to 25 °C. 
Room temperature: Average temperature in a workspace.
Warm: Between 30 and 40 °C 
Excessively hot: Any temperature over 40 °C 

Online Reference: Khuluza F, Chiumia FK, Nyirongo HM, Kateka C, Hosea RA, Mkwate W. Temperature variations in pharmaceutical storage facilities and knowledge, attitudes, and practices of personnel on proper storage conditions for medicines in southern Malawi. Front Public Health. 2023 Sep 22;11:1209903. doi: 10.3389/fpubh.2023.1209903. PMID: 37808988; PMCID: PMC10556513.

questions.text: What determines a drug's loading dose?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 1) Volume of distribution​​​​​​​

Loading dose= Volume of distribution* plasma concentration
Loading Dose is a single or few quickly repeated doses given in the beginning to attain target concentration rapidly.
 
Loading dose depends on the volume of distribution and not on CL or t½.

Loading Dose immediately raises the concentration of the medication in plasma to the desired concentration and given when the delay to reach steady state is significant, as it is for medicines having extended half-lives.

The proportionality factor that links the overall amount of drug in the body to the concentration is the volume of distribution.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 41.

choices.text: Drug is not extensively distributed in organs and tissues

questions.text: What does a low apparent volume of distribution indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 4) Drug is not extensively distributed in organs and tissues.
 
  • The drug is more concentrated in the vascular compartment and less so in the organs and tissues, according to the low apparent volume of distribution.
  • Poor lipid solubility or strong plasma protein binding of the medication can cause low distribution volume. 

* Factors determining Volume of Distribution: -

1. Lipid solubility- directly proportional 
2. Fat content - directly proportional 
3. Plasma Protein Binding- inversely proportional 
 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 23, 24.

questions.text:
Diamox, a noncompetitive antagonist of carbonic anhydrase, is prescribed for glaucoma. What causes the effect?
1. Increase in Km and Vmax
2. Decrease in Km
3. Decrease in Vmax
4. No change in Vmax
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) due to a decrease in Vmax.

A noncompetitive antagonist of carbonic anhydrase Diamox (acetazolamide) is given for glaucoma. 

* Non competitive antagonism:

  • Drug binds to a difficult allosteric site altering the receptor so unable to combine with agonist.  

  • Efficacy and Vmax decreases.

  • Dose, potency and Km does not change.

Trick : -
KiVu- Kmax increase, Vmax unchanged- Competitive
KuVr- Kmax unchanged, Vmax reduced- Non competitive
 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 47.

questions.text: Store a medicine in a cool place refers to keeping it at what temperature?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) 8°–15°

Store a drug in a cool place refers to storing at the temperature of 8-15°C.

Any temperature below 8 °C, typically between 2 and 8 °C, is considered Cold.

Cool: a temperature range of 8 to 25 °C. 
Room temperature: Average temperature in a workspace.
Warm: Between 30 and 40 °C 
Excessively hot: Any temperature over 40 °C 

Online Reference: Khuluza F, Chiumia FK, Nyirongo HM, Kateka C, Hosea RA, Mkwate W. Temperature variations in pharmaceutical storage facilities and knowledge, attitudes, and practices of personnel on proper storage conditions for medicines in southern Malawi. Front Public Health. 2023 Sep 22;11:1209903. doi: 10.3389/fpubh.2023.1209903. PMID: 37808988; PMCID: PMC10556513.

questions.text: Which is the schedule of drugs to be sold only on prescription?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Schedule H

Schedule H can only be sold after prescription.
 
  • Schedule H is a group of prescription pharmaceuticals that are legal in India and are listed as an appendix to the 1945 Drugs and Cosmetics Rules.
  • These are medications that require a prescription from a licensed physician in order to be acquired over-the-counter.
* Other Important Schedules: -

Schedule X- narcotics and psychotropic drugs 
Schedule G- Includes hormonal medications
 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page No 7.

questions.text: What is being tested in the phase 1 trial?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Safety.

Phase I trials are done mainly for testing Human pharmacology and safety> Maximum tolerable dose> Pharmacokinetic parameters.
So answer varies depending upon the options provided. The correct answer would be safety.

Therapeutic Exploration and Dose Ranging is Main focus of Phase 2 Clinical trial.
 
  • The human pharmacokinetic parameters of the drug are measured for the first time.
  • Subjects (mostly healthy volunteers, sometimes patients) are exposed to the drug one by one, starting with the lowest estimated dose and increasing stepwise to achieve the effective dose.
  • An attempt is made to determine the dose range that may be used in further studies. The emphasis is on safety, tolerability, and to detect any potentially dangerous effects.
  • No blinding is done: the study is open label.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page No 90.

questions.text:
A patient needs 180 mg of ceftriaxone. A 2 mL syringe with 10 divisions per mL is at your disposal. Ceftriaxone 500 mg/5 ml is what's in the vial.
How many divisions will you fill in the 2 ml syringe to administer 180 mg of ceftriaxone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 18

18 divisions in the 2ml syringe should be filled to give 180 mg ceftriaxone.
• 5 mL contains 500 mg drug
• So, 1mL will contain 100 mg
• 1.8 mL will contain 180 mg.
• So 1.8 mL of drug solution is required to give 180 mg of drug to the patient. That is to be taken in a 2 mL syringe.
• In 2mLsyringe, 1mL contains 10 divisions.

So 1.8 mL would come up to 18 divisions.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 24.

choices.text: No advice is required as most of the drugs are secreted negligibly in the milk
Tell her to feed the baby just before next dose
Tell mother to feed when it is least efficacious

questions.text: Which of the following instructions regarding drug use should be given to a nursing mother?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Tell her to feed the baby just before the next dose.
 
  • Toxic effects on the infant are largely dependent on entry of the drug in milk in pharmacologically significant amounts.
  • In the case of large number of drugs (except those acting on CNS and few others), the concentration in milk is low, and the breastfed infant receives insufficient quantity to produce adverse effects.
  • But to be on the safer side nursing mothers should be encouraged to feed the infant right before the next dose because this is when the plasma concentration of the drug is at its lowest.
Maintain a gap of 2-3 hours between drug intake and breast feeding. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page No 1020.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not prohibited by the International Olympic Committee?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Cromoglycate
 
  • As analytical science validated improved techniques to identify these drugs, Olympic athletes, including many medalists were caught and disqualified.
  • When the International Olympic Committee (IOC) prohibited beta blockers (beneficial in shooting), diuretics (assist weight classified athletes) and Glucorticosteroids, some athletes with genuine medical conditions were denied legitimate medical therapy.
  • To overcome this, in 1992 the IOC introduced a system known now as Therapeutic Use Exemption (TUE). This paper discusses Olympic athletes who have been known to dope at past Games and some medical indications and pitfalls in the TUE process.

Online Reference:
Fitch K. Proscribed drugs at the Olympic Games: permitted use and misuse (doping) by athletes. Clin Med (Lond). 2012 Jun;12(3):257-60. doi: 10.7861/clinmedicine.12-3-257. PMID: 22783779; PMCID: PMC4953490.

choices.text: Both A and B are having same potency
B and C have the same efficacy
A and C have same binding site

questions.text: Pick the statement that is true about the following dose response.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) C is a noncompetitive antagonist

C is a noncompetitive antagonist as it shows less efficacy than A and B.

 
* Efficacy is measured by the maximal height of the curve.

Order of Efficacy: A=B>C

* Potency is measured by the distance of the curve from the Y-axis.

Order of potency - A>B>C

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page No 64.

choices.text: Research papers and other articles proving the efficacy of the drug

questions.text: Each medication formulation must include a drug advertisement letter that provides numerous details regarding the drug, such as dosage, frequency, and half-life. Which of the following details does the medication advertisement letter not need to include?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is (Option 1) Research papers and other articles proving the efficacy of the drug

The medication advertisement letter does not need to include research papers and other articles proving the efficacy of the drug. This is because the efficacy of the drug has already been proven through clinical trials and is approved by the FDA/CDSCO

* The medication advertisement letter should include the following details:

  • Dosage: The recommended dosage of the drug, as well as any dosing adjustments that may be necessary for certain populations (e.g., children, elderly, pregnant women).
  • Frequency: How often the drug should be taken.
  • Half-life: The amount of time it takes for the body to eliminate half of the drug.
  • Adverse effects: Any potential side effects of the drug, including both common and rare side effects.
  • Precautions: Any special instructions or warnings that patients should be aware of before taking the drug.
  • Storage instructions: How the drug should be stored to ensure its potency.
  • Call to action: A statement that encourages patients to talk to their doctor about whether or not the drug is right for them.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 93.

choices.text: Postauricular skin > scalp > scrotum > dorsal aspect of hand > sole
Postauricular skin > scrotum > scalp > dorsal aspect of hand >sole
Scalp >scrotum > postauricular skin > dorsal aspect of hand >sole
Scrotum > scalp > postauricular skin > dorsal aspect of hand >sole

questions.text: Select the option that correctly represents the sequence of the rate of topical drug absorption.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Postauricular skin > scrotum > scalp > dorsal aspect of hand >sole

*Factors that affect the absorption of drugs through the skin:
  • 1. Concentration
  • 2. The molecular weight of the molecule
  • 3. Duration of contact
  • 4. Solubility of medication
  • 5. Physical condition of the skin
  • 6. Part of the body exposed including the amount of hair on the skin.

In general, the rate of absorption of chemicals through the skin follows the following scheme:

Postauricular skin > Scrotal > Armpit= Scalp > Back = Abdomen > Palm= under the surface of the foot.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: Which of these drugs does not cause pigmentation of nail?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Amiodarone
 
  • All of the given options cause nail pigmentation except Amiodarone.
  • Amiodarone can cause corneal deposits but doesn't cause nail pigmentation.  Amiodarone also can cause skin hyper pigmentation. Skin hyperpigmentation is another important adverse effect, affecting 4–9% of patients taking amiodarone.
  • long-term therapy with amiodarone leads to characteristic blue-grey discolorations, located mostly on the face, ears, and palms of the hands.

* Nail pigmentation causing drugs:

  • Phenothiazines like chlorpromazine
  • Chloroquine
  • Minocycline
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 578.

choices.text: To adjust maintenance dose of digoxin required to keep the blood levels within therapeutic range
Intravenous administration in emergency and urgent dosing
It requires a high loading dose to be administered

questions.text: Digoxin has a 36-hour half-life and is derived from a plant product. How can this information aid in the creation of a treatment plan?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) To adjust maintenance dose of digoxin required to keep the blood levels within therapeutic range 

 
The given half-life determines the daily maintenance dosing to maintain therapeutic plasma levels.
 
  • The half-life of digoxin is 36 to 48 hours in patients with normal renal function and 3.5 to 5 days in anuric patients.
  • In patients with normal renal function, an oral daily maintenance dose without a loading dose results in a steady-state blood concentration in approximately 7 days.
  • Hence, the daily maintenance dose is decided based on the half-life of the drug.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 559.

questions.text: You are to begin the treatment of an 80 kg male patient with an inotrope at a dose of 10 mcg/kg/min after he reported to the emergency room with hypotension. 200 mg of the medication are present in each 5 mL amp. You decide to produce a 250 mL solution using the medication from 2 ampules combined with saline. Given that 16 drops equal 1 mL, what should the drug solution flow rate be to maintain the patient's blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 8 drops/min

A dosing of 10 microgram/kg/min of the drug is required 

Weight = 80 kg

Total dose required= 10*80 = 800 mcg/min = 0.8 mg/min

Now,
two 5 mL vials each containing 200 mg are diluted to a 250 mL solution 

i.e. 400 mg is mixed in 250 mL

 

Concentration of solution: 1 mL = 400/250 mg = 8/5 = 1.6 mg/mL 

Now, 1 mL = 16 drops= 1.6 mg

i.e. 16 drops contain 1.6 mg

Hence, 0.8 mg/min= 8 drops/min= 0.5 mL/min
 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 24.

questions.text: What of the following does not become an active metabolite?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1)  Lisinopril
 
  • Lisinopril is a lysine derivative of enalaprilat and requires no active hydrolysis. Enalapril is a prodrug and its active metabolite is Enalprilat. 
  • Cyclophosphamide gets converted to its active metabolite  4-hydroxycyclophosphamide in liver while Fluoxetine gets converted to the active metabolite norfluoxetine in liver (desmethylfluoxetine). 
  • Another ACE inhibitor that is not prodrug is Captopril.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 532.

questions.text: A clinical trial's post-marketing surveillance is a component of which stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Phase IV

* [Extra Edge]: Phase 4 of clinical trials

A type of clinical trial that studies the side effects caused over time by a new treatment after it has been approved and is on the market. These trials look for side effects that were not seen in earlier trials and may also study how well a new treatment works over a long period of time.

* Phase 1: First testing in humans, primarily to test safety. A drug is given to a small number of healthy volunteers who are closely monitored.

* Phase 2: Testing in a small number of patients, to assess safety, to monitor how a drug is metabolized, and to gather initial data on efficacy.

* Phase 3: A large trial in patients to test efficacy and safety. Pivotal phase 3 trials (or registration trials) provide the key data on efficacy in submissions for regulatory approval.

* Phase 4: Studies undertaken after a drug has been licensed, to gather further safety, efficacy or effectiveness data in routine clinical use.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 91.

questions.text: What is the name given to the body's ability to eliminate the drug from the body?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Clearance

The clearance of the drug is the theoretical volume of plasma from which the drug is completely removed in unit time. 

It can be calculated as:

Clearance = Rate of elimination/Concentration



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 38.

questions.text: Pick the trial that can be performed to determine the maximal tolerated dose of a drug.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Phase I trial

Phase I which includes Human Pharmacology and safety testing is performed to determine the maximum tolerated dose of a drug.
* Later stages include -
  • Phase II: Therapeutic exploration and dose-ranging
  • Phase III: Therapeutic confirmation and comparison
  • Phase IV: Post-marketing surveillance and studies.
In Phase I Clinical trial - Subjects (mostly healthy volunteers, sometimes patients) are exposed to the drug one by one, starting with the lowest estimated dose and increasing stepwise to achieve the effective dose.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 90.

choices.text: Both efficacy and non-efficacy of the drug
Either efficacy and non-efficacy of the drug

questions.text: The 95% confidence interval is employed in clinical trials to look for the following things when evaluating a newly produced drug's effectiveness in contrast to placebo:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Efficacy of the drug

  • Confidence intervals are estimates that provide a lower and upper threshold to the estimate of the magnitude of effect.
  • By convention, 95% confidence intervals are most typically reported.
  • These intervals represent the range in which we can, with 95% confidence, assume the treatment effect to fall within.
  • Confidence interval in a drug trial is used to test its clinical efficacy, it would suggest to what amount the effect observed can be contributed to the drug and is not by chance.
  • In contrast, if the clinical merits of a treatment appear different when considering the possibility of the lower versus the upper confidence intervals, one may be more cautious about the expected benefits to be anticipated with treatment.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 84.

choices.text: Should be present in the same tissue as the primary target

questions.text: One of the many mechanisms of adverse events of a drug is its increased binding to secondary targets, usually proteins. With respect to the primary target, the secondary target:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Should have similar binding sites 
 
  • One of the many mechanisms of adverse events is its increased binding to secondary targets, usually proteins. With respect to primary target, the secondary target should have similar binding sites. 
  • Many drugs, such as aspirin, barbiturates, phenytoin, sulfonamides, valproic acid, and warfarin, are highly protein bound in the plasma, and it is the free (unbound) drug that produces the clinical effects.
  • These drugs may have enhanced toxicity in overdose if protein-binding sites become saturated in physiological states that lead to hypoalbuminemia, or when displaced from plasma proteins by other drugs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 94.

questions.text: Pick the option that is correct regarding orphan drugs.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Drugs used for rare diseases 
 
  • Orphan drug is a medication used to treat, prevent, or diagnose an orphan disease.
  • An orphan disease is a rare disease or condition that affects fewer than 200,000 people in the United States.
  • Orphan diseases are often serious or life threatening. In 1983, the U.S. government passed a law, called the Orphan Drug Act, to give drug companies certain financial benefits for developing orphan drugs that are safe and effective.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 7.

choices.text: Decreasing binding affinity of the drug to target protein
Increasing binding affinity of the drug to non-target protein
Increasing number of interactions of drug with target protein

questions.text: The primary concern in drug designing is in ensuring  ______________________?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Increasing number of interactions of drug with target protein 
 
  • Identification of the target biomolecule is the starting point for new drug invention. A lead compound capable of interacting with the target is searched by applying diverse approaches.
  • It is then chemically modified to optimize parameters such as pharmacokinetic, pharmaceutical, toxicological and other characteristics.
  • One concern of drug designing is to improve the “fit” of the drug with the target and thus enhancing the high-affinity interactions with the target protein with the help of Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) studies of the drug-receptor complex.
  • The number interactions help in stimulating the desired result, the affinity of interaction as such doesn't change the desired outcome even if the affinity is increased.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 88.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below ought to only be available with a doctor's prescription?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1)  Schedule H drugs

Under Drugs and Cosmetics Rules, 1945, Schedule H is a class of prescription drugs, which cannot be purchased over the counter without the prescription of a qualified doctor.

* Schedule H drug Warning: To be sold by retail on the prescription of a Registered Medical Practitioner only.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 7.

questions.text: Which of the following provides a graph showing the rate of medication absorption in plasma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Tmax and Cmax 

Tmax - Time to attain the peak plasma concentration
Cmax - Peak plasma concentration These give the rate of drug absorption in plasma concentration graphs.

Bioavailability refers to the rate and extent of absorption of a drug from a dosage form administered by any route, as determined by its concentration-time curve.
  • Rate of drug absorption - Tmax and Cmax.
  • Extent of drug absorption - Area under the curve (AUC).

 Diagram: Formulation B is more slowly absorbed than A, and though ultimately both are absorbed to the same extent (area under the curve same).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: Which of the following ways is most likely to result in 100% bioavailability of the drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Intravenous 

* Intravenous drug route:
 
  • Factors limiting absorption i.e., Aqueous solubility, Concentration, Area of absorbing surface and Vascularity of the absorbing surface etc. are circumvented by intravenous injection of drugs in aqueous solution because bioavailability is complete and rapid.
  • Also, drug delivery is controlled and achieved with an accuracy and immediacy not possible by any other procedure.

Bioavailability of drug injected via intravenous route is 100%, but is frequently lower after oral ingestion because—

(a) the drug may be incompletely absorbed.
(b) the absorbed drug may undergo first pass metabolism in the intestinal wall/liver or be excreted in bile.

* Incomplete bioavailability after subcutaneous or intramuscular injection is less common but may occur due to local binding of the drug.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: Which of the following medication delivery methods will not circumvent hepatic first-pass metabolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Oral 
 
  • When drugs are taken orally, they may not be absorbed by the body as much as they should be.
  • This is due to two main factors: the incomplete extent of the drug being absorbed by the gut wall and the liver being able to break down or eliminate the drug before it has a chance to be absorbed.
  • As a result, the bioavailability of the drug is less than 100%.
  • All orally administered drugs are exposed to drug metabolizing enzymes in the intestinal wall and liver (where they first reach through the portal vein).
  • Presystemic metabolism in the gut and liver can be avoided by administering the drug through sublingual, transdermal or parenteral routes.

* Clinical points about drugs with high first pass metabolism:

(a) Oral dose is considerably higher than sublingual or parenteral dose.

(b) There is marked individual variation in the oral dose due to differences in the extent of first pass metabolism.
(c) Oral bioavailability is apparently increased in patients with severe liver disease.
(d) Oral bioavailability of a drug is increased if another drug competing with it in first pass metabolism is given concurrently, e.g. chlorpromazine and propranolol.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 34.

questions.text: Narrow therapeutic index can be observed with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Lithium

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index and hence, requires TDM (Therapeutic Drug Monitoring).
Therapeutic levels are 0.8-1.2mEq/L while toxicity is seen at >1.5mEq/L.

* [Extra Edge]: Drugs with low safety margin
  • Digoxin
  • Anticonvulsants
  • Antiarrhythmics
  • Theophylline
  • Aminoglycoside antibiotics
  • Lithium
  • Tricyclic antidepressants
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 476.

questions.text: Which of the following teratogenic effects in incorrectly matched?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Zidovudine - Skull Defects

Zidovudine is not a known teratogenic drug. Animal studies have revealed evidence of embryofetal toxicity but have failed to reveal evidence of teratogenicity.

* [Extra Edge]: Teratogenic Drugs




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 100.

questions.text: Select the drug from the given graph which has the highest potency.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Drug A

The Dose Response Curve (DRC) on the X axis defines the potency of a drug. The further left the DRC is positioned on the X axis, the more potent the drug is. In the graph provided, the DRC of Drug A is to the far left, indicating that Drug A is the most potent of the three drugs. This means that the potency of Drug A is greater than B and C.

The position of DRC on the dose axis is the index of drug potency which refers to the amount of drug needed to produce a certain response. 
The upper limit of DRC is the index of drug efficacy and refers to the maximal response that can be elicited by the drug.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 64.

questions.text: What is the therapeutic index a measure of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) Safety

The therapeutic index of a drug is a measure of its safety, because it means that a high value creates a wide space between doses that can cause harm.

The median lethal dose (LD50) and median effective dose (ED50) are used to measure the therapeutic index of a drug: the ratio between the dose required to produce a desired effect and the dose necessary to cause the drug's adverse effects.

Therapeutic window is a range of steady-state concentrations of a drug that provides therapeutic efficacy with minimal toxicity. In clinical studies, the dose or concentration required to produce toxic effects can be compared to concentrations that produce therapeutic effects to evaluate the clinical therapeutic index.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 65.

questions.text: What does the loading dose of a drug depend upon
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Volume of distribution 

Loading Dose is a single or few quickly repeated doses given in the beginning to attain target concentration rapidly.
Thus, loading dose is governed only by V and not by CL or t½.

Variables are used to calculate the loading dose:
  • Cp = desired peak concentration of drug,
  • F = bioavailability, 
  • Vss = volume of distribution of drug at steady state,
                                                                                   Loading dose= Cp*Vss/F
    

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 41.

questions.text: 500 mg of paracetamol are listed on the label by the drug's manufacturer. Analysis revealed that it barely contained 200 milligrammes of the substance. What class of drug is it considered to be
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Counterfeit drug

Counterfeit medicine is a fake product, which might be contaminated or have the incorrect or absent active ingredients. They may also have the right active ingredient, but not in the amount labelled on the drug company's label. For example, if the label says the product contains 500 mg of paracetamol, but upon analysis only 200 mg is present, then it is a counterfeit drug. It's not adulterant drug because there is no addition of other drug or substance.

* Other options:-

2. Spurious drug- False identity drugs that deceive buyers 
3. Adulterant drug- Is substance mixed with drug which is not a constituent of it to reduce the quality
4. Unethical drug- no such term exist

Online Reference:
Pathak R, Gaur V, Sankrityayan H, Gogtay J. Tackling Counterfeit Drugs: The Challenges and Possibilities. Pharmaceut Med. 2023 Jul;37(4):281-290. doi: 10.1007/s40290-023-00468-w. Epub 2023 May 15. PMID: 37188891; PMCID: PMC10184969.

choices.text: Tenofovir: Inhibits assembly of proviral components into viral proteins
Enfuvirtide: An entry inhibitor, inhibits viral entry by binding to CCR5  receptor
Dolutegravir: Inhibits integration of viral DNA into host

questions.text: Which of the following medications matches its mode of action correctly
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Dolutegravir: Inhibits integration of viral DNA into host 

Integrase Strand Transfer Inhibitors (INSTIs) are antiviral agents that bind to the integrase enzyme of HIV-1 and HIV-2 and prevent the third and final stage of viral DNA integration into host cell chromosomes.
Dolutegravir is an INSTI that inhibits the integration of viral DNA into the host cell, successfully halting the replication of the virus.

*Trick- Anti HIV drugs ending with suffix -gravir are integrase inhibitors.

* [Extra Edge]: Anti-Retroviral Drug-
 
MECHANISM OF ACTION  EXAMPLE
NRTIs Zidovudine
Emtricitabine
Tenofovir
Lamivudine
NNRTIs Nevirapine
Efavirenz
PIs Ritonavir
Indinavir
Lopinavir
Entry inhibitor Enfuvirtide
CCR-5R inhibitor Maraviroc
INSTIs Raltegravir
Deglutagravir


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 867.

questions.text: Identify the schedule X drug from the given options-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ketamine

Psychotropic medications are classified as Schedule X substances and require specific permission to manufacture and sale. The list of medications on schedule X is below: Amobarbital, Glutethimide, Pentobarbital, Ketamine, Amphetamine, Meprobamate, Phencyclidine, Methamphetamine, Phendimetrazine, Methylphenidate, Ethchlorvynol.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 101.

questions.text: Identify the GPCR that does not function through opening of K+.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Angiotensin 1 receptor

M2, D2, and 5HT1 are Gi/o subtypes of GPCRs and work by opening potassium channels. In addition, the Go subtype lowers calcium while the Gi subtype lowers cyclic AMP. 

* On the other hand, the angiotensin 1 receptor is a Gq subtype of GPCR that works by raising calcium through IP3. (Phospholipase IP3/DAG activation)
  • Gs : Adenylyl cyclase activation, Ca2+channel opening
  • Gi : Adenylyl cyclase inhibition, K+ channel opening
  • Go : Ca2+ channel inhibition
  • Gq : Phospholipase C activation

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 54.

questions.text: What is the management in case of a person taking 60,000 IU of vitamin D for long time, which lead to Vitamin D toxicity
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 2) Glucocorticoid

The use of glucocorticoid (Dexamethasone, prednisolone, etc.) therapy will lower plasma calcium levels by inhibiting the action of vitamin D (1,25D), which leads to decreased intestinal calcium absorption and increased urine calcium excretion. Loss of osteoid (decreased formation and increased resorption) indirectly results in loss of Ca2+ from bone, producing negative calcium balance.

Other medications like chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine are less effective in treating hypercalcemia due to vitamin D toxicity.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 309.

choices.text: Half-life remains same and plasma concentration doubles.

questions.text: When a drug's dose is doubled while adhering to first order kinetics, what happens to the drug's half life and plasma concentration
questions.solution:
The correct option is (1) Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles.

  • In first-order kinetics, the rate of drug elimination is proportional to its plasma concentration.
  • The half-life (t½) remains constant because it depends on the drug's clearance and volume of distribution, which do not change with dose.
  • Plasma concentration doubles because the drug is eliminated at a proportional rate, maintaining first-order kinetics.



 Fig: Plasma concentration-time plot of a drug eliminated by first order kinetics after intravenous injection

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 38.

choices.text: Fixed dose combination over single dose drugs

questions.text: Except for the following, all are criteria for essential drugs:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Fixed dose combination over single dose drugs

The WHO has defined Essential Medicines (drugs) as “those that satisfy the priority healthcare needs of the population.”
They are selected with due regard to public health relevance, evidence on efficacy and safety, and comparative cost effectiveness.


 *The WHO's criteria for an Essential drug- 
  • Adequate information on its adequacy and safety should be available from clinical research. 
  • available in a form whose quality, including bioavailability, and storage stability can be guaranteed. 
  • The pattern of prevalent diseases, the availability of facilities and qualified staff, financial resources, as well as genetic, demographic, and environmental factors should all be taken into consideration while choosing drug. 
  • When two or more drugs are similar, a decision should be made based on the relative efficacy, safety, quality, price, and availability of each. A key factor to take into account is the cost-benefit ratio.
  • Comparative pharmacokinetic characteristics and available manufacturing and storage options in the area.
  • The majority of basic medications ought to be single compounds. Only when the dosage of each ingredient satisfies the needs of a specific population group and when the combination has a demonstrated benefit in therapeutic impact, safety, adherence, or reducing the establishment of drug resistance, could products with fixed ratio combinations be included. 
  • Choosing essential drugs should be an ongoing process that takes into consideration the shifting priorities for public health action, epidemiological conditions, the availability of better medications/formulations, and advancements in pharmacological knowledge. 
  • Recently, the importance of choosing important medications based on clinically sound treatment recommendations has been stressed.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 6.

choices.text: Blood from a dengue patient is injected into stomach of Aedes mosquito and the mosquito is used for vira
Sandfly is allowed to bite a hamster infected with leishmaniasis

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of xenodiagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Rabbit ileal loop toxin study

  • Xenodiagnosis is a diagnostic method used to document the presence of infectious disease microorganisms or pathogens by exposing possibly infected tissue to a vector and then examining the vector for the presence of the microorganisms or pathogens it may have ingested.
  • It is mainly used in the diagnosis of Chaga’s disease, Arboviral infections, Trypanosomiasis.
  • Rabbit ileal loop study is for food poisoning of clostridium.
Online Reference:
Duncan CL, Sugiyama H, Strong DH. Rabbit ileal loop response to strains of Clostridium perfringens. J Bacteriol. 1968 May;95(5):1560-6. doi: 10.1128/jb.95.5.1560-1566.1968. PMID: 4297020; PMCID: PMC252176.

questions.text: What is a drug's half-life if its elimination rate constant is 0.05/hr
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 13.9 hr

Plasma half-life (t½) of a drug is the time taken for its plasma concentration to be reduced to half of its original value.
Elimination rate constant (k) of the drug is the fraction of the total amount of drug in the body which is removed per unit time.
     
      * t1/2 = ln2/k 
      * t1/2 = 0.693/ Elimination Rate Constant = 0.693/0.05=13.9 hr.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 39.

questions.text: Which of the following does an anionic and slightly acidic medication often bind to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Albumin

  • Drugs can either be acidic or basic in nature. Depending on this, they bind to different plasma proteins in the blood.
  • Acidic drugs tend to bind to basic plasma proteins like Albumin. Eg : NSAIDs, Warfarin, Aspirin.
  • Basic drugs bind to acidic plasma proteins like α1 - acid glycoprotein. Eg. Opiods, Tricyclic antidepressants, amiodarone.
* The clinically significant implications of plasma protein binding are:
 
  • (i) Highly plasma protein bound drugs are largely restricted to the vascular compartment, so they tend to have smaller volumes of distribution.
  • (ii) The bound fraction is not available for action. However, it is in equilibrium with the free drug in plasma and dissociates when the concentration of the latter is reduced due to elimination.
  • (iii) High degree of protein binding generally makes the drug long acting, because bound fraction is not available for metabolism or excretion, unless it is actively extracted by liver or by kidney tubules.
  • (vi) In hypoalbuminemia, binding may be reduced and high concentrations of free drugs may be attained, e.g. phenytoin and furosemide.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 25.

questions.text: What are the bases for the drug classifications A, B, C, D, and X?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Safety in pregnancy

The Classification is based on safety in pregnancy.

  1. Category A - No demonstrable risk to the foetus. Eg : Levothyroxine, Folic Acid.
  2. Category B - Animal reproduction studies have failed to demonstrate a risk to the foetus and there are no adequate and well controlled studies in pregnant women. Eg : Metformin.
  3. Category C - Animal reproduction studies have shown an adverse effect on fetus.
  4. Category D - Positive evidence of human fetal risk, but potential benefits may warrant use of drugs in pregnant women despite potential risk. Eg : Losartan.
  5. Category X - Animal studies have demonstrated foetal abnormalities. Eg, Atorvastatin.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 101.

choices.text: Drug B decreases the first pass metabolism of drug A
Drug B increases the systemic metabolism of drug A
Drug B decreases the intestinal absorption of drug A
Drug B increases the renal clearance of drug A

questions.text:
The data for drug A's AUC alone and when coupled with drug B are shown in the following table. The p value is 0.0
DRUG Area Under The Curve (AUC)
A alone 550 \(\pm\) 150
A plus B 850 \(\pm\) 150
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Drug B decreases the first pass metabolism of drug A

The most accurate interpretation of this data is that Drug B reduces the First Pass Metabolism of Drug A.

AUC (Area under the curve) demonstrates the extent of absorption of a drug. The given data has a p-value < 0.01 which is significant. According to the given data, AUC of drug A is increased when combined with drug B. This implies that drug A is absorbed better when combined with drug B.

First - pass metabolism refers to the metabolism of a drug that occurs in the liver and intestine after absorption from the gastrointestinal tract before it reaches the systemic circulation. If first - pass metabolism is reduced, more of the drug will reach the systemic circulation, resulting in increased bioavailability and a higher AUC.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 34.

choices.text: Should not be used as it is irrational
Can be used as both have a different mechanism of action
Should not be used due to addiction
Can be used to treat cough effectively

questions.text: If dextromethorphan and codeine are being marketed together as an antitussive. How should the combination be handled?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Should not be used as it is irrational

Codeine combined with dextromethorphan as an anti-tussive is an irrational combination.

Codeine and dextromethorphan like central antitussive agents must be combined with:

i. Nasal decongestants
ii. Mucolytic
iii. Expectorant
iv. Paracetamol

Combing two centrally acting antitussive agents have no added advantage so it's an irrational combination. 

These can help to reduce cough effectively.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 239.

choices.text: it increases the half-life of the drug
It protects the acid labile drug from gastric pH
It increases the absorption of drugs that are preferentially absorbed distal to the stomach
It protects the stomach from irritant drugs

questions.text: Identify the one which is not an advantage of an enteric-coated tablet:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) it increases the half-life of the drug

All of the following are advantages of enteric coated tablet except option A- it increases the half life of the drug.

Certain drugs are degraded in the gastrointestinal tract, e.g. penicillin G by acid, insulin by peptidases, and are ineffective orally.
Enteric coated tablets (having acid resistant coating) and sustained release preparations (drug particles coated with slowly dissolving material) can be used with superadded benefits.

* Advantages of enteric coated tablets are as follows:
 
  • Enteric-coated capsules do not dissolve in the mouth and therefore are perfect for formulations that need not to be activated by acid exposure.
  • This enteric coated capsule typically takes an hour or two to dissolve, making it ideal for time- sensitive medications.
  • It protects the acid labile drug from gastric pH.
  • It protects the stomach from irritant drugs 
  • It increases the absorption of drugs that are preferentially absorbed distal to the stomach
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 21.

questions.text: The activity of vitamin K is countered by dicumarol by:
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 1) Competitive Inhibition.

Dicumarol is a competitive inhibitor of vitamin K epoxide reductase; thus, it inhibits vitamin K recycling and causes depletion of active vitamin K in blood.

*Mechanism of action:

Dicumarol inhibits the enzyme vit K epoxide reductase (VKOR) and interfere with regeneration of the active hydroquinone form of vit K which acts as a cofactor for the enzyme γ-glutamyl carboxylase that carries out the final step of γ carboxylating glutamate residues of prothrombin and factors VII, IX and X. This carboxylation is essential for the ability of the clotting factors to bind Ca2+ and to get bound to phospholipid surfaces, necessary for the coagulation sequence to proceed.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 667.

choices.text: Dosing rate = Vd x Target Plasma Concentration
Dosing rate = CL x Target Plasma Concentration

questions.text: Drug administration and elimination rates are equal. How will you determine the drug's dosing rate to keep the concentration at a constant state?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Dosing rate = CL x Target Plasma Concentration

The formula for drug dosing rate is clearance x plasma concentration.

*Steady-state concentration (Css) = F x Dosing rate/ CL
  • where dosing rate is the dose per time interval and is dose/T
  • F is the fractional bioavailability, CL is clearance.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 40.

questions.text: Dicoumarol inhibits the effects of vitamin k by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Competitive inhibition
 
  • Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by competitive inhibition.
  • Dicoumarol and warfarin competitively inhibit the gamma-carboxylation system due to structural similarity with vitamin K.
  • Therefore, they can act as anticoagulants used for therapeutic purposes.
Dicumarol is a competitive inhibitor of vitamin K epoxide reductase; thus, it inhibits vitamin K recycling and causes depletion of active vitamin K in blood.

*Mechanism of action:

Dicumarol inhibits the enzyme vit K epoxide reductase (VKOR) and interfere with regeneration of the active hydroquinone form of vit K which acts as a cofactor for the enzyme γ-glutamyl carboxylase that carries out the final step of γ carboxylating glutamate residues of prothrombin and factors VII, IX and X. This carboxylation is essential for the ability of the clotting factors to bind Ca2+ and to get bound to phospholipid surfaces, necessary for the coagulation sequence to proceed.

* [Extra Edge]: Competitive Inhibitor Vs Non competitive Inhibitor
 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 667.

choices.text: Eye drops applied first, wait 15 minutes then apply ointment
Eye ointment applied first, wait 15 minutes, then apply eyedrops

questions.text: A nurse prescribes an eye drop and an eye ointment to a patient. What should she suggest about applying it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option C) - Eye drops applied first, wait for 15 mins and then apply ointment.

Ointments are greasy semisolid preparations meant for external application to the skin, eye, nasal mucosa, ear or anal canal.

The drug is incorporated in an oily base, such as soft or hard paraffin, wool fat, bee’s wax, etc. Ointments are not suitable for oozing surfaces, because they are more occlusive and do not allow evaporation of water.

Thus, Eye drops must be instilled before applying eye ointment, since the ointment will affect the absorption of the eye drop.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 9.

choices.text: It is time consuming and extremely costly
It is based on trial and error
Structure of biological target is obtained via Xray crystallography
Not a part of rational drug designing

questions.text: What is true about structural drug designing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) The structure of the biological target is obtained via Xray crystallography
 
  • Rational design of drugs refers to the ability to predict the appropriate molecular structure of a drug on the basis of information about its biological receptor.
  • Structure-based drug design is becoming an essential tool for faster and more cost-efficient lead discovery relative to the traditional method.
  • The 3D structures of all therapeutically important proteins are determined experimentally by integrative structure biology techniques such as NMR, X-ray crystallography, or cryo-electron microscopy.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's the pharmacological basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 4.

choices.text: Decreasing interaction of drug with target proteins

questions.text: Where does the issue occur in the design of new drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Increasing drug interaction with non-target proteins.


Drug design, often referred to as rational drug design is the inventive process of finding new medications based on the knowledge of a biological target.

  • A successful drug with a protein target must bind to its target with high affinity so that even a small dose of the drug will yield a blood concentration high enough to bind a large fraction of the targeted protein.
  • If the affinity were low, then a high concentration of drug would be needed for a substantial fraction of the target sites to be occupied, and a large dose of drug would need to be administered, leading to inconvenience and an increased risk of side effects.
  • The affinity of a small molecule for a protein is generally given as the dissociation constant, the concentration of free drug molecules in solution at which 50% of the targeted protein has bound drug, the lower this concentration, the higher the affinity
 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 88.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an unfavourable interaction of drug and substrate in human beings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Retinoic acid inhibits vitamin E

Unfavorable interaction of drug and substrate in human beings are all except (d) Retinoic acid inhibits vitamin E.
Retinoic acid has zero effect on vitamin E absorption.

*Other options: -
1. Ompeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor thus it reduces stomach acid secretion
2. Methotrexate is a dihydrofolate reductase inhibitor so it inhibits folic acid.
3. Babiturates decreases B12 absorption

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 953.

choices.text: Increasing the absorption of drug in intestine

questions.text: Identify the effect of P-glycoprotein.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option 3) Decreasing concentration of drug in brain

P-GLYCOPROTEIN:
  • ATP dependent efflux pump also called Multidrug Resistant protein 1
  • Functions
  1. Biological barrier – Extrudes toxins and xenobiotics ( like chemotherapeutic agents ) out of cells. 
  2. Protect the body from harmful substances by removing drugs absorbed in the intestines back into the gut lumen. 
  3. Maintains the integrity of the blood brain barrier
  4. Excretes drugs from the kidneys and liver into the urine and bile respectively.
Option 3: P glycoprotein maintains the integrity of the blood brain barrier thereby decreasing the drug entry inside brain. This leads to the decrease in drug concentration in the brain. Hence, its the correct option

Other options

Option 1  P-glycoprotein helps in removing drugs absorbed in the intestines back into the gut lumen. Therefore the statement "Increasing the absorption of drug in intestine" is incorrect. 

Option 2  P-glycoprotein increases excretion of drugs from the kidneys into the urine. Hence, option 2 " Decreasing excretion of drug by kidney" is incorrect.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 19.

choices.text: Constant amount of drug is eliminated in first order kinetics
Half life is constant in first order kinetics
Elimination is dependent on plasma concentration in first order kinetics

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding drugs.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Constant amount of drug is eliminated in first order kinetics

* [Extra Edge]: Elimination Kinetics 






Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 38.

choices.text: Quinine induced hemolytic anemia in G6PD deficiency

questions.text: The following adverse effect is not a pharmacogenetic condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Glaucoma precipitated by atropine

Pharmacogenetics is commonly referred to as the study of a single genetic variation on a drug's disposition and effects.
  • In G6PD deficiency, red blood cell destruction can be triggered by infections, certain foods (such as fava beans), and certain medicines, including antimalarial medicines such as quinine.
  • Barbiturates may exacerbate acute intermittent porphyria or porphyria variegata by inducing the enzymes responsible for porphyrin synthesis.
  • Atropine may precipitate angle closure glaucoma in those predisposed to the disorder. Drops such as tropicamide, atropine and cyclopentolate cause the iris to swell also which also can help to create an environment where closed-angle glaucoma is more likely to occur.
  • Methoxyflurane is an inhalational anesthetic, which, if used for extended periods, especially in patients with renal insufficiency, causes irreversible renal failure as a result of deposition of calcium oxalate crystals in the kidney.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 76.

questions.text: Which of the following studies gives the highest degree of reliability for a drug X?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Systematic reviews



* [Extra Edge]: Hierarchy of different studies
 
  • CASE REPORTS :- It is the report of an individual patient
  • CROSS SECTIONAL STUDY :- Individual based Observational study and is used to estimate the prevalence
  • CASE CONTROL & COHORT STUDY :- Types of observational study
  • RANDOMISED CONTROL TRIALS :- It is used to assess drug or treatment. Clinical trials fall in this category
  • SYSTEMATIC REVIEWS :- It is a systematic review to reduce random errors and bias
  • METAANALYSIS :- It summarises the results using quantitative methods.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 87.

questions.text: What medications fall under the WHO classification of "High Potency" medicines for Topical Steroids?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Class II and Class III

There are seven groups of topical steroid potency, ranging from ultra-high potency (group I) to low potency (group VII).

Class I is the most potent, and class VII is the least potent.
Potency depends on many factors, including the drug’s characteristics and concentration and the base in which it is used.
  • Super high-potency drugs are group I drugs
  • High-potency steroids are the steroids of groups II and III.
  • Medium-potency drugs are group IV drugs.
  • Lower mid-potency drugs are group V drugs.
  • Low-potency drugs are group VI drugs.
  • Least potency drugs are group VII drugs.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 955.

questions.text: A drug that is highly ionised:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Is excreted mainly by the kidney
 
  • Highly ionized drugs are mainly excreted by the kidneys. 
  • They are not reabsorbed from the renal tubules and are hence excreted unchanged by glomerular filtration. 
  • Dose reduction is necessary in renal impairment to avoid the accumulation of the drug and associated toxicity. 
  • The non-ionized forms of weak acids and bases undergo tubular reabsorption. 
Non ionized drugs can easily cross placental barrier, are well absorbed from intestine and accumulate in cellular lipids.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 37.

choices.text: Includes drugs for some uncommon diseases in developing countries

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding orphan drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Includes drugs for Rare Diseases
 
  • Orphan drugs are medications that are developed to treat rare diseases or conditions that affect a small number of people.
  • These drugs are often not commercially viable for pharmaceutical companies to develop due to the limited patient population.
  • Therefore, governments around the world have implemented policies to incentivize the development of orphan drugs.
Option 1 is correct because while orphan drugs are developed for rare diseases
Option 2 is incorrect because orphan drugs cannot include medications for uncommon diseases in developing countries. 
Option 3 is incorrect because orphan drugs are not necessarily profitable for pharmaceutical companies to develop.
Option 4 is incorrect because all drugs, including orphan drugs, can have adverse effects.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 7.

choices.text: Receptors for which there is no endogenous mediator or ligand
Receptors which bind specific drugs but no pharmacological response is elicited

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Orphan Receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Receptors for which there is no endogenous mediator or ligand

Orphan drugs are for the treatment or prevention of rare diseases with little commercial value for pharmaceutical companies.
Therefore, special incentives are given by the government for pharmaceutical companies for the development and marketing of orphan drugs.

* Some of the orphan drugs are:
  • Clofazimine
  • Carboprost
  • Rifaximin
  • Rituximab
  • Busulfan
Orphan receptors are receptors that are discovered yet no known ligands are identified. Therefore, option B is true.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 52.

questions.text:
What is the best way to define a drug's bioavailability when taken orally?
1. \(AUC intravenous \times 100\over AUC oral\)
2. \(AUC orals \times 100\over AUC intravenous\)
3. \(AUC oral \times 100\over Time\)
4. \(AUC intravenous \times 100\over Times \)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2)  \(AUC orals \times 100\over AUC intravenous\)
 
  • Bioavailability refers to the extent and rate at which a drug is absorbed into the systemic circulation after administration, specifically when taken orally.
  • It is commonly expressed as a percentage and is calculated by comparing the area under the curve (AUC) of the drug's concentration-time profile after oral administration (AUCoral) to the AUC after intravenous administration (AUCintravenous).
  • Therefore, the correct formula for calculating bioavailability when taken orally is AUCoral × 100 / AUCintravenous.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: The response curve for a logarithmic graded dosage is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Sigmoid
 
  • The log dose-response curve is essentially represented by a sigmoid curve if the experimentalist determines a wide range of doses and identifies the threshold or the lowest active dose, as well as that dose which produces a maximal effect.
  • Based on this, one can determine the linear portion of the sigmoid curve and thus that area in which responses can be used for comparing the effects of various other treatments (such as the effect of pH, the effect of antagonists, the effect of other agonists with similar structures, etc.).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 63.

questions.text: Select the appropriate agonist-antagonist pairing from the list of adrenergic medications.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Clonidine- Yohimbine

The correct pairing from the list above is:
Clonidine is a selective alpha 2 receptor agonist. Yohimbine shows selective α2 receptor antagonism.

* Other options:
  • Phenylephrine is an α1-selective agonist, Yohimbine shows selective α2 receptor antagonism.
  • Dobutamine shows both α and β receptor agonism. Butaxamine (INN, also known as butoxamine) is a β2-selective beta blocker.
  • Salbutamol is a beta-2 adrenergic receptor agonist. Atenolol is a second-generation beta-1-selective adrenergic antagonist



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 140.

choices.text: Fall followed by rise in blood pressure

questions.text: What is the effect of adrenaline when administered after alpha-receptors blockade?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Fall in blood pressure
 
  • Adrenaline acts on both alpha-adrenergic and beta-adrenergic receptors in the body.
  • Alpha-receptors are located in various tissues, including blood vessels, where their activation leads to vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure.
  • When alpha-receptors are blocked, either by specific medications or antagonists, their vasoconstrictive effects are inhibited.
  • As a result, the administration of adrenaline after alpha-receptor blockade will predominantly activate beta-receptors, leading to vasodilation and a fall in blood pressure.
  • Beta-receptor activation also causes increased cardiac output and bronchodilation.
  • Therefore, the net effect of adrenaline administration after alpha-receptor blockade is a fall in blood pressure. The phenomenon is known as vasomotor reversal of Dale.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 143.

questions.text: A common technique for getting rid of some poisons and medications from the body is forced diuresis with urine that has been acidified or alkalinized. Which of the following medications' elimination is frequently aided by alkaline diuresis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Phenobarbitone

Alkaline diuresis with sodium bicarbonate 1 mEq/kg IV with or without mannitol is helpful only in the case of long-acting barbiturates which are eliminated primarily by renal excretion.
As phenobarbitone is acidic drug forced alkaline diuresis helps in elimination of the drug.

Other management methods for phenobarbitone poisoning are:
  • Gastric lavage
  • Scandinavian method
  • Hemodialysis and Charcoal hemoperfusion.
  • CNS stimulants are to be avoided.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 427.

questions.text: Out of the following agents, which is not associated with Hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Alcohol

Alcohol intoxication would cause features like blackouts, nystagmus, slurred speech etc.
Hyperthermia is not a feature seen with it.
Intoxication with all other drugs causes hyperthermia. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 417.

questions.text: A drug 'A' is already in use and drug B needs to be introduced. The value of the new drug in relation to the old drug can be established by which phase of drug trial?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Phase III 
 
  • Phase III trials are large-scale, randomized, controlled trials that compare the efficacy and safety of the new drug (drug B) with the standard treatment (drug A) or a placebo.
  • These trials involve a larger number of participants and are designed to provide more definitive evidence of the effectiveness and safety of the new drug.




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 91.

questions.text: The preferred method of drug designing is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Target-structure based
 
  • Structure-based drug design (SBDD) and ligand-based drug design (LBDD) are the two general types of computer-aided drug design (CADD) approaches in existence.
  • SBDD methods analyze macromolecular target 3-dimensional structural information, typically of proteins or RNA, to identify key sites and interactions that are important for their respective biological functions.
  • Such information can then be utilized to design antibiotic drugs that can compete with essential interactions involving the target and thus interrupt the biological pathways essential for the survival of the microorganism(s). 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 88.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the shown graph?
questions.solution:
The graph shown is a Dose-response curve, which is used to determine the relationship between the dose or concentration of a drug and its effect. In this case, the graph shows the response of a tissue to three different drugs A,B & C.
  • The correct option is 3 as both Drug A & B are producing the same effect.
  • The y-axis represents the response of the drug, and the x-axis represents the concentration of the drug.
  • In this graph, both A and B are producing a response in the tissue, which means they are agonists.
  • Potency refers to the concentration of the drug required to produce a certain response. In this graph, we can see that drug A is more potent than drug B because a lower concentration of drug A is required to produce the same response as a higher concentration of drug B.
  • Efficacy refers to the maximum response that can be produced by a drug. In this graph, we can see that drug A is equally efficacious to drug B because it produces an equal maximum response at the highest concentration.
  • Whereas, Both A & B are more efficacious and more potent than Drug C. 
  • Drug C is a partial agonist.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 45-47.

questions.text: New drug application is done after which phase of clinical trial?
questions.solution:
After the Phase III trial, the FDA reviews the clinical trial results to make sure the treatment is safe and effective for people to use.
 
  • A New Drug Application (NDA) is submitted to regulatory authorities (e.g., the FDA) after the completion of Phase 3 clinical trials.
    • Phase 3 trials involve large-scale testing to confirm the drug's effectiveness, monitor side effects, and compare it to standard treatments or placebos.
    • If the results are positive and meet the required safety and efficacy standards, the NDA is filed for regulatory review and approval for general use.

Other options:
 
  1. Phase 1:
    • Focuses on safety and dosage in a small group of healthy volunteers.
  2. Phase 2:
    • Focuses on efficacy and safety in a larger group of patients with the disease being treated.
  3. Phase 4:
    • Occurs after the drug has been approved and marketed. It monitors long-term effects and collects additional data on the drug’s safety and efficacy.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 6, 7.

questions.text: In a clinical trial 400-500 patients were taken to find the efficacy of a new drug in multiple centers, half were given a new drug, and half were given a placebo, both patients and researchers were blinded, this is done in which phase of the clinical trail?
questions.solution:
• The given scenario describes a randomized controlled trial (RCT) where a new drug is tested against a placebo in multiple centers with blinding of both patients and researchers to test and confirm its efficacy.
  • This type of trial is typically conducted in Phase 3 of clinical trials.
 
  • Phase 3 trials are designed to confirm the efficacy and safety of a new drug in a larger population (typically 400-500 patients or more) and across multiple centers.
  • Randomized controlled trials (RCTs), where participants are randomly assigned to either the new drug or a placebo, are commonly used in Phase 3.
  • Blinding (both patients and researchers being unaware of the treatment group) is a typical feature of Phase 3 trials to prevent bias in the results.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 14.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
In phase III of clinical trials, 500-3000 patients (not 5-10) are taken.
 

  1. Phase 1 - Pharmacokinetics:
    Correct. Phase 1 trials focus on understanding the pharmacokinetics (absorption, distribution, metabolism, excretion) and pharmacodynamics (effect on the body) of a drug, as well as its safety profile. These trials typically involve a small number of healthy volunteers (20-100).

  2. Phase 4 - Post-marketing surveillance:
    Correct. Phase 4 involves monitoring the drug's safety and effectiveness in the general population after it has been approved for marketing. This is known as post-marketing surveillance.

  3. Phase 3 - 5-10 patients are taken:
    Incorrect. Phase 3 trials are large-scale studies involving hundreds to thousands of patients (usually 300-3,000 or more). These trials aim to confirm the drug's efficacy, monitor side effects, and compare it to standard treatments.

  4. Phase 0 - Microdosing:
    Correct. Phase 0 involves administering sub-therapeutic doses (microdosing) to a very small number of participants to gather preliminary data on how the drug behaves in the human body.




Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 6, 7.

questions.text: What is the measure of extend of drug absorption?
questions.solution:
• The extent of drug absorption is represented by  AUC (Area Under the Curve). AUC represents the total exposure of a drug in the systemic circulation over time after administration. It provides information about the amount of drug that reaches the systemic circulation.
  • T max (time to reach maximum concentration) and C max (maximum concentration) are measures of the rate of drug absorption rather than the extent.
  • T max indicates the time it takes for a drug to reach its highest concentration in the blood
  • C max represents the peak concentration achieved.
  • T1/2 (half-life) is a measure of the rate of drug elimination and represents the time it takes for the drug concentration to decrease by half in the body. It is not directly related to the extent of drug absorption
