Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 32,38 .

questions.text: A company makes T. Paracetamol 500mg, but it has only 250mg of paracetamol. What is this called?
questions.solution:
• The correct term for a situation where a product is labeled with incorrect information regarding its content is "misbranding."
  • Misbranding refers to the labeling or packaging of a product that is false or misleading. In the given scenario, if a company labels a product as containing 500mg of paracetamol when it actually contains only 250mg, it would be considered misbranding.


As per Drugs and Cosmetic Act, 1940 - a drug is deemed to be misbranded:

(a) If it is so colored, coated, powdered, or polished that damage is concealed or if it is made to appear of better or greater therapeutic value than it really is; or

(b) If it is not labeled in the prescribed manner; or

(c) If its container is composed, in whole or in part, of any poisonous or deleterious substance which may render the contents injurious to health; or

(d) If it bears or contains, for purposes of coloring only, a color other than one which is prescribed; or

(e) If it contains any harmful or toxic substance which may render it injurious to health; or

(f) If any substance has been mixed therewith so as to reduce its quality or strength.



Reference: The Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940, Amended in 2016, CDSCO, Page no 10. URL: https://cdsco.gov.in/opencms/export/sites/CDSCO_WEB/Pdf-documents/acts_rules/2016DrugsandCosmeticsAct1940Rules1945.pdf

questions.text: Which among the following in the graph denotes antagonist action?
questions.solution:
A - Full agonist
B- Partial agonist
C- Neutral antagonist
D- Inverse agonist



 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 46 .

questions.text: A patient who was on digoxin therapy developed toxicity and the level was 4 ng/ml. How much time would it take to reach the therapeutic PC which is 1 ng/ml? (Given t1/2 = 40 hours)
questions.solution:
Digoxin follows first-order kinetics.

  • In first-order kinetics, Drugs have constant half-lives, irrespective of plasma concentration.
  • Therefore, in first half-life (40 hours) digoxin concentration will fall from 4ng/ml to 2ng/ml.
  • In the next half-life (next 40 hours), the concentration will fall from 2ng/ml to 1ng/ml (desired therapeutic concentration).

Therefore, in 2 half lives i.e. 80 hours therapeutic concentration will be reached.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page. No- 35.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts via the ATP- Binding Cassette transporter ?
questions.solution:
Verapamil is an Inhibitor of P glycoprotein drug transporter. It belongs to the family of ATP Binding Cassette (ABC) family.
Other drugs that inhibit P glycoprotein are -Clarithromycin, Erythromycin, Amiodarone, Quinidine, Diltiazem.
Among the given options Verapmil is the most potent inhibitor of P glycoprotein.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page. No- 25, 85, 616, 1588.

questions.text: Which of the following is correctly marked with its intrinsic drug resistance?
questions.solution:
Candida Krusei- Intrinsic resistance to fluconazole.
Candida Albican and Glabrata- Secondary resistance to Amphotericin B
Sporothrix - DOC is Itraconazole.
Aspergillus Niger - DOC is Voriconazole, Amphotericin B.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3nd Edition, Page. No- 581.

questions.text: Which of the following is complimentary to active site of enzyme?
questions.solution:
Substrate is complimentary to active site of enzyme.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with fears of becoming pregnant and presents a history of unprotected sex five days ago. Which of the following emergency contraceptives can be used in this case?
questions.solution:
Since the patient had unprotected sex 5 days ago, an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) can be used for emergency contraception. It can be inserted within 5 days (120 hours) after intercourse.

Emergency contraceptives, also known as postcoital contraceptives, are designed to prevent conception after unprotected intercourse. They act primarily as interceptives, making the endometrium unsuitable for implantation. They can also delay or inhibit ovulation and prevent fertilization of the egg by sperm. The options include:

• RU 486 (Mifepristone): A single 25 mg dose is effective in 99.1% of cases as a postcoital drug.
• Prostaglandins
• Copper T: An IUCD that can be inserted for emergency contraception.
• Yuzpe Method: Involves using combined high-dose estrogen-progestin pills as postcoital contraceptives.

questions.text: Which of the following acts by suicide inhibition?
questions.solution:
• Suicide inhibition is when an inhibitor binds to an enzyme and then undergoes a reaction to form an irreversible complex with the enzyme, inactivating it permanently.
  • Such a mechanism is seen in benzbromarone a uricosuric agent used to treat gout by increasing uric acid excretion.
  • It inhibits CYP2C9 via mechanism-based on (suicide) inhibition.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page No 47,1255.

choices.text: Protein Kinase A- Cyclic AMP- Adenyl cyclase
Adenyl cyclase- Protein Kinase A- Cyclic AMP

questions.solution:
• Adenyl Cyclase -Cyclic AMP -Protein Kinase A is the correct sequence in Gs subtype G protein coulped receptors.
  • The Gs Subtype receptors act by activating Protein Kinase A.



Reference: Sassone-Corsi P. The cyclic AMP pathway. Cold Spring Harb Perspect Biol. 2012 Dec 1;4(12):a011148. doi: 10.1101/cshperspect.a011148. PMID: 23209152; PMCID: PMC3504441.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Voricanazole?
questions.solution:
All the other statements are true except the second one.
  • Voricanazole is an azole antifungal which should not be combined with Pyrazinamide as it can cause Fulminant Liver failure if given together
  • Voricanazole is an azole antifungal used in treatment of Aspergillosis.
  • It is the DOC for Invasive aspergillosis, disseminated Fluconazole resistant candida, fusarium infections and febrile neutropenia not responding to Antibiotics.
  • ADR-  Rash, Photosensitivity transient Visual and auditory hallucinations and Anaphylactoid reactions.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1681.

choices.text: Ratio of median lethal dose in 50% of population to median effective dose in 50% of population
Denotes safety and efficacy in an individual
Denotes safety and efficacy in the population
Denotes safety and efficacy after experiments on humans

questions.text: True about the therapeutic index of a drug is:
questions.solution:
The therapeutic index of a drug indicates its safety and effectiveness for the population, rather than for individuals. It is determined using the equation:

Therapeutic Index (TI) = LD50 / ED50

This index, also known as the therapeutic ratio, reflects the relationship between doses that cause lethal or toxic effects and the dose that provides therapeutic benefits. It is used to evaluate a drug's safety profile.

Mathematically, TI can be expressed as:

TI = LD50 / ED50 or TD50 / ED50

where LD50 represents the median lethal dose, TD50 denotes the median toxic dose, and ED50 is the median effective dose.

Median lethal dose (LD50) and median toxic dose (TD50):

LD50 is the dose at which 50% of experimental animals die.

In human trials, TD50 is used, representing the dose causing adverse effects in 50% of the population.


A higher LD50 or TD50 implies a safer drug.

Median effective dose (ED50):

ED50 is the dose at which 50% of experimental animals exhibit the desired therapeutic effect.

It is the amount of drug needed to achieve the desired effects in 50% of the population.


The therapeutic window refers to the range of drug concentrations where efficacy is high and the risk of adverse effects is low.


 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 53,54 .

choices.text: Drug B is more efficacious than drug A
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the given dose-response curve:
questions.solution:
Potency refers to the amount of drug required to produce a specific effect. In a dose-response curve (DRC), the further left a curve is, the more potent the drug is.

In the given DRC, Drug B is the most potent as its curve is positioned farthest to the left.
Drug D is the least potent, as its curve is furthest to the right.
Efficacy is the maximum effect a drug can produce, indicated by the peak of the curve.

In the given DRC, Drug B has the least efficacy because its peak is lower compared to the others.
Drugs A, C, and D are equally efficacious since their peaks reach the same level on the curve.

questions.text: Which of the following indicates the therapeutic index of a drug? ED50-Median effective dose LD50-Median lethal dose
questions.solution:
The Therapeutic Index (TI) is defined as the ratio of LD50 to ED50 (Option D).

The therapeutic index represents the relationship between the doses of a drug that induce lethal or toxic effects and the dose that produces therapeutic effects. This concept is also referred to as the therapeutic ratio.

Mathematically, the therapeutic index can be expressed as follows:

Therapeutic Index (TI) = LD50 / ED50

Where:

LD50 (Median Lethal Dose) is the minimum dose of a drug that causes adverse effects in 50% of the population.
ED50 (Median Effective Dose) is the dose that produces the desired therapeutic effects in 50% of the population.

questions.text: The dose-response curve (DRC) is plotted for drug A both in the presence and absence of drug B. What type of effect does drug B have on drug A?
questions.solution:
In non-competitive antagonism, there is flattening of the agonist DRC. Non-competitive antagonism effects occur when the agonist and antagonist bind to different sites on the receptor. ( allosteric site) and inhibits the response. The response curve progressively shifts in a right and downward direction until it reaches a limiting value when the allosteric site is fully occupied.
In competitive antagonism, DRC shows a parallel rightward shift.
Competitive antagonism occurs when the agonist and antagonist compete for the same binding site on the receptor. The response curve for the agonist shifts to the right in a concentration-related manner by the antagonist.Ref- KD Tripathy 8th edition page 67,68,69

choices.text: It is related to the various steps in clinical trial.
It lists out steps of drug metabolism
It helps to calculate volume of distribution of drugs

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding STEP criteria of drugs?
questions.solution:
The selection of P medicines is the main application for the STEP criteria.

P medicines, sometimes referred to as Physician's drugs or Personal drugs, are prescription drugs that a doctor regularly prescribes for particular illnesses and is well-versed in. This idea includes the name of the medication, its dosage, its schedule, and how long it will be used to treat a specific ailment.

STEP is an acronym for:

The medication's safety

Tolerability of the medication

The drug's effectiveness

The medication's cost

The following steps are involved in the process of choosing P drugs:

1. Describe the medical diagnosis.

2. Indicate what the therapeutic goal is.

3. Create a list of medicine groups that work well.

4. Using the criteria, choose a productive group.

5. Select a P medication.

Reference
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics,13th Edition,Page no. 243,244

questions.text: Which of the following does not have use for Cholinomimetic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Bradycardia
 
  • Cholinomimetics cannot be used in bradycardia. 
  • They cause bradycardia by its action on M2 receptors on the heart. 
  • ACh hyperpolarizes the SA nodal cells and decreases their rate of diastolic depolarization. As a result, rate of impulse generation is reduced which leads to bradycardia or even cardiac arrest may occur
Option 2- Use in Glaucoma -Miotics increase the tone of ciliary muscle (attached to scleral spur) as well as that of sphincter pupillae which pull on and somehow improve alignment of the trabeculae so that outflow facility is increased. As a result i.o.t. falls in open angle glaucoma.

Option 3- Use in Myasthenia gravis - Cholinomimetics improve muscle contraction by allowing ACh released from prejunctional endings to accumulate and act on the receptors over a larger area, as well as by directly depolarizing the endplate.

Option 4 - Use in Post surgical atony or ileus - This may be relieved by 0.5–1 mg subcutaneous neostigmine, provided no organic obstruction is present by activating Bowel and Bladder smooth muscle.

* [Extra Edge]: Direct Agonist Vs Indirect Agonist
 



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 114.

questions.text: Pick the option that is not a tertiary amine derivative.
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 2): Glycopyrrolate.

* Audio Explanation:

All the anticholinergic drugs given in the option are Tertiary amines means they have a nonpolar tertiary amino N, rendering the compound lipid soluble except Glycopyrrolate which is a Quaternary amine i.e., has a quaternary N+—rendering it lipid insoluble.
Because of these advantages Glycopyrrolate is used for preanaesthetic medication and during anaesthesia.

Examples of some Quaternary compounds:

  • Anticholinergics - Glycopyrrolate, Isopropamide
  • Anticholinesterase - Neostigmine

These drugs have certain common features:

  • Incomplete oral absorption (10–30%).
  • Poor penetration in brain and eye; central and ocular effects are not seen after parenteral/ oral administration.
  • Elimination is generally slower; majority are longer acting than atropine.
  • Have higher nicotinic blocking property. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 124, 127.

questions.text: What is Dexmedetomidine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option1) Centrally acting alpha-2 agonist.
 
  • Dexmedetomidine, the active S-enantiomer of medetomidine, is a approved for use in intensive care units to sedate critically ill/ventilated patients that has been approved for use in intensive care units to sedate critically ill/ventilated patients.
  • It is also used to sedate patients during endoscopies, spinal/ epidural/ regional anesthesia and as adjunct to GA by lowering the dose of the inhalational anesthetic.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 412.

questions.text: Which receptor does methacholine act on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) M2
 
  • Methacholine (acetyl-β-methylcholine), the β-methyl analogue of ACh, is a synthetic choline ester that differs from ACh chiefly in its greater duration and selectivity of action.
  • Its action is more prolonged because the added methyl group increases its resistance to hydrolysis by cholinesterases.
  • Its selectivity is reflected in a predominance of muscarinic actions manifest most clearly in the cardiovascular system; methacholine’s nicotinic actions are minor.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 112.

questions.text: What kind of acetylcholinesterase inhibition does organophosphates cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4): Competitive & Irreversible.

Organophosphates which are tertiary Amino compounds react covalently with the esteretic site of the enzyme Acetylcholinesterase which leads to irreversible and competitive inhibition of the enzyme.

A Competitive non-equilibrium type of enzyme inhibition occurs with drugs which react with the same catalytic site of the enzyme but either form strong covalent bonds or have such high affinity for the enzyme that the normal substrate is not able to displace the inhibitor.
Another example of the same type of enzyme inhibition is 50,000 times higher affinity of Methotrexate for dihydrofolate reductase than the normal substrate DHFA.


In these situations, kM is increased and Vmax is reduced contrary to unchanged Vmax in Competitive equilibrium type of enzyme inhibition.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 47.

choices.text: Stimulation of alpha-1 followed by stimulation of beta-2
Block of alpha-1 followed by stimulation of beta-2
Stimulation of alpha-1 followed by block of beta-2
Stimulation of beta-1 receptor followed by block of beta-2 receptor

questions.text: What among the following may be used to show the phenomenon of vasomotor reversal of dale in an animal model?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2): Block of alpha-1 followed by stimulation of beta-2
 
  • Administration of epinephrine (Adrenaline) after administration of α-blockers produces only a fall in BP. This is because the α-mediated response is abolished and hence, only the β-mediated response is seen, resulting in a fall in BP. This phenomenon is called the Vasomotor reversal of Dale. 
  • Vasomotor reversal of Dale is a blockade of alpha (α1) followed by stimulation of beta (β2) receptors.




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 143.

questions.text: Which of the following medications, when acting on dilator pupillae, has an action similar to pilocarpine on sphincter papillae?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Timolol

The Iris sphincter, which is made up of circularly arranged muscle fibers, and the iris dilator, which is made up of radially arranged muscle fibers, are the two types of muscles that regulate the size of the iris. The parasympathetic nervous system innervates the sphincter, while the sympathetic nervous system innervates the dilator.

The radial muscle contracts as a result of sympathetic stimulation of the adrenergic receptors, and the pupil then enlarges. Contrarily, parasympathetic activation results in circular muscle contraction and thus the constriction of the pupil.

* Miotics: (Fig C)
  • Cholinergic: Pilocarpine, Physostigmine, Methacholine
  • Sympatholytic: Timolol, Propranolol

* Mydriatics (with or without cycloplegia): (Fig B)
  • Sympathomimetics: Phenylephrine, adrenaline, cocaine
  • Anticholinergics: Tropicamide, cyclopentolate, atropine, hyoscyamine, and scopolamine.




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 126.

questions.text: Except for ____ atropine is indicated in all of the following poisonings.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Endrin.

Atropine is not indicated in Endrin poisoning as it is a Organochlorine compound.

In cases of Organophosphate and carbamate poisoning, atropine is the medicine of choice. In poisoning cases involving Baygon (which contains carbamates and organophosphorus), Tik-20 (which contains organophosphorus), and Parathion (which contains organophosphate), atropine is the medication of choice, but not endrin (organochlorine). There is no specific antidote for organochlorine poisoning.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 116, 122.

choices.text: Decreased renal perfusion and reduced urine output

questions.text: A septic shock patient was given intravenous norepinephrine. This drug's response is best assessed by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Increase in mean arterial pressure

Norepinephrine is a medication that is commonly used to treat septic shock.
 
  • Septic shock is a condition that occurs when an infection in the body triggers a severe immune response, leading to low blood pressure and reduced blood flow to vital organs.
  • Norepinephrine is a vasopressor medication that works by constricting blood vessels, which increases blood pressure and helps to improve blood flow to vital organs. The response to norepinephrine is best assessed by monitoring the patient's mean arterial pressure (MAP).
  • Mean arterial pressure is the average pressure in a patient's arteries during one cardiac cycle. It is calculated by adding one-third of the difference between the systolic and diastolic blood pressures to the diastolic blood pressure.
  • MAP is an important indicator of tissue perfusion, which is the delivery of oxygen and nutrients to the body's tissues. In septic shock, tissue perfusion is often impaired, and improving MAP with norepinephrine can help to restore perfusion.
  • Monitoring heart rate is not the best way to assess the response to norepinephrine.
  • While norepinephrine can increase heart rate, this is a secondary effect of the medication and may not be a reliable indicator of its efficacy. Decreased renal perfusion and reduced urine output may occur in septic shock, but they are not the best way to assess the response to norepinephrine.
Therefore, the correct Answer is Increase in mean arterial pressure.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 143.

questions.text: Which of the following drug can decrease the size of prostate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Finasteride.
 
  • Finasteride is a competitive inhibitor of the enzyme 5 α-reductase which converts testosterone into the more active DHT responsible for androgen action in many tissues including the prostate gland and hair follicles. It is relatively selective for 5 α-reductase type 2 isoenzyme which predominates in male urogenital tract.
  • Treatment with finasteride results in decreased prostate size and increased peak urinary flow rate in ~50% patients with symptomatic benign hypertrophy of prostate (BHP).
  • Finasteride has also been found effective in male pattern baldness, though hair follicles have primarily type 1 enzyme.

Option 1 and 4: Prazosin and tamsulosin are selective alpha receptor blockers involved with dynamic component of BPH.

Option 2: Sildenafil acts by selectively inhibiting PDE-5 and enhancing NO action in corpus cavernosum. It is the DOC for erectile dysfunction.

* High Yield Concept-
The urinary obstruction caused by BHP has a static component due to increased size of prostate and a dynamic component due to increased tone of bladder neck/prostate smooth muscle.


Two classes of drugs are available:

  •  α1 adrenergic blockers (prazosin like): they decrease tone of prostatic/bladder neck muscles.
  •  5-αreductase inhibitor (finasteride/dutasteride) which arrest growth/reduce size of prostate.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 326.

choices.text: Ranitidine one night before and then before the trip

questions.text: Next morning, a person has to travel to Shimla. Which of the following medications could help him with motion sickness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Scopolamine

The most effective medication for the prevention and treatment of motion sickness is scopolamine, a muscarinic antagonist administered orally, parenterally, or trans-dermally. Scopolamine is the doc for motion sickness.

Scopolamine transdermal preparation (TRANSDERM SCOP) has been demonstrated to be extremely effective when administered prophylactically to avoid motion sickness especially in vigorous motions.

The drug should be given prophylactically (0.2 mg oral), because administration after symptoms have set in is less effective; action lasts 4–6 hours. A transdermal preparation applied behind the pinna 4 hours before journey has been shown to protect for 3 days.

Option 2, 3 and 4 doesn't show a lot of promise to be used in motion sickness and are considered to be inferior to hyoscine. Ranitidine and omeprazole decrease the acidity of stomach so are of no use. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 132.

choices.text: Adrenaline 0.5 ml of 1:1000 solution by intramuscular route

questions.text: What is the preferred method of treatment for anaphylactic shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Adrenaline 0.5 ml of 1:1000 solution by intramuscular route

Treatment of choice for anaphylactic shock is: Adrenaline 0.5 ml of 1:1000 solution by intramuscular route.

In cases of anaphylactic shock, the parenteral administration of 0.3-0.5 mg of epinephrine usually has a quick effect on the symptoms of bronchospasm, mucous membrane congestion, angioedema, and severe hypotension (0.3-0.5mL of a 1:1000 epinephrine solution). Since skin blood flow (and hence systemic medication absorption from subcutaneous injection) is uncertain in hypotensive patients, intramuscular injection may be the preferred mode of delivery.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 97.

choices.text: Action of C is antagonized by muscarinic blockers

questions.text: Three medicines were the subject of a pharmacological experiment to determine how they affected blood pressure and heart rate. The graphs below were acquired before and after the medication was administered. Which of the subsequent claims is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is 2: B is epinephrine
 
  • At higher concentrations of adrenaline, alpha action predominates and hence a rise in BP is seen.
  • Therefore an increase in BP is seen with IV administration of adrenaline.
  • Due to rapid metabolism and uptake, the concentration of adrenaline decreases, and the β2 action predominates. Hence a decrease in BP is seen.
  • This is referred to as the biphasic reaction. 
* [Extra Edge]: Anti cholinergic drugs




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 143.

questions.text: Methacholine is a type of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) M2 receptor agonist

Methacholine show maximum agonist action at M2.
Acetyl-methylcholine, also known as methacholine, is a synthetic ester of choline which is slightly different from acetylcholine, with an added methyl group which makes it resistant to hydrolysis by cholinesterase, thus making it last longer in the body.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 112.

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by Alpha 2 agonists?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hyperalgesia

Alpha 2 agonist do not cause hyperalgesia.
They could be a beneficial option for certain individuals undergoing anesthesia as it may reduce the need for anesthetics and make hemodynamic stability more attainable. Additionally, clonidine can reduce preoperative anxiety, lessen mucus secretions, and provide conditioning to mitigate feelings of pain.

*Important functions of Alpha 2 receptors:
  • Inhibition of transmitter release
  • Vasoconstriction
  • Decreased central sympathetic flow
  • Decreased insulin release
  • Platelet aggregation


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 140.

questions.text: Which of the following contains both alpha and beta agonists?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Epinephrine

Epinephrine or adrenaline has both alpha and beta receptor action, with a weak effect on the gamma receptor.

Option 1 Dobutamine primarily acts upon beta-1 receptors, and is a selective beta-1 agonist
Option 4 Phenylephrine is a selective alpha agonist with no effect on beta receptors
Option 2 Fenoldopam is not an inducer of either alpha, beta, or gamma receptors, but rather is a selective agonist on dopamine-1 receptors.




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 142.

questions.text: Which is the correct match between drug and mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Brimonidine decreases aqueous production

Brimonidine lowers IOP by reducing aqueous production and by increasing uveoscleral flow. Brimonidine is alpha-2 agonist therefore it causes vasoconstriction and inhibits aqueous humor production.

Option B- Latanoprost is a PGF2 alpha analogue which acts by increasing uveoscleral outflow.
Option C- Pilocarpine is a cholinergic drug which acts by increasing trabecular outflow.
Option D- Betaxolol is a beta 1 antagonist which acts by decreasing aqueous production.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 168.

questions.text: What medication has both alpha and beta agonist properties?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Epinephrine

Epinephrine or adrenaline has both alpha and beta receptor action, with a weak effect on the gamma receptor.

Option 1 Fenoldopam is not an inducer of either alpha, beta, or gamma receptors, but rather is a selective agonist on dopamine-1 receptors.
Option 2 Dopamine is a dopaminergic (D1 and D2) as well as weaker adrenergic β1 (but not β2) + very weak α receptor agonist.
Option 4 Phenylephrine is a selective alpha agonist with no effect on beta receptors




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 142.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not include the usage of cholinomimetic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Partial heart block

  • Cholinomimetic is not used in partial heart block because they cause Bradycardia and Heart block in severe patients.
  • At the A-V node and His-Purkinje fibres refractory period (RP) is increased and conduction is slowed, P-R interval increases and partial to complete A-V block may be produced.
  • The force of atrial contraction is markedly reduced and RP of atrial fibres is abbreviated.

* Uses of Cholinomimetic-

  • Diseases of eye: Glaucoma and accommodative esotropia
  • Gastrointestinal and urinary tract: Post-operative atony, neurogenic bladder
  • Neuromuscular junction: Myasthenia gravis, Curare induced neuromuscular paralysis
  • Heart: Certain atrial arrhythmias
  • Atropine overdoses
  • Alzheimer's disease
  • Cobra bite: Neostigmine and edrophonium

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 114.

questions.text: Which of the following anticholinergic medications cannot pass through the blood–brain barrier?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Glycopyrrolate

  • Glycopyrrolate is a synthetic quaternary anticholinergic drug, which doesn't cross the blood brain barrier and completely lacks central effects. Other drugs such as atropine do however cross the BBB.
  • Glycopyrrolate is potent in producing anti-secretory, tachycardia and bronchodilation because of these advantages it is used for Preanaesthetic medication and during anaesthesia.


Option 2,3 and 4 all are Tertiary Amino Compounds so they are lipid soluble and does cross the BBB and produces central effects.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 127.

questions.text: During a prone dark room test, a 36-year-old woman has eye pain. Which medication from the list below has to be avoided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Atropine
 
  • In the given case where a 36-year-old female on prone dark room test develops pain in the eyes. This is due to pupillary dilatation in the dark causing obliteration of the narrow angle in the anterior chamber. The most probable diagnosis is angle closure glaucoma.
  • Atropinic drugs are absolutely contraindicated in individuals with a narrow iridocorneal angle—may precipitate acute congestive glaucoma since it is a anticholinergic drug.

Option 1 acetazolamide reduces aqueous formation by limiting generation of bicarbonate ion in the ciliary epithelium. It is used to supplement ocular hypotensive drugs for short-term indications like angle closure, before and after ocular surgery/laser therapy.

Option 2 and 4 pilocarpine and timolol have cholinergic/ parasympathomimetic action they penetrate cornea and promptly causes miosis, ciliary muscle contraction and fall in intraocular tension. Timolol is better than pilocarpine in cases of chronic dosing as the action is smooth and well sustained with lesser side effects like no induced myopia, no headache / brow pain and no fluctuation of i.o.p etc. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 132.

questions.text: Concentration of tropicamide:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 1:0.01

Tropicamide acts on M3 receptors and causes passive Mydriasis.
Mechanism of action – Cycloplegic and mydriatic
Use – Ocular fundal examination, Refractive error testing in adults
Concentration – 1% Drugs acting on the pupil

*[Extra Edge]:

Tropicamide has the quickest (20–40 min) and briefest (3–6 hours) action but is a relatively unreliable cycloplegic. However, it is satisfactory for refraction testing in adults and as a short acting mydriatic for fundoscopy. Phenylephrine is often combined with tropicamide for faster and stronger mydriatic action.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 130.

questions.text: Choose the correct option.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Brimonidine decreases aqueous production

Brimonidine lowers IOP by reducing aqueous production and by increasing uveoscleral flow. Brimonidine is alpha-2 agonist therefore it causes vasoconstriction and inhibits aqueous humor production.

Option B- Latanoprost is a PGF2 alpha analogue which acts by increasing uveoscleral outflow.
Option C- Pilocarpine is a cholinergic drug which acts by increasing trabecular outflow.
Option D- Betaxolol is a beta 1 antagonist which acts by decreasing aqueous production.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 168.

questions.text: Pick the Rho kinase inhibitor from the following options.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option1) Fasudil
 
  • Fasudil is a selective Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitor. ROCK is an enzyme that plays an important role in mediating vasodilation and vascular remodeling in the pathogenesis of pulmonary hypertension.
  • ROCK induces vasoconstriction by phosphorylating the myosin-binding subunit of myosin light chain (MLC) phosphatase, thus decreasing MLC phosphatase activity and enhancing vascular smooth muscle contraction.

Option 2 Ranolazine novel antianginal drug primarily acts by inhibiting a late Na+ current (late INa) in the myocardium which indirectly facilitates Ca2+ entry through Na+/Ca2+ exchanger.
Option 3 Amiloride approaches the Na+ channel from the luminal side and blocks it—reducing the lumen negative transepithelial potential difference which governs K+ and H+ secretion
Option 4 Nicorandil is a dual mechanism antianginal drug activates ATP sensitive K+ channels (KATP) in smooth muscle membrane thereby hyperpolarizing and relaxing it.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 313.

choices.text: Activated charcoal has no proven therapeutic benefit

questions.text: Two hours after ingesting insecticide, a 24-year-old female from a rural location is taken to the emergency room complaining of nausea, vomiting, and shortness of breath. Upon examination, the patient has razor-sharp pupils and is releasing a kerosene-like odour. Which of the following regarding this patient's care is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Atropine reverses respiratory muscle weakness

Atropine is a muscarinic receptor blocker, used to revert the bradycardia and hypotension but It does not reverse peripheral muscular paralysis which is mediated by nicotinic receptor.

Option 2,3 and 4 are all Correct statement regarding the treatment of Organophosphate poisoning.

The given features are suggestive of organophosphorus poisoning. They have a characteristic pungent kerosene like odor. Organophosphorus compounds irreversibly inhibit acetyl cholinesterase decreasing its activity.

*ANTICHOLINESTERASE POISONING:
Local muscarinic manifestations at the site of exposure (skin, eye, g.i.t.) occur immediately and are followed by complex systemic effects due to muscarinic, nicotinic and central actions. They are—
  • Irritation of eye, lacrimation, salivation, sweating, copious tracheobronchial secretions, miosis, blurring of vision, bronchospasm, breathlessness, colic, involuntary defecation and urination.
  • Fall in BP, bradycardia or tachycardia, cardiac arrhythmias, vascular collapse.
  • Muscular fasciculations, weakness, respiratory paralysis (central as well as peripheral).
  • Irritability, disorientation, unsteadiness, tremor, ataxia, convulsions, coma and death.
  • Death is generally due to respiratory failure.
*TREATMENT OF ANTICHOLINESTERASE POISONING:
  1. Termination of further exposure to the poison—fresh air, wash the skin and mucous membranes with soap and water, gastriclavage according to need.
  2. Maintain patent airway, positive pressure respiration if it is failing.
  3. Supportive measures—maintain BP, hydration, control of convulsions with judicious use of diazepam.
  4. Specific antidotes—
             (a) Atropine It is highly effective in counteracting the muscarinic symptoms, It does not reverse peripheral muscular paralysis which is a nicotinic action. All cases of anti-ChE (carbamate or organophosphate) poisoning must be promptly given till dryness of mouth or other signs of atropinization appear.
            (b) Cholinesterase reactivators Pralidoximes are used to restore neuromuscular transmission only in case of organophosphate anti-ChE poisoning.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 122.

questions.text: Choose the treatment to relieve a patient with COPD who developed postoperative urinary retention.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Tamsulosin

While Bethenechol as a muscarinic agonist is typically used for the management of Post-operative urinary retention - its use is contraindicated in COPD/Asthma since it would worsen the bronchospasm.
Tamsulosin - an alpha-1a receptor antagonist which relaxes the bladder muscle is the most appropriate treatment.

Option 2 and 3 have no use in postoperative urinary retention

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 156.

questions.text: Select the drug used for reversal of muscle relaxation after surgery on a person who has been treated with a muscle relaxant that blocks nicotinic receptors.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Neostigmine

  • Neostigmine is a reversible anticholinesterase, meaning it is an enzyme that blocks the action of the enzyme acetylcholinesterase (AchE) which is involved in the breakdown of acetylcholine (Ach). By preventing the breakdown of Ach, Neostigmine increases the amount of Ach available at the postsynaptic cleft and postsynaptic membrane, enhancing cholinergic neurotransmission at the skeletal muscle endplate, and restoring normal muscle tone. This makes Neostigmine ideal for use in the reversal of anesthesia/postoperative decurarization. 
  • Physostigmine is a tertiary amine so it crosses BBB hence is not preferred. It is used in closed angle glaucoma.
  • However, Neostigmine can cause unwanted side effects, such as nausea and excess salivation, which can be prevented by the use of an anti-muscarinic drug such as Atropine and Glycopyrrolate. By combining these two types of medications, it is possible to successfully reverse anesthesia/postoperative decurarization without the risk of side effects.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 122.

questions.text: What is the anti-glaucoma drug which acts by increasing uveoscleral outflow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Latanoprost

  • Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analogue that works to reduce intraocular pressure by increasing the outflow of aqueous humour from the eyes. By relaxing the eye muscles around the drainage angle, it reduces the blockage of aqueous humour that can lead to increased intraocular pressure. This is done by converting to a biologically active form of prostaglandin, specifically to prostaglandin F2α (PGF2α), within the eye. Once PGF2α is formed within the eye, it acts to open the trabecular meshwork within the drainage angle, which then causes the aqueous humour to flow out of the eye at a faster and more efficient rate.
  • This increased outflow helps reduce the elevated pressure levels within the eye and brings it back to within the normal range. Additionally, PGF2α also works by decreasing the amount of aqueous humour that is produced. This combination of increased outflow and decreased production of aqueous humour helps to control the IOP levels and bring them to within the normal range.


* Other options: -

Option 2- Timolol is a beta antagonist which acts by decreasing aqueous production.
Option 3- Pilocarpine is a cholinergic drug which acts by increasing trabecular outflow.
Option 4- Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor acts by decreasing aqueous production.
 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 168, 169.

questions.text: Which is the exception to the causes of pin point pupil?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Belladonna

The belladonna plant (Atropa belladonna) is the source of the scopolamine and atropine (anticholinergic drugs). Therefore, belladonna poisoning will result in mydriasis, an anticholinergic symptom.

Organophosphates and pilocarpine are cholinergic medicines and cause miosis.

Opioids, such as morphine, cause miosis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 125.

questions.text: A competitive neuromuscular blockade that targets nicotinic receptors was given to a patient. Which of the following medications can be used to counteract its effects after surgery
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Neostigmine
 
  • Neostigmine is used to reverse the effects of muscle relaxants given during surgery that cause muscle paralysis. Neostigmine works by inhibiting the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, which breaks down the neurotransmitter acetylcholine.
  • This leads to an increase in available acetylcholine, allowing muscles to return to their normal activity. Neostigmine is commonly injected intravenously or subcutaneously, and its effects are reversible. The addition of atropine is used to reduce potential adverse effects, such as bradycardia, bronchospasm, and increased secretions.
  • Physostigmine is also acetylcholinesterase blocker but as it is a tertiary amine it crosses BBB, hence is not preferred. It is used in treatment of closed angle glaucoma.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 122.

choices.text: 0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by IM route
1 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by IM route
5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by IM route
0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by IV route

questions.text: How to manage a patient who was given ampicillin 2g I/V and after that, the person developed rash on skin, hypotension and difficulty in breathing
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by IM route
 
  • Rashes, hypotension, and breathing problems are signs of ampicillin-induced anaphylaxis. In anaphylaxis, epinephrine 0.3–0.5 ml intramuscularly at a dilution of 1:1000 is the preferred medication (0.3-0.5 mg).
  • Only in severe anaphylactic shock should intravenous epinephrine 2.5 ml at 1:10,000 (0.25 mg) be administered. Steroids, bronchodilators, and antihistaminics are further supportive medications used in anaphylaxis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 97.

questions.text: Which dosage of dopamine favorably affects beta-1 receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 2-10 mcg

Dopamine is a catecholamine and is an important neurotransmitter in the brain. Dopamine has a dose dependent action on autonomic nervous system.

At 0 - 2 mcg/kg/min dosage, dopamine is more active on D1 receptors. Action on these receptors cause diuresis.

At 2 - 10 mcg/kg/min, dopamine acts on Beta 1 receptor thereby increasing cardiac contraction. 

At > 10mcg/kg/min, dopamine acts on alpha 1 receptor causing vasoconstriction. ( used in management of cardiogenic shock).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 146.

questions.text: Which of the following best illustrates how organophosphorus chemicals reduce acetylcholine esterase inhibition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Irreversible inhibition

Acetyl Choline Esterase has two sites— esteratic and an ionic site. The anioic site accommodates the positive quarternary amine of Ach while the esteratic site hydrolyses the Ach into Acetate and Choline.
In case of OP poisoning, Organophosphates bind with PO4 in the esteratic site reversibly but later the PO4 bond is replaced by a much stronger bond (ageing) making the binding irreversible, preventing the ACh from binding to the enzyme.
 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 47.

questions.text: Which among the following occurs due to stimulation of muscarinic receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Erection

Erection among following is an action expected of muscarinic receptors.
Remaining options occur in response to stimulation of sympathetic nervous system or antagonism of Muscarinic receptors. 

Note- In penis, ejaculation is a sympathomimetic action mediated via alpha 1 receptor whereas erection is a parasympathomimetic action mediated via M3 muscarinic receptors.  

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 113.

choices.text: Highly specific, competitive and reversible carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
Highly specific, non-competitive and reversible carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
Highly specific, competitive and irreversible carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
Highly specific, non-competitive and irreversible carbonic anhydrase inhibitor

questions.text: Which of the following properties best describes brinzolamide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Highly specific, non-competitive and reversible carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
 
  • Brinzolamide is a highly specific, non-competitive and reversible carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It is administered topically but systemic absorption is significant. Primarily excreted unchanged in urine.
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibition reduces aqueous production and decreases intraocular pressure. Its indication is glaucoma.
  • Side effects include blurring of vision, itching, headache and runny nose.

Online Reference:
Iester M. Brinzolamide ophthalmic suspension: a review of its pharmacology and use in the treatment of open angle glaucoma and ocular hypertension. Clin Ophthalmol. 2008 Sep;2(3):517-23. doi: 10.2147/opth.s3182. PMID: 19668749; PMCID: PMC2694021.

questions.text: What results in lid retraction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Apraclonidine
 
  • Apraclonidine causes lid retraction. Apraclonidine 1% eye drops are used to prevent or reduce increased pressure in the eye during and after certain types of laser eye surgery.
  • Apraclonidine is in a class of medications called alpha-2-adrenergic agonists. It lowers the pressure in the eye by decreasing the amount of fluid produced within the eye.

* Other options:-
Option 2 Brominidine- side effects include transient myopia, periorbital dermatitis.
Option 3 and 4 Bimatoprost and Travoprost are prostaglandin analogues, side effects includes trichomegaly, cystoid macular edema and pigmentation of iris. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 168.

questions.text: Systemic beta blockers are being used to treat a glaucoma patient. The patient can receive all of the following except for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) levobunolol

 Levobunolol is a non- selective beta blocker used as eye drops in open angle glaucoma.

All of the following can be given to the patient of glaucoma, who is being treated with systemic beta blocker, except levobunolol.
Levobunolol should not be used in the patients on systemic beta blocker since it may exacerbate the negative effects of systemic beta-blockers in  these patients.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1461.

questions.text: Cholinomimetic is not used for:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Bradycardia

Cholinomimetic is not used for bradycardia. They might be used for;
    • ￲open angle glaucoma
    • ￲cobra bite
    • ￲myasthenia gravis￲

* [Extra Edge]:
 
  • ACh hyperpolarizes the SA nodal cells and decreases their rate of diastolic depolarization. As a result, rate of impulse generation is reduced, bradycardia or even cardiac arrest may occur.
  • At the A-V node and His-Purkinje fibres refractory period (RP) is increased and conduction is slowed: P-R interval increases and partial to complete A-V block may be produced. The force of atrial contraction is markedly reduced and RP of atrial fibres is abbreviated.
A tip to remember this is to understand Atropine(Anticholinergic) is the DOC for most of bradycardia. Hence automatically cholinergic & antiadrenergic will cause bradycardia. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 114.

questions.text:
Which one of the following receptors uses cAMP as a secondary messenger?
1. Histaminic H1 receptors 
2. Muscarinic M1 Receptors 
3. \(\alpha \)-1 adrenergic receptors
4. Histaminic H2 receptors
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Histaminic H2 receptors 

*Adenylyl cyclase (cAMP pathway):
 It stimulates the Gs and Gi [ PYQ frequently tested]
  • The following hormones act via the cAMP pathway: - [MNEMONIC – Base FLAT CAMP βHCG]
    • Hormones secreted from Basophils of Anterior pituitary
    • FSH
    • LH
    • ACTH
    • TSH
    • Calcitonin
    • ADH ( V2 receptors )
    • MSH
    • PTH
    • β1β2 receptors
    • Histamine, HCG
    • CRH
    • Glucagon
Option 2,3 and 4 are all function by activation of Phospholipase -- IP3/DAG Pathway.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 55.

choices.text: Increased acetylcholine to act at M1 muscarinic receptors
Increased acetylcholine to act at M2 muscarinic receptors
Increased acetylcholine to act at NN receptors

questions.text: What is the rationale behind use of neostigmine in myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Increased acetylcholine to act at NM receptors
 
  • Neostigmine is an acetylcholine esterase inhibitor and the primary mechanism of action is decreased breakdown of acetylcholine at the motor endplate. Neostigmine indirectly stimulates nicotinic and muscarinic receptors.
  • Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor used mainly to improve muscle tone in people with myasthenia gravis, and also to reverse the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants such as rocuronium and vecuronium at the end of an operation. 
  • Inhibition of acetylcholine esterase increases the acetylcholine levels in the synapse that can act on receptors over the large surface area and for longer periods of time, reducing the weakness.
  • It is also used in postoperative and neurogenic ileus and urinary retention, myasthenia gravis, reversal of neuromuscular junction blockade (postoperative).
* [Extra Edge]:
 



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 120.

questions.text: Which antidepressant from the list below is an SNRI (selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Duloxetine
 
  • Venlafaxine, desvenlafaxine, duloxetine, Levomilnacipran, milnacipran are some SNRIs (Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors).
  • They inhibit 5-HT and norepinephrine reuptake.
  • Used in: Depression, general anxiety disorder, diabetic neuropathy. Venlafaxine is also indicated for social anxiety disorder, panic disorder, PTSD, OCD. Duloxetine is also indicated for fibromyalgia.
  • Side effects: HTN, stimulant effects, sedation, nausea.
* [Extra Edge]: SSRIs Vs SNRIs
 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 489.

questions.text: The following drug cannot be used for the treatment of vomiting:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) H1 histamine agonists
 

H1 antagonists, also known as antihistamines, are commonly used in the treatment of various conditions, including allergies and motion sickness. While they primarily block the action of histamine at H1 receptors, their role in directly treating vomiting is limited. However, they can sometimes be used as part of a broader treatment approach for vomiting in specific situations:

  1. Motion Sickness:

    • H1 antagonists like dimenhydrinate (Dramamine) and meclizine (Antivert) are often used to prevent and alleviate symptoms of motion sickness, which can include nausea and vomiting. They work by exerting antiemetic effects and reducing the symptoms associated with motion-induced nausea and vomiting.

  2. Nausea and Vomiting due to Vestibular Disorders:

    • Certain H1 antagonists, particularly meclizine, can also be used to manage nausea and vomiting associated with vestibular disorders, such as vertigo.

  3. Adverse Effects of Medications:

    • In some cases, medications prescribed for other conditions may cause nausea and vomiting as side effects. H1 antagonists can be used to alleviate these symptoms, although they do not address the underlying cause directly.

  4. Adjunctive Therapy:

    • H1 antagonists may be used as adjunctive therapy in combination with other antiemetic medications to enhance the overall efficacy in managing vomiting. For instance, they may be combined with dopamine receptor antagonists (e.g., metoclopramide) or serotonin receptor antagonists (e.g., ondansetron) for better control of nausea and vomiting in certain clinical scenarios.

  5. Pediatric Use:

    • Some H1 antagonists are also used in children to manage motion sickness and associated vomiting, although dosages must be adjusted based on age and weight.
* [Extra Edge]: Drugs used in vomiting




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 183.

questions.text: Which of the following is an exception to actions of muscarinic antagonists ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Contract radial muscles of iris 
 
  • Muscarinic antagonists, also known as anticholinergic drugs, block the action of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors.
  • The general effects of muscarinic antagonists include:
    • Decrease in secretions
    • Relaxation of smooth muscles
    • Dilation of the pupils.
  • Muscarinic antagonists typically decrease gastric secretions (option 1) and decrease respiratory secretions (option 2).
  • However, muscarinic antagonists do not contract the radial muscles of the iris (option 3). Instead, they block the action of acetylcholine on circular muscle, causing passive mydriasis and called cycloplegics.
  • Muscarinic antagonists can also have an effect on AV conduction, as they can block the parasympathetic influence on the AV node, which may result in AV nodal block or decreased AV conduction (option 4).
* [Extra Edge]: Muscarinic Agonist Vs Antagonist



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 112.

questions.text: A patient comes to emergency with increased salivation, diarrhea, watery eyes and dysuria. What will be the first line of management?
questions.solution:
• The symptoms mentioned by the patient, including increased salivation, diarrhea, watery eyes, and dysuria, could be indicative of a possible cholinergic crisis.
  • The cholinergic crisis is a condition characterized by excessive stimulation of the parasympathetic nervous system, due an overactivity of acetylcholine.

Possible causes of a cholinergic crisis include:

  1. Organophosphate or carbamate poisoning: Exposure to pesticides or insecticides that inhibit the enzyme acetylcholinesterase can result in excessive accumulation of acetylcholine.
  2. Overdose of cholinergic medications: Excessive use or overdose of medications that enhance cholinergic activity, such as cholinesterase inhibitors or muscarinic agonists, can lead to a cholinergic crisis.
DOC for the management of any drug causing excessive cholinergic activity is using a Muscarinic antagonist like Atropine.

 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 165,167 .

questions.text: A 50-year old chronic smoker with a 20-pack year history of smoking was on treatment for smoking cessation.  The patient was also on clonidine for withdrawal symptoms. He developed a pounding headache, three days after he stopped clonidine. What could be the likely cause for his headache?
questions.solution:
Rebound Hypertension could be the likely cause of the patient's headache.

  • When clonidine is abruptly stopped, the body may experience a rebound effect, where there is an increase in sympathetic nervous system activity and an increase in blood pressure.
  • Clonidine is an alpha-2 receptor agonist and a centrally acting antihypertensive agent.
  • Alarming rise in BP, in excess of pretreatment level, with tachycardia, restlessness, anxiety, sweating, headache, nausea and vomiting occur in some patients when doses of clonidine are missed for 1–2 days.
  • The syndrome is very similar to that seen in pheochromocytoma: plasma catecholamine (CA) concentration is increased.

    This is due to:
    (a)  Sudden removal of central sympathetic inhibition resulting in release of large quantities of stored CAs.
    (b) Super-sensitivity of peripheral adrenergic structures to CAs that develops due to chronic reduction of sympathetic tone during clonidine therapy.
    * A combination of α blocker with a β blocker, or a potent vasodilator (nitroprusside) or clonidine itself can be used to treat the syndrome.

    Severe hypertension, restlessness and sympathetic overactivity may occur shortly after discontinuing clonidine.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 611.

questions.text: A farmer developed organophosphate poisoning. Atropine and pralidoxime were given. After 2 hours, a rise in temperature was noted. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Atropine administration is likely responsible for the rise in temperature.
 
  • This is due to the decrease in sweating since the body’s sweat glands are innervated by post-sympathetic cholinergic fibers.
  • Belladonna poisoning may occur due to drug overdose or consumption of seeds and berries of belladonna/datura plant. Children are highly susceptible. Manifestations are due to exaggerated pharmacological actions. 
  • Dry mouth, difficulty in swallowing and talking. Dry, flushed and hot skin (especially over face and neck), fever, difficulty in micturition, decreased bowel sounds.
  • A scarlet rash may appear. 
  • Dilated pupil, photophobia, blurring of near vision, palpitation. Excitement, psychotic behaviour, ataxia, delirium, dreadful visual hallucinations. 
  • Hypotension, weak and rapid pulse, cardiovascular collapse with respiratory depression. Convulsions and coma occur only in severe poisoning.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 132.

questions.text: Which of the following can lead to acute liver failure?
questions.solution:
Amanita phalloides, also known as the death cap mushroom, produces amatoxins (especially α-amanitin) that cause massive hepatic necrosis, leading to acute liver failure.

Mechanism:

  • α-amanitin inhibits RNA polymerase II, blocking mRNA synthesis.

  • This results in cellular apoptosis and necrosis, particularly in hepatocytes, leading to acute hepatic failure with jaundice, coagulopathy, and encephalopathy.

Other options:

  • Organophosphate poisoning: Causes cholinergic crisis (salivation, lacrimation, bradycardia, bronchorrhea), not liver failure.

  • Belladonna poisoning: Causes anticholinergic symptoms (dry mouth, mydriasis, tachycardia), not liver injury.

  • Morphine poisoning: Causes respiratory depression and coma, not hepatic necrosis.

Hence, Amanita phalloides is the classic cause of acute liver failure due to toxic mushroom ingestion.

questions.text: A young female patient presents with ptosis which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. A diagnosis of Myasthenia gravis is made. What is the preferred treatment for this patient at this stage?
questions.solution:
The patient’s ptosis that worsens in the evening and improves with rest is characteristic of Myasthenia Gravis, an autoimmune disorder caused by antibodies against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors.

The drug of choice for symptomatic management is Pyridostigmine, a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. It increases acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction, improving muscle strength.

Other options:

  • Plasma exchange – used in myasthenic crisis or before thymectomy.

  • Cyclosporine – used as a second-line immunosuppressant if steroids fail.

  • Physostigmine – used for anticholinergic poisoning, not for Myasthenia Gravis.

Therefore, the preferred initial treatment is Pyridostigmine.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the casualty department with torticollis and dystonia. His attender reported that he had been diagnosed with schizophrenia and had recently started treatment with Haloperidol. What is the next best step to treat the patient's presenting symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has developed acute dystonia (involuntary muscle contractions causing torticollis, oculogyric crisis, etc.) — a common extrapyramidal side effect (EPS) of haloperidol, a typical antipsychotic.

Mechanism:
Haloperidol blocks dopamine D₂ receptors in the nigrostriatal pathway → dopamine deficiency → excess cholinergic activity → dystonia.

Management:

  • Immediate treatment: Give an anticholinergic such as

    • Benzhexol (Trihexyphenidyl), or

    • Benztropine, or

    • Diphenhydramine (IM/IV) if severe.

  • Do not increase haloperidol or switch to another typical antipsychotic (like fluphenazine), as these will worsen EPS.

  • Clozapine is used in refractory schizophrenia, not for acute dystonic reactions.

questions.text:
Match the following
Column I Column II
A Mirabegron 1 Beta 1
B Indacaterol 2 Beta 
C Betaxolol 3 Beta 2
D Isoproterenol 4 Beta 3
questions.solution:
Mirabegron is a beta 3-adrenergic receptor agonist used to treat bladder incontinence. It works by activating this receptor in the bladder, leading to relaxation of the detrusor muscle and increased bladder capacity. This action helps prevent urination and provides relief for individuals with an overactive bladder or urinary incontinence.

Indacaterol is a very long-acting beta-2 agonist (V-LABA) used for the maintenance treatment of COPD and is effective with once-daily dosing.

Betaxolol is a selective third-generation beta-blocker (beta 1-selective) that also blocks calcium entry and has slight membrane-stabilizing properties, but no agonist activity. Isoproterenol, on the other hand, is a non-selective beta agonist (?1 = ?2) with no alpha activity. It directly stimulates ?1 receptors in the heart, increasing the risk of tachycardia and arrhythmias. The reduction in peripheral vascular resistance, caused by ?2 stimulation, leads to a drop in diastolic blood pressure. Isoproterenol is sometimes used as a cardiac stimulant in patients with bradycardia.


 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 277,278,280 .

questions.text: Which drug elicits the following response on blood pressure and heart rate as shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image depicts an increase in systolic pressure, diastolic pressure, mean arterial pressure, and reflex bradycardia, which is characteristic of the action of norepinephrine.

Norepinephrine stimulates α1 receptors leading to an increase in peripheral vascular resistance and β1 receptors causing an increase in stroke volume. As a result, both diastolic and systolic pressures rise, along with the mean arterial pressure. This elevation in mean arterial pressure triggers a reflex bradycardia through baroreceptor-mediated mechanisms.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation described is most consistent with myasthenia gravis. This patient exhibits symptoms of ptosis, progressive muscle weakness, and fatigability that improves with neostigmine, all of which are hallmark features of the disease.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder affecting the neuromuscular junction, characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. The condition results from autoantibodies that target and destroy acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) on the postsynaptic membrane, reducing neuromuscular transmission and leading to muscle weakness.

Key Points about Myasthenia Gravis:
Epidemiology: More common in females, typically manifesting in middle age.

Clinical Features:

Muscle weakness worsens with repetitive activity and improves with rest.
Weakness primarily affects the proximal muscles and is often asymmetrical.
Cranial nerve involvement: Early involvement includes ptosis and diplopia due to extraocular muscle weakness, as well as facial weakness (e.g., snarling expression when smiling). Other features include difficulty chewing, swallowing, and nasal speech due to the involvement of the palate and tongue muscles.
Deep tendon reflexes are typically preserved.

Myasthenic crisis: An acute, severe exacerbation of weakness, particularly in respiratory muscles, which can lead to ventilatory failure. This is often triggered by infections or excessive anticholinesterase medication use.
Repetitive nerve stimulation test: Shows a decremental response in muscle action potentials.
Edrophonium (Tensilon) test: Short-term improvement of symptoms after administering edrophonium, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, which increases acetylcholine availability at the neuromuscular junction. Neostigmine produces a similar effect.

Treatment Options:
Anticholinesterase drugs: Pyridostigmine is commonly used to enhance neuromuscular transmission by inhibiting the breakdown of acetylcholine.
Thymectomy: Surgical removal of the thymus may reduce symptoms or induce remission in some patients.
Immunosuppressive therapy: Includes glucocorticoids, azathioprine, tacrolimus, or rituximab to reduce autoantibody production.
Plasmapheresis and intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG): Used in severe cases or myasthenic crises to remove circulating antibodies.

Other options:

  • ALS → UMN + LMN signs, no fatigability.

  • Huntington chorea → movement disorder with chorea, psychiatric symptoms.

  • External ophthalmoplegia → progressive but not fluctuating, and not relieved by neostigmine.

choices.text: Which of the following medications must have caused this presentation?

questions.text: A male patient presented with headache, nausea, vomiting, and diaphoresis since early morning. He was diagnosed with depression 4 months back and has been taking medication. He gives the history of attending an office party the previous night where he consumed some red wine. On examination, his BP was 190/120. Which of the following medications must have caused this presentation?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with headache, nausea, vomiting, diaphoresis, and severe hypertension after consuming red wine while on antidepressant therapy.

  • This is characteristic of a hypertensive crisis due to a tyramine interaction.

  • Phenelzine is a MAO inhibitor (MAOI) used for depression.

    • MAOIs inhibit monoamine oxidase, which normally metabolizes tyramine found in foods like aged cheese, red wine, cured meats.

    • Tyramine accumulation → massive release of norepinephrine → severe hypertension, headache, sweating, nausea.

Other options:

  • Phentolamine: α-blocker used to treat hypertensive crises, not cause them.

  • Propranolol: β-blocker; would reduce BP and heart rate, not cause hypertensive crisis.

  • Prazosin: α1-blocker; antihypertensive, not causative.



Reference
Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry - 11th Edition - Page no 995, 782

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with diarrhea, sweating, excessive lacrimation, and salivation. His pulse rate is 55/min and his plasma cholinesterase level was 50U/mL. Which of the following can be used to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is presenting with cholinergic toxicity, likely due to organophosphate poisoning, as suggested by:

  • Symptoms: Diarrhea, sweating, lacrimation, salivation 

  • Bradycardia (pulse 55/min)

  • Very low plasma cholinesterase level (normal: ~3,500–8,500 U/mL), indicating AChE inhibition

    Drug Analysis:

  1. Neostigmine

    • A cholinesterase inhibitor, it would worsen cholinergic symptoms.

    • Contraindicated in organophosphate poisoning.

  2. Epinephrine

    • A sympathomimetic, may help with bradycardia but does not counteract muscarinic toxicity.

    • Not the drug of choice.

  3. Atropine

    • A muscarinic antagonist.

    • Mainstay of treatment for organophosphate poisoning.

    • It competes with acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors and reverses bradycardia, salivation, lacrimation, diarrhea, etc.

  4. Benztropine

    • A central anticholinergic used in Parkinsonism, not effective in reversing peripheral muscarinic effects in poisoning.

      Management of Organophosphate Poisoning:

  • Atropine: For muscarinic symptoms

  • Pralidoxime (2-PAM): To reactivate acetylcholinesterase

  • Supportive care: Airway, fluids, oxygen


Reference:Goodman and gillmans The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics 13th edition page no 170

questions.text: Which of the following medications is safe for pregnancy-induced hypertension?
questions.solution:
Pregnancy-Induced Hypertension (PIH) requires antihypertensives that are both effective and safe for the fetus.

  1. Alpha methyl dopa 

    • First-line drug for hypertension in pregnancy

    • Centrally acting alpha-2 agonist

    • Long-standing safety record during pregnancy

    • Safe in all trimesters

  2. Losartan 

    • Angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB)

    • Contraindicated in pregnancy, especially in 2nd and 3rd trimesters

    • Associated with fetal renal damage, oligohydramnios, skull hypoplasia

  3. Propranolol 

    • Non-selective beta-blocker

    • Can cause fetal growth restriction and neonatal bradycardia/hypoglycemia

    • Not preferred; labetalol (a mixed α/β-blocker) is safer and preferred if beta-blockers are used

  4. Lisinopril 

    • ACE inhibitor

    • Absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy

    • Associated with fetal renal anomalies, oligohydramnios, IUGR, neonatal death


      Summary Table: Safe Antihypertensives in Pregnancy
       

      Drug Safety Status Comment
      Methyldopa Safe First-line for PIH
      Labetalol Safe Commonly used alternative
      Nifedipine Safe Calcium channel blocker alternative
      ACE inhibitors (e.g., Lisinopril) Unsafe Fetotoxic
      ARBs (e.g., Losartan) Unsafe Fetotoxic
      Propranolol Caution advised Not first choice

Reference:Goodman and Gillmans The pharmacological basis of Therapeutics 13th edition page no 514

questions.text: Choose the statement that is untrue for NSAIDs.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Used in Neuropathic Pain.
  • NSAIDs are helpful for nociceptive pain (they inhibit COX which produces Prostaglandins which mediates nociceptive pain) but cannot relieve neuropathic pain as the physiologic process behind both are different.
  • NSAIDs do not affect the tenderness induced by direct application of PGs, but block the pain sensitizing mechanism induced by bradykinin, TNFα, interleukins (ILs) and other analgesic substances primarily by inhibiting COX-2. This constitutes the peripheral component of the analgesic action of NSAIDs. They are, therefore, more effective against inflammation associated pain. Drugs like Gabapentin/SSRIs are used for Neuropathic pain.

Option 2 and 3 are correct regarding NSAIDs interaction: Renal effects of NSAIDs become significant in those with CHF, hypovolemia, hepatic cirrhosis, renal disease and in patients receiving diuretics or antihypertensives. In them Na+ retention and edema can occur; diuretic and antihypertensive drug effects are blunted.
Option 4 is correct as NSAIDs have been marketed in topical formulations (mostly as gels) for application over painful muscles or joints.
It is presumed that the drug would penetrate to the subjacent tissues attaining high concentrations in the affected muscles/joints, while maintaining low blood levels. Some Topical Preparations are Diclofenac gel 1%, Ibuprofen 10% etc.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 210.

questions.text: What is Abatacept, a new drug inhibiting costimulation, used for treating?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Rheumatoid Arthritis
 
  • Abatacept is composed of the Fc region of the IgG1 fused to the extracellular domain of CTLA-4.
  • It inhibits the costimulation signal by binding to CD80/86 and preventing T cell activation. 
  • It's used in the treatment of Rheumatoid arthritis. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 230.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-rheumatoid medications that change illness functions by raising extracellular adenosine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Methotrexate
 
  • Methotrexate is a disease-modifying anti rheumatoid drug that increases extracellular adenosine.
  • It relates to the inhibition of amino-imidazole carboxamide ribonucleotide (AICAR) transformylase and dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR).
  • AICAR accumulates intracellularly, and competitively inhibits AMP deaminase, leading to an accumulation of AMP. 
  • The AMP is released and converted extracellularly to adenosine, which is a potent inhibitor of inflammation.
  • As a result, the inflammatory functions of neutrophils, macrophages, dendritic cells, and lymphocytes are suppressed.
Online Reference:
Riksen NP, Barrera P, van den Broek PH, van Riel PL, Smits P, Rongen GA. Methotrexate modulates the kinetics of adenosine in humans in vivo. Ann Rheum Dis. 2006 Apr;65(4):465-70. doi: 10.1136/ard.2005.048637. Epub 2005 Nov 24. PMID: 16308339; PMCID: PMC1798086.

questions.text: Rheumatoid arthritis is treated with the disease-modifying drug etanercept. What is its mode of operation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option1) Inhibition of TNF alpha

It is a recombinant fusion protein of TNF-receptor with Fc portion of human IgG1 and is administered by s.c injection 50 mg weekly. It binds to and prevents TNFα from activating TNF receptors on the membrane of T-cells/macrophages.

TNF alpha inhibitors memorising trick:

Trick: -
ACE Inhibitor ko Goli maro
A-Adalimumab
C- Certolizumab
E- Eternacept
I-Infliximab
Goli- Golimumab

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 230.

questions.text: Which drug should be used as the least-resort treatment for a male with insulin-dependent diabetes who has macular edema and develops glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Prostaglandin analogue
 
  • Prostaglandin analogues can potentially worsen diabetic macular edema and is generally not recommended in patients with diabetic retinopathy due to its potential effects on retinal fluid dynamics.
  • Therefore, it would be considered the least appropriate choice for managing glaucoma in this context. Common side effect of prostaglandin analogue is Cystoid Macular edema.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 169.

questions.text: Allopurinol is used to treat:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option  2) Gout
 
  • Allopurinol is a purine antimetabolite and a competitive inhibitor of the xanthine oxidase enzyme.
  • It prevents the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid reducing plasma uric acid levels.
  • The metabolite of allopurinol called oxypurinol is a non-competitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase.
  • It is used in the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients with gout and also in patients with haematological malignancies about to undergo chemotherapy.
* [Extra Edge]: Drugs used in Gout

+ Acute gout:
Drugs that relieve inflammation and pain:
  • NSAIDs
  • Colchicine
  • Glucocorticoids

+ Uricosuric drugs- These drugs increase the excretion of uric acid.
  • Probenecid
  • Benzbromarone
  • Lesinurad



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 233.

questions.text: Which type of steroid is more potent at the same concentration:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Ointment

 The vehicle is the carrier of the drug, and it depends on the region affected and the type of lesion present. 

* TABLE SHOWING THE DIFFERENT TYPES OF VEHICLES FOR DRUG DELIVERY:-



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 10.

questions.text: What is colchicine's mode of action in acute gout?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Leukocytes, lymphocytes inhibition & microtubular inhibitor.
 
  • Colchicine works to treat acute gout by inhibiting neutrophilic migration, which is the movement of white blood cells (neutrophils) to the site of inflammation caused by the accumulation of uric acid crystals in the joint. This inhibition reduces the inflammatory response in the affected area and thus helps to alleviate pain, swelling, and tenderness. 
  • It binds to tubulin and inhibits microtubule polymerization thereby impairing neutrophil chemotaxis and degranulation.
  • Colchicine does not inhibit urate oxidase, xanthine oxidase, or cyclooxygenase, which are enzymes involved in the production of uric acid or inflammation. Allopurinol inhibits Xanthine oxidase while NSAIDs inhibit cyclooxygenase.
  • Colchicine is considered a second-line treatment for acute gout, used when nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or corticosteroids are ineffective, contraindicated, or not tolerated.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 231.

questions.text: How does colchicine work to treat acute gout?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Inhibits neutrophilic migration
 
  • Colchicine works to treat acute gout by inhibiting neutrophilic migration, which is the movement of white blood cells (neutrophils) to the site of inflammation caused by the accumulation of uric acid crystals in the joint. This inhibition reduces the inflammatory response in the affected area and thus helps to alleviate pain, swelling, and tenderness.
  • Colchicine does not inhibit urate oxidase, xanthine oxidase, or cyclooxygenase, which are enzymes involved in the production of uric acid or inflammation. Allopurinol inhibits Xanthine oxidase while NSAIDs inhibit cyclooxygenase.
