  • Colchicine is considered a second-line treatment for acute gout, used when nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or corticosteroids are ineffective, contraindicated, or not tolerated.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 231.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Rheumatoid arthritis was on medications. Which drug is responsible to cause blurring vision and corneal opacity post 2 years of medication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Chloroquine

  • For RA, Chloroquine has to be given for long periods accumulate in tissues (especially melanin containing tissue) and produce toxicity, particularly in the eyes.
  • These include retinopathy, blurred or distorted vision, loss of central vision, Corneal Opacity and difficulty seeing in dim light.
  • In some cases, long-term use of chloroquine can lead to irreversible retinal damage and a condition known as pigmentary maculopathy, which can cause a permanent loss of vision.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 229.

questions.text: Pick the drug which would prevent motion sickness in a person who is planning to travel by bus.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Promethazine

  • Promethazine is a first-line medication for the prevention and treatment of motion sickness. It is generally effective for preventing nausea and vomiting due to motion. It works by blocking dopamine, a neurotransmitter that helps regulate nausea.
  • It also has antihistamine properties that can help provide relief from symptoms of motion sickness such as dizziness, irritability and headache.
  • In addition, it is a sedative and calming agent, which can help to relieve anxiety associated with motion sickness.
* Other options: 

Option 2 Meclizine- It is also a first generation antihistaminic used in prevention of motion sickness but it is not as effective as promethazine 
Option 3 and 4 They are second generation antihistaminic therefore can't cross BBB and not effective in motion sickness.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 183.

questions.text: What injection amongst the following was given to a patient of biliary colic which worsened the pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Morphine
 
  • Morphine is an opioid drug that is often used to treat pain.
  • In the case of biliary colic, however, morphine can worsen the pain because of the bile duct spasm that can cause constriction of sphincter of oddi and lead to increased billiary pressure to 10 folds, which can lead to an increase in pain. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 502.

questions.text: Choose the option that best describes a prucalopride-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 5HT4 Agonist
 
  • Prucalopride, a 5HT4 agonist, increases intestinal motility is licensed for the treatment of chronic constipation in females who are resistant to laxatives. It is also used in GERD and gastroparesis. Most common side effect is diarrhea.
  • Tegaserod, mosapride, and cisapride are further medications in this class.
  • Tegaserod and cisapride are banned due to the possibility of QT prolongation.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 724.

questions.text: In which of the following do we use pegloticase-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Chronic Gout
 
  • Pegloticase is a recombinant mammalian uricase that is covalently attached to methoxy polyethylene glycol (mPEG) to prolong the circulating half-life and diminish immunogenic response.
  • Pegloticase is the newest urate-lowering therapy to be approved for the treatment of refractory chronic gout.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 235.

questions.text: An older woman with migraines who is currently receiving therapy reports recent onset chest pain with no history of angina or MI. Which of the following drugs might have caused this presentation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 5HT2 Agonist

Drug 5HT1b/1d agonists like sumatriptan have mechanics of actions causing these presentations.

* 5HT Agonists:
  • Sets off the migraine's vasoconstrictor phase.
  • Takes part in the neurogenic inflammation of the blood vessels
  • Major side effects include Tightness in chest and head, Dizziness, Weakness, Bradycardia, Seizures.
  • Contraindications are Ischemic heart disease, hypertension, epilepsy, hepatic or renal impairment and pregnancy.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 194.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the medications used to treat gout is correct
A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid secretion
B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint
C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways
D. Aspirin is used as it is most powerful NSAID
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Statement A, B & C

Gout results from the precipitation of urate crystals in the tissues and the subsequent inflammatory response. Acute gout usually causes painful distal mono arthritis and can cause joint destruction, subcutaneous deposits (tophi), and renal calculi and damage. In most patients with gout, hyperuricemia arises from underexcretion rather than overproduction of urate.

* The aims of treatment are to:
  • Decrease the symptoms of an acute attack
  • Decrease the risk of recurrent attacks
  • Lower serum urate levels
Statement C Indomethacin is a potent nonselective inhibitor of the COXs. It also inhibits the motility of polymorphonuclear leukocytes, depresses the biosynthesis of mucopolysaccharides, and may have a direct COX-independent vasoconstrictor effect. Indomethacin has prominent anti-inflammatory and analgesic-antipyretic properties like those of the salicylates.
Statement B The drug accumulates in synovial fluid after oral administration, which may explain why its duration of therapeutic effect is considerably longer than its plasma t1/2.
Statement A Aspirin has a bimodal effect on the renal handling of uric acid: High doses of aspirin (>3 g/day) are uricosuric (probably by blocking urate reabsorption), while low dosages (1–2 g/day) cause uric acid retention (probably via inhibiting urate secretion). Low-dose aspirin, indicated for the prophylaxis of cardiovascular events, can cause changes in renal function and uric acid handling in elderly patients.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 33, 842.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient who has been using low-dose aspirin for the past six months was diagnosed with rectal haemorrhage. Which of the following substances is likely to be inhibited and cause the bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Thromboxane A2
 
  • Aspirin is an irreversible inhibitor of the COX (cyclooxygenase enzyme). Aspirin at low doses (75mg) primarily acts by inhibiting cyclooxygenase 1 (COX-1).
  • Low-dose aspirin, used for antiplatelet action, results in selective inhibition of platelet COX-1 (thromboxane synthase) inhibiting its ability to form thromboxane A2 (needed for platelet aggregation).
  • At higher doses, aspirin also inhibits COX-2 and results in decreased production of prostacyclin from endothelium. This may nullify the beneficial anti-aggregatory effect of aspirin.
  • Side effects: Gastric ulceration, tinnitus (CN VIII). Chronic use can lead to acute renal failure, interstitial nephritis, GI bleeding. Risk of Reye syndrome in children treated with aspirin for viral infection. Toxic doses cause respiratory alkalosis early, but transitions to mixed metabolic acidosis-respiratory alkalosis.
* [ Extra Edge ]: Mechanism of Actions 
 

 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 215.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below is not used to treat rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Febuxostat

Febuxostat, a nonpurine selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, which is used to treat hyperuricemia and has fewer hypersensitivity reactions than allopurinol in lowering blood uric acid level in patients with hyperuricemia and gout.

Option 1, 2 and 4 Etanercept, leflunomide, and methotrexate are commonly used in the management of rheumatoid arthritis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 235.

questions.text: Of the following, which one is not a second-generation antihistamine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Cyclizine

Cyclizine is a first generation antihistaminic and cetirizine, loratadine and fexofenadine are second generation antihistaminic.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 179.

questions.text: The following Prostaglandin causes both vasodilatation and vasoconstriction:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) PGF2α

Among the four types of prostaglandins mentioned in the question, PGF2α is the only one that causes both vasodilatation and vasoconstriction.
  • PGF2α is produced by the smooth muscle cells of blood vessels and has a potent vasoconstrictive effect. This means that it causes the blood vessels to narrow, which increases the resistance to blood flow and raises blood pressure.
  • However, PGF2α also has a vasodilatory effect on certain blood vessels, such as those in the coronary arteries and the uterus. This means that it causes these blood vessels to relax and widen, which increases blood flow to these areas.
Option 1 PGE2 is primarily a vasodilator, which means that it causes blood vessels to relax and widen.
Option 3 PGI2 (prostacyclin) is a potent vasodilator and inhibitor of platelet aggregation.
Option 4 Thromboxane A2, on the other hand, is a potent vasoconstrictor and platelet aggregator.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 200.

questions.text: Which biological agent for rheumatoid arthritis is a JAK inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Tofacitinib
 
  • Tofacitinib is a novel, oral JAK inhibitor which will inhibit the JAK-STAT pathway responsible for the production of cytokines and chemokines.
  • It is a new synthetic drug approved for severe cases of RA that are not responding to Methotrexate. Tofacitinib can be used alone or concurrently with Methotrexate, but should not be combined with azathioprine, cyclosporine or biological DMARDs.
  • It has been approved for the treatment of psoriatic arthritis and is also used in rheumatoid arthritis and ulcerative colitis.
Option 1 Etanercept is a recombinant fusion protein of TNF-receptor with Fc portion of human IgG1. It binds to and prevents TNFα from activating TNF receptors on the membrane of T-cells/macrophages.
Option 2 Tocilizumab, an IL-6 receptor antagonist, is FDA-approved for treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis, giant cell arteritis, polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis, and cytokine release syndrome.
Option 3 Abatacept is a recombinant fusion protein which combines part of Fc domain of human IgG with extracellular domain of T-cell inhibitory receptor CTLA4. It is approved for moderate-severe active RA not responding to Mtx. It can be combined with Mtx and other DMARDs, but not with TNFα antagonists due to greatly increased risk of infections.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 229.

questions.text: Which of the following antihistamines has the least sedative effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Chlorpheniramine 
 
  • Chlorpheniramine is an antihistamine that is commonly used to treat allergic conditions such as hay fever, allergic rhinitis, and hives.
  • Chlorpheniramine is considered to have a relatively low sedative effect compared to some other antihistamine.
  • Chlorpheniramine has a relatively lower ability to cross the blood-brain barrier compared to other antihistamines like Diphenhydramine or Promethazine. This is believed to be the reason why Chlorpheniramine is associated with less sedation.
Option1, 2 and 3 Drugs are high or moderately sedating compounds as they cross BBB easily.  



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 180.

questions.text:
How is Buprenorphine classified?
1. Partial agonist at \(\mu\) receptor 
2. Partial agonist at \(\kappa\) receptors
3. Full agonist at \(\mu\) receptor 
4. Full agonist at \(\kappa\) receptors
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Partial agonist at μ receptors

Buprenorphine is a partial μ agonist and an antagonist at δ and κ receptors. It is used as an analgesic and in the management of opioid dependence. It does not have an effect on the neuronal uptake of serotonin so is not implicated in causing serotonin syndrome. 

* [Extra Edge]: Opioids
All opioid agonist-antagonists are µ antagonists and k agonists, except buprenorphine and dezocine. Buprenorphine and dezocine are partial agonists at the μ receptor.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 508.

questions.text: What is not true about serotonin syndrome ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Dantrolene is the drug of choice

Serotonin syndrome occurs due to the combined side effects with any drug that increases serum serotonin levels like MAOIs (monoamine oxidase inhibitors), SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors), TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants), tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA (amphetamine), dextromethorphan, etc.

* Serotonin syndrome – TRIAD:
  • Autonomic instability - hyperthermia, hypertension, tachycardia, diaphoresis, vomiting, diarrhea.
  • Altered mental status - agitation, confusion, delirium.
  • Neuromuscular hyperactivity - tremor, hyperreflexia, myoclonus.
* Cyproheptadine is the drug of choice in serotonin syndrome.

Option 3 Dantrolene reduces spasticity in upper motor neuron disorders, hemiplegia, paraplegia, cerebral palsy and multiple sclerosis. 
Used I.V. it is the drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia which is due to persistent release of Ca2+ from sarcoplasmic reticulum (induced by fluorinated anesthetics and Succinylcholine in genetically susceptible individuals with abnormal RyR1).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 488.

questions.text: Which of the statements is not true about 'Aprepitant' ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Agonist at Neurokinin receptor (NK1) 
 
  • Aprepitant is a neurokinin receptor antagonist that is used treatment of cytotoxic (chemotherapy) drug-induced vomiting. It is the doc of late onset chemotherapy induced nausea and vomiting.
  • It works by blocking the action of substance P, a neurotransmitter that plays a role in triggering nausea and vomiting.
  • Aprepitant is known to cross the blood-brain barrier, which allows it to exert its effects centrally in the brain.
  • It is metabolized primarily by the CyP3A4 pathway in the liver.
  • The primary therapeutic use of Aprepitant is to ameliorate the nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy regimens.
* [Extra Edge]: Mechanism of Action



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 718.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice in over dosage of paracetamol?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for paracetamol poisoning is N-acetylcysteine. 
 
  • Acetaminophen is an important cause of acute liver failure.
  • It is metabolized by cytochrome P450 CYP 2E1 which converts acetaminophen to N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone-imine ( NAPQ1 ).
  • Glutathione is responsible for its detoxification.
  • Depletion of glutathione results in excessive production of NAPQ1 which causes acute liver necrosis. 
 
  • N-acetylcysteine helps in replenishment of glutathione. 



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 198, 241, 452-454.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2586, 2588, 2589, 2623, 2627.

questions.text: NAPQI is an intermediate metabolite of which drug toxicity?
questions.solution:
• The correct answer is 1. Paracetamol (also known as acetaminophen).
  • NAPQI (N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine) is a toxic metabolite that is formed during the metabolism of paracetamol (acetaminophen) in the liver. In therapeutic doses, paracetamol is primarily metabolized by conjugation with glucuronic acid and sulfate, which are nontoxic pathways.
  • However, when paracetamol is taken in excessive amounts or in the presence of certain risk factors, a significant portion of it is metabolized by the cytochrome P450 enzyme system in the liver, leading to the production of NAPQI.
  • NAPQI is highly reactive and can cause liver damage by depleting glutathione and forming toxic adducts with cellular proteins.
 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 696 .

choices.text: Hemodialysis for elimination of drug from the body

questions.text: A 24-year male was brought to the emergency due to consumption of 100 tablets of Aspirin. On ABG analysis; pH=7.1; HCO3-= 7 mmol/l. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The scenario presents a medical emergency of acute salicylate (aspirin) poisoning. The ABG parameters reveal metabolic acidosis (pH < 7.36 in the setting of low bicarbonate, often defined as <22 mEq/L).

Thus, the next step in the management of this patient will be the administration of IV sodium bicarbonate to correct acidemia and urinary alkalinization for systemic toxicity to increase aspirin excretion. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 224.

questions.text: A patient is taking anti-gout medications. Which of the following drugs work by inhibiting the synthesis of uric acid?
questions.solution:
• Allopurinol is a purine antimetabolite and competitively inhibits xanthine oxidase at low concentrations and is a noncompetitive inhibitor at high concentrations.
  • It prevents the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid reducing plasma uric acid levels. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 233.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with diffuse abdominal pain. He has a known history of chronic NSAID's usage. Physical examination reveals rigidity. X-ray abdomen is as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 40-year-old man with chronic NSAID use and diffuse abdominal pain suggests a high risk of peptic ulcer disease (PUD). NSAIDs inhibit prostaglandin synthesis, reducing mucosal protection in the stomach and duodenum, thereby increasing the risk of ulcer formation and complications like perforation.

Key clinical findings:

  • Diffuse abdominal pain that may become sudden and severe.

  • Rigidity on examination, indicating peritonitis.

  • History of NSAID use is a major risk factor for peptic ulcer.

Radiographic clue (on upright abdominal or chest X-ray):

  • Presence of free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum), which is a hallmark sign of gastrointestinal perforation, most commonly due to peptic ulcer perforation.

    Other options: 

  • Intestinal obstruction typically presents with abdominal distension, vomiting, and visible peristalsis; X-ray shows multiple air-fluid levels, not free air under diaphragm.

  • Pericarditis causes chest pain, not abdominal rigidity, and does not explain free air on abdominal X-ray.

  • Gallstones may cause biliary colic or cholecystitis, but not pneumoperitoneum or generalized peritonitis.

Hence, the most likely diagnosis is peptic ulcer perforation.


Reference:Katzung Basic and clinical pharmacology 13th edition page no 638

questions.text: Pick the option that does not cause edema.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Digoxin

Digoxin is used to treat CHF so it helps to treat volume overload .It does not cause edema

* Other options: -
1. Amlodipine causes lower limb edema by pre-capillary dilatation
3. Estrogen causes edema by salt and water retention
4. Cyclosporine also increases chances of edema

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 565.

questions.text: Because ___________, nitroglycerin works well as a sublingual medicine.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Nonionic and highly lipid soluble

Because it is non-ionic and highly lipid soluble, nitroglycerin is beneficial as a sublingual drug also it bypasses the first pass metabolism and causes quick and near ​​total systemic absorption.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 588.

questions.text: What is the most effective antihypertensive medication for pulmonary hypertension
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Bosentan

Bosentan is a non-specific antagonist of endothelin receptors (both ET-A & ET-B). It is approved by FDA for the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension. 

Other options: -
1. Digoxin- It increases myocardial contractility and is used in heart failure
2. Furosemide- It is a loop diuretic used in heart failure mainly
3. Amlodipine- It is a Calcium Channel Blocker used in hypertension

The treatment of PAH is important for INICET -

First we will do a Vasoreactivity test, if it is positive the DOC is Ca Channel blockers. If negative based on severity we can use oral drugs like PDE inhibitors like Sildenafil or Endothelin Receptor antagonists like Bosentan. Severe cases we can use IV Prostaglandins, inhaled NO etc.
        
Online Reference: Gabbay E, Fraser J, McNeil K. Review of bosentan in the management of pulmonary arterial hypertension. Vasc Health Risk Manag. 2007;3(6):887-900. PMID: 18200808; PMCID: PMC2350123.

questions.text: Which of the following diuretics can be used in the treatment of mild to moderate hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Thiazide diuretic

Thiazide diuretic can be given in mild to moderate hypertension.
  • Low-dose thiazide diuretics may be used alone or in combination with other antihypertensive drugs.
  • Thiazides inhibit the Na+Cl- pump in the distal convoluted tubule and hence increase sodium excretion. In the long term, they also may act as vasodilators.
  • Thiazides are safe, efficacious, inexpensive, and reduce clinical events.
  • They provide additive blood pressure-lowering effects when combined with beta blockers, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE/s), or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 606.

questions.text: A lipid profile is performed on a 60-year-old patient who had a myocardial infarction two weeks ago. The results show HDL 32 mg/dL, LDL 126 mg/dL, and TG 276 mg/dL. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Atorvastatin 80 mg
 
  • Statins are competitive inhibitors of HMG-CoA reductase.
  • This leads to a decrease in cholesterol biosynthesis. Statins are also effective in reducing LDL and triglyceride levels. 
  • Atorvastatin 80 mg can be used to treat this condition. 
  • The first line of therapy in controlling cholesterol in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) is starting a high-intensity statin. (similar to the above case scenario where the patient has MI)
  • High-intensity statins include atorvastatin (40-80 mg) and rosuvastatin (20-40 mg).
NOTE: While fibrates are known to reduce TG, they are not considered first-line therapy in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Statin+ Fibrate therapy(option 1) has not been shown to reduce mortality. Fibrates are only recommended in moderate to severe TG levels (more than 500mg/dL).

Online Reference: Aronow WS. Management of hyperlipidemia with statins in the older patient. Clin Interv Aging. 2006;1(4):433-8. doi: 10.2147/ciia.2006.1.4.433. PMID: 18046920; PMCID: PMC2699649.

questions.text: What antihypertensive medication is not prescribed during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Enalapril
 
  • Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor and ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in pregnancy.
  • They cause severe fetal malformations such as fetal growth retardation, hypoplasia of organs and fetal death may occur if ACE inhibitors are given during later half of pregnancy.
  • A recent report indicates 2.7-fold higher malformation rate in fetuses exposed to ACE inhibitors in the first trimester.
  • ACE inhibitors must be stopped when the woman conceives.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 531.

questions.text: Which medication is preferred for pregnancy-related hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Methyldopa
 
  • Drug of choice for hypertension in pregnancy is methyldopa.
  • Methyldopa is a centrally acting antihypertensive agent. It is a prodrug that exerts its antihypertensive action via an active metabolite.
  • Methyldopa was a widely used antihypertensive in the 1960s and 1970s, especially in combination with a diuretic. However, it is rarely used now, except to treat hypertension during pregnancy wherein it has a long track record of safety, both for the mother as well as the fetus.
  • Labetolol is preferred to Methyl dopa due to the drugs association with post partum depression
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 612.

questions.text: Where does the primary action of nitrates in angina patients occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Decreases Preload

Sublingual administration of nitrates reduces O2 demand primarily by preload reduction rather than coronary artery vasodilation.
* Antianginal Effects of Organic Nitrates depends on Following mechanisms:
  • Reduced cardiac O2 demand- The major determinants of myocardial O2 consumption are left ventricular wall tension, heart rate, and myocardial contractility. Ventricular wall tension is affected by preload and afterload.
  • Increase in the delivery of O2 to ischemic regions of myocardium- When considering the effect of vasodilators in the ischemic heart, it is important to realize that myocardial ischemia itself is a powerful stimulus to coronary vasodilation and part of an autoregulatory mechanism.
* Experimental Evidence:
  • when GTN is injected directly into the coronary circulation of patients with CAD, anginal attacks (induced by electrical pacing) are not aborted even when coronary blood flow is increased.
  • In contrast, sublingual administration of GTN does relieve anginal pain in the same patients, indicating that the major antianginal effect of nitro vasodilators is mediated by preload reduction rather than coronary artery dilation.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 611.

questions.text: When should we switch to heparin in a pregnant woman with rheumatic heart disease who has a prosthetic valve?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 36 weeks.

Warfarin should be held after 36 weeks' gestation (during 37th week) and replaced with LMWH or unfractionated heparin.
 
  • Before giving birth, anticoagulation should be avoided because warfarin, which crosses the placenta, raises the risk of fetal intraventricular hemorrhage, and therapeutic anticoagulation increases the risk for hemorrhagic complications with regional anesthetic.
  • The purpose of conversion to UFH has less to do with any risk of maternal bleeding at the time of Delivery, but rather with neuraxial blockade complicated by an epidural or spinal hematoma.
  • Administration of warfarin during pregnancy causes birth defects and abortion especially in first trimester.  Fetal or neonatal hemorrhage and intrauterine death may occur, even when maternal INR values are within the therapeutic range. Vitamin K antagonists should not be used during pregnancy, but heparin or LMWH can be used safely.
  • Anticoagulation algorithm is pregnancy- 1st trimester LMWH, 2nd trimester upto 36 weeks warfarin, after 36 weeks LMWH or Heparin.
Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page No 985.

questions.text: What is the mechanism through which acetylcholine lowers heart rate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Delayed diastolic depolarization

Acetylcholine lowers heart rate primarily through preventing diastolic depolarization, or the spontaneous depolarization of cells in the SA node.
  • Acetylcholine hyperpolarizes the SA nodal cells and decreases their rate of diastolic depolarization. As a result, rate of impulse generation is reduced bradycardia, or even cardiac arrest may occur.
  • At the A-V node and His-Purkinje fibers refractory period (RP) is increased and conduction is slowed: P-R interval increases and partial to complete A-V block may be produced.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 114.

questions.text: Which mechanism does nitroprusside's active metabolite use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Guanyl cyclase

Sodium nitroprusside active metabolite is Nitric oxide.
Nitric oxide activates guanylyl cyclase and raises levels of cyclic GMP. Myosin light chain phosphorylase, which is dephosphorylated by protein kinase G when cyclic GMP is activated, relaxes the smooth muscles in blood vessels.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 544.

questions.text: Verapamil was administered to a patient who was taking metoprolol for hypertension. What will this lead to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Bradycardia with AV block 
 
  • Among the following bradycardia with AV block are likely to happen with the above combination therapy.
  • Verapamil and metoprolol (beta-blocker) show drug interaction and result in precipitation of bradycardia and AV block since both have inhibitory action on AV node and oppose positive inotropic action.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: A young female patient on antidepressants arrives at the emergency department with hypotension and impaired sensory function. Wide QRS complexes and a right axis deviation are visible on the ECG. What is the best course of action for this patient's care now?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Sodium Bicarbonate.
 
  • The clinical features and ECG findings typically suggest a diagnosis of tricyclic antidepressant poisoning.
  • Treatment is primarily supportive with gastric lavage, respiratory assistance, fluid infusion, maintenance of BP and body temperature.
  • Acidosis must be corrected by sodium bicarbonate infusion given intravenously in doses of 100 mEq (1-2 mEq/kg), repeated every few minutes until BP recovers and QRS complexes start to narrow.
  • Diazepam may be injected I.V. to control convulsions and delirium.
  • Most important is the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias, for which propranolol/lidocaine may be used. 
Option 2 hemodialysis should not be used as TCAs have a significant volume of distribution and are largely protein-bound.
Option 3 Fomepezole is used as specific antidote of Methanol poisoning.
Option 4 Flumazenil is used as specific antidote of Benzodiazepine poisoning.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 487.

questions.text:
In an experimental setting, an unknown drug is being tested. The obtained results are shown in the table. Which new drug is likely to result from these actions?
 
Parameter Placebo treated New Drug treated
Heart rate 72 86
Systolic BP 110 150
Diastolic BP 80 68
Tremors Absent Present
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Beta-1 and beta-2 agonist
 
  • Beta-1 stimulation increases heart rate and systolic blood pressure, because of its receptors present in the heart.
  • Beta-2 stimulation cause vasodilation by it receptors present in the blood vessels and thus decreases diastolic blood pressure and tremors.
  • Hence, the drug appears to be beta-I and beta-2 agonist. Beta 2 causes phosphorylation of calcium channels and results in palpitations (cardiac muscle) and tremors (skeletal muscle).

Reference:  Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 143.​​​

questions.text: Isosorbide mononitrate is given to a patient suffering from Prinzmetal's angina. In this case, what is the mechanism of action of nitrates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Endothelium independent coronary vasodilation
 
  • Prinzmetal Angina is due to recurrent localized (occasionally diffuse) coronary vasospasm which may be superimposed on arteriosclerotic coronary artery disease. Abnormally reactive and hypertrophied segments in the coronary arteries have been demonstrated.
  • Nitrates work by causing endothelium-independent coronary vasodilation in Prinzmetal's angina
  • Organic nitrates are broken down to produce nitric oxide (NO), which binds to guanylyl cyclase in vascular smooth muscle cells and raises the level of cyclic guanosine monophosphate, which relaxes the smooth muscle.
Option 1, 2 and 3 are useful in antianginal property of Nitric oxide.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 613.

questions.text: Angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) with PPARgamma function as well is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Telmisartan 

Telmisartan has a dual function as ARB and PPAR gamma blocker.

Some special points about ARBs
  • Telmisartan and losartan have PPAR gamma blocking action
  • Telmisartan undergoes biliary excretion, can be given in CRF
  • Losartan increases Uric acid excretion (use – hypertension + gout), blocks thromboxane A2
  • Olmesartan and Candesartan are prodrugs
  • Olmesartan causes sprue like syndrome
Online Reference:
Cai W, Yang T, Liu H, Han L, Zhang K, Hu X, Zhang X, Yin KJ, Gao Y, Bennett MVL, Leak RK, Chen J. Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPARγ): A master gatekeeper in CNS injury and repair. Prog Neurobiol. 2018 Apr-May;163-164:27-58. doi: 10.1016/j.pneurobio.2017.10.002. Epub 2017 Oct 12. PMID: 29032144; PMCID: PMC6037317.

choices.text: Alpha-1 agonist action leading to peripheral vasoconstriction
Increase in renal perfusion due to agonist action on D1 receptors
Releases noradrenaline and causes positive inotropic effect
Direct action on heart via beta-1 receptors

questions.text: Which of the following dopamine characteristics is not beneficial in acute shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Increase in renal perfusion due to agonist action on D1 receptors
 
  • Dopamine at low concentrations (2 to 5 mcg/kg per minute) primarily acts on vascular D1 receptors, especially in the renal, mesenteric, and coronary beds.
  • By activating adenylyl cyclase and raising intracellular concentrations of cyclic AMP, D1 receptor stimulation leads to vasodilation and reducing cardiac load. The net result is a decrease in blood pressure and an increase in cardiac contractility. 
  • Infusion of low doses of dopamine causes an increase in glomerular filtration rate and renal blood flow and Na+- K+ -ATPase pump. Increased renal perfusion and decrease in blood pressure caused by dopamine due to D1 agonism (at low doses) doesn’t improves survival in acute shock.
  • As circulating DA concentrations rise, DA is able to activate β adrenergic receptors to further increase cardiac contractility. At very high concentrations, circulating DA activates α adrenergic receptors in the vasculature, thereby causing vasoconstriction; thus, high concentrations of DA increase blood pressure, i.e, a concentration  of 10mcg/kg/min infusion.

Option 1, 3 and 4 all points towards a Vasoconstrictive action on vasculature and a positive inotropic effect on heart.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 298.

questions.text: Which action of adrenaline is not noticed when treating anaphylaxis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Action on presynaptic alpha-receptors
 
  • Adrenaline action on presynaptic alpha receptors (alpha 2) decreases its actions centrally by presynaptic inhibition and hence not helpful in management of Anaphylactic Shock.
  • The prejunctional α2 receptor activates Gi-protein which then inhibits neuronal Ca2+ channels and also limits the intracellular availability of Ca2+ by decreasing cAMP production. Transmitter (NA) release is consequently diminished. Hyperpolarization through activation of G-protein gated K+ channels may also occur.
  • The use of epinephrine in countering anaphylaxis represents functional antagonism. Functional antagonism refers to the inhibition of an agonist’s action downstream of the receptor.
  • Epinephrine increases cyclic AMP levels within bronchiolar smooth muscle cells, which in turn inhibits myosin light chain kinase and thereby diminishes the contractile response engendered by histamine, thromboxane A2, and other substances released by mast cells
  • The alpha 1 receptor agonism  by epinephrine causes vasoconstriction which counter acts the vasodilatation caused by histamine. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 145.

choices.text: Decrease in blood pressure on adrenaline administration after phentolamine has been given

questions.text: Which of these statements best describes Dale's vasomotor reversal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Decrease in heart rate on adrenaline administration after phentolamine has been given

Adrenaline is a both alpha and beta agonist and Phentolamine is an alpha blocker.
  • Administration of epinephrine (Adrenaline) after administration of α-blockers produces only a fall in BP. This is because the α-mediated response is abolished and hence, only the β-mediated response is seen, resulting in a fall in BP. This phenomenon is called the Vasomotor reversal of Dale. 
  • Vasomotor reversal of Dale is a blockade of alpha (α1) followed by stimulation of beta (β2) receptors.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 143.

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitor of Rho kinase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fasudil 

  • Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitors, such as fasudil, ripasudil, and netarsudil, target the ROCK pathway, influencing smooth muscle contraction, fibrosis, and cellular motility. They are primarily used in treating glaucoma (reducing intraocular pressure) and cerebral vasospasm after subarachnoid hemorrhage. They also show potential for pulmonary hypertension, fibrosis, cancer, and neurological recovery. Side effects include conjunctival hyperemia and hypotension.
  • Fasudil is an inhibitor of smooth muscle Rho kinase and reduces coronary vasospasm in experimental animals. In clinical trials in patients with CAD, it has improved performance in stress tests. It is investigational in angina.
  • Fasudil appears to reduce pulmonary artery pressure in PAH. Surgical treatment for advanced disease includes creation of a right atrial to left atrial shunt and lung transplantation.


Option 2 Ranolazine is a novel antianginal drug primarily acts by inhibiting a late Na+ current (late INa) in the myocardium which indirectly facilitates Ca2+ entry through Na+/Ca2+ exchanger.
Option 3 Amiloride block ENaCs in the luminal membrane of principal cells in late distal tubules and collecting ducts by binding to a site in the channel pore.
Option 4 Nicorandil is a dual mechanism antianginal drug activates ATP sensitive K+ channels (KATP) in smooth muscle membrane thereby hyperpolarizing and relaxing it.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 313.

questions.text: Which medication exhibits Q-T Prolongation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Quinidine
 
  • Quinidine blocks Na+ current and multiple cardiac K+ currents. It is an open-state blocker of Na+ channels, with a τ recovery in the intermediate range. Thus, after therapeutic dosages, QRS duration increases modestly, usually by 10% to 20%.
  • At therapeutic concentrations, quinidine commonly prolongs the QT interval up to 25%, but the effect is highly variable.
  • Drugs causing QTc prolongation - 
  • Category Drugs
    Antiarrhythmics (Class 1a & 3) Quinidine, Procainamide, Disopyramide, Amiodarone, Sotalol, Dofetilide, Ibutilide
    Antibiotics Erythromycin, Clarithromycin, Levofloxacin, Ciprofloxacin, Moxifloxacin
    Antifungals Fluconazole, Itraconazole, Voriconazole
    Antipsychotics Haloperidol, Quetiapine, Risperidone, Olanzapine, Ziprasidone
    Antidepressants Amitriptyline, Imipramine, Citalopram, Escitalopram
    Antiemetics Ondansetron, Granisetron, Domperidone
    Other Drugs Methadone, Chloroquine, Hydroxychloroquine, Lithium, Tacrolimus
Other options: -
2. Amiodarone- class 3 antiarrythmic drug blocks potassium channel, causes QT prolongation but lesser than quinidine.
3. Magnesium sulfate is used in treatment of Torsa des depointes
4. Lignocaine - class 1b antiarryhmic drug doesn't cause QT prolongation 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 572.

questions.text: What exactly is Sacubitril?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Neutral endopeptidase inhibitor

* Sacubitril: -
  • It is an example of Neprilysin / Neutral endopeptidase inhibitor 
  • Mechanism of action: - It prevents the degradation of Bradykinin, Natriuretic Peptides, Angiotensin II, Substance P which  leads to increase in vasodilation and thereby decrease in ECF volume.
  • Use: - Used in combination with Valsartan to treat Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction
  • Adverse effects: - Hypotension, Cough (Due to increase in levels of Bradykinin)
  • Contraindications: - It is contraindicated with ACE inhibitors since both drugs increase the level of Bradykinin
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 553.

questions.text: You shouldn't take tadalafil with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Vasodilator
 
  • Tadalafil markedly potentiates the vasodilator action of nitrates and precipitous fall in BP, MI can occur.
  • Tadalafil is contraindicated in patients of coronary heart disease and those taking nitrates. Though sildenafil remains effective for <8 hours, it is advised that nitrates be avoided for 24 hours.
  • Tadalafil is an example of PDE5 inhibitor. Inhibition of Phosphodiesterase leads to increased levels of cGMP. Drugs like Tadalafil, Sildenafil thus leads to vasodilation, flushing, smooth muscle relaxation, tachycardia.
  • Hence Tadalafil should not be combined with other vasodilator drugs.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 328.

questions.text: Under what condition does Theophylline cause diuresis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Adenosine A1 receptor antagonism

  • Remember TEA - Theophylline - Enzyme inhibitor (PDE) - Adenosine A1 Receptor inhibitor, and is found in tea and coffee
  • Because of PDE inhibition - smooth muscle relaxation - Bronchodialation occurs - hence can be used in the treatment of status asthmaticus
  • Theophylline is an Adenosine receptor antagonist, meaning it blocks the binding of adenosine, a neurotransmitter, to A1 and A2a receptors located throughout the body. 
  • The A1 receptor is expressed in the proximal tubule and stimulates reabsorption of Na+. Consequently, antagonists of A1 receptors cause diuresis/natriuresis.
  • S/E due to Adenosine A1 R antagonism - Insomnia, seizures, tachypnea, tachycardia, Diuresis, Nausea and Vomiting (most common)

Option 1, 4 PDE3 and PDE4 are likely account for the bronchodilator action of theophylline which is involve in PDE inhibition and the concomitant elevation of cellular cAMP and cyclic GMP.
Option 3 there is no B2 agonist action of Theophylline.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 572.

questions.text: Select the antiarrhythmic drug which needs to be avoided in a patient with Interstitial lung diseases
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Amiodarone
 
  • Amiodarone is a drug used to treat arrhythmias and is associated with a number of dose dependent pulmonary side effects, including interstitial lung disease (ILD), Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis.
  • The most serious adverse effect during chronic amiodarone therapy is pulmonary fibrosis, which can be rapidly progressive and fatal.
  • Underlying lung disease, doses of 400 mg/d or more, and recent pulmonary insults such as pneumonia, ILD appear to be risk factors.
  • Thus, Amiodarone needs to be avoided in a patient with Interstitial lung diseases.
  • Serial chest X-rays or pulmonary function studies may detect early amiodarone toxicity but monitoring plasma concentrations has not been useful.
  • With low doses, such as 200 mg/d or less as used in AF, pulmonary toxicity is less common.
Option 2, 3 and 4 Drugs doesn't have any known contraindication to be used in a patient of ILD
 

Drugs that can cause lung fibrosis (drug-induced interstitial lung disease) include:

Category Examples
Chemotherapeutics Bleomycin, Busulfan, Methotrexate, Cyclophosphamide
Antiarrhythmics Amiodarone
Antibiotics Nitrofurantoin, Sulfasalazine
Biologics TNF-alpha inhibitors (e.g., Etanercept, Infliximab)
Immunosuppressants Sirolimus, Everolimus

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 578.

questions.text: Name the principal late inward sodium channel blocker.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ranolazine
 
  • Ranolazine is a late inward sodium channel blocker, meaning that it can be used to reduce the influx of sodium ions into the cell by blocking the late inward sodium currents.
  • This property can be used to prevent arrhythmias, as excessive influx of sodium can lead to abnormal electrical signals that trigger arrhythmia.
  • Furthermore, ranolazine can reduce the excitability of the ventricular myocardium, decreasing heart rate and lowering the amount of oxygen used by the heart. This can help reduce the symptoms of angina and reduce the risk of ischemic heart failure.
Trick:-
RaNolazine- Na+ channel blocker

Option 1 Ivabradine is a selective blocker of hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide–gated (HCN) ion channels involved in the generation of automaticity in the SA node.
Option 3 Trimetazidine is a partial fatty acid oxidase (PFOX) inhibitor that prevents cardiac tissue from oxidizing free fatty acids (major source of ATP in heart).
Option 4 Fasudil is a selective RhoA/Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitor that appears to reduce pulmonary artery pressure in PAH.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 600.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a drug related to heart failure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Trimetazidine
 
  • Trimetazidine is a partial fatty acid oxidase (PFOX) inhibitor that prevents cardiac tissue from oxidizing free fatty acids (major source of ATP in heart). In order to generate ATP, the heart therefore adjusts by boosting glycolysis. Since glycolysis requires less oxygen than other metabolic processes, there is a significant reduction in myocellular oxygen demand.
  • There is no effect on determinants of myocardial O2 consumption, such as HR and BP, both at rest as well as during exercise, but angina frequency is reduced, and exercise capacity is increased.
  • Thus Trimetazidine is an anti-anginal drug and not used in heart failure.

Option 1 Nesiritide, a BNP analog that has been approved for the treatment of resistant pulmonary edema associated with acute CHF.
Option 3 Sacubitril, a neutral endopeptidase inhibitor, is approved for use in conjunction with valsartan to treat chronic CHF.
Option 4 Metoprolol if introduced gradually and maintained for long term, can retard the progression of CHF and prolong life. The benefit may result from antagonism of delete­rious effects of sympathetic overactivity (invoked reflexly by heart failure) on the myocardium.

A frequent area of questions is regarding drugs with mortality benefit in treatment of Heart failure, remember the 2 D's - Digoxin and Diuretics do not have mortality benefit in maintainance treatment of CHF. the drugs having mortality benefit in their descending order are given below, with the best being Beta blockers.
Rank Drug Class Examples
1 Beta-Blockers Bisoprolol, Carvedilol, Metoprolol Succinate
2 ARNI (Angiotensin Receptor-Neprilysin Inhibitor) Sacubitril/Valsartan 
3 ACE Inhibitors (ACEi) Enalapril, Lisinopril (if ARNI not available)
4 Mineralocorticoid Receptor Antagonists (MRA) Spironolactone, Eplerenone
5 SGLT2 Inhibitors Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 599.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions calls for the use of inhaled nitric oxide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Pulmonary hypertension
 

  • Nitric Oxide inhalation dilates pulmonary vessels, resulting in decreased pulmonary vascular resistance and reduced pulmonary artery pressure.

  • Inhaled Nitric Oxide also improves oxygenation by reducing mismatch of ventilation and perfusion in the lung.

* Mechanism of Action:

Nitric oxide (NO) activates cytosolic soluble guanylyl cyclase → increased cGMP → causes dephosphorylation of myosin light chain kinase (MLCK) through a cGMP dependent protein kinase (PKG) → Reduced availability of phosphorylated (active) MLCK interferes with activation of myosin → it fails to interact with actin to cause contraction → Relaxation occurs.

* Indications: 

  • Therapeutic: The FDA has only approved chronic pulmonary neonatal hypertension as the use of inhaled NO. 

  • Diagnostic: During cardiac catheterization, inhaled NO can be utilized to assess the ability of patients with heart failure and newborns with congenital heart disease to dilate their blood vessels in the lungs to ascertain the alveolar-capillary unit's diffusion capacity (DL).

Option 1, 2 and 3 doesn't have an indication to use Inhaled nitric oxide.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 344.

questions.text: Clopidogrel was given to a patient who had suffered an ischemic stroke. He experienced another stroke episode even after six months of therapy. Which of the following describes clopidogrel's failure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) CYP2C19 inhibition
 
  • Clopidogrel is a prodrug only 50% of the ingested drug is absorbed, out of this only a fraction is activated in the liver by two step metabolism into an active thiol metabolite via CYP2CI9.
  • CYP2C19 inhibition by proton pump inhibitors (e.g., omeprazole, lansoprazole, dexlansoprazole, and pantoprazole) may reduce conversion to the active metabolite of clopidogrel, which may contribute to the lower efficacy of clopidogrel when coadministered with proton pump inhibitors.
  • Since CYP2C19, exhibits genetic polymorphism, the activation of clopidogrel and consequently its antiplatelet action shows high interindividual variability. Some patients are nonresponsive.
* Mechanism of action
Clopidogrel reduces ADP-induced aggregation by inhibiting the P2Y12 receptors on the surface of platelets. This Gi-coupled GPCR inhibits adenylyl cyclase and lowers cAMP. It permanently reduces platelet function.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 678.

questions.text: Resistant hypertension occurs when blood pressure is not controlled despite the use of three types of antihypertensive medicines. Which of the following classes of medications must the patient be taking to meet the criteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Diuretics
 

  • Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains high despite the use of 3 different classes of anti-hypertensives, one of which must be a diuretic. Especially Thiazide group of diuretic. 
  • The underlying cause of resistant hypertension is increased production of aldosterone. The drug of choice for resistant hypertension is spironolactone.

Here is an updated table with the treatment strategies for each type of hypertension:

Type Definition Treatment
Resistant Hypertension Blood pressure remains above target despite the use of 3 antihypertensive drugs, including a diuretic, at optimal doses. Optimize medication (adding spironolactone). 
Refractory Hypertension Extremely difficult to control blood pressure despite 5 or more drugs, including a diuretic. Consider renal denervation
Hypertensive Emergency Severe hypertension (>180/120 mmHg) with acute target organ damage (e.g., stroke, heart failure, renal failure). Intravenous antihypertensive agents (e.g., nitroprusside, labetalol, nicardipine) to rapidly lower blood pressure under close monitoring.
Hypertensive Urgency Severe hypertension (>180/120 mmHg) without acute target organ damage. Oral antihypertensive agents (e.g., labetalol, captopril, clonidine) to lower blood pressure gradually over hours to days.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 616.

questions.text: A man arrives at the OPD with a history of falling. He is hypertensive with a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently taking captopril, atenolol, aspirin, and amiodarone. As indicated in the graphic, he offers the following findings. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Amiodarone induced skin lesion   

  • The given image shows a bluish discoloration of skin of face. It is a common side effect associated with long term use of Amiodarone.
  • Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug used in the treatment of atrial fibrillation.
  • The skin deposits result in a photodermatitis and a gray-blue skin discoloration in sun-exposed areas, the malar regions.
Option 1 Lupus pernio is a characteristic sign present in chronic Sarcoidosis. Rashes involved Raised skin lesions not maculopapular rashes.
Option 2 Captopril Toxicity may lead to allergic maculopapular skin rashes, but the malar gray blue skin discoloration described in the image is characteristic of Amiodarone.
Option 4 Silver toxicity also known as Argyria is a condition where deposits of silver build up in your body at toxic levels. This causes your skin and nails to turn bluish gray, but the Clinical scenario given in the above question has nothing to do with silver toxicity.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 244.

questions.text: An individual was receiving metoprolol treatment for hypertension. VERAPAMIL was also given to him. With the aforementioned combo therapy, which of the following is most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Bradycardia with AV block 
 
  • Among the following bradycardia with AV block are likely to happen with the above combination therapy.
  • Verapamil and metoprolol (beta-blocker) show drug interaction and result in precipitation of bradycardia and AV block since both have inhibitory action on AV node and oppose positive inotropic action.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: Which of the following medications should a patient taking rosuvastatin therapy avoid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Clarithromycin

Clarithromycin should be avoided in a patient on rosuvastatin therapy.
  • Inhibition of OATP1B1 by Clarithromycin reduces tissue uptake of rosuvastatin.
  • The overall result is an increase in systemic plasma levels of rosuvastatin, which may result in increased susceptibility to statin-induced myopathy.
  • Efficacy will depend upon the net effect on hepatic levels of rosuvastatin, driven by the lower hepatic uptake via OATP1B1 inhibition.
* All statins, except rosuvastatin are metabolized primarily by CYP3A4.
* Metabolism of Rosuvastatin is mainly done through BCRP and OATP1B1.

Option 2, 3 and 4 Drugs doesn't have any known role in inducing or inhibiting Rosuvastatin metabolism.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 160.

questions.text: Identify the drug that can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic overdose:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Epsilon amino caproic acid

Epsilon amino caproic acid can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic overdose. 

* Mechanism of action- Being a lysine analogue, it combines with the lysin binding site of plasminogen and plasmin. As a result, plasmin is unable to bind to fibrinogen and lyse it. 

* Indication-
  • It is a specific antidote for fibrinolytic agents and has been used in many hyperplasminemic states associated with excessive intravascular fibrinolysis resulting in bleeding.
  • The primary indication of EACA is to counteract the effect of fibrinolytic drugs and bleeding due to their use.
  • In hemophiliacs, it has adjunctive value for controlling bleeding due to tooth extraction, prostatectomy, trauma, etc.
Following are the antidotes that are used in case of fibrinolytic agent overdose
  • Epsilon amino caproic acid
  • Tranexamic acid
Option 1 Ethamsylate reduces capillary bleeding when platelets are adequate; probably corrects abnormalities of platelet adhesion but does not stabilize fibrin (not an antifibrinolytic).

Option 2 Alteplase is a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA) Produced by recombinant DNA technology from human tissue culture, it catalyzes the cleavage of endogenous plasminogen to generate plasmin, and is moderately specific for fibrin bound plasminogen, so that circulating fibrinogen is lowered only by ~ 50%.

Option 3 Recombinant coagulation factor Xa, also called Andexanet alfa, is FDA-approved for reversal of patients treated with rivaroxaban and apixaban with serious bleeding.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 676.

questions.text: Identify the drug that is not indicated in the treatment of NSTEMI:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Streptokinase 

All of the following drugs are indicated in the treatment of NSTEMI except streptokinase.
Following are the drugs indicated for the treat of NSTEMI:
 
  • NSTEMI is treated with beta-blockers and statins that improve circulation and prevent further damage to the heart muscle.
  • At the same time, blood thinners like aspirin or Plavix (clopidogrel) are used to prevent blood clots and the complete blockage of the vessel.
  • Patients of NSTEMI who are managed without PCI/thrombolysis are generally put on a combination of aspirin + clopidogrel or ticagrelor, which is continued for upto one year.
Remember- Thrombolysis is not indicated in NSTEMI since the risk of thrombolysis, particularly bleed outweighs its benefit of thrombolysing the clot since the clot in NSTEMI is small in dimension. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 674.

questions.text: Digoxin was being taken by an AF patient. Aspirin, KCl, Triamterene, and Clarithromycin were the first medications he received. Digoxin's serum concentration increases from 2.5 mg/dl to 3.4 mg/dl. ECG thickening of the T waves is the problem. Which medication among the following is to blame for the rise in digoxin levels in the serum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Clarithromycin
 
  • MDR1 (P-Glycoprotein) is expressed on the brush border membrane of renal epithelia, and its function can be monitored using digoxin (>70% excreted in the urine).
  • MDR1 inhibitors (e.g., quinidine, verapamil, valspodar, spironolactone, clarithromycin, and ritonavir) all markedly reduce renal excretion of digoxin.
  • This means that more of the drug Digoxin is present in the body for a longer period of time, which can increase the risk of Digoxin toxicity.
Option1, 2 and 3 Drugs have no enzyme induction or inhibition action significant to Digoxin Metabolism.

* Symptoms of Digoxin toxicity can include,
- Anorexia, nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain are usually reported first, are due to gastric irritation, mesenteric vasoconstriction and CTZ stimulation.
- Almost every type of arrhythmia can be produced by digoxin, pulsus bigeminies is common; others are nodal and ventricular extrasystoles, ventricular tachycardia and terminally ventricular fibrillation.

Drugs that can cause digoxin toxicity (P glycoprotein/MDR 1 inhibitors) are remembered  as CAVE Q drugs. These include:   

Drugs
C - Clarithromycin, Cyclosporine
A - Amiodarone
V - Verapamil
E - Erythromycin
Q - Quinine/Quinidine

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 91.

questions.text:
Chronic hypertension affects a 35-year-old lady. To receive preconception counselling, she goes to the clinic.
Which anti-hypertensive medication from the list below needs to be stopped before conception?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) ACE inhibitors
 
  • Fetal growth retardation, hypoplasia of organs and fetal death may occur if ACE inhibitors are given during later half of pregnancy.
  • A recent report indicates 2.7-fold higher malformation rate in fetuses exposed to ACE inhibitors in the first trimester.
  • ACE inhibitors must be stopped when the woman conceives.
Option 1,2 and 4 Drugs does not have known Teratogenic Side effects in humans.

* THE FOLLOWING TABLE IS TO SUMMARISE A FEW EXAMPLES OF TERATOGENIC DRUGS AND SUBSTANCES FREQUENLY TESTED IN EXAMS ALONG WITH THE DEFECTS THEY CAUSE: -



* VACTERL: -
  • V = Vertebral abnormalities
  • A= Anal Atresia
  • C = Cardiac defects
  • TE = Tracheal-oesophageal abnormalities, including atresia, stenosis and fistula.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 531.

questions.text: A 68yr old female patient presented with Atrial fibrillation with Mitral stenosis. ECHO does not show any thrombus. Which among the following is the best to prevent stroke ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Warfarin

Anti coagulation is a very important part of the treatment of Atrial Fibrillation in order to prevent stroke.

Novel Oral anticoagulants like Dabigatran can generally be used for anti-coagulation in Atrial Fibrillation except the following: -
 
  • NOAC are contraindicated in patients with Mechanical prosthetic valves
  • NOAC are contraindicated in patients with Atrial Fibrillation in the backdrop of valvular heart disease like Moderate / Severe mitral stenosis
In such cases Warfarin can be used for the purpose of Anticoagulation.

* NOAC are preferred compared to Warfarin in case of stroke prevention in patients with Atrial Fibrillation who are at a high risk of Ischemic Stroke.

* A higher INR range (2.5–3.5) is recommended for patients with mechanical heart valves in the mitral position or for patients with mechanical valves in another position who have concomitant atrial fibrillation or a prior history of stroke.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 717.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not correctly matched with their metabolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Digoxin: p-glycoprotein
 
  • P-glycoprotein is not involved in the metabolism of digoxin it is involved in Efflux of the drug. Metabolism and Elimination of drug, and Toxicity parameter depends on both but as question on Metabolism specifically answer have to be 1.
  • Digoxin has small amount of Hepatic metabolism via Glucuronide and Hydrolysis in liver and then rest mostly in large intestine by bacteria.
  • The cytochrome P450 (CYP) isoform CYP3A4 serves as the major pathway for metabolism of lovastatin, simvastatin and atorvastatin.
  • Carvedilol is extensively metabolized by oxidation by CYP1D6 and CYP2C9.
  • Verapamil is metabolized CYP3A4.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 141.

questions.text: What is the latest oral direct thrombin inhibitor (DTI) for preventing acute stroke?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Dabigatran
  • The most recent oral direct thrombin inhibitor (DTI) for acute stroke prevention is Dabigatran.
  • Dabigatran is used to treat deep vein thrombosis (DVT; a blood clot, usually in the leg) and pulmonary embolism (PE; a blood clot in the lung). Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTIs) are small molecules that inhibit thrombin directly, with no need for a cofactor.
  • DTI action results in specific inhibition of free and fibrin-bound thrombin, thereby preventing:
                            -​Fibrin formation
                         -​Thrombin-mediated activation of FV, FVIII, FXI, and FXIII.
                      -​Thrombin induced platelet aggregation.

Option 1 Ximelagatran has been investigated in several large randomized controlled studies for prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism occurring after major orthopedic surgery, therapy in vein thrombosis, stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation, and acute coronary syndromes. It is a Prodrug of melagatran.
Option 2 Idraparinux is a heparinoid Penta saccharide, antithrombin III-dependent Factor Xa inhibitor
Option 4 warfarin works as an anticoagulant by inhibiting vitamin K epoxide reductase (VKOR) in the liver.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 672.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Rho kinase inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fasudil 
Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitors, such as fasudil, ripasudil, and netarsudil, target the ROCK pathway, influencing smooth muscle contraction, fibrosis, and cellular motility. They are primarily used in treating glaucoma (reducing intraocular pressure) and cerebral vasospasm after subarachnoid hemorrhage. They also show potential for pulmonary hypertension, fibrosis, cancer, and neurological recovery. Side effects include conjunctival hyperemia and hypotension.
  • Fasudil is an inhibitor of smooth muscle Rho kinase and reduces coronary vasospasm in experimental animals. In clinical trials in patients with CAD, it has improved performance in stress tests. It is investigational in angina.
  • Fasudil appears to reduce pulmonary artery pressure in PAH. Surgical treatment for advanced disease includes creation of a right atrial to left atrial shunt and lung transplantation.

Option 2 Ranolazine is a novel antianginal drug primarily acts by inhibiting a late Na+ current (late INa) in the myocardium which indirectly facilitates Ca2+ entry through Na+/Ca2+ exchanger.
Option 3 Amiloride block ENaCs in the luminal membrane of principal cells in late distal tubules and collecting ducts by binding to a site in the channel pore.
Option 4 Nicorandil is a dual mechanism antianginal drug activates ATP sensitive K+ channels (KATP) in smooth muscle membrane thereby hyperpolarizing and relaxing it.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 313.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions makes the usage of beta blockers safe?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) HOCM 
 
  • In HOCM the sub aortic region is hypertrophied. Forceful contraction of this region under sympathetic stimulation increases outflow resistance which has incapacitating hemodynamic consequence.
  • Beta blockers improve cardiac output in these patients during exercise by reducing left ventricular outflow obstruction, though they have little effect at rest.
 Option 1, 2 and 3 are all Contraindications for using Beta blockers.

* USES OF BETA BLOCKERS:-
 
  • Aortic dissection.
  • Arrhythmias (SVT, ventricular rate control for atrial fibrillation, Atrial Flutter)
  • Coronary artery disease.
  • Chronic heart failure
  • Hypertension
  • Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM)
  • Migraines 
  • Portal hypertension
  • Essential tremor
  • Glaucoma
  • Hyperthyroidism 

* CONTRAINDICATIONS OF BETA BLOCKERS:-
 
  • Impotence
  • COPD
  • Asthma
  • Bradycardia , AV Block
  • Vasospastic Angina
  • Acute Heart Failure

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page No 214,215.

choices.text: Acts as diuretic by preventing NaCl reabsorption in loop of Henle

questions.text: Hypertension is treated with aliskiren. Aliskiren reduces blood pressure because it-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Prevents formation of Angiotensin-1

*ALISKIREN:-
Trials so far have shown that aliskiren reduces hypertensive left ventricular hypertrophy and benefits CHF patients, but its value compared to ACE inhibitors/ARBs as monotherapy and as additional drug remains to be established on the basis of outcome data. Aliskiren reduces albuminuria and has reno protective effect in hypertension and diabetes mellitus.
 
  • It is an example of Direct Renin inhibitor
  • MECHANISM OF ACTION – It blocks the conversion of Angiotensinogen to Angiotensin 1 and the effector chain of RAS is interrupted. While the concentration of renin in plasma is increased by feedback, the plasma renin activity (PRA) is decreased.
  • USE – At present, aliskiren is recommended as an alternative antihypertensive drug (for those who do not respond or do not tolerate 1st line drugs) and in combination with ACE inhibitor/ARB to achieve more complete RAS blockade and greater BP lowering/ cardio protection
  • ADEVERSE EFFECTS – Hyperkalemia, Hypotension, Angioedema
  • CONTRAINDICATIONS – Pregnancy; In patients taking ACE inhibitors and ARBs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 538.

questions.text: The following antiarrhythmic drug and its respective use is correct:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Adenosine in supraventricular tachycardia

Adenosine and Verapamil both can be used in case of SVT but there is following instances Adenosine has advantage over Verapamil-
  • Efficacy equivalent to or better than verapamil.
  • Action lasts < 1 min; adverse effects (even cardiac arrest, if it occurs) are transient.
  • No hemodynamic deterioration. It can be given to patients with hypotension, CHF or those receiving β blockers. Verapamil is contraindicated in these situations.
  • Safe in wide QRS tachycardia (verapamil is unsafe).
  • May be effective in patients not responding to verapamil.
However, adenosine produces transient dyspnea, chest pain, fall in BP and flushing in 30–60% patients; ventricular standstill for few sec or VF occurs in some patients, but resolves quickly. Bronchospasm may be precipitated in asthmatics; verapamil is the drug of choice for such patients.

So, Between Option 2 and Option 4 Adenosine should be chosen as the answer in this question.
Option 1 and 3 Regarding Lidocaine and Quinidine is Untrue.



TRICK TO REMEMBER COMMON ARRYTHMIA AND THEIR DRUGS WHICH ARE FREQUENTLY ASKED:-
 
  • SUPRAVENTRICULAR – Adenosine, Verapamil, Diltiazem, Digoxin
  • VENTRICULAR –Lidocaine, Mexiletine
  • BOTH – Amiodarone, class 1a,1c, Beta blockers

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 581.

questions.text: ACE inhibitors are not the primary pharmacological treatment for which of these:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Myocardial infarction 

* ACE INHIBITORS :-
 
  • EXAMPLES :- CAPTOPRIL, ENALAPRIL, LISINOPRIL, RAMIPRIL
  • MECHANISM OF ACTION :-
    • Inhibits Angiotensin converting enzyme thereby decreasing AT 2 levels which thus decreases the GFR by preventing the constriction of efferent arterioles.
    • Inhibition of Angiotensin Converting Enzyme prevents inactivation of Bradykinin
  • USE :-
    • Hypertension- Prevents heart remodelling in chronic hypertension
    • Heart Failure
    • Proteinuria
    • Diabetic Nephropathy
  • ADVERSE EFFECTS :-
    • Cough & Angioedema (due to increase in levels of bradykinin)
    • Teratogen
    • Increase in level of Creatinine
    • Hyperkalemia
    • Hypertension
  • CONTRAINDICATIONS :- Bilateral Renal Artery Stenosis

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 534.

questions.text: Select the one that acts for the longest duration-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Rosuvastatin

Rosuvastatin are not extensively metabolized by CYP3A4, is excreted unchanged in the urine, greater LDL-CH reduction can be obtained in severe hypercholesterolemia partly due to its longer persistence in the plasma.
  • Rosuvastatin is a statin medication used to lower cholesterol levels.
  • It has a long half-life, which means it stays in the body for a longer duration compared to other statins.
  • The half-life of rosuvastatin is approximately 19 hours, allowing for sustained cholesterol-lowering effects over an extended period.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 684, 685.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a side effect of nitrates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) GI disturbance
 
  • Nitrates are a class of medications commonly used for the treatment of angina (chest pain) and certain cardiovascular conditions.
  • Nitrates primarily work by dilating blood vessels, leading to improved blood flow and reduced cardiac workload.
  • While nitrates can cause several side effects, including vasodilation-related effects, GI disturbance is not typically associated with their use.
Option 1, 2 and 4 are correct regarding Side effects of Nitrate 
  • Nitrates can cause a drop in blood pressure, especially when changing positions from lying down to standing, leading to orthostatic hypotension.
  • Nitrates can cause an increase in heart rate, due to reduced BP causing Bainbridge reflex resulting in tachycardia.
  • Tachyphylaxis refers to a reduced response to a drug over time with repeated administration. Nitrates are known to develop tolerance, and their effectiveness can decrease with prolonged use, requiring dose adjustments or drug holidays.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 587.

questions.text: Which of the following best sums up the way that Levosimendan works?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Calcium Sensitizer
 
  • This inotropic drug acts by sensitizing myocardial troponin C to Ca2+, as well as by inhibiting PDE3. It also opens ATP-sensitive K+ channels in vascular smooth muscle cells to cause vasodilatation. Thus, it is another ‘inodilator’, Haemodynamic improvement in heart failure is both due to increase in cardiac contractility as well as reduction in preload and afterload.
  • Levosimendan infused i.v. is primarily indicated for short-term treatment of acutely decompensated severe chronic heart failure. Though it relieved symptoms of heart failure, but survival rate was not improved.
  • The most common side effect is hypotension which may last for few days due to its active metabolite that has long t½.
  • Another Example is Pimobendan

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 568.

questions.text: For the treatment of dyslipidemia, cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP) inhibitor is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Torcetrapib

Torcetrapib increase HDL cholesterol by inhibiting CETP (cholesterol ester triglyceride transport protein).

* Mechanism of action:
  • Cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP) transfers cholesteryl esters from mature, large diameter HDL particles to triglyceride rich lipoproteins that ultimately deliver the esters to liver whence both cholesterol and bile acids can be eliminated into the intestine.
  • Inhibition of CETP leads to accumulation of mature HDL particles and diminution of the transport of cholesteryl esters to liver. The accumulation of large HDL particles does not have the cardioprotective effect anticipated on the basis of epidemiologic studies.
  • Some reduction of LDL-C can be achieved and cholesterol efflux capacity enhanced. 

* Examples:
  • Torcetrapib
  • Anacetrapib 
* Adverse Effects: 
Adverse effects may have included hypertension, other non-mechanism related adverse vascular effects, and the putative decrease in ABCA1-mediated cholesterol efflux reflecting diminished lipid exchange-lipolysis of HDL particles.

The development of torcetrapib has been halted as it showed increased mortality in the ILLUMINATE trial.

Trick:- 
TorCETraPib- CETP inhibitor

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 638.

questions.text: All of the following are first-line medications for the therapy of hypertension in patients with no additional comorbidities with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Beta-blocker
 
  • Mainly due to inferior efficacy in primary prevention of MI and stroke, as well as other drawbacks like there are several contraindications to β blockers, including cardiac, pulmonary and peripheral vascular disease.
  • The nonselective β blockers have an unfavorable effect on lipid profile that's why b blockers are no longer considered first line antihypertensive drugs for monotherapy, except in patients with other compelling indications (JNC 8, NICE guidelines 2011) - Stable heart failure, post-myocardial infarction, High coronary artery disease risk etc.

Option 1, 3 and 4 are all First-line medications for the therapy of hypertension in patients with no additional comorbidities typically include ACE inhibitors, calcium channel blockers, and diuretics.
  • These medications are commonly recommended due to their efficacy, safety profiles, and ability to lower blood pressure effectively.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 610.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is least effective in lowering blood pressure when used with Thiazide diuretics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Calcium channel blockers 
 
  • Thiazide diuretics are a class of drugs that are commonly used to treat hypertension.
  • They work by increasing the excretion of sodium and water in the urine, which leads to a decrease in blood volume and a subsequent decrease in blood pressure.
  • Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are another class of drugs that are often used to treat hypertension, and they work by blocking the entry of calcium into smooth muscle cells, which causes relaxation of the blood vessels and a subsequent decrease in blood pressure.
  • When used together, thiazide diuretics and CCBs have a synergistic effect on blood pressure reduction. However, the other options - ACE inhibitors, ARBs, and beta-blockers - are also commonly used in the treatment of hypertension and can be used in combination with thiazide diuretics to reduce comorbidities.
  • Therefore, the correct answer to this question is option 4 - Calcium channel blockers. This is because calcium channel blockers in combination with thiazide diuretics can cause hypokalemia, hence the combination is not preferred.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 615.
