choices.text: May be used as first line agent in chronic angina
Works by decreasing the late sodium current in cardiac cells

questions.text: Which of the statements is not true about Ranolazine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) May be used as first line agent in chronic angina

Ranolazine is FDA and EMA approved as a second-line agent for the treatment of chronic angina. The drug may be used with a variety of other agents, including β blockers, Ca2+ channel blockers, ACEIs, ARBs, and therapeutic agents for lowering lipids and reducing platelet aggregation.

Option 1, 3 and 4 are true statements -
  • Ranolazine is an antianginal medication that works by decreasing the late sodium current in cardiac cells, which can lead to a reduction in myocardial ischemia. 
  • Ranolazine is a piperazine derivative and is used as an antianginal medication. It is used when other treatments are not effective or not tolerated.
  • Ranolazine may improve glycemic control in patients with diabetes. It does not directly affect blood glucose levels, but it may improve insulin sensitivity and glucose uptake in peripheral tissues.
  • It is important to note that although hypotension is not an established adverse effect of ranolazine, it may cause other adverse effects such as dizziness, headache, constipation, and nausea. 

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page No 500.

questions.text: Which of the following antihypertensive drugs should not be used in a patient on Lithium in order to prevent Lithium Toxicity
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Diuretics
 
  • Thiazide diuretics are known to decrease the renal clearance of Lithium, which can lead to an increase in Lithium levels in the blood.
  • This effect is due to the fact that Thiazides reduce the excretion of Sodium in the kidneys, leading to increased Sodium reabsorption at PCT and this leads to decreased Lithium secretion. This can result in Lithium toxicity.
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 477.

questions.text: Which medication has been associated with a rise in cardiac mortality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Rofecoxib
 
  • Rofecoxib has been associated with a rise in cardiac mortality.
  • Rofecoxib is a NSAID that was used for the treatment of pain and inflammation.
  • However, rofecoxib was withdrawn from the market due to safety concerns, including an increased risk of heart attacks and strokes.
  • Several studies found an elevated risk of cardiovascular events, including cardiac mortality, among patients taking rofecoxib.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 222.

questions.text: Hypolipidemic drug, which acts by inhibiting PCSK-9:
questions.solution:
Option A- Rosuvastatin acts by inhibiting HMG CoA reductase, which is the rate limiting enzyme of cholesterol synthesis. 

Option B- Clofibrate stimulates PPAR-alpha which increases fatty acid oxidation and LPL synthesis. This inturn reduces triglycerides, LDL and HDL. 

Option C- Evolocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor. 

Option D- Ezetemibe inhibits cholesterol absorption in the small intestine. 



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 613-615.

questions.text: A young patient consumed 8 tablets of 0.25 mg of Digoxin and developed features of digoxin toxicity. His heart rate was 55 beats/minute and ECG showed third degree AV block. Such a patient is best managed by:
questions.solution:
Administration of digiband which is an antibody against digoxin will be the most appropriate answer. 

A hemodyanamically unstable patient with 3rd degree heart block and bradycardia is presentation of digoxin toxicity. 
Aspect Details
What is Digibind? A digoxin-specific antibody used to treat digoxin toxicity.
Indications - Severe digoxin toxicity- Life-threatening arrhythmias- Significant overdose- Hyperkalemia (high potassium)
Mechanism of Action Binds to free digoxin in the bloodstream, forming a complex that is excreted in urine, neutralizing its effects.
Administration Intravenous (IV), dose based on digoxin levels and toxicity severity.
Side Effects - Rare allergic reactions (rash, anaphylaxis)- Hypokalemia (low potassium)
Monitoring Monitor ECG, serum potassium, and digoxin levels.
Duration Half-life: 20-30 hours; may need re-administration for severe cases.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 556, 558, 560, 561.

questions.text: A patient with erectile dysfunction was prescribed sildenafil. What mediator is involved in the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
• The mechanism of action of sildenafil is that it inhibits the enzyme phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5), which is responsible for the degradation of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) in the corpus cavernosum of the penis.
 
  • By inhibiting PDE5, sildenafil increases the concentration of cGMP, which leads to smooth muscle relaxation, vasodilation, and increased blood flow to the penis.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 494, 840-842.

questions.text:
Which of the following act on agonist on beta-2 receptor? 
(i) Dipivefrine 
(ii) Fenoldopam 
(iii) Mirabegron 
(iv) Dopexamine
questions.solution:
1. Dipivefrine:

    • Prodrug of epinephrine. Epinephrine activates beta-2 receptors, so dipivefrine indirectly acts as a beta-2 agonist.

  2. Fenoldopam:

    • Selective dopamine D1 receptor agonist with no significant beta-2 receptor activity. It does not act on beta-2 receptors.

  3. Mirabegron:

    • Selective beta-3 adrenergic receptor agonist used for overactive bladder. It does not significantly affect beta-2 receptors.

  4. Dopexamine:

    • Dopamine agonist with beta-2 receptor agonist activity. It stimulates beta-2 receptors and is used to enhance cardiac output.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 259, 261, 262.

questions.text: Find out right match regarding drug and its side effect?
questions.solution:
The correct match regarding the drug and its side effect is: Verapamil - Constipation

  • Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker used to treat Hypertension. One of the common side effects of verapamil is constipation. It can slow down the movement/peristalsis of the intestines(due to calcium channel blockage), leading to difficulty in passing stools.

The other options do not have the correct drug-side effect match:

  1. Hydralazine is primarily used for hypertension and does not typically cause heart failure.
  2. Atenolol is a beta-blocker commonly used for hypertension and other cardiovascular conditions, but it does not cause hemolytic anemia.
  3. Aliskiren is a renin inhibitor used for hypertension, and it does not typically cause hypokalemia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 530,580 .

questions.text: Maximum dose of labetalol that can be given to a pregnant woman in 24 hours?
questions.solution:
A maximum iv dose of 2400 mg labetalol (DOC for hypertension in pregnancy) can be given to a pregnant woman in a time span of 24 hours.
 

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 256-267 .

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs inhibits the area marked with 1 and 2 both?

1. Sacubitril
2. Losartan
3. Nesiritide
4. Omapatrilat
questions.solution:
• The marked arrows indicate a drug that inhibits both ACE and NEP. ACE here refers to Angiotensin Converting Enzyme, and NEP here refers to a neutral endopeptidase called Neprilysin.
  • The drug that inhibits both enzymes is Omapatrilat.
  • Sacubitril is an isolated neprilysin inhibitor
  • Losartan is ARB(Angiotensin receptor blocker)
  • Nesiritide is synthetic natriuretic peptide(BNP)
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 536.

questions.text: A patient had ventricular tachycardia 4 months back. He was given treatment for the same. The patient was on the prescribed drug. The patient now complains of weight gain, dyspnea, dry cough and fatigue. Which of the following drugs is the likely culprit?
questions.solution:
The weight gain and fatigue may indicate thyroid dysfunction leading to hypothyroidism, while the dyspnea and dry cough may occur in the setting of pulmonary fibrosis.
This symptom complex fits the adverse effect profile of amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic.

* Extra Edge: 

  • Fall in BP, bradycardia and myocardial depression occurs on i.v. injection and after drug cumulation.
  • Nausea, gastrointestinal upset may attend oral medication, especially during the loading phase.
  • Photosensitization and sun burn like skin pigmentation occurs in about 10% patients.
  • Corneal microdeposits (Corneal verticillata) are common with long- term use, may cause headlight dazzle, but are reversible on discontinuation.
  • Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis is the most serious toxicity of prolonged use, but is infrequent if daily dose is kept below 200 mg.
  • Peripheral neuropathy generally manifests as weakness of shoulder and pelvic muscles. Liver damage is rare.
  • Amiodarone interferes with thyroid function in many ways including inhibition of peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and interaction with thyroid hormone receptor. It is a source of iodine as well. Goiter, hypothyroidism and rarely hyperthyroidism may develop on chronic use.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 576.

choices.text: Candesartan clearance dose should be reduced in hepatic insufficiency but not by renal disease.
Losartan is a competitive antagonist of TXA2 and attenuates platelet aggregation.
Telmisartan dose should be reduced in renal insufficiency but not in hepatic failure.

questions.text: A diabetic patient with hypertension was started on ARB. Which of the following is the true statement?
questions.solution:
Losartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB).
In addition to its antihypertensive effects, losartan also has antiplatelet activity and can attenuate platelet aggregation by competitively antagonizing thromboxane A2 (TXA2) at its receptor site.
  • Option 1 is incorrect because candesartan clearance is primarily dependent on renal function, and dose adjustment may be necessary in patients with renal impairment, but not in those with hepatic insufficiency.
  • Option 3 is also incorrect because telmisartan is primarily metabolized by the liver and dose adjustment may be necessary in patients with hepatic impairment, but not in those with renal failure.
  • Option 4 Irbesartan doesn't require dose adjustment in renal failure. 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 535.

questions.text: 45y on fluoxetine was started on pain control for neuropathic pain. He developed syncope after 2 weeks . ECG - QT interval of 477. Which of the following is causative drug?
questions.solution:
The most likely drug implicated in this case is Methadone as it causes QT prolongation on co administration with other QT prolonging drugs like Fluoxetine.
Other drugs causing QT prolongation- Levofloxacin, Ciprofloxacin, Gatifloxacin, Clarithromycin, Ketoconazole.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 500, 502.

questions.text: 55y old male presents to ER with Dizziness and Palpitations. ECG showed Atrial Fibrillation. Which of the following drugs cannot be used in this condition?
questions.solution:
Lignocaine is a class IB anti arrhythmic agent. It blocks Sodium channels in closed/inactivated state. It is not used in Atrial arrhythmias because the atrial action potential is of very short duration. It is used in Ventricular arrhythmias.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page No 392.

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is least likely to be associated with amiodarone use?
questions.solution:
Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic with multiple systemic side effects, but gynecomastia is not commonly associated.

Common adverse effects of amiodarone:

  • Thyroid dysfunction:

    • Hypothyroidism (more common in iodine-sufficient areas)

    • Hyperthyroidism (more common in iodine-deficient areas)

  • Pulmonary toxicity: Pulmonary fibrosis, interstitial pneumonitis

  • Hepatic toxicity: Elevated liver enzymes

  • Ocular deposits: Corneal microdeposits

  • Skin: Photosensitivity, blue-gray discoloration

Gynecomastia, on the other hand, is typically associated with drugs like spironolactone, cimetidine, and ketoconazole, not amiodarone.

Hence, gynecomastia is the least likely adverse effect of amiodarone.

questions.text: What ECG change is associated with the use of the anti-tubercular drug Bedaquiline?
questions.solution:
Bedaquiline is known to be associated with a prolonged QT interval. It is a diarylquinoline that specifically targets the subunit c of the ATP synthase in M. tuberculosis, inhibiting its proton pump activity and disrupting the bacillary energy metabolism. Due to its amphiphilicity, bedaquiline tends to accumulate in tissues. Resistance can develop through mutations in efflux pumps and their regulators, which may also lead to cross-resistance with clofazimine.

The metabolism of bedaquiline primarily involves the enzyme CYP3A4. Given the significant risk of QT prolongation, the FDA has issued a black box warning, restricting its use in patients with cardiac conduction abnormalities.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for arthritis in acute rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
Acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is an autoimmune sequela of group A streptococcal infection, characterized by carditis, arthritis, chorea, erythema marginatum, and subcutaneous nodules.

Key points:

  • Arthritis in ARF:

    • Usually polyarthritis of large joints (knees, ankles, elbows, wrists)

    • Migratory pattern

  • Drug of choice:

    • Aspirin (NSAID) for anti-inflammatory effect, rapid relief of joint pain and swelling.

    • Typical dose: high-dose aspirin during acute phase, then tapered.

  • Other options:

    • Digoxin: Cardiac glycoside, for heart failure

    • Amiodarone: Antiarrhythmic

    • Furosemide: Loop diuretic, used in heart failure, not arthritis

questions.text: A patient presents to the ER with complaints of headache, seizures and blurred vision. His BP was recorded as 220/120 mmHg. Which of the following will be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with severe hypertension (BP 220/120 mmHg) along with neurological symptoms (headache, seizures, blurred vision) — this indicates a hypertensive emergency with hypertensive encephalopathy.

In such cases, immediate controlled BP reduction using intravenous antihypertensives is required.

  • IV labetalol is the drug of choice as it provides combined α- and β-blockade, allowing a controlled and predictable BP reduction without causing reflex tachycardia.

Other options:

  • Oral nifedipine: Contraindicated — causes rapid, uncontrolled BP fall → risk of ischemia/stroke.

  • IV hydralazine: Used in pregnancy-related hypertensive emergencies (e.g., eclampsia), not preferred otherwise.

  • Oral methyldopa: Used for chronic hypertension in pregnancy, not for emergencies.

Hence, IV labetalol is the next step in management.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs given below is a PCSK -9 Inhibitor?
questions.solution:
• PCSK- 9 causes Lysosomal degradation of LDL receptors hence reducing LDL uptake.
  • PCSK-9 inhibitors prevents this degradation hence increasing LDL uptake. Eg- Alirocumab and Evolocumab.
  • Bempedoic acid- Prevents de novo cholesterol Synthesis
  • Lomitapide -Inhibits microsomal Triglyceride Transfer protein
  • Ezetimibe-Inhibts Luminal cholesterol uptake
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page No 740.

questions.text: Inhaled nitric oxide is used for?
questions.solution:
• Inhaled NO is used in Persistent Pulmonary HTN of new born.
  • It selectively dilates the Pulmonary Vasculature, hence used in conditons with increased Pulmonary vasculature resistance.
  • Inhaled NO is administered at low concentrations as high concentrations can cause Methhemoglobinemia and can even cause death
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page No 268,481,485.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reduces mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)?
questions.solution:
Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction (HFrEF), certain drug classes reduce mortality.
These include:

Option-wise analysis:

1. Furosemide → Loop diuretic; provides symptomatic relief, but does not reduce mortality.
2. Torsemide → Also a loop diuretic; longer acting than furosemide but no proven mortality benefit.
3. Prazosin → Alpha-blocker; not recommended in HFrEF as it may worsen outcomes.
4. Metoprolol → A selective β1-blocker (succinate form), proven to reduce mortality in HFrEF (as shown in the MERIT-HF trial).


Pathophysiology of HFrEF:

In HFrEF, the heart cannot pump blood effectively due to weakened ventricular contraction. This activates neurohormonal systems (like sympathetic nervous system and RAAS), which initially help but eventually worsen heart failure by:

  • Increasing heart rate

  • Causing vasoconstriction

  • Promoting myocardial remodeling and fibrosis
    → All of which increase mortality.

    Role of Metoprolol:

    Metoprolol (succinate) is a β1-selective blocker that:

  • ↓ Heart rate → allows more time for ventricular filling

  • ↓ Myocardial oxygen demand

  • Result: Improved survival and reduced hospitalization.

  • Inhibits harmful effects of chronic sympathetic stimulation

  • Prevents arrhythmias

  • Slows ventricular remodeling

choices.text: Increase in pulse pressure is produced by intravenous administration of isoprenaline
A patient pretreated with phentolamine develops severe hypotension on administration of adrenaline
High dose of acetylcholine after pretreatment with atropine produces increase in blood pressure and heart rate
Repeated administration of ephedrine decreases its effect on blood pressure

questions.text: The most appropriate description of vasomotor reversal of Dale is
questions.solution:
A patient pretreated with phentolamine who develops severe hypotension after the administration of adrenaline exemplifies the vasomotor reversal of Dale.

Vasomotor reversal of Dale occurs due to the blockade of α receptors, followed by stimulation of β2 receptors.

Normally, a high dose of adrenaline leads to an α-mediated increase in blood pressure followed by a β2-mediated decrease.

In vasomotor reversal of Dale, after administering an α-blocker like phentolamine, the α-mediated vasoconstriction is inhibited, and only the β2-mediated vasodilation occurs, causing a fall in blood pressure.

choices.text: Blocks both alphal and beta adrenergic receptors
Primarily acts as venodilator with little effect on arterioles
Directly acts as arterial vasodilator resulting in indirect effect tachycardia
Decreases peripheral vascular resistance by directly acting as relaxant vascular smooth muscles

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct regarding the mechanism of action of labetalol?
questions.solution:
Option A correctly describes the mechanism of action of labetalol.

Labetalol is a competitive antagonist at both alpha-1 and beta-adrenergic receptors. The alpha-1 receptor blockade leads to relaxation of arterial smooth muscle, resulting in vasodilation, which is more pronounced when the patient is upright. The beta-1 blockade further lowers blood pressure by inhibiting the reflex sympathetic stimulation of the heart.

Labetalol is available in oral form for treating chronic hypertension and as an intravenous formulation for use in hypertensive emergencies, including hypertensive crises during pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice in a middle aged woman with hypertriglyceridemia with TGL>600mg/dl, despite lifestyle modifications and statins?
questions.solution:
Gemfibrozil belongs to the fibrate group of drugs that bind to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARa), which stimulate fatty acid oxidation, reduce the expression of apo C-Ill (inhibitor of lipolysis), and thereby reduce triglyceride levels.
Gemfibrozil is a first-line drug for patients with markedly raised triglyceride levels. Episodes of acute pancreatitis are prevented in patients with chylomicronaemia and severe hypertriglyceridemia. It is most effective in type Ill hyperlipoproteinemia.Ref- KD tripathi 8th edition Page 683,686

questions.text: Which of the following medications can be safely used for a pregnant lady diagnosed with hypertension?
questions.solution:
Hypertension during pregnancy requires carefully selected medications to avoid harm to the fetus while effectively controlling blood pressure in the mother.


Alpha methyldopa:

  • It is a centrally acting α2-adrenergic agonist.

  • Safely used during all trimesters of pregnancy.

  • Extensive safety data available; not associated with teratogenicity.

  • Preferred for chronic hypertension in pregnancy.

    Why others are incorrect:

  • Losartan (an ARB):

    • Contraindicated in pregnancy—especially in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters.

    • Associated with fetal renal agenesis, oligohydramnios, skull hypoplasia, and even fetal death.

  • Captopril (an ACE inhibitor):

    • Contraindicated, especially in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters.

    • Causes teratogenic effects: fetal renal failure, oligohydramnios, hypocalvaria, and fetal growth restriction.

  • Nitroprusside:

    • Used only in emergencies, and with extreme caution.

    • Risk of cyanide toxicity to the fetus.

    • Not a first-line or routine agent for pregnancy-related hypertension.


Reference:Goodman and gillmans The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics 13th edition page no 514-518

questions.text: What medication is used to prevent acute mountain sickness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Acetazolamide

Acetazolamide can provide symptomatic relief in patients with high-altitude illness or mountain sickness in which there is Weakness, dizziness, insomnia, headache, and nausea in mountain travelers who rapidly ascend above 3000 meters.
 
  • Acetazolamide can improve breathing and lessen the effects of mountain sickness by reducing CSF production and by lowering the pH of the CSF and brain.
  • Furthermore helpful in the management of sleep apnea is this modest metabolic central and CSF acidosis.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 633.

choices.text: Thick ascending limb of loop of Henle

questions.text: What part of the body does the loop diuretic furosemide act on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Thick ascending limb of loop of Henle
 
  • Furosemide acts on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle and inhibits Na+K+Cl- symporters thus increasing the Renal blood flow.
  • The major site of action is the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle (TAL), therefore, called loop diuretics.
  • Furosemide inhibits Na+- K+-2Cl¯ cotransport. A minor component of action on PT has also been demonstrated. It is secreted in PT by organic anion transport and reaches TAL where it acts from luminal side of the membrane.
  • The corticomedullary osmotic gradient is abolished and positive as well as negative free water clearance is blocked. K+ excretion is increased mainly due to high Na+ load reaching DT.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 606.

questions.text: Which part of the nephron is affected by Vasopressin antagonist?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Medullary collecting duct
 
  • Vasopressin antagonists act on Medullary collecting duct of nephron.
  • By inhibiting vasopressin receptors, they decrease binding of vasopressin to its target site thereby decreasing adenylyl cyclase activity and reduced intracellular cAMP. Decreased cAMP prevents the fusion of aquaporin 2 containing vesicles with plasma membrane, leading to increased urinary water excretion and decrease in urine osmolality.
  • Examples are- Conivaptan (acts on V1 and V2 receptors and given intravenously) and tolvaptan (V2 selective given orally)

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 644.

questions.text: In renal failure, which of the following thiazide diuretics is used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Metolazone
 
  • All Na+-Cl symport inhibitors are referred to by this term, which was given to them because the original inhibitors of this symport were benzothiadiazide derivatives.
  • Used to treat edema brought on by cardiac diseases (CHF), liver disease (hepatic cirrhosis), and kidney disease (nephrotic syndrome, chronic renal failure, and acute glomerulonephritis). 
  • When the GFR is less than 30–40 mL/min, metolazone and indapamide are beneficial.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 630.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with hepatic cirrhosis is admitted after presenting with severe ascites. Which of the following diuretics is best for mobilizing the edema fluid
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Eplerenone
 
  • In hepatic cirrhosis aldosterone is raised, therefore the doc is aldosterone antagonists like Spironolactone and Eplerenone. 
  • However, in severe cases furosemide is used in combination with aldosterone antagonists.
  • But according to the question the best diuretic best for mobilizing edema fluid among the given options remain, Eplerenone.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 635.

The correct option is 3.

questions.text: In middle aged diabetic patient with CKD-stage 5, which of the following drugs can be safely given?
questions.solution:
• Linagliptin can be safely given in this patient without altering the dose.
 
  • Because it is eliminated by hepatobiliary route therefore no dose adjustment is needed in case of renal failure.

choices.text: Inhibits the Na-Cl pump in late distal convoluted tubule
Inhibits the Na-Cl in early distal convoluted tubule
Inhibits the Na-K-2Cl pump in the descending limb of loop of henle
Inhibits the Na-K-2Cl pump in the ascending limb of loop of henle

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of thiazides in DCT?
questions.solution:
hiazide diuretics act primarily on the early distal convoluted tubule (DCT) of the nephron.

Mechanism:

  • Inhibit the Na⁺-Cl⁻ symporter, reducing sodium and chloride reabsorption.

  • Leads to mild diuresis and potassium excretion.

  • Additional effect: Increases calcium reabsorption, which can help prevent calcium kidney stones.

Comparison with other options:

  • Late DCT: Target of potassium-sparing diuretics

  • Descending loop: Impermeable to Na⁺, mainly water reabsorption

  • Ascending loop of Henle: Target of loop diuretics (Na⁺-K⁺-2Cl⁻ symporter)

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypertensive male patient was prescribed hydrochlorothiazide and he developed fatigue and hypokalemia. Which of the following medications could be introduced instead of thiazide diuretics to prevent potassium depletion in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient on hydrochlorothiazide developed hypokalemia, a common side effect of thiazide diuretics.

Key points:

  • Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that acts on the late distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct by inhibiting epithelial sodium channels (ENaC).

  • This prevents sodium reabsorption while reducing potassium excretion, helping prevent hypokalemia.

  • Other options:

    • Furosemide: Loop diuretic, also causes potassium loss

    • Acetazolamide: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, mild diuretic, can cause metabolic acidosis

    • Adenosine: Not a diuretic; acts on kidney for vasoconstriction of afferent arteriole

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of action of Thiazide diuretics?
questions.solution:
• Thiazide diuretics act on Sodium Chloride symporter on distal convoluted tubule.
  • Below is the image given below with detailed site of action of various diuretics




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page No 628-637.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs increases uric acid in urine?
questions.solution:
Probenecid

  • Class: Uricosuric drug.

  • Mechanism: Inhibits renal tubular reabsorption of uric acid at the proximal tubule.

  • Effect: Increases urinary excretion of uric acid, thereby lowering serum uric acid levels.

  • Clinical use:

    • Chronic gout (not in acute attacks).

    • Used to prolong the action of penicillin (by decreasing its renal clearance).

  • Adverse effects: Risk of uric acid stones, GI upset, rashes.

    Incorrect Options 

  • Allopurinol → Xanthine oxidase inhibitor; decreases uric acid production, does not increase urinary uric acid.

  • Febuxostat → Selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor; lowers uric acid synthesis, no increase in urinary uric acid.

  • Colchicine → Microtubule polymerization inhibitor; reduces inflammation in acute gout, has no effect on uric acid levels or excretion.

questions.text: A patient with a history of hypertension is given the drug X. Identify the drug X?
questions.solution:
• Drug X is identified as a direct renin inhibitor, with aliskiren being a specific example of this type of medication.
  • Aliskiren is a nonapeptide that selectively binds to the catalytic site of renin, competitively preventing angiotensinogen from accessing this site. This inhibition results in the reduction of angiotensin I production.
  • Aliskiren is recommended as an alternative antihypertensive option for patients who either do not respond to or cannot tolerate first-line antihypertensive medications. 
Other options
Option 1: Losartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB).
Option 2: Spironolactone is an aldosterone antagonist that blocks mineralocorticoid receptors
Option 4: Captopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, which prevents the formation of angiotensin II.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was prescribed a diuretic by a doctor for the management of hypertension. Which of the following diuretic acts on the site 'A' marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
Site A in the provided image represents the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), where Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic, exerts its effects.

Thiazides act by inhibiting the Na+/Cl- symporter in the DCT, resulting in increased excretion of sodium and chloride. They are the preferred diuretics for treating uncomplicated hypertension and are also used to manage edema linked to conditions such as congestive heart failure, hepatic cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome, chronic renal failure, and acute glomerulonephritis.

The benefits of thiazides as antihypertensive agents include:

They can be administered as a once-daily dose and have a flat dose-response curve.
There is a reduced incidence of postural hypotension and a relative absence of central nervous system side effects.
They do not lead to tolerance.
There is no fluid retention.
They lower the risk of osteoporotic fractures due to their hypocalciuric effect.
They are cost-effective.
However, the potential adverse effects include extracellular volume depletion, hypotension, hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis, hypomagnesemia, hypercalcemia, and hyperuricemia.

questions.text: A patient presents with urinary symptoms due to benign prostatic hyperplasia. Which of the following is used to manage the urinary symptoms in the initial stage of this condition?
questions.solution:
• Tamsulosin is an α1-adrenergic receptor antagonist that relaxes the smooth muscles of the bladder neck and prostate, improving urinary flow in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

  • It is often used in the initial stage to relieve urinary symptoms such as hesitancy, weak stream, and incomplete emptying.

  • Symptom relief is usually rapid, within days to weeks.

Other options:

  • Atropine: Anticholinergic; may worsen urinary retention in BPH.

  • Finasteride: 5α-reductase inhibitor; reduces prostate size over months, used for long-term management, not initial symptom relief.

  • Danazol: Androgenic steroid; not used in BPH.


Reference
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 27th Edition - Page no. 1459, 1463-1464

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can cause gynecomastia?
questions.solution:
Gynecomastia refers to the benign enlargement of male breast tissue due to an imbalance between estrogens and androgens. Certain drugs can disrupt this balance, leading to gynecomastia.

Spironolactone can cause gynecomastia because it has anti-androgenic properties. It acts by blocking androgen receptors and inhibiting testosterone synthesis, leading to a relative increase in estrogenic activity. This hormonal imbalance can stimulate breast tissue growth in males.

Clomiphene citrate is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that actually increases gonadotropin secretion and is sometimes used to treat male infertility; it does not cause gynecomastia.

Oxytocin is a hormone used to stimulate uterine contractions and has no role in androgen or estrogen balance; it does not cause gynecomastia.

Tamoxifen is another SERM used to block estrogen receptors in breast tissue. In fact, it is often used to treat gynecomastia, not cause it.

Thus, spironolactone is the only option listed that is known to cause gynecomastia.


Reference:Goodman and gillmans The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics 13th edition page no 913

questions.text: Which of the following does not stimulate insulin secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Rosiglitazone

Rosiglitazone does not act by increasing insulin secretion. Rosiglitazone is an oral antihyperglycemic agent that acts primarily by decreasing insulin resistance.

* Mechanism of action:
  • Potent and highly selective agonist for peroxisome proliferator activated receptor gamma (PPARg). 
  • PPAR receptors are found in tissues important for insulin action such as adipose tissue, skeletal muscle and liver (highest level in adipose tissue).
  • Activation of (PPAR) nuclear receptors modulates the transcription of a number of insulin responsive genes involved in the control of glucose & lipid metabolism. 
  • Rosiglitazone appears to reduce insulin resistance by enhancing fatty acids storage and possibly by increasing adiponectin levels

* Other options: 
2. Repaglinide- Is a meglitinide which increases insulin release
3. Exenatide- GLP 1 analogue which increases insulin release
4. Sitagliptin- It is a DPP-4 inhibitor, it increases incretin level, which in turn increases insulin release

Anti Diabetic Drugs -
 
Class Examples Mechanism of Action
1. Insulin - Regular insulin- Long-acting (e.g., glargine)- Rapid-acting (e.g., lispro) Mimics natural insulin to control blood glucose.
2. Insulin Secretagogues DPP-4 Inhibitors: sitagliptin, saxagliptin, linagliptin
GLP-1 Agonists: exenatide, liraglutide-
Sulfonylureas: glibenclamide, glimepiride
 Meglitinides: repaglinide, nateglinide		 Stimulate insulin release from the pancreas.
3. Drugs that Reduce Insulin Resistance - Biguanides: metformin-
Thiazolidinediones (TZDs): pioglitazone, rosiglitazone		 Improve insulin sensitivity in muscle and fat.
4. SGLT-2 Inhibitors - Empagliflozin- Canagliflozin Increase glucose excretion by inhibiting renal glucose reabsorption.
5. Alpha-glucosidase Inhibitors - Acarbose- Miglitol Slow carbohydrate breakdown, reducing post-meal blood sugar spikes.
6. Amylin Analogs - Pramlintide Delay gastric emptying and reduce glucagon release.
7. Bile Acid Sequestrants - Colesevelam Improve insulin sensitivity and lower blood glucose.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 300.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with stage 5 chronic renal disease and hypertension recently received a Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosis. He does not desire to use insulin injections. Which of the following oral hypoglycemic medications, which doesn't require renal dosage modification, is preferred for this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Linagliptin

Linagliptin binds extensively to plasma proteins and is cleared primarily by the hepatobiliary system, with little renal clearance.

*[Extra Edge]: Linagliptin

  • Linagliptin is a competitive inhibitor of DPP 4 enzyme.
  • Dipeptidyl peptidase 4 is a serine protease that is widely distributed throughout the body, expressed as an ectoenzyme on vascular endothelial cells, on the surface of T lymphocytes, and in a circulating form. DPP-4 cleaves the two N-terminal amino acids from peptides with a proline or alanine in the second position and seems to be especially critical for the inactivation of GLP-1 and GIP.
*Audio Explanation:
 

Trick:- 
Linagliptin- Liver excretion, therefore safe in Renal failure.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1039.

choices.text: To be given empty stomach with a glass of water

questions.text: What directions should be given to a patient while administering bisphosphonates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) To be given empty stomach with a glass of water
 
  • Oral bisphosphonates have the potential to cause stomach discomfort, inflammation, and esophageal erosions.
  • This can be avoided by taking the drug on an empty stomach and being seated upright for 30 to 60 minutes afterward.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 370.

questions.text: Which of these does not use levonorgestrel for purposes other than contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Premenstrual tension
 
  • In premenstrual tension combined OCPs are used instead of Levonorgestrel.
  • In all other cases Levonorgestrel is used.
  • Severe premenstrual syndrome requires suppression of ovulation by combined estrogen-progesterone treatment given cyclically. Relatively higher dose of progestin is generally used.
  • Ovarian suppression with GnRH agonist may be required in nonresponsive cases. Progestins are added to estrogen when it is used for severe dysmenorrhoea.
     
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 344.

InformedHealth.org [Internet]. Cologne, Germany: Institute for Quality and Efficiency in Health Care (IQWiG); 2006-. Premenstrual syndrome: Learn More – Treatment for PMS. [Updated 2022 May 18]. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK279264/

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be used for post-coital contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1)  Desogestrel 

After having sex, women may use emergency contraception (EC), sometimes known as emergency postcoital contraception, to avoid becoming pregnant.
Desogestrel is not as an emergency contraceptive.

Emergency Contraception Methods:
1. Progestin-only Pill-0.75 mg levonorgestrel 2 doses 12 hours apart with 72 hours
2. Copper-containing IUD within 5 days
3. Combined oral contraceptive pills that can be used for emergency contraception when taken in multiple doses 12-24 hours apart, within 72 hours.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 347.

questions.text: What exactly is an ulipristal acetate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answers is (Option 4) Selective progesterone receptor modulator
 
  • Ulipristal acetate exerts its pharmacological activity by binding to the body’s progesterone receptors to produce an anti-progesterone contraceptive effect on the ovary (by suppressing or delaying ovulation) and on the endometrium (by decreasing endometrial thickness).
  • It inhibits ovulation by suppressing LH surge as well as by direct effect on follicular rupture. In addition, its action on endometrium can interfere with implantation.
  • In clinical trials the efficacy of ulipristal (30 mg) as emergency contraceptive has been rated equal to that of levonorgestrel (1.5 mg) when taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse, and to be more effective when taken between 72–120 hours.
  • Thus, it may have an advantage, if the woman misses to take the drug within 72 hours.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 346.

questions.text: Which is not a side-effect of growth hormone therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hypoglycemia

* [Extra Edge]: GH therapy in pediatrics age group
  • Rarely, patients develop intracranial hypertension with papilledema, visual changes, headache, nausea, or vomiting. Because of this, funduscopic examination is recommended at the initiation of therapy and at periodic intervals thereafter.
  • The consensus is that GH should not be administered in the first year after treatment of pediatric tumors, including leukemia, or during the first 2 years after therapy for medulloblastomas or ependymomas.
  • Because an increased incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus has been reported, fasting glucose levels should be followed periodically during therapy. Finally, too-rapid growth may be associated with slipped epiphyses or scoliosis.
* [Extra Edge]: GH therapy in adult age group
  • Side effects associated with the initiation of GH therapy in adults (peripheral edema, carpal tunnel syndrome, arthralgias, and myalgias) occur most frequently in older or obese patients and generally respond to a decrease in dose.
  • Estrogens (e.g., birth control medications and estrogen supplements) inhibit GH action so that a larger dose is needed to maintain the same IGF-1 level.
  • GH therapy can increase the metabolic inactivation of cortisol in the liver.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 930.

questions.text: When should the next dose of levonorgestrel 0.75 mg be given for adequate protection following unprotected intercourse?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 1 tab after 12 hours
 
  • Levonorgestrel is used as an emergency contraceptive, first at 0.75 mg and then again at 0.75 mg after 12 hours.
  • Levonorgestrel acts via multiple mechanisms including prevention of ovarian development, fertilization, and implantation.
  • It should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 348.

questions.text: Identify the site that is least commonly preferred for insulin injection.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) dorsum of hand

* [ Extra Edge]Sites of insulin injection:
  • The four safe areas for insulin injections are the sides of the thighs, the backs of the upper arms, the abdomen and the upper outer buttocks.
  • To avoid bumps and scar tissue on the skin, rotation of insulin injection sites should be done and a systematic approach to injection site rotation adopted.
  • Thus, injections may be given in the abdomen, outer thigh, back of the arm, and flank/buttocks regions.
  • Insulin injected on the abdomen acts faster than insulin injected on the thigh.
  • The rate of absorption of insulin injected on the arm is between that of insulin injected on the abdomen and that injected on the thigh.

questions.text: Identify the drug that does not have a role in osteoporosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Milnacipran
 
  • All of the given options except Milnapricin are used in managing Osteoporosis.
  • Milnacipran is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). It is not used in treating Osteoporosis. It is used in the management of Fibromyalgia.
  • PTH and strontium can be used in treating osteoporosis in some cases.
  • denosumab is anti-RANK ligand monoclonal antibody used in osteoporosis.
Treatment of Osteoporosis
Class Examples Mechanism of Action
Bisphosphonates - Alendronate- Risedronate- Zoledronic acid Inhibit bone resorption, increasing bone density.
SERMs (Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulators) - Raloxifene Mimic estrogen to protect bones, reduce resorption.
PTH Analogues - Teriparatide- Abaloparatide Stimulate bone formation.
RANK Ligand Inhibitors - Denosumab Inhibit bone resorption by blocking RANKL.
Calcitonin - Calcitonin (salmon) Inhibit bone resorption.
Strontium Ranelate - Strontium ranelate Increases bone formation and reduces resorption.
Estrogen Therapy - Conjugated estrogens Increase bone density by reducing resorption.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 345.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of drugs and their indications is mismatched?
questions.solution:

Carbamazepine is the drug of choice for partial seizures and trigeminal neuralgia.

  • 1. SIADH- hyponatremia- seen more commonly with oxcarbazepine in elderly individuals. 
  • 2. MC-drowsiness
  • 3. SJS/TEN- Associated with HLA-B-1502 gene.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the uses of iodine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Its use is contraindicated in hyperthyroidism

Iodine is not contraindicated in hyperthyroidism.

Iodine is used to treat hyperthyroidism in the following ways: 

  • In the perioperative period in preparation for thyroidectomy. 
  • In conjunction with other antithyroid drugs and propranolol in the treatment of thyrotoxicosis. 
* Excess iodine prevents release of T3 and T4 this is known as Wolf-Chaikoff effect.

Thyroid hormone release is inhibited: One important clinical effect of high iodine is the inhibition of thyroid hormone release, which is rapid and effective in severe thyrotoxicosis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: An individual with spread cancer visits the palliative care clinic complaining of nausea, vomiting, and impaired sensory perception. Investigations reveal hypercalcemia. What will be the initial chain of command?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Intravenous fluids
 
  • Hypercalcemia is a sign of paraneoplastic syndromes which arise due to several types of cancers in the body.
  • Intravenous fluids will increase blood volume thereby reducing the concentration of blood calcium levels.
  • Hence it is the first step, after that IV bisphosphonates can be given. Hence correct option is 3.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1058.

choices.text: Increase secretion of both insulin and C-peptide

questions.text: The potassium ionophore valinomycin has the following effects on pancreatic beta cells:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Decrease the secretion of insulin 
 
  • Valinomycin is a natural neutral ionophore account for its lack of a residual charge, allowing it to move potassium ions through membranes as it acts as a potassium-specific transporter.
  • It increases the permeability of potassium ions which results in hyperpolarization of beta cells and inhibiting the release of insulin.
Online Reference:
Huang S, Liu Y, Liu WQ, Neubauer P, Li J. The Nonribosomal Peptide Valinomycin: From Discovery to Bioactivity and Biosynthesis. Microorganisms. 2021 Apr 8;9(4):780. doi: 10.3390/microorganisms9040780. PMID: 33917912; PMCID: PMC8068249.

questions.text: Drug that does not cause Hirsutism:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Flutamide

Flutamide is androgen receptor blocker used in the treatment of Hirsutism.

A.M.D COP is the mnemonic for drugs causing Hirsutism
  • A – Androgens
  • M – Minoxidil
  • D – Diazoxide, Danazol
  • C – Cyclosporine
  • O – OCPs that contain progestin
  • P – Phenytoin

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 326.

questions.text: Which of the following inhibits the production of glucocorticoids?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Metyrapone



* [Extra Edge]: Metyrapone 
  • It prevents cortisol synthesis by inhibiting 11 β-hydroxylase enzymes
  • It is used in the diagnosis of Adrenal insufficiency
  • It is used as a test of the feedback hypothalamic-pituitary mechanism in the diagnosis of Cushing syndrome.
  • May also be used for the medical control of hypercortisolism in Cushing's syndrome

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 319.

questions.text: Which is the first line of RX of osteoporosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Bisphosphonates

  • First line drugs used in postmenopausal osteoporosis include bisphosphonates, selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs), and calcitonin.
  • Bisphosphonates are typically used as the first line of treatment, as they can help reduce the risk of fractures. SERMs are useful for decreasing the amount of bone loss.
  • Finally, calcitonin is generally used as a short-term preventive measure to reduce the risk of vertebral fractures.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 369.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below is used to treat obesity over the long term?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Liraglutide
 
  • Because of growing evidence of cardiovascular and other hazards, sibutramine and rimonabant were no longer sold or used.   
  • Fenfluramine and Dexfenfluramine are non-selective 5-HT2 agonists. 
  • When combined with phentermine as Fen-Phen and Dex-Phen, they were somewhat effective. They were the most widely used and successful appetite suppressants. However, these were removed once it was shown that they contributed to heart valve abnormalities and pulmonary hypertension. 
  • Metformin, which is advised as the initial treatment for type 2 diabetes.
  • Liraglutide is a GLP1 agonist. It decreases appetite.
Online Reference:
Mehta A, Marso SP, Neeland IJ. Liraglutide for weight management: a critical review of the evidence. Obes Sci Pract. 2017 Mar;3(1):3-14. doi: 10.1002/osp4.84. Epub 2016 Dec 19. PMID: 28392927; PMCID: PMC5358074.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs promote bone formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Teriparatide 

Drug that promotes bone formation is Teriparatide.
Drugs promoting bone formation are called anabolic drugs

* [Extra Edge]: Teriparatide
 
  • This recombinant preparation of 1–34 residues of amino terminal of human PTH has been recently introduced for the treatment of severe osteoporosis. It duplicates all the actions of the long (1–84) PTH.
  • Injected s.c. 20 mg once daily, it acts only for 2–3 hours, and has been found to increase bone mineral density in osteoporotic women. The effect was faster and more marked than that produced by estrogens and bisphosphonates (BPNs).
  • Teriparatide is the only agent which stimulates new bone formation, whereas the other two only check bone resorption.
  • In clinical trials it was found to be equally or more effective than estrogens and BPNs in reducing risk of vertebral as well as non-vertebral fractures in osteoporotic women as well as men.
  • Treatment with teriparatide beyond 2 years is not recommended, but BPNs may be continued thereafter. Side effects include dizziness, headache and leg cramps. 
* Other Options are either work by decreasing bone resorption or inhibiting it, no other drug stimulates new bone formation.

* Examples:
  • (a) TERIPARATIDE: a Parathyroid hormone (PTH) analog
  • (b) ABOLAPARATIDE: a PTH receptor peptide analog
  • (c) STRONTIUM RONELATE: anti-osteoporotic agent
  • (d) ROMOSUZUMAB: sclerostin glycoprotein inhibitor

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 365.
