questions.text: A 70-year-old patient has both hypertension and diabetes mellitus. He presents with late-stage chronic kidney disease. Which anti-diabetic medication of the following needs the least dose adjustment in renal disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Linagliptin
 
  • Linagliptin is an anti-diabetic drug that requires least dose modification in case of renal disease.
  • Linagliptin is one of the DPP-4 inhibitor drugs
* Other DPP-4 inhibitors used as anti-diabetic are:
  • Sitagliptin
  • Vildagliptin
  • Saxagliptin
  • Alogliptin
All DPP-4 inhibitors require dose adjustment in renal failure except Linagliptin since it has hepatic excretion. 

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1039.

questions.text: A female patient receiving tamoxifen therapy has unilateral breast cancer. Which of the following negative effects is connected to tamoxifen use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Endometrial carcinoma

Endometrial carcinoma is the adverse effect associated with the use of tamoxifen.

* Following are the side effects of tamoxifen:
  • Selective estrogen activation effect (due to which blood clots, stroke and endometrial cancer is seen)
  • Increased tumor or bone pain
  • Hot flashes
  • Mood swings and depression
  • Hair thinning
  • Constipation
  • Loss of libido
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 377.

choices.text: Inhibit implantation by bringing change in the uterus

questions.text: With the exception of ________ combined oral contraceptives work by all of the following mechanisms.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Increase gonadotrophin secretion

Combined oral contraceptive pills act by all of the following mechanics except by increase in gonadotrophin secretion.

* For the combined oral contraceptives, main mechanism of action are as follows-
  • Inhibition of follicular development,
  • Inhibition of ovulation, and as consequence, corpus luteum formation.
  • It is also involved in the alteration of the cervical mucus that inhibit sperm penetration.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 346.

questions.text: Identify the drug that acts through intracellular receptors.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Thyroxin

Only Thyroxine acts through intracellular receptors all other act via cell membrane receptors.

* [Extra Edge]:
  • Both T 3 and T4 penetrate cells by active transport and produce majority of their actions by combining with a nuclear thyroid hormone receptor (TR) which belongs to the steroid and retinoid superfamily of intracellular receptors.
  • Two TR isoform families (TRα and TRβ) have been identified. Both bind T 3 and function in similar manner, but their tissue distribution differs, which may account for quantitative differences in the sensitivity of different tissues to T3.
  • In contrast to the steroid receptor, the TR resides in the nucleus even in the unliganded inactive state. It is bound to the ‘thyroid hormone response element’ (TRE) in the enhancer region of the target genes along with corepressors

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 363.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who had Grave's disease was pregnant and receiving medication for hyperthyroidism. She gave birth to a child who has congenital anomaly aplasia cutis congenita. Which medication is most likely to be responsible for this teratogenic effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Carbimazole
 
  • Most likely drug implicated for this teratogenic effect is carbimazole.
  • Aplasia cutis congenita (ACC) following is seen following utero exposure to antithyroid drugs such as methimazole or carbimazole. 
  • Aplasia cutis congenita (ACC) or aplasia cutis is a rare skin defect characterized by either a focal or extensive absence of the epidermis, dermis, and in some cases the subcutaneous tissue.
  • It may be unifocal or multifocal and involve underlying bone, intracranial, or vascular structures. Although ACC may affect any part of the body, the scalp is most commonly affected.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 952.
Online Reference: P. Bowman, N.J. Osborne, R. Sturley, B. Vaidya, Carbimazole embryopathy: implications for the choice of antithyroid drugs in pregnancy, QJM: An International Journal of Medicine, Volume 105, Issue 2, February 2012, Pages 189–193, https://doi.org/10.1093/qjmed/hcq248

questions.text: Identify the one not used in the treatment of polycystic ovarian disease:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Ulipristal 

Ulipristal among the following is not used in treatment of polycystic ovarian disease.

* Treatment for polycystic ovarian disease include
  • birth control pills to regularize periods
  • medication called metformin to prevent diabetes
  • statins to control high cholesterol
  • hormones to increase fertility like - letrozole and clomiphene 
  • procedures to remove excess hair
Ulipristal which is a contraceptive is therefore not used.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 978.

questions.text: Which of the following does not prevent T4 to T3 conversion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Methimazole
 
  • Methimazole and carbimazole do not block the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.
  • Methimazole and carbimazole interfere with the oxidation of the iodide ion and iodotyrosyl groups. Eventually, thyroglobulin gets depleted and circulating thyroid hormone levels decrease.
  • All other drugs mentioned prevent conversion of T4 to T3. Thus Propranolol and Propylthiouracil are used in management of Thyroid storm.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 269.

questions.text: What is bremelanotide used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Low sexual desire
 
  • Bremelanotide injection (given Sc) is used to treat hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD) in premenopausal women who previously had no problems with sexual desire.
  • Bremelanotide acts as a melanocortin receptor agonist, specifically targeting the melanocortin-4 receptor (MC4R) in the brain. It is believed to increase sexual desire and arousal by stimulating the presynaptic MC4R (causing release of dopamine), which plays a role in regulating sexual function

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 985.

questions.text: Which is the best agent for premenstrual syndrome management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) SSRI
 
  • Best agent for premenstrual syndrome management is SSRI.
  • SSRIs which show effect due to increase in pregnenolone levels are treatment of choice for pre-menstrual syndrome.
  • Some women develop headache, irritability, fluid retention, distention and breast tenderness a few days preceding menstruation.
  • When depression predominates, it has been labelled ‘premenstrual dysphoric disorder’.
  • Fluoxetine and other SSRIs given daily on symptom days dampen irritability and mood changes in majority of women.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 344.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below is not used to treat erectile dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Phenylephrine

Phenylephrine is not used in erectile dysfunction. Phenylephrine is a vasoconstrictor used in treatment of priapism. 

* Agents used in erectile dysfunction are:
    • ￲PGE2
    • ￲Vardenafil (phosphodiesterase-V inhibitor)
    • ￲Alprostadil (PGE1)￲

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 327.

choices.text: Belongs to a class of Drugs known as SERD

questions.text: Which of the following statements about fulvestrant is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Less effective than SERM
 
  • Fulvestrant is generally considered to be as effective as selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) such as tamoxifen in the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. It is a pure estrogen antagonist with no agonist action. Fulvestrant is a selective estrogen-receptor down regulator (SERD).
  • Fulvestrant works differently from SERMs, as it acts as a selective estrogen receptor downregulator (SERD). It not only blocks estrogen receptors but also induces the degradation of the receptors, further reducing estrogen signaling.
  • By blocking and degrading estrogen receptors, fulvestrant helps to inhibit the growth and proliferation of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer cells.
  • It is longer acting and is administered once a month (250- 500mg) intramuscularly. It is generally well tolerated.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 337.

questions.text: Except for______, all of the following are appropriately matched.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (Option 4) Aromatase inhibitor-Triptorelin
 
  • Aromatase inhibitor - Triptorelin: This pairing is not appropriately matched.
  • Triptorelin is a medication that belongs to a class of drugs called gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists.
  • It is used to treat conditions such as endometriosis, prostate cancer, and precocious puberty.
  • It does not belong to the class of aromatase inhibitors, which are medications used to reduce estrogen levels in postmenopausal women with hormone receptor-positive breast cancer.
* [Extra Edge]: Drugs and their mechanism of action




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 265.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a pure estrogen receptor antagonist?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Fulvestrant
 
  • Fulvestrant is generally considered to be as effective as selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) such as tamoxifen in the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. It is a pure estrogen antagonist with no agonist action. Fulvestrant is a selective estrogen-receptor down regulator (SERD).
  • Fulvestrant works differently from SERMs, as it acts as a selective estrogen receptor downregulator (SERD). It not only blocks estrogen receptors but also induces the degradation of the receptors, further reducing estrogen signaling.
  • By blocking and degrading estrogen receptors, fulvestrant helps to inhibit the growth and proliferation of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer cells.
  • It is longer acting and is administered once a month (250- 500mg) intramuscularly. It is generally well tolerated.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 377.

questions.text: What is known as "peakless" insulin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Insulin Glargine
 
  • Insulin Glargine, a long-acting insulin analog, is commonly referred to as "peakless" insulin.
  • It is designed to provide a continuous and steady level of insulin activity over an extended duration.
  • Unlike some other insulin formulations, Insulin Glargine has a relatively flat and prolonged action profile, which means it does not have a distinct peak in its activity.
  • This steady release of insulin helps provide basal insulin coverage throughout the day and night, mimicking the body's natural basal insulin secretion pattern.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 287.

choices.text: Hypoglycemia is less common than with sulfonylureas

questions.text: Which of the statements is not true about bout meglitinides ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Act by decreasing insulin resistance 
 
  • Meglitinides are oral antidiabetic medications used for type 2 diabetes.
  • Meglitinides work by stimulating insulin release from pancreatic beta cells, which helps to lower blood glucose levels.
  • Meglitinides do not have a direct effect on insulin resistance.
  • They are insulin secretagogues that act by inhibiting the ATP-sensitive K+ channels of the beta cells of the pancreas to cause insulin release.
Anti Diabetic Drugs
Class Examples Mechanism of Action
1. Insulin - Regular insulin- Long-acting (e.g., glargine)- Rapid-acting (e.g., lispro) Mimics natural insulin to control blood glucose.
2. Insulin Secretagogues - DPP-4 Inhibitors: sitagliptin, saxagliptin, linagliptin
 GLP-1 Agonists: exenatide, liraglutide
Sulfonylureas: glibenclamide, glimepiride
 Meglitinides: repaglinide, nateglinide		 Stimulate insulin release from the pancreas.
3. Drugs that Reduce Insulin Resistance - Biguanides: metformin
Thiazolidinediones (TZDs): pioglitazone, rosiglitazone		 Improve insulin sensitivity in muscle and fat.
4. SGLT-2 Inhibitors - Empagliflozin- Canagliflozin Increase glucose excretion by inhibiting renal glucose reabsorption.
5. Alpha-glucosidase Inhibitors - Acarbose- Miglitol Slow carbohydrate breakdown, reducing post-meal blood sugar spikes.
6. Amylin Analogs - Pramlintide Delay gastric emptying and reduce glucagon release.
7. Bile Acid Sequestrants - Colesevelam Improve insulin sensitivity and lower blood glucose.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 296.

choices.text: Used in the treatment of breast cancer
Slower acting, safer and less effective than SERM
May be administered as 'once a month' dose

questions.text: Which of the statements is not true about Selective Estrogen Receptor Downregulator (SERD), Fulvestrant ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Slower acting, safer and less effective than SERM 
 
  • Fulvestrant is an estrogen antagonist which is indicated in postmenopausal women with hormone-positive breast cancer, which is progressive even after first-line therapy such as tamoxifen.
  • It is longer acting and is administered once a month (250- 500mg) intramuscularly. It is generally well tolerated.
  • It is given as initial biweekly loading doses in the 1st month followed by once-monthly injections. Steady-state levels are achieved in the first month.
  • It is as effective as SERM
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 337.

questions.text: An exception to presence of Mineralocorticoid Receptors is -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Liver 
 
  • Mineralocorticoid receptors (MR) are a type of nuclear receptor that specifically binds to mineralocorticoid hormones, such as aldosterone.
  • These receptors are primarily found in target tissues that are involved in electrolyte and fluid balance regulation, such as the kidney, colon, and certain parts of the brain.
  • However, the exception to the presence of mineralocorticoid receptors is the liver (option A).
  • Unlike other target tissues, the liver does not express significant levels of mineralocorticoid receptors.
  • Instead, the liver primarily expresses glucocorticoid receptors (GR), which mediate the effects of glucocorticoid hormones like cortisol.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 1010.

questions.text: Which antidiabetic medication can cause bone fracture in female?
questions.solution:
There is an increased risk of bone fractures in females with Rosiglitazone (option 2).
Rosiglitazone belongs to the class of thiazolidinediones (TZDs) and has been linked to an increased risk of fractures, particularly in postmenopausal women. 

 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 1036,1037,1043 .

questions.text: Which of the following Anti Diabetic drug is currently used in the management of heart failure with reduced EF and slowing progression of kidney disease?
questions.solution:
SGLT -2 inhibitors are class of OHA which are used in treatment of HFrEF and slows down progression of Kidney disease.
They include canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin. Empaglifozin can be used in patients with CKD if GFR >20ml/min.
Side effects - Urogenital infections, Euglycemic ketoacidosis, Necrotising Facsitis.

DAPA-HF (Dapagliflozin and Prevention of Adverse Outcomes in Heart Failure) trial:
*In addition to diuretic and related hemodynamic actions of SGLT2 inhibitors, effects on myocardial metabolism, ion transporters, fibrosis, adipokines, and vascular function have also been proposed. These actions, along with preservation of renal function, would also benefit patients with established heart failure, including those without diabetes, in whom SGLT2 inhibitors have not been tested.

Pioglitazone -thiazolidinedione - Activates PPAR Gamma receptors causing insulin mediated glucose uptake peripherally -Side Effects- Causes weight gain by fluid retention hence CI in Heart failure.
Linagliptin -DPP -4 inhibitor - Approved in renal failure.

Reference: McMurray JJV, Solomon SD, Inzucchi SE, Køber L, Kosiborod MN, Martinez FA, Ponikowski P, Sabatine MS, Anand IS, Bělohlávek J, Böhm M, Chiang CE, Chopra VK, de Boer RA, Desai AS, Diez M, Drozdz J, Dukát A, Ge J, Howlett JG, Katova T, Kitakaze M, Ljungman CEA, Merkely B, Nicolau JC, O'Meara E, Petrie MC, Vinh PN, Schou M, Tereshchenko S, Verma S, Held C, DeMets DL, Docherty KF, Jhund PS, Bengtsson O, Sjöstrand M, Langkilde AM; DAPA-HF Trial Committees and Investigators. Dapagliflozin in Patients with Heart Failure and Reduced Ejection Fraction. N Engl J Med. 2019 Nov 21;381(21):1995-2008. doi: 10.1056/NEJMoa1911303. Epub 2019 Sep 19. PMID: 31535829.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs does not require any renal dose modification in those with chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
In patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), drug dosing must often be adjusted because many drugs are renally excreted.

Key points:

  • Linagliptin:

    • A DPP-4 inhibitor used in type 2 diabetes.

    • Primarily excreted via the bile and gut, not kidneys.

    • No renal dose adjustment required, even in severe CKD.

  • Other drugs:

    • Saxagliptin: Requires dose adjustment in CKD (mainly renally excreted).

    • Repaglinide: Requires caution; dose adjustment is often necessary in renal impairment.

    • Glyburide (glibenclamide): Risk of prolonged hypoglycemia in CKD; dose adjustment recommended.

questions.text: Which of the following OHA increases the risk of urinary tract infections?
questions.solution:
• SGLT2 inhibitors such as dapagliflozin are known to cause UTI inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule and is responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose.
  • This results in glycosuria. common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine.
  • There is also a risk of the developing diabetic ketoacidosis.
  • Benefits include weight reduction and BP lowering action.
  • It has also shown benefits in management of heart failure.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page No 301.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of Teriparatide?
questions.solution:
• Teriparatide is a parathormone analog, administered subcutaneously.
  • Dose being 20mcg once daily into the thigh or abdomen.
  • Teriparatide and abaloparatide (PTHrP analog) are the only anabolic agents currently available that increase new bone formation .
  • Adverse effects include hypercalcemia, exacerbation of nephrolithiasis, elevation of serum uric acid levels and increased risk of developing osteosarcoma. Hence not to prescribed for more than 2 years.
  • Ostenecrosis of Jaw is associated with Bisphosphonates
Reference: Katzung Basic and clinical Pharmacology, 14th Edition, Page No 789.

questions.text: Which of the following causes a decrease in serum parathyroid hormone?
questions.solution:
• Lithium can increase PTH secretion by affecting calcium-sensing receptors in the parathyroid glands.
  • The active form of vitamin D, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol), directly suppresses PTH gene expression
  • Calcitriol is the active form of vitamin D. It increases calcium absorption from the intestines and helps maintain adequate serum calcium levels.
  • When calcium levels rise, this triggers a negative feedback mechanism on the parathyroid glands, leading to decreased secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH).
  • PTH's raises blood calcium levels, so when calcium is sufficient, the need for PTH decreases, resulting in lower PTH levels.
  • Risedronate is a bisphosphonate that inhibits bone resorption, but it doesn't directly affect PTH secretion.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page No 1052,1059.

questions.text: Which of the following Anti Diabetic drug is known to cause Unexplained Diarhoea?
questions.solution:
• Metformin is known to cause Unexplanied Diarrhoea as its side effect.
  • Other side effects of Metformin include - Nausea and vomiting, Abdominal cramps and Vit B12 deficency.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page No 1036.

questions.text: The anti-diabetic medication that lowers HbA1C by increasing GIP and GLP-1 levels and reducing glucagon levels is an oral drug that decreases both pre- and post-prandial glucose levels. This drug is:
questions.solution:
Alogliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. Incretins such as glucagon-like peptide (GLP) and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) stimulate insulin secretion into the bloodstream, but they are quickly inactivated by dipeptidyl peptidase. By inhibiting dipeptidyl peptidase, alogliptin enhances the effects of these incretins, leading to increased insulin release. DPP-4 inhibitors thus improve postprandial insulin release, reduce glucagon levels, and help lower both mealtime and fasting glucose levels.

Other DPP-4 inhibitors include saxagliptin, linagliptin, alogliptin, and vildagliptin, all of which are weight-neutral. These drugs are known to cause severe joint pain, which typically resolves after discontinuation. Linagliptin is primarily eliminated through the hepatobiliary system, with minimal renal clearance. Saxagliptin is metabolized by the liver and should be used at reduced doses if administered with a cytochrome P450 enzyme inhibitor. The other DPP-4 inhibitors are excreted through the kidneys, so they should be used with caution in patients with renal insufficiency.


 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 1035-1041 .

questions.text: A diabetic patient began taking a medication that reduced her HbA1c from 7.6 to 6.7. She has since reported itching in the vulvovaginal area. Which drug is she most likely using?
questions.solution:
In the described clinical scenario, the most likely cause of itching in the vulvovaginal area is canagliflozin. This medication, a sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor, is associated with side effects such as urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the increased glucose content in urine. Other potential side effects include a higher risk of fractures and lower extremity amputations.

Canagliflozin, along with other SGLT-2 inhibitors like dapagliflozin and empagliflozin, works by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter located in the proximal renal tubule, which is responsible for reabsorbing 80-90% of filtered glucose. By blocking glucose reabsorption, these drugs lead to glycosuria and alter the renal threshold for glucose.

SGLT-2 inhibitors can also lead to mild weight loss and lower blood pressure. Empagliflozin and canagliflozin have been shown to reduce major cardiovascular events. Common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the glucose in urine. There is also a risk of diabetic ketoacidosis, fractures, and lower limb amputations related to imbalances in minerals, parathormone, and vitamin D. The effectiveness of SGLT-2 inhibitors may diminish in stage 3 kidney disease (GFR 60-30 mL/min) because their action depends on the rate of glucose filtration.


 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 1038-1040,1043 .

questions.text: A 50 year old male with prior history of ischemic heart disease having ejection fraction of 28% is at your clinic for management of type 2 diabetes. Which of the following OHA's should be avoided in this case?
questions.solution: Pioglitazone is an activator of the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor y (PPARy), which is involved in the regulation of genes related to glucose and lipid metabolism. Its adverse effects include increased incidence of heart failure, peripheral edema, weight gain, macular edema, and osteoporosis.Ref- Goodman and Gillman 13th edition Page 874-875

questions.text: Which of the following drug is more prone to cause hypoglycaemic episode?
questions.solution:
Among the following options, Glimepiride which is a sulphonylurea is known to cause hypoglycemia.
Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea that also stimulates insulin secretion. They bind to a specific site on the β cell K-ATP channel complex and inhibit its activity. This causes cell membrane to depolarize and leads to a cascade of events resulting in insulin secretion.
Antidiabetic Drugs that pose a risk of leading to hypoglycemia (insulin secretagogue):
• Sulfonylureas
• Meglitinides: Nateglinide, Repaglinide
The following drugs are not directly responsible for stimulating insulin secretion and hence do not cause hypoglycemia:
• Metformin
• Alpha-glucosidase inhibitor
• Pioglitazone
• DPP-4 inhibitor: Sitagliptin. Ref -KD Tripathi essential of Medical pharmacology 8th edition page 215,297

questions.text: Which of the following anti- Diabetic drug is known to cause unexpplained diarrhoea?
questions.solution: Metformin is an Oral Anti Diabetic drug, It belongs to the class of Biguanides. It is known to cause Unexplained Diarrhoea as its side effect. The other side effects of Metformin Include - Nausea and vomiting, Lactic acidosis, abdominal cramps, Vit B12 deficency. Ref- Essentials of medical pharmacology K.D Tripathi 7th edition page number 276

choices.text: Bolus of 200 mg, followed by 500 over 24 hours
Bolus of 100 mg, followed by 200 over 24 hours

questions.text: A 55-year-old male was diagnosed with Addison's disease. What is the steroid regime for this patient?
questions.solution:
For Addison's disease, a 100 mg bolus is administered right away, then 200 mg over the course of 24 hours. In cases of acute adrenal insufficiency, the following treatment plans must be started right away:

* Rehydration: saline infusion with ongoing cardiac monitoring at a starting rate of 1 L/h.

° Glucocorticoid replacement: 100 mg of hydrocortisone injected as a bolus, followed by a 24-hour maintenance dosage of 100–200 mg.

* Mineralocorticoid replacement: this is started after reducing the daily hydrocortisone dosage to less than 50 mg because larger hydrocortisone dosages provide enough mineralocorticoid action.

Reference
Harrisons Principles Of Internal Medicine - 19th Edition - Page no: 2325

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese lady with diabetes was managed with oral hypoglycemic agents. She now presents to the casualty with a hypoglycemic episode. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for her hypoglycemic episode?
questions.solution:
Drug Class Risk of Hypoglycemia Mechanism
Glimepiride Sulfonylurea High Stimulates insulin release from pancreatic β-cells regardless of glucose level
Metformin Biguanide Very Low Reduces hepatic gluconeogenesis; does not increase insulin
Pioglitazone Thiazolidinedione Very Low Improves insulin sensitivity; does not stimulate insulin
Sitagliptin DPP-4 inhibitor Low Increases incretin levels → glucose-dependent insulin secretion

  

Key point: 

Among all oral hypoglycemic agents, sulfonylureas (like glimepiride, gliclazide, glibenclamide) have the highest risk of causing hypoglycemia, especially in:

  • Elderly patients

  • Those with irregular meals

  • Renal insufficiency


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 2866

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presented with difficulty in urination, back pain, and an elevated PSA blood test. An X-ray revealed two radiolucent lesions in the bony pelvis and MRI revealed several enlarged lymph nodes in the lower abdomen. Which of the following drugs can most likely be used to treat the given condition? PSAProstate-specific antigen
questions.solution:
The patient is an elderly man presenting with:

  • Urinary difficulty

  • Back pain

  • Elevated PSA (Prostate-Specific Antigen)

  • Bone lesions (radiolucent)

  • Pelvic lymphadenopathy on MRI

These findings are highly suggestive of metastatic prostate cancer.

Treatment Strategy for Metastatic Prostate Cancer:

  • Prostate cancer is androgen-dependent, especially in early and locally advanced stages.

  • One of the main treatment strategies is androgen deprivation therapy (ADT), either via:

    • Surgical orchiectomy

    • Medical castration with GnRH analogues (e.g., goserelin, leuprolide)

      Drug Choices Explained:

  1. Oxandrolone

    • An anabolic steroid and androgen agonist

    • Contraindicated as it may worsen prostate cancer.

  2. Goserelin 

    • A GnRH agonist that causes initial stimulation followed by downregulation of GnRH receptors.

    • Results in decreased LH → decreased testosterone → regression of prostate cancer.

    • Commonly used in hormonal therapy for advanced/metastatic prostate cancer.

  3. Desogestrel

    • A progestin used in contraception.

    • Not effective in prostate cancer treatment.

  4. Anastrozole

    • An aromatase inhibitor used for estrogen-sensitive breast cancer in postmenopausal women.

    • Has no role in prostate cancer treatment.

Goserelin is the drug of choice among the options provided, as it effectively suppresses testosterone, which is essential for the growth of prostate cancer.


Reference:Katzung Basic and Clinical Pharmacology 14th Edition - Page no 677, 678, 729, 739, 741, 742, 972

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common side effect of orlistat?
questions.solution:
Orlistat is a reversible inhibitor of gastric and pancreatic lipases, prescribed for the management of obesity. It acts locally in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract to prevent the hydrolysis of dietary fat (triglycerides) into absorbable free fatty acids and monoglycerides.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Orlistat inhibits pancreatic lipase, the enzyme responsible for breaking down triglycerides in the intestine.

  • As a result, ~30% of dietary fat is not absorbed and is instead excreted in the feces.

  • This leads to reduced calorie absorption and aids in weight loss.

    Most Common Side Effect: Steatorrhea

Steatorrhea refers to the presence of excess fat in stools, making them:

  • Bulky

  • Foul-smelling

  • Oily or greasy

  • Sometimes difficult to flush

This happens because:

  • The unabsorbed fat travels through the intestine and is excreted.

  • When high-fat meals are consumed during orlistat therapy, the amount of undigested fat increases dramatically, resulting in gastrointestinal (GI) side effects.

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 2849

questions.text: Serum levels that are suggestive of lithium toxicity:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 2 mEq/L

Therapeutic range 0.8-1.2 mEq/L
Levels above 1.5 mEq/L are considered toxic. Hence, option (1) is the most appropriate answer.

* [Extra Edge]: Lithium

questions.text: Which of the following has an acrid or a pear odour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Paraldehyde

Paraldehyde is a clear, colorless liquid with an unpleasant ethereal odour, and an acrid nauseous taste. It is used as a hypnotic by mouth, rectum or parenterally and as a basal anesthetic.

questions.text: Which anticonvulsant causes the vision field to contract?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Vigabatrin

  • The retinal nerve fiber layer suffers from permanent widespread atrophy brought on by vigabatrin.
  • The outside region of the retina is mainly affected by this (as opposed to the macular or central region), which causes contraction of visual field.
  • Taurine depletion may be the cause of vigabatrin's retinal toxicity.
* Audio Explanation:


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 448.

questions.text: Which of the following effects of valproate is exclusive to gender?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) polycystic ovarian syndrome

The most frequent side effects of valproate are "nausea (22%)" and "drowsiness (19%)."
Vomiting (12%), dizziness (12%), and weakness (10%)

* Severe side effects are:

  • Bleeding
  • reduced blood platelets
  • Encephalopathy
  • Suicidal actions and ideas
  • decreased body temperature

* Valproic acid may raise the risk of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) in females with epilepsy or bipolar disorder, according to some data.

* Audio Explanation:


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 444.

questions.text: In a pregnant female taking lithium - what needs to be checked for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Cardiac anomaly
 
  • Lithium is categorized as having a D risk level.
  • Cardiac anomalies should be checked in the newborn if lithium is given to a pregnant female. 
  • Cardiac Malformations (especially Ebstein Anomaly) are commonly associated with using Lithium in pregnancy.
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 476.

questions.text: Which of the following side effects increases when valproate is used with carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hepatotoxicity

The risk of hepatotoxicity increases if carbamazepine is used along with valproate.
  • By way of CYP450 enzymes, valproate is converted into the hepatotoxic minor metabolite 2-propyl-4-pentenoic acid (4-ene-VPA).
  • The microsomal enzymes can be induced, and the production of this metabolite increased by enzyme inducers like carbamazepine, phenytoin, and phenobarbital.
Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 416.

choices.text: Stop treatment and follow-up with 6 monthly EEG

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl was taking antiepileptic medication to treat episodes of epilepsy while she slept. After six months without a seizure, her NCCT and EEG were both normal. What is the next course of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Continue for 2 years

Drug is slowly tapered off after Continuing for 2 years.

* [Extra Edge]: Withdrawal of Antiepileptic drugs - 
  • Seizure free period of 2 years 
  • Normal CNS examination 
  • Normal EEG and normal MRI
  • Single seizure type
  • No F/H/O seizure
Online Reference:
Laue-Gizzi H. Discontinuation of antiepileptic drugs in adults with epilepsy. Aust Prescr. 2021 Apr;44(2):53-56. doi: 10.18773/austprescr.2021.005. Epub 2021 Apr 1. PMID: 33911333; PMCID: PMC8075746.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions should morphine not be given to a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Biliary colic
 
  • Morphine can cause contraction of sphincter of Oddi and biliary spasm; hence it can worsen pain of biliary colic and is not used for the same.
  • The opioids can cause biliary colic by tightening the biliary smooth muscle and
  • As a result of the sphincter of Oddi constricting, biliary and pancreatic secretions may reflux, and plasma amylase and lipase levels may rise.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 500.

questions.text: A patient complained of pain in the right lower quadrant of his abdomen. He has a history of right kidney stones. He was given an opioid, which is both a partial agonist mu and an antagonist at kappa receptors. What was the most likely medication administered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Buprenorphine
 
  • Buprenorphine is partial agonist at mu and antagonist at kappa
  • Pentazocine is full agonist at kappa and antagonist at mu
* [Extra Edge]: Nature of interaction of opioid ligands with the three major types of opioid receptors




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 510.

choices.text: Lamotrigine acts by opening of GABA mediated Cl-channels

questions.text: What is false about antiepileptics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Lamotrigine acts by opening of GABA mediated Cl-channels
 
  • The main mechanism of action of lamotrigine is inactivation of voltage gated sodium channels.
  • It also stabilizes presynaptic neuronal membrane and prevents pre-synaptic release of aspartate and glutamate. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 446.

questions.text: Blood alcohol level of an alcoholic with poor judgment and decreased in skilled movements would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 80-200 mg/dl
 
  • Alcohol intoxication occurs when an individual has consumed a large enough quantity of alcohol to raise their blood alcohol content level past the legal limit of 0.08%.
  • At blood alcohol levels between 80-200 mg/dl, the individual will exhibit a number of impairments, primarily related to motor coordination and judgment. These impairments may include slurred speech, blurred vision, and unstable balance, poor judgment, and lack of coordination.
  • At higher levels of intoxication > 300 mg/dl, more serious impairments can occur, such as unconsciousness, coma, and even death in extreme cases.
* [Extra Edge]: Serum Ethanol level Vs Symptoms



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 522.

questions.text: Select the drug that can be used in benzodiazepine toxicity.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Flumazenil

Flumazenil is a competitive inhibitor of BZD, hence is used in cases of its toxicity.

Flumazenil abolishes the hypnogenic, psychomotor, cognitive and EEG effects of BZDs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 435.

questions.text:
Which is the incorrect match about anti-epileptic drugs ?
1st line drugs Second line drugs
Focal seizure Lamotrigine, CBZ, Phenytoin Valproate
Absence seizure CBZ Ethosuximide, Valproate
Myoclonic seizure  valproate, Lamotrigine Clonazepam

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is prescribed phenytoin and valproate after being diagnosed with epilepsy. She experienced a generalised rash all over her body four weeks later, which eventually went away after she stopped using both medications. When she is given another chance to take phenytoin and valproate, how many weeks will pass before the rash reappears?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 1 day
 
  • The situation given in the question appears to be of a hypersensitivity to Phenytoin.
  • This manifests in 3- to 4-week intervals. 
  • When the medication is retested, the mediators are already created and released considerably more quickly, resulting in the rash developing much more quickly.
Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 419.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-Parkinsonian medications causes peripheral vasospasm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answers is (Option 3) Bromocriptine
 
  • Bromocriptine is a dopamine-receptor agonist derived from the vasoconstrictive alkaloid ergotamine.
  • It is typically administered in slowly increasing doses over a period of 2 to 3 months, but there are numerous potential side effects, including hallucinations, confusion, delirium, nausea and orthostatic hypotension.
  • It can also increase the risk of psychiatric illness, and serious cardiac problems, such as myocardial infarction, may develop.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 261.

choices.text: It is rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and is detected in plasma 30 minutes after oral administration
The primary use of methadone is relief of chronic pain
The onset of analgesia is 30-60 minutes after parenteral administration and 1-2 hours after oral administration

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about methadone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) The onset of analgesia is 30-60 minutes after parenteral administration and 1-2 hours after oral administration
 
  • Methadone is a mu full agonist.
  • The onset of analgesia occurs 10-20 minutes after parenteral administration and 30-60 minutes after oral medication.
  • The average minimal effective analgesic concentration in blood is ~30 ng/mL.
  • It is used in management of chronic pain and antitussive.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 504.

questions.text: How long does flumazenil take to start working?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) within seconds
 
  • Flumazenil typically starts its action within 60- 90 seconds of IV administration.
  • Duration of action of flumazenil is 40 minutes. It is a BZD analogue, with little intrinsic activity, used in overdose of BZD.
  • On IV injection, action of flumazenil starts in seconds and lasts for 1-2 hours; elimination t-half is 1 hour, due to rapid metabolism.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 435.

choices.text: Has been known to cause Steven-Johnson's syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following statements about carbamazepine is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Has been known to cause Steven-Johnson's syndrome 

  • Carbamazepine has been known to cause Steven-Johnson's syndrome.
  • Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to medication that starts with flu-like symptoms, followed by a painful rash that spreads and blisters. Then the top layer of affected skin dies, sheds and begins to heal after several days.
  • Acute intoxication with carbamazepine can result in stupor or coma, hyperirritability, convulsions, and respiratory depression.
  • During Long term therapy, the more frequent untoward effects of the drug include drowsiness, vertigo, ataxia, diplopia, and blurred vision. The frequency of seizures may increase, especially with overdose.
  • Other adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, serious hematological toxicity (aplastic anemia, agranulocytosis), and hypersensitivity reactions (dangerous skin reactions, eosinophilia, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly).
  • A late complication of therapy with carbamazepine is retention of water, with decreased osmolality and concentration of Na+ in plasma, especially in elderly patients with cardiac disease.
     
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 442.

questions.text: Which receptors are affected by tricyclic antidepressants, causing side effects like dry mouth and urinary retention?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Muscarinic receptors

  • Tricyclic antidepressants produce side effects like dry mouth, urinary retention due to action on Muscarinic receptors.
  • Muscarinic receptors are the most widespread receptors of the parasympathetic nervous system bringing about associated changes in the body.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 485.

questions.text: Which receptor mediates dysphoria caused by opiates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) kappa

Kappa receptors for opioids cause dysphoria.

* [Extra Edge]: Functions of Opioid Receptor



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 507.

questions.text: Which of the following medications can effectively treat juvenile myoclonic epilepsy in a female of childbearing age group in substitution of sodium valproate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Levetiracetam
 
  • Levetiracetam can be prescribed as monotherapy in a female patient of childbearing age as a replacement of valproate for JME, because of no known significant drug interactions. Rest options have their fare risk of adverse effects associated.
  • Carbamazepine and phenytoin are in fact contraindicated in JME. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 401.

questions.text: The newest medication for Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Edaravone
 
  • The recently sanctioned medicine for Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) is Edaravone. The US FDA authorized it on the grounds of a six-month test including a specific set of ALS sufferers, which showed a small decline in their disability rate.
  • Edavarone acts as an antioxidant, however the actual mechanism of action is not known.
  • This drug, thought to act as an antioxidant, is administered through a 10-day cycle of daily intravenous infusions, each month. Previously, Riluzole was approved, albeit with a mild survival extension benefit. However, survival was not an inspected factor in the Edaravone trial.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 423.
Online Reference:
Cruz MP. Edaravone (Radicava): A Novel Neuroprotective Agent for the Treatment of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. P T. 2018 Jan;43(1):25-28. PMID: 29290672; PMCID: PMC5737249.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a side effect of escitalopram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Sialorrhea 
 
  • Escitalopram is selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI).
  • SSRIs have side effects, including insomnia, increased anxiety, irritability, decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, anorgasmia, ejaculatory delay and gastrointestinal effects.
  • Some patients also experience increased anxiety during the initial dosing, and dullness of intellectual ability and concentration with continued treatment.
  • Paroxetine in particular is linked to higher levels of sexual side effects. Sialorrhea is not the side-effect of SSRIs.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 489.

choices.text: No fade on train of four stimulation

questions.text: The statements concerning succinylcholine causing neuromuscular blockade are all accurate, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Fade on tetanic stimulation

On tetanic stimulation, Sch undergoes post-tetanic potentiation instead of fade.
Succinyl choline is a depolarizing muscle relaxant. It has a TOF>0.4

* [Extra Edge]: Clinical assessment of neuromuscular block


FIG: TOF protocol
  • During partial competitive block (as occurs during onset and recovery or reversal) the degree of block corresponds to the decrease in TOF-ratio, because competitive blockers exhibit ‘fade’ phenomenon.
  • As the muscles recover, the TOF-ratio improves and becomes 1.0 at complete recovery.
  • Spontaneous breathing may be resumed when TOF-ratio recovers to > 0.7.
  • On the other hand, classical or phase-I depolarizing block does not exhibit fade; the TOF-ratio remains 1.0, though all the 4 twitches are depressed equally depending on the degree of block.
  • Fade is again seen when phase II or desensitization block occurs with prolonged use of a depolarizing agent and TOF-ratio is depressed as in the case of competitive block. However, SCh generally requires no monitoring.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 379.
Online Reference:
Xue L, Wu LG. Post-tetanic potentiation is caused by two signalling mechanisms affecting quantal size and quantal content. J Physiol. 2010 Dec 15;588(Pt 24):4987-94. doi: 10.1113/jphysiol.2010.196964. Epub 2010 Nov 1. PMID: 21041528; PMCID: PMC3036192.

questions.text: The primarily use of Methyldopa is in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Pregnancy Induced hypertension

Methyldopa is an Anti-hypertensive primarily used in cases of Pregnancy induced hypertension

Option 1 : Parkinsonism – drugs like levodopa, carbidopa are used

Option 3 : Hirsutism – OCPs, Spironolactone

Option 4 : Patients not responding to at least 3 drugs, one of them being a diuretic are said to have Refractory Hypertension. Spironolactone is given in such cases

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 612.

questions.text: The cause of Fetal Hydantoin Syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Phenytoin 

Fetal hydantoin syndrome is a characteristic pattern of mental and physical birth defects that results from maternal use of the anti-seizure (anticonvulsant) drug phenytoin (Dilantin) during pregnancy.
  • The range and severity of associated abnormalities will vary greatly from one infant to another. However, characteristic features may include distinctive skull and facial features, growth deficiencies, underdeveloped (hypoplastic) nails of the fingers and toes, and/or mild developmental delays.
  • Other findings occasionally associated with this syndrome include cleft lip and palate, a head circumference that is smaller than would be expected based upon an infant’s age and gender (microcephaly), and skeletal malformations particularly of the fingers or hands.

* [Extra Edge]: Teratogenic Drugs


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 441.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used with Rivastigmine in patients with Alzheimer's?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) SSRI

TCA and other atypical anti-depressant drugs have anti cholinergic properties hence they are not preferred in Alzheimer as they can worsen the condition.
Therefore, SSRI is the preferred drug in treating depression in Alzheimer patients.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 485.

choices.text: Naloxone can be used for treatment of opioid induced constipation
Naltrexone may be used for treatment of alcohol dependence
Nalmefene has a longer half-life than Naloxone

questions.text: Pick the incorrect statement regarding Opioid receptor antagonists.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Naloxone is more potent than Naltrexone

Option 1, 2 and 4 are regarding Naltrexone and Naloxone
  • Naltrexone differs from naloxone in being orally active and having a long duration of action (1–2 days) which makes it suitable for ‘opioid blockade’ therapy of postaddicts. 
  • Naltrexone is more potent than naloxone.
  • There is evidence that naltrexone decreases the craving for alcohol in chronic alcoholics by increasing baseline β-endorphin release, and it has been approved by the FDA for this purpose.
  • Methylnaltrexone bromide and Naloxone is approved for the treatment of constipation in patients with opioid-induced constipation (OIC) with chronic noncancer pain.
  • late-stage advanced illness naloxegol, alvimopan approved for the treatment of postoperative ileus following bowel resection surgery.
Option 3 Nalmefene pure opioid antagonist lacks hepatotoxicity of naltrexone, has higher oral bioavailability and is longer acting than Naloxone.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 512.

choices.text: Inhibit conversion of levodopa to dopamine in the CNS

questions.text: The reason why L-Dopa is combined with Carbidopa in the treatment of parkinsonism is to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Inhibit peripheral decarboxylation of levodopa

Levodopa is metabolized by dopa decarboxylase in the whole body. 90% of levodopa gets metabolized into dopamine in the periphery and only a small amount reaches the brain

Carbidopa is an analog of levodopa. It does not cross the blood brain barrier. So if carbidopa is given with levodopa , it competitively blocks dopa decarboxylase in the periphery preventing peripheral metabolism of levodopa. Thus, it helps in reducing the dopamine related peripheral side effects and increase central concentration of dopamine. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 457.

questions.text: The following statement about Phenytoin is false:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Stimulates insulin secretion

Phenytoin follows Michaelis Menten kinetics, elimination changes from first order to zero order kinetics when dose is increased beyond saturation levels.

Option 2 :  Causes foetal hydantoin syndrome – microcephaly, cleft lip/palate, hypoplastic phalanges

Option 3 : Phenytoin is highly bound to plasma protien and thus has low volume of distribution.

Option 4 : This is a false statement, phenytoin inhibits glucose-stimulated insulin secretion by interfering with Ca2+ uptake via voltage-gated Ca2+ channels.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 393.

questions.text: Agent not used for prophylaxis of migraine:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Ethosuximide

Among the given options, Ethosuximide is not used for prophylaxis of migraine.

* Management of migraine:


* Migraine prophylaxis:


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 195.

questions.text: It is prohibited to use MAO inhibitors with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Pethidine
 
  • Pethidine undergoes hydrolysis and is excreted in the kidney. Some amount (1%) is metabolized by Dealkylation into Normeperidine which then undergoes hydrolysis.
  • MAO inhibitors block this hydrolysis leading to accumulation of toxic Normeperidine which is neurotoxic.
Thus, MAO inhibitors are contraindicated with Pethidine.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 482.

questions.text: Serotonin syndrome cannot be precipitated by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Chlorpromazine
 
  • The typical antipsychotic drugs have potent dopamine D2 receptor blocking property and produce extrapyramidal motor side effects.
  • CPZ produces indifference to surroundings, paucity of thought, psychomotor slowing, emotional quietening, reduction in initiative and tendency to go off to sleep from which the subject is easily arousable.
  • Spontaneous movements are minimized but slurring of speech, ataxia or motor incoordination does not occur.
  • This is mostly perceived to be unpleasant and has been referred to as the ‘neuroleptic syndrome’.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 464, 488.

questions.text: Which is the most common congenital anomaly associated with lithium use in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Cardiac Malformations

Cardiac Malformations (especially Ebstein Anomaly) are most commonly associated with using Lithium in pregnancy.
 
  • Valproate and carbamazepine have been linked to NTDs, especially spina bifida. 
  • Fetal hydantoin syndrome is a characteristic pattern of mental and physical birth defects that results from maternal use of the anti-seizure (anticonvulsant) drug phenytoin (Dilantin) during pregnancy.
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 476.

questions.text: What is the name of the centrally acting alpha 2 agonist muscle relaxant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Tizanidine

Tizanidine is an FDA-approved drug for managing spasticity. It is a centrally acting alpha-2 receptor agonist. Tizanidine effectively works with spasticity caused by multiple sclerosis, an acquired brain injury, or a spinal cord injury.

* [Extra Edge]: Muscle Relaxant



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 384.

questions.text: The drug that is used for Narcoanalysis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Scopolamine

* The drugs used for Narcoanalysis includes the following:
  1. Hyoscine/ Scopolamine
  2. Sodium thiopental
  3. Amobarbital /Amytal Sodium

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 132.

questions.text: Which of the following medications' withdrawal can result in anxiety and insomnia leading to discontinuation syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Venlafaxine
 
  • Venlafaxine is an SNRI, a type of medication that can cause anxiety, insomnia and other adverse reactions if stopped suddenly.
  • SNRIs have similar side effects to SSRIs, including nausea, constipation, insomnia, headaches, and sexual dysfunction.
  • Higher doses of the immediate release form of venlafaxine can cause high blood pressure, but this is lowered when taken in extended-release form.
  • Venlafaxine is the shortest acting SNRI therefore has withdrawal symptoms.
  • Duloxetine, another SNRI, does not have this same side effect.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 489.

questions.text: Identify the additional mechanism of action of tramadol apart from its regular function like all opioids, where it acts as an analgesic drug by stimulating M opioid receptors.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Serotonin and nor-adrenaline reuptake inhibitor

  • A synthetic codeine analogue called tramadol is used to relieve mild to moderate acute pain.
  • In an FDC format, it is combined with acetaminophen to provide analgesia.
  • As a result, it is ineffective for treating persistent or severe pain.
* It is an enantiomer racemic combination. In addition to µ receptor agonism, it is an agonist at the alpha 2 receptor and prevents serotonin and norepinephrine from being reabsorbed.
  • Dextro (+) enantiomer--- µ agonist and inhibits serotonin reuptake
  • Levo (-) enantiomer ----Alpha 2 agonist and inhibits norepinephrine reuptake

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 504.

choices.text: Retching and vomiting will be the symptoms

questions.text: Which of these are the clinical features of a patient who was on 3 ml of Morphine epidurally until one day, when the nurse accidentally gave 12 ml of morphine epidurally
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 4) Urinary retention
 
  • When morphine is injected epidurally, it first settles in the epidural space around sacral segments due to gravity.
  • This phenomenon will occur even if the dose is increased from 3 ml to 12 ml.
  • Therefore, urinary retention will always be seen as urinary bladder is innervated by sacral spinal nerves.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 501.

questions.text: What are its other actions besides Tramadol providing sedation by its action on M opioid receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 5HT and NE uptake inhibitor
  • A synthetic codeine analogue called tramadol is used to relieve mild to moderate acute pain. In an FDC, it is combined with acetaminophen to provide analgesia.
  • As a result, it is ineffective for treating persistent or severe pain.
* It is an enantiomer racemic combination. In addition to µ receptor agonism, it is an agonist at the alpha 2 receptor and prevents serotonin and norepinephrine from being reabsorbed.
 
  • Dextro (+) enantiomer -- µ agonist and inhibits serotonin reuptake
  • Levo(-) enantiomer -- Alpha 2 agonist and inhibits norepinephrine reuptake

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 504.

questions.text: Topiramate is used to treat which of the following conditions:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) Lennox-Gastaut syndrome
 
  • FDA approved it as initial monotherapy (in patients at least 10 years old) and as adjunctive therapy (for patients as young as 2 years) for focal-onset or primary generalized tonic-clonic seizures, for Lennox-Gastaut syndrome in patients 2 years of age and older, and for migraine prophylaxis in adults.
  • MOA- It activates a hyperpolarizing K+ current, decreases voltage-gated Na+ currents in cerebellar granule cells, enhances postsynaptic GABA-A receptor currents, and restricts activation of the AMPA-kainate subtype(s) of glutamate receptors. Carbonic anhydrase's weak inhibitor.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 447.

choices.text: Can be initiated in minimally motivated person
When used with alcohol, the patient feels drowsiness, chest discomfort and respiratory depression
It’s action persists for 2~3 days after stopping the drug

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Disulfiram is correct
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) When used with alcohol, the patient feels drowsiness, chest discomfort and respiratory depression
 
  • Disulfiram used with alcohol causes patient to feel drowsiness, chest discomfort & respiratory depression.
  • Disulfiram is given to highly motivated patients. It is an aversive agent. It inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase leading to increase in concentration of acetaldehyde which causes: Drowsiness Chest discomfort Respiratory depression.
  • Its action persists for upto 2 weeks after stopping it.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 421.

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants is the least likely to cause sexual dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 2) Mirtazapine
 
  • The antidepressant Mirtazapine causes the least sexual dysfunction.
  • SSRIs cause increase in serotonin that stimulates 5HT-2 receptor present in spinal cord and leads to sexual dysfunction such as erectile dysfunction and anorgasmia.
  • 5HT-2 receptor blockers such as mirtazapine do not have this action and hence, are associated with  decreased sexual side effects.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 490.

questions.text: Which one of the following medications is an opioid antitussive
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Levopropoxyphene
 
  • Levopropoxyphene is derived from propoxyphene which is an opioid.
  • Propoxyphene is a racemic mixture of Levo - propoxyphene and dextro - propoxyphene. Levo - propoxyphene is used as an antitussive while dextro - propoxyphene is used as an analgesic.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 239.

questions.text:
Which of the following is used in treatment of both seizures as well as neuropathic pain?
(i) Gabapentin
(ii) Lamotrigine
(iii) Carbamazepine
(iv) Pregabalin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) i, iii, iv

  • Among the given options, Gabapentin, Pregabalin and Carbamazepine are used in the treatment of neuropathic pain and seizures.
  • Gabapentin and pregabalin act by increasing GABA release at synapse by binding to presynaptic calcium channels and blocking endocytosis of calcium.
  • Carbamazepine is a sodium channel blocker. It is the drug of choice in the treatment of partial seizures and trigeminal neuralgia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 446.

questions.text: A patient who had suffered a pelvic fracture and head injuries was given morphine for pain. As a result, he started having trouble breathing. What might be the reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) CO2 retention due to opioid use

CO2 retention due to opioid use is the cause for respiratory difficulty.

* Morphine use in head injury causes:
  • i. Respiratory depression
  • ii. Increases CO2
  • iii. Increases ICT
  • iv. Miosis
Therefore, use of morphine in cases of head injury is contraindicated.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 499.

questions.text:
Which of the following medications are used to treat absence seizures?
A. Carbamazepine
B. Valproate
C. Ethosuximide
D. Gabapentin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) B and C only
 
  • Valproate and ethosuximide are the drugs used for absence seizures.
  • Most preferred drugs in absence seizures are those which have calcium channel blocking property. 
  • Valproate is used for atypical absence seizure
  • Ethosuximide is used for Typical absence seizure

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 390.

questions.text:
Match the following drugs with their antidotes.
A. Heparin 1. Levocarnitine
B. Ethylene glycol 2. Protamine
C. Hydrofluoric acid 3. Fomepizole
D. Valproate 4. Calcium gluconate
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

* Drug Effect Antidote:
  • Heparin Excessive Bleeding = Protamine
  • Ethylene glycol Metabolic Acidosis= Fomepizole
  • Hydrofluoric Acid Electrolyte Abnormality = Calcium gluconate
  • Valproate Hyperammonemia = Levocarnitine

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 167.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct
A. Morphine used in pulmonary oedema
B. Pethidine used in biliary colic
C. Indomethacin is used in headache
D. Aspirin used in peptic ulcer
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) A, B, & C

* Morphine
  • i. Used in pulmonary oedema as it transfers blood from pulmonary to systemic circulation.
  • ii. Used in MI as it decreases preload as well as pain.
  • iii. Decreases sympathetic outflow
  • iv. Contraindicated in biliary colic.
* Pethidine
  • i. Has anticholinergic properties.
  • ii. Used in colicky abdominal pains
  • iii. Relaxes the spasm of biliary sphincter
* Indomethacin
  • i. Preferred for paroxysmal hemicrania
  • ii. Side effect causes frontal headache Aspirin is not used in peptic ulcer cases.
* Aspirin causes peptic ulcer due to COX-1 inhibition-> less prostaglandin production, which act as barrier against gastric acid.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 213.

questions.text:
Which of the following medications will aggravate myasthenia gravis?
A. Lidocaine
B. Meropenem
C. Phenytoin
D. Digene
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) A & D only
 
  • Drugs that will worsen myasthenia gravis are lidocaine and digene.
  • Lidocaine decreases the sensitivity of the postsynaptic membrane to acetylcholine and Antacids like digene may interfere with neuromuscular transmission and hence may lead to worsening of MG.
* Drugs which aggravate myasthenia gravis include:

Aminoglycosides, beta-blockers, LAs, Magnesium (present in digene ), non-depolarizing muscle relaxants and quinine.
 

Here’s a simplified table of drugs to avoid in Myasthenia Gravis along with a mnemonic to remember them:

Drug Class/Example Drugs to Avoid
Aminoglycosides - Gentamicin- Tobramycin
Beta-blockers - Propranolol- Atenolol
Calcium Channel Blockers - Verapamil- Diltiazem
Chloroquine/Hydroxychloroquine - Chloroquine- Hydroxychloroquine
Magnesium Salts - Magnesium sulfate
Quinidine (Antiarrhythmic) - Quinidine
Phenytoin (Anticonvulsant) - Phenytoin
Sedatives (Benzodiazepines) - Diazepam- Lorazepam

Mnemonic: "ABC's Can Cause Myasthenic Problems Quickly"

  • A = Aminoglycosides
  • B = Beta-blockers
  • C = Calcium channel blockers
  • C = Chloroquine/Hydroxychloroquine
  • M = Magnesium salts
  • P = Phenytoin
  • Q = Quinidine
  • S = Sedatives (Benzodiazepines)
Online Reference:
Sheikh S, Alvi U, Soliven B, Rezania K. Drugs That Induce or Cause Deterioration of Myasthenia Gravis: An Update. J Clin Med. 2021 Apr 6;10(7):1537. doi: 10.3390/jcm10071537. PMID: 33917535; PMCID: PMC8038781.

questions.text: A patient is receiving ongoing anticonvulsant treatment. The visual field is gradually contracting. The following anti-epileptic drug is most likely to blame for the side effect:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Vigabatrin

The likely anti-epileptic drug responsible for the adverse effect is vigabatrin.
A common side effect in case of vigabatrin consumption is the involvement of optic nerve that may lead to progressive contractility of visual field.
* Visual field changes as a rare ocular side effect is seen in case of:
  • Vigabatrin
  • Chloroquine (paracentral scotoma is seen)
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 448.

questions.text: Identify the one that is not a prodrug.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Primidone

Primidone among following is not a prodrug.

Primidone acts both directly and through its metabolites
This means that Primidone itself is active and also produce active metabolites.

Active compounds of other options: -
5FU- 5dUMP
Proguanil- cycloguanil
Sulindac- sulindac sulfide

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 443.

choices.text: Alprazolam 1/2 mg one tab HS for 7 days
Alprazolam 0.5mg one tab at bedtime for 7 days

questions.text: How would you correctly prescribe Alprazolam if you were a medical professional?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Alprazolam 0.5mg one tab at bedtime for 7 days

Abbreviations like OD(once a day) or HS(at bedtime/before sleep) are to be avoided in prescriptions. More over dose of medicine is written in decimal not in fraction.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 1146.

questions.text: Anti-emetics were administered to the patient who was vomiting. After the patient's symptoms were eased, strange motions later developed. What medication is recommended to lessen the movements?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Benzhexol

The given clinical vignette describes the condition called Drug induced Parkinsonism. Here in the question it has been mentioned that the patient was administered an anti emetic drug following which he/ she developed movements. This implies that the person was given D2 receptor antagonist ( Eg PROCHLORPERAZINE, METOCLOPRAMIDE ) as Anti emetic drug following which he developed extra pyramidal symptoms.

A general rule is that when the dopamine levels in brain falls as a reflex the cholinergic levels rise in our bodies. Hence the treatment of Drug induced parkinsonism involves the administration of drugs which can reduce the excess cholinergic activity.

* DOC FOR DRUG INDUCED PARKINSONISM/DRUG INDUCED DEVELOPMENT OF EXTRAPYRAMIDAL SYMPTOMS :- Benztropine, Trihexyphenidyl

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 460.

questions.text: Which anticonvulsant results in loss of the bilateral concentric visual field?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) vigabatrin

Visual loss is commonly seen as a side effect in Vigabatrin

[TRICK – Visual field loss – V – Vigabatrin ]

COMMON SIDE EFFECTS SEEN WITH ANTICONVULSANT DRUGS :-
 
  • CARBAMAZEPINE – Diplopia
  • PHENYTOIN – Diplopia
  • TOPIRAMATE- Glaucoma
  • VIGABATRIN- Visual Field Defects

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 448.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below can be applied as a transcranial patch to treat Parkinson's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Rotigotine
 
  • Rotigotine can be used as a transcranial patch for the treatment of Parkinson’s disease.
  • It is a dopamine agonist that works on the nervous system to help treat the symptoms of Parkinson disease.
  • Rotigotine is also used to treat a condition called Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS).
  • Rotigotine should not be stopped abruptly because sudden withdrawal of Dopaminergic agonists has been associated with a syndrome resembling neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 418.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who first had weakness in his right lower limb then, within a year, in his left lower limb. He has been experiencing distal upper limb weakness, increased tone, and rapid reflexes in the last two months. Neither sensory loss nor bladder dysfunction have a history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) ALS

 
* CLINICAL MANIFESTATIONS:
 
  • Asymmetric weakness that slowly develops and usually manifests itself distally in one of the limbs. 
  • Sudden onset of cramping during voluntary movements, usually in the early morning (e.g., while stretching in bed). 
  • Muscle atrophy and progressive muscular withering.
  • fasciculations, or the spontaneous twitching of motor units, early in the illness. 
  • Extensor weakness predominates over flexor weakness in the hands. 
  • Early denervation affects bulbar muscles as opposed to limb muscles, and the condition initially manifests as difficulty chewing, swallowing, and moving the face and tongue. 
  • Muscle-stretch reflexes are overactive (tendon jerks), and there is frequently spastic resistance to passive motions of the affected limbs. 
  • Muscle stiffness frequently outweighs weakness. 
  • Cognitive, digestive and bladder, and sensory functioning are unaffected.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 3410.

questions.text: A 72-year-old guy who has healthy kidney function shows up with recent-onset focal seizures. Which of the following medications is ideal for treating the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Oxcarbazepine
 
  • Among the options provided, oxcarbazepine is the best drug to manage this old patient with normal renal functions and new onset focal seizures.
  • Partial seizure will now be addressed as focal seizure.
  • Drugs to be used for its management are in order of preference Lamotrigine > Oxcarbazepine-Carbamazepine > Phenytoin > Levetiracetam. The change in deciding the best drug is based on side effects and efficacy profile.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 442.

questions.text: A young man with known history of heroin addiction is brought in the emergency in an unconscious state by friends. On examination his pupil are pin point. What will be the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) IV naloxone
 
  • Heroine is diacetylmorphine. In case of opioid overdose IV Naloxone is used as treatment of choice.
  • Naloxone is the drug of choice for morphine poisoning (0.4–0.8 mg i.v. every 2–3 min: max 10 mg) and for reversing neonatal asphyxia due to opioid use during labor (10 µg/kg in the cord).
  • It is also used to treat overdose with other opioids and agonist-antagonists (except buprenorphine). Repeated doses of naloxone are needed because of its short duration of action.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 512.

questions.text: Which antiepileptic medicine among the following works by opening the Cl- channel?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Tiagabine 
 
  • Tiagabine is an antiepileptic medication that works by selectively inhibiting the reuptake of GABA by the GABA transporter-1 (GAT-1) in the brain.
  • By inhibiting GABA reuptake, tiagabine increases the concentration of GABA in the synaptic cleft, leading to enhanced GABAergic neurotransmission.
  • Increased GABA levels can result in the opening of Cl- channels, hyperpolarization of neurons, and overall inhibition of neuronal activity, which can help prevent seizures.
Trick: -
TiaGABINe- meaning GABA reuptake INhibitor



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 429.

questions.text: Which of the following behaviours is exclusive to opioid receptors of the \(\mu\)[mu] type?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Pupillary constriction
 
  • Pupillary constriction (miosis) is primarily associated with the activation of opioid receptors of the mu type.
  • When mu opioid receptors are activated by opioid medications or endogenous opioids, they can cause the muscles in the iris of the eye to constrict, resulting in pupillary constriction.
  • This effect is commonly observed with mu opioid agonists, such as morphine and other opioids.
  • Supraspinal analgesia, dysphoria, and constipation can be associated with the activation of both mu (μ) and other opioid receptor types, such as delta (δ) and kappa (κ) receptors.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 507.

questions.text: Except for______, all of the following are known side effects of Phenytoin at therapeutic dosages.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Hypoglycemia
 
  • Phenytoin primarily affects the central nervous system and does not directly interfere with blood glucose regulation or the production and release of insulin.
  • While phenytoin can have various effects on the body, hypoglycemia is not a commonly reported side effect of the phenytoin at therapeutic dosages.
* Other options:
  • Long-term use of Phenytoin can interfere with folic acid metabolism, leading to megaloblastic anemia.
  • Phenytoin can cause gingival overgrowth or hypertrophy, leading to swollen and enlarged gums.
  • Prolonged use of Phenytoin has been associated with an increased risk of osteoporosis and decreased bone mineral density.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 441.

questions.text: What is an inverse agonist of the benzodiazepine receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Beta-carboline
 
  • Benzodiazepine receptors are found in the central nervous system and are targets for medications such as benzodiazepines, which are commonly used as sedatives, anxiolytics, and anticonvulsants.
  • An inverse agonist is a type of ligand that binds to the same receptor as an agonist but produces the opposite effect, reducing the constitutive activity of the receptor.
  • Beta-carbolines, including compounds such as Hermine and harmaline, act as inverse agonists of the benzodiazepine receptor.
  • They can produce anxiogenic (anxiety-promoting) effects and counteract the sedative and anxiolytic effects of benzodiazepines.
  • Beta-carbolines can be found in certain plants and are structurally different from benzodiazepines, but they interact with the same receptor.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 429.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about pethidine or meperidine is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Has pronounced Antitussive action
 
  • Pethidine or meperidine is an opioid analgesic commonly used for pain relief.
  • While pethidine does have antimuscarinic effects (option A), meaning it can block the actions of acetylcholine, leading to potential side effects such as dry mouth, urinary retention, and blurred vision
  •  It does not have pronounced antitussive action (option C).
  • Antitussive medications are used to suppress or relieve coughing.
  • Pethidine is known for its analgesic properties and its ability to relieve pain, but it is not considered a primary antitussive medication.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 503.

questions.text: Which of the following side effects is seen more with Oxcarbazepine than Carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
Hyponatremia is more commonly seen with oxcarbazepine than with Carbamazepine.
It can cause SIADH resulting in water retention causing Hyponatremia.
