Other side effects are -SJS, Aplastic anemia and hepatotoxicity.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No: 442.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used in Peripheral Neuropathy, Spinal cord injury and post herpetic Neuralgia?
questions.solution:
Pregabalin is an anti epileptic, its analgesia is due to binding to Alpha2 a protein that is subunit of voltage gated Calcium channel causes decrease in glutamate release.
It can be used in Diabetic Neuropathy, Post Herpetic Neuralgia, Spinal cord Injury.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition, Page No: 72, 1357, 2879.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man joins a pilgrimage to a shrine at a mountain peak. At the summit, he develops tightness in the chest, associated with breathlessness and altered sensorium. Which of the following can be given for symptomatic relief?
questions.solution:
This patient developed acute mountain sickness (AMS) due to rapid ascent to high altitude. The fall in atmospheric oxygen pressure leads to hypoxemia, causing cerebral and pulmonary edema, manifesting as headache, breathlessness, chest tightness, and altered sensorium.

Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, is the drug of choice for both prevention and treatment of acute mountain sickness.

Mechanism of action:

  • Causes metabolic acidosis by increasing renal bicarbonate excretion.

  • This stimulates hyperventilation, improving arterial oxygenation.

  • Also acts as a mild diuretic, reducing cerebrospinal fluid formation and intracranial pressure.

Other options:

  • Diltiazem: Calcium channel blocker, used for hypertension or angina, not AMS.

  • Digoxin: Cardiac glycoside for heart failure, not useful here.

  • Mannitol: Osmotic diuretic used for raised intracranial pressure due to other causes, not indicated for AMS.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used to prevent breast engorgement and pain in the mother following death of the neonate?
questions.solution:
• Dopamine regulates prolactin secretion in the body.
  • Dopamine released from the hypothalamus into the hypophyseal portal blood supply acts on lactotroph D2 receptors to decrease prolactin secretion.
  • Hence DA agonists like bromocriptine and cabergoline are used in conditions requiring suppression of prolactin.
Reference: Katzung Basic and clinical Pharmacology, 14th Edition, Page No 679.

questions.text: Cannabinoid oil is not indicated in_______
questions.solution:
• Cannabinoid oil is an oral deriative of the cannabis plant.
  • FDA has approved it use in treatment of seizures associated with
  1. Tuberous sclerosis,
  2. Dravet syndrome and
  3. Lennox Gastaut syndrome.
It is not indicated in RETT syndrome.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page No 514.

questions.text: A patient underwent a hysterectomy and was given morphine in the post-operative period and in the ward for pain. She now presents with respiratory depression and pin point pupils. What is the drug used to treatThis condition?
questions.solution:
Naloxone is a competitive antagonist at mu-opioid receptors and quickly reverses opioid toxicity effects when given. It is the drug of choice for addressing opioid overdose, characterized by a triad of coma, respiratory depression, and pinpoint pupils (miosis), along with hypotension, bradycardia, shallow breathing, and hypothermia. While naloxone is a pure opioid antagonist that counteracts all effects of opioid toxicity except sedation, it is also employed to reverse neonatal asphyxia caused by opioid use during labor.


 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 213-218,166,449-456,461 .

questions.text: Which is a rare but very severe side effect of clozapine that requires regular monitoring?
questions.solution:
Agranulocytosis, though rare, is a severe side effect of clozapine that necessitates regular monitoring. Patients on clozapine should undergo consistent hematological checks due to the risk of agranulocytosis and should avoid combining clozapine with other drugs that can cause agranulocytosis, such as carbamazepine, phenytoin, propylthiouracil, and sulfonamides.

The adverse effects of clozapine include:

Sedation and weight gain due to H1 receptor antagonism

Syncope, tachycardia, and hypotension from alpha-1 receptor antagonism

Hypersalivation/sialorrhea caused by M4 receptor agonism

Seizures, which are dose-dependent

Agranulocytosis, which is dose-independent


Clozapine can lower the seizure threshold, thereby increasing the risk of seizures. As an atypical antipsychotic, clozapine acts as an antagonist at 5HT2A, D1, D3, D4, and alpha receptors. It is used for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, suicidal patients with schizophrenia, severe psychotic depression, and Huntington‘s disease.

 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 381 .

questions.text: Which of the following drugs cannot be prescribed in a patient suffering from coronary heart disease and migraine?
questions.solution:
Triptans are selective 5HT 1B/1D agonists. They are indicated in the management of acute attacks of migraine. They act by arresting the nociceptive nerve signalling in the trigeminovascular system. They also act by causing vasoconstriction of vessels. Hence it is contraindicated in cases of prior MI, CVA, peripheral vascular disease, ischemic bowel disease,hemiplegic or basilar migraine.

Ergotamine should not be used in CAD patients because of its vasoconstriction and ischemic side effects. 

Therefore both Sumatriptan & Ergotamine is C/I in CAD

Lasmiditan is an 5HT1F agonist which acts similar to Triptans but with no s/e of vasoconstriction; therefore can be used in HTN/CAD patients

Ref- Goodman and Gillman 13th edition Page 232-233

questions.text: Following Haloperidol administration a patient developed deviation deviation of eyes, inability to open mouth, and torticollis. What is the first-line management of this case?
questions.solution:
The given Clinical scenario of occulogyric crisis, torticolis and this is is suggestive of haloperidol induced extrapyramidal syndrome that occurs due to the antagonism of dopamine D2 receptors. The first-line treatment for antipsychotic-induced acute dystonia is diphenhydramine.
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition •
Page no 290

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient who is migraine prophylaxis presented with sudden onset right eye pain associated with blurring of vision and also gives history of seeing rainbow coloured halos in her visual field. On Evaluation she was found to have shallow anterior chamber and raised intraoccukar pressure. Which of the following drugs has led to the following condition
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma. Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug that blocks the voltage-gated Na+ channels. Apart from that, it activates hyperpolarizing K* channels, increases GABA activity, and blocks glutamate AMPA-kainate receptors. It is known to cause ciliochoroidal effusion leading to angle closure glaucoma. treatment would consist of reducing the intraocular pressure and stopping the causative drug. Other side effects include weight loss and renal stones.
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition • Page no. 315, 316, 318-319

choices.text: Both T and L type calcium channel inhibitor

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Ethosuxamide
questions.solution: Ethosuxamide is the drug of choice in abscence seizures. It acts by blocking the T type calcium channels . These channels are activated at a much lower threshold and produce larger currents as compared to most other calcium channels in the brain. Hence, inhibition of these T-type calcium currents in the neurons of the thalamus by ethosuximide is effective for the management of absence seizures. Ref Ref - KD Tripathi Essentials of Medical Pharmacology 8th edition Page 443,449

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency room in a drowsy state after taking an overdose of his sleeping pills. His medical history includes insomnia for which he was on alprazolam. Which of the following medications will you administer to this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient took an overdose of alprazolam, a benzodiazepine.

  • Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine receptor (GABA-A receptor site) and is the specific antidote for benzodiazepine overdose.

  • It rapidly reverses CNS depression, drowsiness, and respiratory depression caused by benzodiazepines.

Other options:

  • 2. Naloxone → Opioid receptor antagonist, used in opioid overdose (e.g., morphine, heroin), not useful in benzodiazepine poisoning.

  • 3. Naltrexone → Long-acting opioid antagonist, used for maintenance therapy in opioid and alcohol dependence, not for acute overdose.

  • 4. Nalmefene → Another opioid receptor antagonist, used in opioid overdose and alcohol dependence, but not effective for benzodiazepine toxicity.


Reference :
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition - Page no 346, 376, 377, 384

questions.text: A male presented with the following findings which he noticed when he woke up in the morning. There was no history of associated fever or rash. What is the drug of choice for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with acute onset unilateral facial weakness upon waking, without fever or rash, which is characteristic of Bell’s palsy (idiopathic facial nerve palsy).

  • First-line treatment: Corticosteroids (Prednisone)

    • Mechanism: Reduces inflammation and edema of the facial nerve, improving recovery.

    • Most effective if started within 72 hours of symptom onset.

Other options:

  • Gabapentin: Used for neuropathic pain, not primary treatment for Bell’s palsy.

  • Paracetamol: Symptomatic relief for pain/fever; does not treat underlying nerve inflammation.

  • NSAIDs: May relieve pain, but no effect on nerve recovery.


Reference
PL Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery 7th edition - Page no 104

questions.text: A male presented with complains of decreased sexual desire. He was recently diagnosed with depression and started ona drug for the same. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with decreased sexual desire after starting an antidepressant.

  • Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), which commonly causes sexual dysfunction including:

    • Decreased libido

    • Delayed ejaculation

    • Anorgasmia

  • These side effects are dose-dependent and can occur in both males and females.

Other options:

  • Trazodone: Can actually improve sexual function and is sometimes used to treat SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction.

  • Bupropion: Has a low risk of sexual side effects, may even improve sexual desire.

  • Mirtazapine: Less likely to cause sexual dysfunction compared to SSRIs.


Reference
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition - Page no 273

choices.text: Manage the fever and wait for seizure to subside
Manage the airway and wait for seizure to subside

questions.text: A child presents with a fever and continuing seizures for the past 30 minutes. The relatives say that there had been no seizure-free intervals in the past 30 minutes. What is the next best step to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
• The child is experiencing status epilepticus: continuous seizure activity lasting >5 minutes or recurrent seizures without recovery between them.

  • Immediate management is critical to prevent neuronal injury, hypoxia, and systemic complications.

  • First-line treatment: Benzodiazepines (e.g., midazolam, lorazepam, diazepam) given immediately to stop the seizure.

    • Midazolam can be given IV, IM, or intranasally for rapid effect.

  • Airway, breathing, and circulation (ABC) should be assessed concurrently.

Other options:

  • Manage fever and wait: Delaying seizure control is dangerous; seizures >5 min require urgent intervention.

  • Clobazam: Not first-line for acute status epilepticus; slower onset.

  • Manage airway and wait: Airway support is important, but seizure termination with benzodiazepine must not be delayed.



Reference
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition - Page no 322

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital following a road traffic accident. The patient was disoriented. CT head showed no evidence of hemorrhage, but features of cerebral edema and raised intracranial pressure was seen. Which of the following drugs can be used for the initial management of raised intracranial pressure?
questions.solution:
Mannitol is the drug of choice for the initial management of raised intracranial pressure (ICP) due to cerebral edema, particularly in acute settings such as trauma, stroke, or intracerebral pathology.

Mechanism of Action of Mannitol:

  • Osmotic diuretic: Mannitol increases plasma osmolality.

  • Draws water out from brain parenchyma into the intravascular compartment.

  • This reduces intracranial pressure and brain volume.

    Why other options are incorrect:

  • 1. Furosemide
    – A loop diuretic, can be used adjunctively with mannitol but is not preferred alone for initial ICP management.
    – Slower onset and less potent in reducing brain edema acutely.

  • 2. Glycerol
    – Oral osmotic agent, used in chronic management of raised ICP (e.g., in glaucoma or chronic hydrocephalus), not suitable in acute trauma.

  • 3. Acetazolamide
    – A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor; used to reduce CSF production in benign intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri).
    – Acts slowly and is not effective for emergency ICP reduction.


Reference:Current Diagnosis and treatment:Surgery 14th edition page no 855-856

questions.text: The parents of a 9-year-old girl have noticed their often staring blankly which is at times, associated with chewing movements. There were also complaints of daydreaming and a decline in school performance. During the episodes, she did not have a problem with maintaining her posture, and there were no generalised tonic and clonic movements. Which of the following is a first-line agent to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Seizure Type Clinical Features First-Line Drug(s)
Focal Seizures (Partial) Begin in one hemisphere; may be with or without awareness Carbamazepine, Lamotrigine, Levetiracetam, Oxcarbazepine
Generalized Tonic-Clonic Loss of consciousness, tonic (stiff) then clonic (jerking) phase Valproate, Lamotrigine, Levetiracetam
Absence Seizures Sudden brief loss of awareness; staring spells; no postictal state Ethosuximide (children), Valproate (adults)
Myoclonic Seizures Brief, shock-like jerks, often in the morning Valproate, Levetiracetam
Atonic Seizures Sudden loss of muscle tone, "drop attacks" Valproate, Lamotrigine, Rufinamide
Tonic Seizures Sudden stiffening of muscles, often during sleep Valproate, Lamotrigine
 

Case Summary:

  • 9-year-old girl with:

    • Episodes of blank staring

    • Chewing movements (automatisms)

    • Complaints of daydreaming

    • Decline in school performance

    • No loss of posture or tonic-clonic movement


    • Interpretation:

This is a classical case of absence seizures (also known as petit mal seizures), commonly seen in children:

  • Sudden onset and offset

  • Short duration (seconds)

  • Automatisms (e.g., lip-smacking, chewing)

  • No postictal confusion

  • Child remains upright (no loss of tone)

The EEG hallmark:
3 Hz generalized spike-and-wave discharges

First-line treatment options for absence seizures

Drug Role in Absence Seizures
Sodium Valproate First-line (especially if other types of seizures are also present)
Ethosuximide First-line (especially if pure absence seizures)
Clonazepam Not first-line (sedating, used in refractory cases)
Carbamazepine May worsen absence seizures
Phenytoin Ineffective or may worsen them

Other options: 

  • Clonazepam – May help in refractory cases, but is not first-line due to sedation and tolerance.

  • Carbamazepine – Exacerbates absence seizures; used in focal seizures, not generalized.

  • Phenytoin – Not effective in absence seizures.



Reference: Harrisons principles of internal medicine 19th edition page no 2543.

questions.text: What dose of folic acid is recommended for a woman who wants to become pregnant but has a history of pregnancy complicated with a neural tube defect?
questions.solution:
For women with a history of a previous pregnancy affected by a neural tube defect (NTD), the recommended dose of folic acid is significantly higher than the standard dose.

Risk Category Recommended Folic Acid Dose Duration
Low risk (general population) 400 mcg/day (0.4 mg/day) At least 1 month before conception & through the first trimester
High risk (previous NTD pregnancy) 4 mg/day At least 1 month before conception & through the first trimester
 

High-dose folic acid (4 mg/day) has been shown to significantly reduce the recurrence risk of neural tube defects in subsequent pregnancies.

 
Risk Category Folic Acid Dose Start Time Duration
Low risk (no personal or family history of NTD) 400 mcg/day ≥1 month before conception Through 1st trimester (12 weeks)
Previous NTD-affected pregnancy 4 mg/day ≥1 month before conception Through 1st trimester
On antiepileptic drugs (e.g. valproate, carbamazepine) 4 mg/day ≥1 month before conception Through 1st trimester
Diabetes mellitus (pre-gestational) 4 mg/day ≥1 month before conception Through 1st trimester
Obesity (BMI ≥ 30 kg/m²) 4 mg/day (some guidelines suggest 5 mg) ≥1 month before conception Through 1st trimester
Multiple gestation (twins, triplets) 1 mg/day ≥1 month before conception Through 1st trimester
Family history of NTD (first-degree relative) 4 mg/day ≥1 month before conception Through 1st trimester


Reference:Goodman and Gillmans The pharmacological basis of Therapeutics 13th edition page no 766

questions.text: Haloperidol (5 mg) was initiated as a treatment for schizophrenia in a young male patient. He arrived at the hospital with his father on the third day, his eyes rolling upward. There were no signs of spasticity or other abnormalities after a thorough neurological evaluation. It was discovered that visual acuity was normal. The most likely conclusion is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Acute dystonia

The clinical scenario in question describes Oculogyric crisis.

* Oculogyric Crisis
Oculogyric crisis (OGC) is the name of a dystonic reaction to certain drugs (mostly antidopaminergic drugs like Haloperidol) characterized by a prolonged involuntary upward deviation of the eyes. It's a type of acute dystonia.



* Audio Explanation:


Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 366.

questions.text: Which of the following medications has no effect on DNA synthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Linezolid
 
  • Linezolid inhibits protein synthesis by attaching to the 50S subunit and preventing the initiation complex formation.
  • Nitrofurantoin acts by damaging bacterial DNA.
  • Metronidazole acts by forming toxic free radicals that damage DNA.
  • Rifampin acts by inhibiting the DNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 807.

questions.text: Which of the following medicines is not utilised in the detoxification of chronic alcoholics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Flumazenil

GABA-A receptor antagonist, flumazenil is typically used intravenously to treat benzodiazepine overdoses and to aid in the reversal of anesthesia. While other medicines play a part in alcohol detoxification, this one does not.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 420.

questions.text: Which of the following is an anti-suicidal mood stabiliser?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Lithium
 
  • Lithium is a mood stabilizer with anti-suicidal properties. It is the DOC in prophylaxis of BPD.
  • It acts by decreasing the levels of excitatory neurotransmitters like Glutamate and increases the activity of GABA. It also downregulates the NMDA receptors.
* Some important values related to lithium


Valproate is given to rapid cyclers in BPD. Carbamazepine and Lamotrigine are also effective in BPD but none of them reduce the suicidal tendencies.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 378.

choices.text: Sodium bicarbonate infusion for alkalization of urine

questions.text: Find out the incorrect statement among the following about the situation where a woman takes a very high dosage of Amitriptyline:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Atropine as an antidote

Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant with additional anti-cholinergic action due to blockage of muscarinic receptors. Administration of atropine will result in further muscarinic block and aggravation of toxicity. Therefore, option D is the incorrect statement. 

Note- The antidote of choice for TCA poisoning is sodium bicarbonate. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 486.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is available in depot form?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fluphenazine
 
  • Fluphenazine decanoate is an antipsychotic medication that is injected into the muscle (i.m.) for long-term treatment of schizophrenia.
  • The injection can be given as a depot injection, which means that the medication is released slowly over time.
  • This type of injection typically needs to be repeated every 2-4 weeks in order to maintain an effective level of the medication in the body over time. The injection should be done by a healthcare professional, such as a doctor or nurse.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 467.

questions.text: A known alcoholic is brought to the emergency department by his wife. The person has not consumed alcohol for the past two days due to religious reasons. The person complained of nausea, vomiting and dizziness. On the second day, he developed seizures, that progressed to generalized tonic clonic seizures (GTCs). Which of the following would be the best medication to manage the seizures of the patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Diazepam
 
  • Antidepressant medications with long-acting abilities, like chlordiazepoxide and diazepam, and those with shorter-acting abilities, such as lorazepam, can be used to safely treat mild to moderate (without major complications) cases of alcohol withdrawal.
  • Chlordiazepoxide is the preferred drug of choice for treating alcohol withdrawal syndrome over diazepam.
* BZDs safe in liver dysfunction: - 
LOve The liver- Lorazepam, Oxazepam, Temazepam 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 494.

questions.text: Anti-craving drug given in alcohol dependence is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Acamprosate
 
  • Acamprosate, marketed under the brand name Campral, is an Anti craving drug used in the treatment of alcohol dependence.
  • It works by blocking the neurochemical pathways that lead to cravings for alcohol and restoring the balance of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and glutamate.
  • It has been shown to be effective in reducing cravings and increasing abstinence from alcohol. Acamprosate has also been found to reduce relapse rates in individuals with a history of heavy drinking.
  • It is thought to be most successful when used in combination with counseling and other treatments for alcohol addiction.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 421.

questions.text: In which of the following do we use the Z tracking technique ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Administering long-acting antipsychotics
 
  • Patients with psychosis or manic episodes who don't adhere to oral medication are administered LAAls i.e long-acting anti-psychotic depot injections. Intramuscular administration is the method of choice.
  • With the exception of the deltoid, all injection sites follow the Z track approach. The skin is pulled laterally away from the injection site before the needle is inserted at a 90° angle. Skin is loosened to allow the dislodged tissue to cover the needle track after 10 seconds of drug injection.
  • It is done to maximize absorption in muscle by preventing the drug from moving back to subcutaneous tissue.
  • This technique is also used to inject iron.
Online Reference: Devrımcı Özgüven H, Kir Y. Long Acting Injectable Antipsychotics in the Treatment of Schizophrenia and Bipolar Disorder. Noro Psikiyatr Ars. 2021 Sep 20;58(Suppl 1):S47-S52. doi: 10.29399/npa.27480. PMID: 34658635; PMCID: PMC8498817.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man and his wife arrive. He believes that he has been a sinner his entire life. He is really depressed and has thought about suicide, but he hasn't figured out how to do it. Additionally, he had sessions scheduled with a spiritual guru. His wife does not agree with him that he has lived a religious life. Anything to the contrary is not what he wants to hear. What will you do with him
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Antipsychotic + Antidepressant

The given clinical vignette describes Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic features.
  • Psychotic features are characterized by guilt occurring in the context of major depressive episode as described in the given question.
  • Treatment: - Antidepressants with Atypical Antipsychotics [A very close similarity to this condition is seen in schizoaffective disorder which is characterized by symptoms of both Schizophrenia and mood disorders.
  • However, patient must have exclusive 14 days of psychotic features without mania / depression]. Here the patient has suicidal ideation which cannot be cured by cognitive behavioral therapy alone. To do so first he needs to be stable with his thoughts.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 360.

questions.text: Which of the following are the key issues to address when thinking about releasing a patient who had TCA treatment for a major depressive episode during a 4-week hospital stay
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Suicidal risk
 
  • Suicidal risk is the main concern while considering discharge. In depressed patients after 2-3 weeks of continuous treatment the mood is gradually elevated.
  • The discharge of patient exposes him to the risk of non-compliance which may lead to relapse of depression and the person may commit suicide.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 487.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used to treat depression
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Vilazodone

Vilazodone is used in the treatment of major depressive disorder. It inhibits serotonin reuptake like SSRIs, and it is also a partial agonist at 5HT1A receptors. Lurasidone controls schizophrenia and depression in people with bipolar disorder but it does not cure these conditions.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 294.

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants should be avoided in a patient with angle closure glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Amitriptyline

  • Angle closure glaucoma occurs when the iris bulges. The bulging iris partially or completely blocks the drainage angle.
  • As a result, fluid can't circulate through the eye and pressure increases. Angle-closure glaucoma may occur suddenly or gradually. T
  • Therefore, anticholinergics are contraindicated in such patients as it will worsen the angle closure by pupillary dilation. Among antidepressants, maximum anticholinergic action is seen with tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) like Amitriptyline, Nortriptyline, Clomipramine, Imipramine.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 483.

questions.text: Which antidepressant is least likely to cause sexual dysfunction, out of the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Mirtazapine
 
  • SSRIs are antidepressants which are most likely to cause sexual side effects e.g. fluoxetine, citalopram.
  • Sexual side effect is caused by 5HT2 stimulation, but Mirtazapine blocks 5HT2 receptor.
  • Thus, it has the least sexual side effect.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 490.

questions.text: Which of the following negative effects is most likely to be brought on by a psychotropic medicine that prevents the reuptake of serotonin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Sexual Dysfunction 
 
  • A psychotropic drug inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin is likely to cause sexual dysfunction.
  • Due to anticholinergic activity, several SSRIs are known to cause dry mouth and impaired vision.
  • The cause of sexual dysfunction and diarrhea is an increase in serotonin brought by reuptake inhibition.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 294.

questions.text: Lithium carbonate was initiated as a treatment for bipolar disorder in a 30-year-old patient. On the side effects of the therapy, the nurse provided instructions. Identify the symptoms upon which the patient must report back.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Tinnitus, severe diarrhea, ataxia
 
  • The patient should report back if the following features are seen- tinnitus, severe diarrhea, and ataxia.
  • Various CNS and GI manifestations are early indications of lithium toxicity.
  • GI manifestations: Diarrhea and vomiting.
  • CNS manifestations: Coarse tremors, drowsiness, muscle weakness, ataxia, blurred vision, and tinnitus.
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 476.

questions.text: When is the monitoring of lithium estimation done for the plasma level?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 12 hours after the last dose
 
  • Lithium's effectiveness is dose-dependent and consistently correlated with serum lithium levels (trough levels).
  • The optimum time to measure trough levels is right before the next dose.
  • Lithium is given in two divided doses in clinical practice, trough levels are best assessed 12 hours following the last dosage.
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 476.

choices.text: Immediately as soon as the last dose given

questions.text: Lithium therapy is continued for a patient with bipolar illness.  When will you, as a doctor, request that the nurse check the serum lithium levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 12 hours after the last dose
 
  • Lithium's effectiveness is dose-dependent and consistently correlated with serum lithium levels (trough levels).
  • The optimum time to measure trough levels is right before the next dose. Lithium is given in two divided doses in clinical practice, trough levels are assessed 12 hours following the last dosage.
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 476.

questions.text: A patient is on Lithium therapy. Which of these clinical symptoms ought the nurse to caution the patient about?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Ataxia, Diarrhea, Tinnitus
 
  • The patient should be cautioned about the following features: tinnitus, severe diarrhea, and ataxia.
  • Various CNS and GI manifestations are early indications of lithium toxicity.
  • GI manifestations: Diarrhea and vomiting.
  • CNS manifestations: Coarse tremors, drowsiness, muscle weakness, ataxia, blurred vision, and tinnitus
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 476.

choices.text: immediately as soon as the last dose given

questions.text: Lithium therapy is continued for a patient with bipolar illness. When will you as a doctor ask the nurse to have the serum lithium levels checked?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 12 hours after the last dose
 
  • Lithium's effectiveness is dose-dependent and consistently correlated with serum lithium levels (trough levels).
  • The optimum time to measure trough levels is right before the next dose. Lithium is given in two divided doses in clinical practice, trough levels are assessed 12 hours following the last dosage.
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 476.

questions.text:
Retigabine is being used to treat a patient with a seizure disorder (focal seizures), although the patient's seizures are not under control at this time.
Which of the following sentences represents the right next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Is (Option 2)  Increase the dose of retigabine
 
  1. Individuals with lower serum protein levels (for example, lower serum albumin due to poor liver or renal function) may have a higher ratio of free to bound drug, but the concentration of free drug may still be sufficient to control seizures in these patients. 
  2. Some patients may have "subtherapeutic" drug levels, but the dose shouldn't be changed solely to get to a "therapeutic" level; it should only be changed if seizures aren't under control. 
  3. It becomes required to switch to another antiepileptic medication if seizures persist after steady increases to the maximum tolerated dose and confirmed compliance.
  4. This is typically accomplished by keeping the patient on the first medication while introducing a second one. 
  5. To reduce seizure frequency without producing toxicity, the dose of the second medication needs to be changed. 
  6. When this is accomplished, the initial medication can be progressively discontinued (usually over weeks unless there is significant toxicity).
Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 421.

questions.text: Off-label uses of Risperidone are all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Bipolar disorder

Risperidone is a second-generation antipsychotic approved by FDA to treat
  • Schizophrenia
  • Bipolar disorder
  • Autism-associated irritability 
  • Resistant depression- in combination with antidepressants
Hence, Bipolar disorder is not an off-label use - rather an approved use of Risperidone.
 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 468.

questions.text: A known case of depressive illness consumed large number of TCA tablets and presented to the Emergency Department with altered sensorium, dryness of mouth, sweating, postural hypotension and urinary retention. ECG was done which showed wide QRS complex. An important step in management of such a patient:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of TCA toxicity. The drug of choice for TCA overdose is sodium bicarbonate. 


Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 62, 158, 271, 273, 276.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1924, 3587.

questions.text: Most effective drug for smoking cessation?
questions.solution:
Varenicline blocks the ability of nicotine to activate its receptors on the brain.
  • It is the most effective drug in smoking cessation.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 185-188, 437.

questions.text: A female patient with previous history of mania 1 year back, who is pregnant now presented with an episode of hypomania. Which of the following drug is to be avoided for being highly teratogenic to the fetus?
questions.solution:
While Valproate/Lithium and Oxcarbamazepine - all three are known to be teratogenic - Valproate is the most teratogenic in nature. Lithium, although it carries some risks, is considered relatively safer compared to valproate.




 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 403,404,376,377 .

questions.text: A patient with persecutory delusions and 3rd person auditory hallucinations was diagnosed as schizophrenic and started on risperidone 2.5 mg daily dose and after the previous night's dose, he today presented with his eyes rolling upward for few hours. What is the next step in the management?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical stem describes an 'Oculogyric crisis' which is an EPS(extrapyramidal side effect) secondary to the use of anti-dopaminergic(anti-psychotic) drugs.
  • The oculogyric crisis is an acute dystonic reaction characterized by the sudden and involuntary upward deviation of the eyes. It is commonly associated with certain medications, particularly antipsychotic drugs such as haloperidol, but can also occur as a symptom of other conditions or drug toxicity.
  • The drug of choice for reversing the symptoms is usually an anticholinergic medication such as benztropine/diphenhydramine or Promethazine. By inhibiting acetylcholine activity, they can help alleviate the dystonic reaction and relieve the oculogyric crisis



 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 290, 291,724 .

questions.text: A 49 year old male with history of alcohol consumption for many years developed liver cirrhosis. LFT of the patient shows GGT: 563 u/L, AST:180 u/L, ALT 150 u/L. Now he has stopped consumption. Which of the following is the most suitable drug to be given to avoid withdrawal symptoms?
questions.solution:
• An alcoholic who has recently stopped consuming is at very high risk for withdrawal symptoms. The DOC for prevention/treatment of alcohol withdrawal is Benzodiazepines. However, in the above scenario - the patient also has features s/o CLD and cirrhosis, and most benzodiazepines being metabolized by the liver are contraindicated. 
  • Among the options provided, Lorazepam (option 1) would be the most suitable choice in this situation. Lorazepam is primarily metabolized in the liver, but it undergoes glucuronidation, which is a different metabolic pathway compared to other benzodiazepines that undergo oxidative metabolism. This means that lorazepam is less dependent on liver enzymes and may have a lower risk of accumulation in individuals with liver impairment. 


Benzodiazepines safe in hepatic failure 

Outside  - Oxazepam
The - Temazepam
Liver - Lorazepam

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3561 .

questions.text: 26y old Surgery Pg student was found lying unconscious in the room with an empty packet of Amitriptyline tablets. Which of the following features is not suggestive of Amitriptyline toxicity?
questions.solution:
• Features of TCA toxicity include Hyperthermia, Coma, Dilated pupils, confusion, dry mouth, urinary retention, tachycardia, myoclonic movements , postural hypotension.
  • Treatment is primarily supportive with gastric lavage, respiratory assistance, fluid infusion, maintenance of BP and body temperature. Acidosis must be corrected by bicarbonate infusion.
  • Diazepam may be injected i.v. to control convulsions and delirium. Most important is the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias, for which propranolol/lidocaine may be used. The class IA and IC antiarrhythmics and digoxin themselves depress cardiac conduction; are therefore contraindicated.
  • f QT prolongation present IV MgSO4 can be given.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 487.

questions.text: Which of the following mood stabilisers cause Hyperammonia and Hepatotoxicity?
questions.solution:
Valproate is an anti epileptic and mood stabiliser, used in bipolar disorder.
It is known to cause Hyperammonia and Microvesicular steatosis thus leading to hepatotoxicity.
Intravenous administration of carnitine can be used to prevent this condition.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 444.

questions.text: 90y old gentleman known case of dementia who frequently forgets to take his oral medicines. Which of the following drugs will help him?
questions.solution:
Rivastigmine transdermal patch can be prescribed in patients with dementia specially who are non compliant on oral medications.

* EXtra EDge: 
In clinical trials an average of 3.8 point improvement in Alzheimer’s Disease Assessment Scale (ADAS-cog) has been obtained compared to placebo. Other symptoms like apathy, delu­ sions, hallucinations and agitation also improve, but to a lesser extent. Disease progression is not affected. Peripheral cholinergic side effects are mild. It has not produced liver damage. Rivastigmine is indicated in mild-to-moderate cases of AD, but not in advanced disease.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 518.

questions.text: A 42-year-old obese female presented to the clinic with Schizophrenia. Which of the following anti-psychotic drugs causes the least weight gain?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 3. Ziprasidone.

Among the atypical antipsychotics listed, Ziprasidone is known to cause the least weight gain compared to other antipsychotics like Chlorpromazine, Clozapine, and Olanzapine. In fact, Olanzapine and Clozapine are associated with significant weight gain(highest with Clozapine) and metabolic side effects, while Chlorpromazine also tends to cause some weight gain.

Ziprasidone, on the other hand, has a more favorable metabolic profile and is less likely to cause significant weight gain, making it a better choice for patients who are at risk for obesity or metabolic syndrome.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male child presented with a episode of convulsions that had been ongoing for 45 minutes. He has a past medical history of GTCS. What would be the most appropriate management in this case? GTCS - Generalized tonic-clonic seizure
questions.solution:
The child is experiencing a prolonged seizure lasting >30 minutes, which qualifies as status epilepticus (SE). Immediate management aims to stop the seizure and prevent complications.

Stepwise management:

  1. First-line (emergency) treatment:

    • Benzodiazepines: Lorazepam IV (or diazepam if IV access is difficult)

    • Rapid onset, enhances GABAergic inhibition → stops seizure promptly

  2. Second-line treatment (if seizures persist):

    • IV antiepileptics: Levetiracetam, valproate, or phenytoin

    • Levetiracetam is preferred in children due to good safety profile and minimal drug interactions

Other options:

  • Valproate/Gabapentin: Not first-line in acute status

  • Carbamazepine: Typically oral, not suitable for acute SE

  • Gabapentin: Adjunctive therapy, not for acute management

It is not absorbed from the stomach

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding lithium?
questions.solution:
Lithium is known to potentially cause fine tremors even when administered within the therapeutic range. Its therapeutic index is very narrow.

A fine tremor is a common side effect at therapeutic doses of lithium. This tremor typically affects the arms symmetrically, is nonprogressive, and does not worsen. In contrast, tremors due to lithium toxicity are coarser, more disabling, may involve the legs, and are accompanied by other signs of toxicity. Additional adverse effects include mental confusion, hypothyroidism, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, and edema. Lithium use during early pregnancy can lead to Ebstein anomaly in the fetus and may result in neonatal goiter, CNS depression, hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), and cardiac murmurs.

In cases of lithium overdose or toxicity, hemodialysis is an effective treatment since lithium is readily dialyzed.

Lithium, a mood stabilizer, is administered orally and is almost completely absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract. It is the first-line treatment for bipolar disorder, including the management of mania, and has anti-suicidal properties. Due to its narrow therapeutic index, monitoring is essential; therapeutic drug levels are measured 12 hours after the last dose to ensure safety and efficacy.


 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 375-380 .

questions.text: A psychiatrist prescribes lithium for a patient who is diagnosed with bipolar disorder. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding lithium?
questions.solution:
Lithium, a small monovalent cation, is used for the treatment of acute mania and for preventing recurrences of bipolar disorder in both adults and adolescents. It acts as a mood stabilizer, reducing the risk of suicide in bipolar patients and is also effective in some cases of unipolar depression that do not respond adequately to antidepressants.

Lithium toxicity can occur when used in conjunction with certain medications, including:

1. Thiazide diuretics (e.g., chlorthalidone) – These diuretics cause sodium loss, which increases proximal tubular reabsorption of both sodium and lithium, leading to a rise in lithium levels.
2. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors
3. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
4. Tetracyclines
5. Loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide)
These medications elevate lithium levels by increasing its tubular reabsorption, thereby reducing its excretion and increasing the risk of toxicity.

Treatment of lithium overdose:

No specific antidote exists.
Osmotic diuretics and sodium bicarbonate infusion can promote lithium excretion.
Hemodialysis is indicated when serum lithium levels exceed 4 mEq/L.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen as a side effect of lithium therapy?
questions.solution:
Lithium, used in bipolar disorder, has several well-known side effects:

  • Hand tremors – fine, postural tremors are common.

  • Polyuria-polydipsia – due to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

  • Hyperreflexia – may occur, especially with mild toxicity.

Tardive dyskinesia is not a side effect of lithium; it is primarily associated with long-term use of antipsychotics (especially typical antipsychotics).

Other options:

  • Hand tremors: Common, dose-related.

  • Polyuria-polydipsia: Due to renal concentrating defect.

  • Hyperreflexia: Can indicate lithium toxicity.



Reference
Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry - 11th Edition , Page no 987

questions.text: A patient with symptoms of psychosis is prescribed aripiprazole. Which of the following best describes this drug, when compared to other antipsychotic drugs?
questions.solution:
Aripiprazole is an atypical antipsychotic with a unique mechanism:

  • It is a partial agonist at D2 receptors — meaning it has low intrinsic activity but high affinity.

  • It modulates dopaminergic activity:

    • Acts as an antagonist in hyperdopaminergic states (e.g., psychosis)

    • Acts as a mild agonist in hypodopaminergic states (e.g., preventing extrapyramidal side effects)

  • Because of this mechanism, it is associated with:

    • Lower risk of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS)

    • Lower risk of weight gain compared to drugs like olanzapine or clozapine

      Why other options are incorrect:

  • Option 1: Aripiprazole does bind to D2 receptors and does not have high EPS.

  • Option 3: It has partial (not "no") intrinsic activity and is less likely to cause weight gain.

  • Option 4: It has high affinity, not low, for D2 receptors.


Reference:Goodman and gillmans The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics 13th edition page no 34

questions.text: Which anaesthetic can cause pain when it is injected into a vein?
questions.solution:

Propofol causes pain on IV administration. Propofol is oil-based preparation containing soybean oil, egg lecithin and glycerol.
As it contains oil so injection is painful and should be preceded or mixed with lignocaine.

questions.text:
A patient with a history of coronary artery disease arrives with a low blood pressure and a pulse rate of 48/min. On echo, the patient's cardiac contractility has diminished.
Which of these anaesthetic substances should not be used?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Can a muscle relaxant be used in a patient with a serum bilirubin level of 6.0 and a creatinine level of 4.5 mg/dL?

questions.text: Propofol was used as an intravenous anaesthetic and succinylcholine as a muscle relaxant during an eye operation. Uncomplicated anaesthetic recovery occurred. However, the patient complained of leg pain when walking eight hours following the surgery. Which of the following explanations is the most likely one?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Succinylcholine

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of post operative myalgia caused by repeated muscular contractions due to succinylcholine.
  • Succinylcholine binds to Ach receptor and causes conformational change in the receptor. Lots of ions are conducted rapidly which produces muscular fasciculations. After a few seconds, time gated Na+ channels close leading to blockade of conduction and eventually muscle relaxation.
  • These initial fasciculations cause post-op myalgia. It can be prevented by giving a small dose of NMDR before Sch. This is known as Precurarization.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 379.

questions.text: What is the maximum dose of lidocaine given with adrenaline for ocular surgery?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about "Scoline Asphyxia"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (Option 2) It is due to deficiency of Cholinesterase
 
  • Scoline Asphyxia occurs due to prolonged effect of Sch due to presence of abnormal variant of Pseudocholinesterase.
  • Qualitative analysis of Pseudocholinesterase is done by calculating Dibucaine number. Normal value is 80 : 20.
  • Quantitative analysis is done by measuring Plasmacholinesterase.

questions.text: Why is 100% oxygen given when nitrous oxide is stopped upon awakening from anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Diffusion hypoxia

  • The procedure is done to prevent diffusion hypoxia.
  • The O2 and CO2 in the alveolus are temporarily diluted by N2O gas while the patient is recovering from the anesthesia because significant amounts of this gas pass from the blood into the alveolus (down its concentration gradient).
  • Hypoxia could result momentarily as a result of this decreasing oxygen partial pressure.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 403.

questions.text: Which of the following medications has no effect on CSF absorption or secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Nitrous oxide
 
  • Thiopentone sodium decreases CNS oxygen utilization, CBF and ICP.
  • Ketamine increases CMRO, CBF and ICP and is relatively contraindicated in cases with an intracranial mass, increased ICP or have suffered recent head trauma.
  • Nitrous oxide increases CBF and cerebral blood volume, resulting in a mild elevation of ICP.
  • Halothane dilates cerebral vessels and increases CBF, however auto regulation is blunted resulting in a rise in ICP.
  • Thus, Nitrous Oxide concludes the best option.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 405.

questions.text: The effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants are enhanced by lithium. How soon should lithium be stopped once the muscle relaxant has been planned to be administered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 2 days
 
  • Lithium tends to potentiate the action of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants given during surgery.
  • In addition, during the perioperative period - dehydration, use of diuretics, and hyponatremia can occur which can exacerbate the toxicity of lithium. 
  • Lithium has a half-life of 18-24 hours - hence it's advised to stop it 48-72 hours prior to surgery or the use of any non-depolarizing muscle relaxants. 
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 474.

questions.text: What is the name of the drug that causes malignant hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Suxamethonium

  • Suxamethonium is the most common drug causing malignant hyperthermia.
  • Other drugs causing malignant hyperthermia are halothane (most common inhalational cause), iso/des/sevo/methoxy – fluranes, lignocaine, TCA, MAO inhibitors and phenothiazines.
  • Thiopentone and pancuronium are protective for malignant hyperthermia, as they raise the triggering threshold.
  • Anesthetics which are safe in malignant hyperthermia include: N2O, non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, opiates, tranquilizers and barbiturates.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 406.

questions.text: Which muscle is affected by tubocurarine first?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Head and neck

  • Tubocurare affects head and neck muscles first. The first muscles that Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants and Non-Depolarizing
  • Muscle Relaxants block are central muscles, which include the muscles of the face, jaw, pharynx, and larynx and muscles of respiration including diaphragm.
  • Sequence of blockade: Face, jaw muscles, pharynx, larynx, intercostals, diaphragm, abdominal muscles, trunk muscles and then peripheral muscles (limb muscles).
  • Recovery proceeds in the same order as blockade. In central muscles, blockage develops faster, lasts for a shorter period of time, and recovers more swiftly. Muscles in the face and limbs recover first and last, respectively.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 122.

questions.text: Suxamethonium is available as a clear, colourless aqueous solution. The shelf-life of suxamethonium is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 2 years
 
  • Succinylcholine chloride (Sch) is a potent and rapid-acting muscle relaxant. It is a dicholine ester of acetylcholine and was first used clinically by Bovet.
  • It is a clear, colorless, aqueous solution with a pH of 3.0-5.0 and has a shelf life of two years when stored at 4°C. Its action is potentiated by opioid and nitrous oxide anesthesia.
  • At a dose of 1-2 mg/kg, it produces a characteristic effect of sustained partial depolarization of muscle end plate by opening sodium channels and initially producing twitching and fasciculations followed by flaccid paralysis. Its rapid onset of action is mainly due to its low lipid solubility.
  • Succinylcholine has a shelf life of around 18 months, generally stored at 20-40 C and can be stored upto 2 years.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 379.

questions.text: Lithium potentiates the action of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants. How many days before administration of the muscle relaxant should lithium be stopped?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 2 days
 
  • Lithium tends to potentiate the action of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants given during surgery.
  • In addition, during the perioperative period - dehydration, use of diuretics, and hyponatremia can occur which can also exacerbate the toxicity of lithium. 
  • Lithium has a half-life of 18-24 hours - hence it's advised to stop it 48-72 hours prior to surgery or the use of any non-depolarizing muscle relaxants. 
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 474.

questions.text: Pick the drug that undergoes Hoffman elimination.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Atracurium

Atracurium is rapidly eliminated by Hoffman elimination and thus can be given in a patient with liver or kidney dysfunction.

* [Extra Edge]: Hofmann elimination

  • This refers to inactivation of the drug in the body fluids by spon­taneous molecular rearrangement without the agency of any enzyme.
  • Atracurium’s disappearance from the body depends on hydrolysis of the ester moiety by plasma esterases and by a spontaneous or Hofmann degradation (cleavage of the N-alkyl portion in the benzylisoquinoline). Hence, two routes for termination of effect are available, both of which remain functional in renal failure.
     
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 32.

questions.text: Which drug does not act on neuromuscular junction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Dantrolene

  • Dantrolene sodium is a postsynaptic muscle relaxant that lessens exci­tation-contraction coupling in muscle cells. It achieves this by inhibiting Ca ions release from sarcoplasmic reticulum stores by antagonizing ryanodine receptors. Hence, it is direct acting on muscle cells rather then the NMJ.
  • Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant and mivacurium and pancuronium are non-depolarizing muscle relaxant, they at in NMJ.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 382.

choices.text: Block of Cardio-accelerator fibers of synthetic origin

questions.text: The anesthetist used high doses of bupivacaine to do a subarachnoid block on a 46-year-old male patient. He was discovered to have 72/44 mm Hg blood pressure and a 52/min heart rate after 10 minutes. The block's level was confirmed to be T6 upon inspection. What is the likely cause of the bradycardia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Reverse Bainbridge reflex
  • The Bezold–Jarisch reflex involves a variety of cardiovascular and neurological processes which cause hypopnea, hypotension and bradycardia in response to noxious stimuli detected in the cardiac ventricles. following i.v. injection of Capsaicin, Veratridine, 5HT etc. Similar to J-Reflex in lungs by J Receptors.
  • The Bainbridge reflex or Bainbridge effect (also called the atrial reflex) is a cardiovascular reflex causing an increase in heart rate in response to increased stretching of the wall of the right atrium due to increased filling of the right atrium with venous blood.
  • A “reverse” Bainbridge reflex has been proposed to explain the decreases in heart rate observed under conditions in which venous return is reduced, such as during spinal and epidural anesthesia, controlled hypotension, and severe hemorrhage.
Online Reference: 
Crystal, George J. PhD, FAHA; Salem, M. Ramez MD. The Bainbridge and the “Reverse” Bainbridge Reflexes: History, Physiology, and Clinical Relevance. Anesthesia & Analgesia 114(3):p 520-532, March 2012. | DOI: 10.1213/ANE.0b013e3182312e21

questions.text: A patient who needs surgery has a bilirubin level of 8 mg/dl and a serum creatinine level of 1.9 mg/dl. What is the preferred muscle relaxant for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Atracurium

Atracurium is metabolized by Hoffman’s Elimination which is non-enzymatic, non-organ dependent clearance.
Thus, it is the safest drug in liver and renal failure.
 

* [Extra Edge]: Hofmann elimination

  • This refers to inactivation of the drug in the body fluids by spon­taneous molecular rearrangement without the agency of any enzyme.
  • Atracurium’s disappearance from the body depends on hydrolysis of the ester moiety by plasma esterases and by a spontaneous or Hofmann degradation (cleavage of the N-alkyl portion in the benzylisoquinoline). Hence, two routes for termination of effect are available, both of which remain functional in renal failure.
* [Extra Edge]: Conditions and the muscle relaxants of choice 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 380.
