questions.text: What degrades Trilene?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Enzymatic Degradation
 
  • Naturally occurring bacteria have the ability to degrade TRILENE / TRICHLOROETHYLENE
  •  In Anaerobic conditions: - Trichloroethylene can be degraded by reductive dichlorination
  • Aerobic conditions: - Pseudomonas can metabolize TCE using the enzyme Toluene Dioxygenase
  • Four main biodegradation processes leading to TCE biodegradation by isolated bacteria and mixed cultures are anaerobic reductive dechlorination, anaerobic cometabolic reductive dichlorination, aerobic co-metabolism, and aerobic direct oxidation. 
Online Reference: Wu Z, Man Q, Niu H, Lyu H, Song H, Li R, Ren G, Zhu F, Peng C, Li B, Ma X. Recent advances and trends of trichloroethylene biodegradation: A critical review. Front Microbiol. 2022 Dec 22;13:1053169. doi: 10.3389/fmicb.2022.1053169. PMID: 36620007; PMCID: PMC9813602.

questions.text: What is the significance of giving glycopyrrolate before General anesthesia ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) \(\downarrow\)se secretions
  • Glycopyrrolate is used to reduce salivary, tracheobronchial, and pharyngeal secretions before anesthesia, as an antispasmodic, to reduce drooling in Parkinson's disease patients, and to prevent the cholinergic effects of neostigmine, which is used to reverse the effects of muscle relaxants, after surgery.
  • Neostigmine 0.5–2.0 mg (30–50 µg/kg) i.v., preceded by atropine or glycopyrrolate 10 µg/kg to block muscarinic effects, rapidly reverses muscle paralysis induced by competitive neuromuscular blockers.

* [Extra Edge]: Preanesthetic medication
  • When irritant general anesthetics (ether) were used, prior administration of anticholinergics (atropine, hyoscine, glycopyrrolate) was imperative to check increased salivary and tracheobronchial secretions.
  • However, with current use of nonirritating anesthetics (halothane, etc.) the requirement has decreased, though atropine may still be employed because halothane sensitizes the heart to NA mediated ventricular arrhythmias which are especially prone to occur during vagal slowing.
  • Atropinic drugs also prevent laryngospasm, not by an action on laryngeal muscles, which are skeletal muscles, but by reducing respiratory secretions that reflexly predispose to laryngo­spasm.
  • Vasovagal attack during anesthesia can also be prevented.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 130.

questions.text: Which of the following substances can be utilised for both induction and intubation alone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Sevoflurane

  • Sevoflurane is the best answer among the given options.
  • Sevoflurane has the smoothest induction and is the least irritative to respiratory system. It is the preferred agent in day - care surgeries.
* [Extra Edge]: Sevoflurane
 
  • Induction and emergence from anesthesia are fast so that rapid changes in depth can be achieved.
  • Absence of pungency makes it pleasant and administrable through a face mask.
  • Unlike desflurane, it poses no problem in induction and is frequently selected for this purpose. Acceptability is good even by pediatric patients.
  • Recovery is smooth; orientation, cognitive and motor functions are regained almost as quickly as with desflurane.
  • Sevoflurane is suitable both for outpatient as well as inpatient surgery, induction as well as maintenance, but its high cost and need for high-flow open or semi closed system makes it very expensive to use.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 408.

questions.text:
During surgery, the patient's anaesthetic caused significant hyperthermia and muscle rigidity.
What other agent from the list below would have contributed to this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Succinylcholine

The given clinical vignette describes the condition called Malignant Hyperthermia which is a very common side effect following the use of succinylcholine.
  • Succinylcholine is a Nicotinic Receptor antagonist which produces sustained muscle depolarisation and prevents muscle contraction.
  • It stimulates the motor endplate to initiate muscle depolarization.
  • In Malignant Hyperthermia patients succinylcholine results in hyperthermia and generalized muscle rigidity.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 379.

questions.text: A young male patient received 0.25% Bupivacaine regional anaesthetic. The patient lost consciousness, and it was impossible to monitor their pulse. The ideal course of action would have been:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) CPCR with 20% intralipid
 
  • Due to the patient's unresponsiveness and unrecordable pulse, CPCR will be initiated, and Intralipid 20% should be administered as an antidote.
  • Most local anesthetics produce similar signs and symptoms, but the ratio of neurotoxicity to cardiotoxicity may differ, with bupivacaine being the most cardiotoxic.
  • The incidence of toxicity is rare: 1 to 1000 to 1 to 10000. Be concerned for local anesthetic toxicity (LAST) with abnormal cardiovascular or neurological signs and symptoms.

* [Extra Edge]: Bupivacaine Toxicity
 
  1. At therapeutic levels, local anesthetics block voltage-gated Na-channels at the alpha subunit inside the channel, preventing Na+ influx, preventing depolarization, and action potential generation. They affect cardiac Na+-channels and neurons in the brain at toxic levels, blocking K+, Ca2+, and NMDA receptors. 
  2. It lowers the seizure threshold and increases cerebral blood flow, leading to more local anesthetic into the brain.
  3. CNS toxicity includes - perioral tingling, tinnitus, blurry vision, and tongue paresthesia.
  4. Terminal Cardiac toxicity includes - vasodilation, severe hypotension, dysrhythmias, conduction blocks, and asystole.
  5. Treatment of bupivacaine toxicity has long been challenging due to its profound neurologic and cardiac toxicity. Previously, treatment had been supportive, with standard cardiopulmonary resuscitation, airway management, and seizure control with quick-acting GABA agonists such as midazolam. 
  6. For a patient of less than 70 kg, bolus 1.5 mL/kg lipid emulsion 20% rapidly over 2 to 3 minutes, followed by an infusion of 0.25 mL/kg/min for ideal body weight to an upper limit of 12 mL/kg.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 393.

Online Reference: Shafiei FT, McAllister RK, Lopez J. Bupivacaine. [Updated 2023 Aug 17]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK532883/

choices.text: Binding to sodium channels and causing their inactivation

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the way a local anesthetic works?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Binding to sodium channels and causing their inactivation

 
* Mechanism of Action:
  • The LAs prevent nerve conduction by reducing the entry of Na+ ions during the action potential's upstroke (AP). 
  • The Na permeability does not rise in response to an impulse or stimulus because the LAs interact with a receptor inside a voltage-sensitive channel and raise the threshold of channel opening.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 387.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent analgesic agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Nitrous oxide
 
  • Most potent analgesic agent among following is nitrous oxide.
  • Nitrous oxide has analgesic actions thought to be mediated by activation of opioid receptors in the periaqueductal grey of the midbrain.
  • This leads to modulation of nociceptive pathways through the release of norepinephrine and activation of α2−adrenoceptors in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
NOTE: Nitric oxide, CO2 and oxygen do not have any analgesic/anesthetic action. Only nitrous oxide is an anaesthetic amongst these. Hence, the answer by elimination. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 405.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle relaxants' dosages must be determined using the obese person's actual weight rather than his ideal weight?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Atracurium
 
  • Dose of atracurium has to be calculated on the basis of total body weight of an obese person rather than its ideal weight.
  • Instead of using the optimal weight, the muscle relaxant atracurium must be calculated using the whole-body weight of an obese person.
  • This is because atracurium is eliminated by Hoffman's elimination, it is not dependent on liver or renal elimination, so ideal body weight is not required, actual bodyweight is required.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 380.

choices.text: It acts on sodium channels in both active and inactive state
It is given IV in cardiac arrhythmias

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about lidocaine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) It is most cardiotoxic local anesthetic 
 
  • All are true about lidocaine except: It is most cardiotoxic local anesthetic. Because bupivacaine is the most cardiotoxic local anesthetic.
  • Bupivacaine is more prone to prolong QTc interval and induce ventricular tachycardia or cause cardiac depression.
* [Extra Edge]: Lidocaine
  • Injected around a nerve it blocks conduction within 3 min, whereas procaine may take 15 min; also, anesthesia is more intense and longer lasting.
  • Vasodilatation occurs in the injected area. It is used for surface application, infiltration, nerve block, epidural, spinal and intravenous regional block anesthesia.
  • Lidocaine 2% with or without adrenaline is the most popular dental anesthetic. Cross-sensitivity with ester LAs is not seen.
  • The early central effects of lidocaine are depressant, i.e. drowsiness, mental clouding, dysphoria, altered taste and tinnitus. Overdose causes muscle twitching, convulsions, cardiac arrhythmias, fall in BP, coma and respiratory arrest like other LAs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 392.

choices.text: Muscle relaxant of choice in crush injury patients

questions.text: The following statement is true for succinylcholine:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Shortest-acting muscle relaxant
 
  • Succinylcholine, also known as suxamethonium, is a neuromuscular blocking agent that acts as a depolarizing muscle relaxant.
  • It binds to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction and causes depolarization of the muscle fiber.
  • Succinylcholine has a rapid onset of action and a short duration of action, making it the shortest-acting muscle relaxant available.
* [Extra Edge]: Non-depolarizing muscle relaxants



* Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant although it is the shortest acting (6-11 minutes).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 379.

questions.text: Which inhalational anaesthetics cause the most cardiac depression?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Halothane
 
  • Halothane is an inhalational anesthetic that has been used in the past but is now less commonly used due to safety concerns.
  • Halothane is known to have a significant depressive effect on cardiac function, including a negative inotropic effect (reduction in contractility), which can lead to decreased cardiac output.
  • It also reduces systemic vascular resistance and can cause arrhythmias.
  • Nitrous oxide, in particular, has minimal cardiac depressant effects and is often used as an adjunct in anesthesia.
  • Desflurane increases cardiac contractility but is irritant in nature.
  • Sevoflurane is the inhalational agent of choice with cardiac compromise.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 406.

questions.text: The following is not a feature of malignant hyperthermia:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) There is hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis 
 
  • ​​​​​Malignant hyperthermia (MH) is a potentially life-threatening condition triggered by certain anesthetic agents, such as volatile inhalational agents (e.g., halothane, sevoflurane) and the depolarizing muscle relaxant succinylcholine.
  • It is characterized by a hypermetabolic response of skeletal muscles, leading to increased body temperature, muscle rigidity, and other manifestations.
  • There is no hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis associated with malignant hyperthermia.
* Other options:
  • Succinylcholine can trigger malignant hyperthermia in susceptible individuals. The release of intracellular calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscles is a key event in the pathophysiology of MH.
  • Rhabdomyolysis, the breakdown of muscle tissue, can occur in malignant hyperthermia, leading to the release of myoglobin into the bloodstream and subsequent myoglobinuria.
  • Dantrolene is the specific antidote and drug of choice for treating malignant hyperthermia. It acts by inhibiting calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle cells.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 241.

questions.text: Which of the following medicines is most likely to provide sedation similar to a normal sleep?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Dexmedetomidine
 
  • Dexmedetomidine is a selective alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used for sedation in various clinical settings.
  • It is known for its unique sedative properties, which include producing a state of "cooperative sedation" or "conscious sedation."
  • Dexmedetomidine provides sedation while allowing the patient to maintain a certain level of responsiveness and cooperation.
  • Its sedative effects are similar to the natural sleep state, as it induces a calm and relaxed state without significant respiratory depression or loss of consciousness.
  • Dexmedetomidine is commonly used in intensive care units (ICUs) and procedural settings where a controlled level of sedation is desired.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 412.

questions.text: Ketamine predominantly affects which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) NMDA
 
  • Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic medication that exerts its effects by interacting with various receptors in the brain.
  • The primary mechanism of action of ketamine involves antagonism of NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptors.
  • NMDA receptors play a crucial role in the transmission and modulation of excitatory signals in the central nervous system.
  • By antagonizing NMDA receptors, ketamine inhibits the activity of glutamate, an excitatory neurotransmitter, leading to its dissociative and anesthetic effects
* [Extra Edge]: 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 400.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with propofol infusion syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Hypokalemia 
 
  • Propofol infusion syndrome is a rare but potentially serious condition that can occur with prolonged high-dose infusions of propofol, a sedative-hypnotic medication.
  • It is characterized by a constellation of symptoms, including metabolic acidosis, rhabdomyolysis, and cardiac dysfunction.
  • Risk factors- poor oxygen delivery, sepsis and cerebral injury
  • While electrolyte disturbances can occur with propofol infusion syndrome, hypokalemia is not specifically associated with this condition.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 475.

questions.text: What is the main factor that determines the potency of a local anesthetic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Lipid solubility
 
  • Lipid solubility is a critical factor in determining the potency of a local anesthetic.
  • Local anesthetics work by blocking nerve conduction, primarily by inhibiting sodium channels in the nerves.
  • To exert their effects, local anesthetics need to penetrate the lipid-rich neuronal membranes and reach the sodium channels.
  • Local anesthetics with higher lipid solubility can more readily cross the lipid membranes and reach their target sites, leading to increased potency.
  • The greater the lipid solubility of a local anesthetic, the more efficiently it can penetrate the neuronal membranes and exert its numbing effects.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 390.

questions.text: According to which law, the amount of pressure exerted by a gas in a mixture is proportionate to the percentage of gas in the mixture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Dalton's law
 
  • Dalton's law, also known as Dalton's partial pressure law, states that the total pressure exerted by a mixture of gases is equal to the sum of the partial pressures of each gas in the mixture.
  • According to Dalton's law, the partial pressure of a gas in a mixture is directly proportional to its mole fraction or percentage in the mixture.
  • In other words, the pressure exerted by a gas is determined by its concentration or abundance in the gas mixture.
  • This law is applicable to ideal gas behavior and assumes that the gases do not interact with each other.



Online Reference: 
Chandan G, Cascella M. Gas Laws and Clinical Application. [Updated 2023 Aug 28]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK546592/

questions.text: What causes thiopentone to have a Cerebro-protective effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Decreased cerebral metabolism
 
  • The Cerebro-protective of thiopentone is primarily attributed to its ability to decrease cerebral metabolism (option A).
  • Thiopentone is an intravenous anesthetic agent commonly used for induction of anesthesia.
  • It acts by enhancing the inhibitory effects of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) on the central nervous system, leading to sedation and anesthesia.
  • By decreasing cerebral metabolism, thiopentone reduces the metabolic demands of the brain, including oxygen consumption and glucose utilization.
  • This can have a beneficial effect on the heart by improving oxygen supply-demand balance and reducing the workload on the cardiovascular system.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 408.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle relaxants produces the most discomfort during injection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Succinyl Choline

Succinylcholine causes pain on injection because it has a pH of 3.5 which is much below normal human blood pH, 7.4.
Rocuronium also causes pain it has a pH of 4.0, but as the pH of succinylcholine is lower it causes more pain.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 240.

questions.text: Which of the following reactions is least impacted by anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA)
 
  • Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is a test that measures the electrical activity of the brain in response to sound.
  • This test is used to diagnose hearing loss and other auditory disorders.
  • The BERA test measures the electrical activity of the brainstem, which is the part of the brain that is responsible for processing auditory information.
  • The BERA  test is least impacted by anesthesia because the electrical activity of the brainstem is not significantly affected by anesthesia. In contrast, other tests such as Visual Evoked Response (VER), Somatosensory Evoked potential (SSEP), and Electroencephalogram (EEG) are more sensitive to the effects of anesthesia.
  • Visual Evoked Response (VER) measures the electrical activity of the brain in response to visual stimuli. Somatosensory Evoked potential (SSEP) measures the electrical activity of the brain in response to sensory stimuli such as touch or pressure. Electroencephalogram (EEG) measures the electrical activity of the brain in real-time and is used to diagnose neurological disorders such as epilepsy.
  • Therefore, the correct option is 1: Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is least impacted by anesthesia.
Online Reference: 
Gundogdu O, Yaman H, Karaaslan P, Serbetcioglu MB. Effect of General Anesthesia on Auditory Brainstem Response Testing. Medeni Med J. 2022 Jun 23;37(2):145-149. doi: 10.4274/MMJ.galenos.2022.25741. PMID: 35734981; PMCID: PMC9234361.

questions.text: Maximum sedation is caused by which of the following anticholinergic premedications?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Scopolamine 
 
  • Among the given anticholinergic premedications, scopolamine is known to cause maximum sedation.
  • This is because scopolamine has a higher affinity for muscarinic receptors than atropine and Glycopyrrolate.
  • It blocks the effects of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter that is involved in a variety of functions, including heart rate, salivation, and sweating.
  • Thus scopolamine is also used in nacro-analysis
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 413.

questions.text: Rapid onset of action of an inhalation agent will be led by which of the following properties?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Low blood: gas partition co-efficient 
 
  • The blood: gas partition coefficient is a measure of how easily a gas dissolves in blood.
  •  A low blood: gas partition coefficient means that the gas will dissolve less easily in blood than in air. This means that the gas will have a faster onset of action, as it will be able to pass from the lungs to the brain more quickly.
  • A high blood: gas partition coefficient (Option A) means that the gas will dissolve more easily in blood than in air. This means that the gas will have a slower onset of action, as it will take longer for the gas to pass from the lungs to the brain.
  • So, the property that will lead to a rapid onset of action of an inhalation agent is a low blood:gas partition coefficient.





Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 403.

questions.text: In which of the following is Ketamine the preferred anesthetic agent ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Bronchial asthma 
 
  • Ketamine is indeed the preferred anesthetic agent in cases of bronchial asthma.
  • Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic that provides analgesia, sedation, and anesthesia while maintaining respiratory function.
  • It has bronchodilator effects, which means that it can help to open up the airways and make it easier for patients to breathe.
  • Ketamine's sympathomimetic effects can help maintain bronchial smooth muscle tone and minimize bronchospasm during induction and maintenance of anesthesia.
* [Extra Edge]: Choice of Anesthesics


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 411.

questions.text: Correct sequence of potency of the following anesthetic agents?
questions.solution:
Arranging the following anesthetics in order of potency, from most potent to least potent:

  1. Methoxyflurane
  2. Halothane
  3. Isoflurane
  4. Nitrous oxide (N2O)

Reference: Miller’s Anaesthesia, 9th Edition, Page no 511.

questions.text: Which of these medicines functions as a fibrinolytic treatment countermeasure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Epsilon aminocaproic acid
 
  • EACA is an Antifibrinolytic. It is a lysine analogue which combines with the lysine-binding sites of plasminogen and plasmin so that the latter is not able to bind to fibrin and lyse it.
  • It is a specific antidote for fibrinolytic agents and has been used in many hyper plasminamic states associated with excessive intravascular fibrinolysis resulting in bleeding.
  • The primary indication of EACA is to counteract the effect of fibrinolytic drugs and bleeding due to their use.

Option 2 : Protamine sulphate is the antidote to heparin toxicity
Option 3 : Heparin is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor
Option 4 : Streptokinase is a fibrinolytic. Heparin stops clot form forming but EACA breaks already formed clot)
 

Here’s a table summarizing common antidotes in pharmacology for various toxic agents:

Toxic Agent Antidote Mechanism of Action
Acetaminophen (Paracetamol) N-acetylcysteine (NAC) Replenishes glutathione to detoxify NAPQI.
Opioids Naloxone Opioid receptor antagonist.
Benzodiazepines Flumazenil GABA-A receptor antagonist.
Heparin Protamine sulfate Neutralizes heparin's anticoagulant effects.
Warfarin Vitamin K, Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) Restores clotting factors.
Iron Deferoxamine Chelates iron.
Lead EDTA, Dimercaprol Chelates lead.
Organophosphates (pesticides) Atropine, Pralidoxime Atropine blocks muscarinic effects; pralidoxime reactivates acetylcholinesterase.
Carbon monoxide (CO) 100% Oxygen, Hyperbaric Oxygen Displaces CO from hemoglobin.
Cyanide Hydroxocobalamin, Sodium thiosulfate Converts cyanide to less toxic forms.
Methanol/Ethylene glycol Fomepizole, Ethanol Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase.
Digoxin Digoxin-specific antibody fragments (Digibind) Binds and neutralizes digoxin.
Beta-blockers Glucagon Increases cAMP independent of beta receptors.
Calcium channel blockers Calcium gluconate, Glucagon, Insulin-Glucose Restores calcium levels and improves cardiac output.
Isoniazid (INH) Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) Reverses GABA depletion.
Methemoglobinemia Methylene blue Reduces methemoglobin to hemoglobin.
Sulfonylureas/Insulin overdose Dextrose, Octreotide Dextrose corrects hypoglycemia; octreotide inhibits insulin release.
Anticholinergics (e.g., Atropine) Physostigmine Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor.
Tricyclic Antidepressants (TCAs) Sodium bicarbonate Alkalinizes serum, reduces cardiotoxicity.
Hydrofluoric acid Calcium gluconate Neutralizes fluoride ions.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 676.

questions.text: Which substance falls under the category of an antifibrinolytic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Epsilon aminocaproic acid
 
  • The plasmin-plasminogen system is artificially inhibited by epsilon-aminocaproic acid (EACA). It is the sole effective antifibrinolytic substance that is marketed.
  • It is an analog and derivative of the amino acid lysine, making it a potent inhibitor of enzymes that bind to that specific residue.
  • Proteolytic enzymes like plasmin, the enzyme in charge of fibrinolysis, are examples of such enzymes. This makes EACA useful in the treatment of several bleeding problems.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 676.

questions.text: What effect is dopamine capable of producing at low infusion rates of 3-5 mcg/kg/min?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Increased cardiac contractility
 
  • Dopamine action: D1 receptors at 2 mcg (renal vasodilation);
  • Beta receptors (2–10 mcg) (increased cardiac contractility);
  • alpha receptors (10–100 mcg) (vasoconstriction).
Higher doses of dopamine (5-10 mcg/kg/min) can increase cardiac contractility by stimulating beta-1 adrenergic receptors,

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 146.

questions.text: Aspirin inhibits platelet aggregation through its effect on:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Thromboxane A2
 
  • Low-dose aspirin use irreversibly blocks the formation of thromboxane A2 in platelets, producing an inhibitory effect on platelet aggregation. (This happens via inhibition of cyclooxygenase and thromboxane synthase inhibition).
  • This antiplatelet property makes aspirin useful for reducing the incidence of heart attacks.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 211.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs do not increase bleeding when given to a patient on warfarin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Carbamazepine
 
  • Inducers of CYP2C9 like carbamazepine, increase metabolism of warfarin and hence decrease plasma concentration and increases risk of thrombosis.
  • Warfarin's ability to break down in the body can be inhibited by CYP2C9 inhibitors such fluoxetine, isoniazid, amiodarone, cimetidine, tolcapone, and cotrimoxazole, which can raise warfarin levels in the blood and cause bleeding symptoms

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 442.

questions.text: An uninjured volunteer was taken for a blood test. Prior to the trial, the volunteer was asked about his medical history, including any exposure to NSAIDs, which he categorically denied. But after testing, it was discovered that the BT had gone up. Which of the following is not a potential causal agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Multivitamins containing Vitamin K
  • Increased BT is suggestive of deficiency of clotting factors.
  • Vitamin K helps in the synthesis of factors 2, 7, 9, 10, protien C and S.
  • Thus, deficiency of vitamin K can be a potential causal agent and not Multivitamins containing Vitamin K.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 661.

questions.text: Which of these is not a Gp IIb/IIIa inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Prasugrel

  • Prasugrel is a thienopyridine, an irreversible antagonist of the ADP P2Y12 receptor.
  • Thienopyridine antiplatelet agents interfere with platelet activation and aggregation induced by ADP.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 679.

choices.text: It interferes with thrombin and antithrombin III simultaneously

questions.text: Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) provides effective anti-coagulant action in comparison to unfractionated heparin because:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) It is less protein bound

  • Compared to unfractionated heparin, Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) has reliable anticoagulant action because it is less protein bound.
  • Less protein bound means more of the compound is in the active state which can bring about the physiological change, and hence is more reliable and effective.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 665.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below is frequently prescribed to treat cancer-related thromboembolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Low molecular weight heparin 
 
  • Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) is a preferred treatment for cancer-associated thromboembolism.
  • Direct oral anticoagulants are the preferred first-line treatment for venous thromboembolism in non-cancer patients, but LMWH is still preferred for those with active cancer.
  • LMWH is also used for out-of-hospital management of patients with venous thrombosis or pulmonary embolism as it does not require laboratory monitoring and reduces healthcare expenditures.
  • Warfarin is less preferred in cancer patients due to nausea and vomiting from chemotherapy, liver involvement, and poor venous access. LMWH is sometimes used as a long-term therapy instead of warfarin.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 713.

questions.text: Select the drug that is recommended for the treatment of Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Lepirudin
 

HIT
Definition Immune reaction causing low platelets and clot formation after heparin use.
Onset 5–10 days after starting heparin (earlier with prior exposure).
Causes Antibodies against platelet factor 4 (PF4)-heparin complex.
Symptoms - Platelet drop >50%- Blood clots (DVT, PE, stroke).
Treatment 1. Stop all heparin (including flushes).
2. Start non-heparin anticoagulant:
- Argatroban
- Fondaparinux
- Lepirudin (direct thrombin inhibitor).
3. Avoid warfarin until platelets recover.
Complications Blood clots (DVT, PE, limb ischemia, stroke).

Lepirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor and is one of the options for anticoagulation in HIT. However, it is less commonly used compared to newer agents.


Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 715.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Prasugrel is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Not a prodrug

* [Extra Edge]: Prasugrel

Prasugrel is a prodrug that is converted to an active metabolite by the hepatic CYP system It is a ADP P2Y12 receptor blocker It is an antiplatelet drug which decreases platelet aggregation

USE :- Prasugrel is used in combination with low dose aspirin to prevent thrombosis in patients with acute coronary syndrome including unstable angina, non ST elevation MI, ST elevation MI who are planned for treatment with PCI.
Prasugrel is associated with a higher bleeding risk, hence should not be given to people with active pathological bleeding such as peptic ulcer or a history of transient ischemic attack or stroke. It is associated with higher risk of stroke (thrombotic stroke and intracranial hemorrhage).

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 678.

questions.text: What is Apixaban?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Direct Xa inhibitor

* [Extra Edge]:

+APIXABAN: - Direct factor Xa inhibitor
+USE :- Treatment and prophylaxis of DVT and Pulmonary Embolism Stroke prophylaxis in patients with Atrial Fibrillation
+ADVERSE EFFECTS :- Bleeding – It can be reversed with Andexanet Alfa These drugs do not require drug monitoring
Examples of other Direct Factor Xa inhibitors are :- RIVAROXABAN, EDOXABAN

[TRICK TO REMEMBER :- Xa inhibitors – APIXABAN , RIVAROXABAN – XA containing drug names]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 671.

questions.text: Which medications require ongoing prothrombin time monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Coumadin

Warfarin inhibits Vitamin K epoxide reductase thereby leading to inhibition of Vitamin K dependent ϒ carboxylation of clotting factors 2,7,9,10, protein C, protein S that is Extrinsic Pathway.

* FREQUENTLY ASKED: -
 
  • WARFARIN/COUMARIN: - MONITORING - PT INR (Extrinsic pathway)
  • HEPARIN: - MONITORING – APTT (Intrinsic Pathway)

[TRICK TO REMEMBER: - TABLE TENNIS – TT – Indoor game – Intrinsic]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 669.

questions.text: Streptokinase and urokinase are contraindicated in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Intracranial malignancy

* THE FOLLOWING ARE THE CONTRAINDICATIONS OF THROMBOLYSIS: -
 
  • Recent Intracranial Haemorrhage (ICH)
  • Structural cerebral vascular lesion.
  • Intracranial malignancy
  • Ischemic stroke within three months.
  • Suspected Aortic Dissection.
  • Active bleeding or bleeding diathesis 
  • Significant head injury  within three months.
  • Recent history of surgery
  • Severe Hypertension
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 673.

questions.text: Which of the following adjuvants does heparin operate through?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Antithrombin III
 
  • Heparin acts through Antithrombin III adjuvant by binding to and activating Antithrombin III (ATIII).
  • ATIII normally circulates in the bloodstream in an inactive form, but when it binds to heparin it becomes activated.
  • The active form of ATIII, in turn, binds to and inactivates a number of key coagulation factors, including thrombin and factor Xa. This prevents thrombosis by inhibiting clot formation.
  • Additionally, heparin may also facilitate the fibrinolysis process by activating plasminogen and allowing it to break down fibrin.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 663.

questions.text: Identify the correct route of administration for post operative thromboprophylaxis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) S/C
 
  • Both LMWH and fondaparinux can be administered subcutaneously once per day for thrombosis prophylaxis and therapy, LMWH is the agent of choice in post operative thromboprophylaxis.
  • Unfractionated heparin can be administered intravenously four times daily to treat thrombosis and subcutaneously twice daily for prevention.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 665.

questions.text: Which among the follow drugs produces vasodilation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Histamine

Among the given options, histamine produces vasodilation. 

It has 2 mechanisms by which it produces vasodilation-

1. Activation of vascular H1 receptors resulting in release of NO which causes vasodilation. 

2. Activation of H3 receptors on sympathetic nerve terminals causing presynaptic inhibition of vasoconstrictor tone. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 176.

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factor in a patient on warfarin therapy, would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Factor 2
 
  • Warfarin is an anticoagulant medication used to reduce the risk of stroke, thromboembolism, and other related events in people with certain medical conditions.
  • It works by inhibiting vitamin K-dependent clotting factors, including factor 2 (prothrombin), which is essential for the formation of fibrin, a protein required for clot formation.
  • Warfarin treatment both reduces the availability of factor 2 and weakens the fibrin bonds, leading to an decrease in the ability of the body to form a clot.
  • In addition, warfarin has been shown to slow the rate of thrombus formation, thus reducing the risk of stroke and other blood clot-related events.
  • Vitamin K-dependent clotting factors are 2,7,9,10.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 668.

questions.text: Find the incorrect match:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Ciraparantag – Fondaparinux
 
  • Dabigatran (direct oral thrombin inhibitor)- antidote is idarucizumab (humanized monoclonal antibody Fab fragment).
  • Rivaroxaban, Apixaban (factor Xa inhibitors)- antidote is Andexanet alfa (factor Xa decoy molecules compete for binding to anti-Xa drugs).
  • Ciraparantag- nonspecific antidote for LMW heparin, factor Xa inhibitors, dabigatran.
  • Fondaparinux- ultra LMW heparin.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 720.

questions.text: What is the GM-CSF used for neutropenia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Molgramostim
 
  • GM-CSF (Granulocyte-Macrophage Colony Stimulating Factor) is a cytokine that stimulates the bone marrow to produce white blood cells, including neutrophils.
  • Neutropenia is a condition in which the body has a low level of neutrophils, which can increase the risk of infections.
  • Molgramostim is a recombinant form of GM-CSF that is used to treat neutropenia by stimulating the production of neutrophils in the bone marrow.
  • Option 1, Filgrastim, is also a recombinant form of G-CSF that is used to treat neutropenia.
  • However, Filgrastim specifically stimulates the production of neutrophils, whereas Molgramostim stimulates the production of both neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Option 3, Romiplostim, is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist that is used to treat thrombocytopenia (a low level of platelets in the blood), not neutropenia.
  • Option 4, Eltrombopag, is also a thrombopoietin receptor agonist that is used to treat thrombocytopenia, not neutropenia.
Trick: -
Molgra mo stim- Graulocyte and Monocyte stimulator

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 936.

questions.text: The agent used for the treatment of thrombocytopenia secondary to myelosuppressive cancer chemotherapy.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Oprelvekin 
 
  • Oprelvekin is an IL-11 analog used in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia. It increases thrombopoiesis.
  • It is used in the treatment of thrombocytopenia due to non-myeloid malignancies.
  • Important adverse effects are fluid retention, tachycardia, palpitation, edema, and shortness of breath.
* Other options:
  • Filgrastim (A) and Sargramostim (B) are agents that stimulate the production of white blood cells, particularly neutrophils, and are used to treat neutropenia in cancer patients.
  • Erythropoietin (D) is a hormone that stimulates the production of red blood cells and is used to treat anemia but is not effective for thrombocytopenia.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 906.

questions.text: A patient of deep venous thrombosis was started on some anticoagulant drug, but after 5 days, he developed some lesion over the toes. Clinical image is shown below. Which of the following drug is responsible for such a presentation?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is suggestive of purple toe syndrome. It is an adverse reaction of warfarin. 
 
  • It occurs due to cholesterol microemboli which are released from atheromatous plaques. These emboli will cause arterial occlusion. 
  • It is an indication to stop warfarin and replace with oral factor Xa inhibitor- apixaban, rivaroxaban. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 663, 665, 670-672.

Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 592-594.

questions.text: A patient on chemotherapy presented with thrombocytopenia. Which of the following drugs will be preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
IL-3, IL-6, and IL-11 stimulate platelet production.

  • Oprelvekin (recombinant IL-11) was approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for use in chemotherapy-associated thrombocytopenia.
  • Darbepoetin alfa and Epoetin alfa are recombinant human erythropoietin.
  • Filgrastim is a granulocyte-colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) that is used for the treatment of severe neutropenia after high-dose cancer chemotherapy
  • Sargramostim is a recombinant Granulocyte macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) used to treat neutropenia induced by chemotherapy.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page. No- 906.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) in MI?
questions.solution:
• Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) - Alteplase is a fibrinolytic drug which initiates the fibrinolytic pathway, causing activation of plasminogen (particularly, fibrin-found plasminogen) to plasmin which is responsible for the digestion of fibrin, resulting in the breakdown of clot.
  • The t-PA selectively activates fibrin-bound plasminogen within the thrombus, and any plasmin that leaks is inactivated by circulating antiplasmins.
  • Fibrin bound plasmin is not inactivated by antiplasmins because of common binding site for both fibrin and antiplasmin.
  • The t-PA itself is inactivated by plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 and -2 (PAI-1, PAI-2).



Fig: The plasminogen-plasmin system

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page No 673.

questions.text: Which of the following  Tyrosine Kinase inhibitor is approved in ITP ?

Ponatinib only TKI active against T3151 mutation.
Nilotinib only TKI given BD and empty stomach.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant female in her first trimester was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis. Which of the following anticoagulant drugs can be used?
questions.solution:
• Pregnancy with DVT requires anticoagulation, but the choice of drug must be safe for the fetus.

  • Enoxaparin is a low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH):

    • Does not cross the placenta → safe in all trimesters

    • Administered subcutaneously

    • Preferred over unfractionated heparin due to lower risk of osteoporosis and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia

  • Why not the others:

    • Warfarin: Crosses the placenta → teratogenic (especially in first trimester)

    • Apixaban (DOAC): Insufficient safety data in pregnancy → not recommended

    • Aspirin: Low-dose aspirin is used for preeclampsia prevention, not for treatment of DVT

choices.text: Coagulation profile monitoring is required while using lepirudin

questions.text: Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
• Lepirudin is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor, which is a recombinant form of hirudin extracted from the saliva of leech.
  • It is administered parenterally and the Mode of action is independent of anti-thrombin, I.e it can reach and inactivate fibrin-bound thrombin in thrombi.
  • Dabigatrin is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor.
  • Enoxaparin is a LMWH and does not need monitoring
  • Fondaparinux  binds to antithrombin resulting in inactivation of Factor Xa.
Reference: Katzung Basic and clinical Pharmacology, 14th Edition, Page No 617.

questions.text: A female patient comes with complaints of swelling and pain in her great toe. Her uric acid level is found to be high. A drug which reduces uric acid levels is prescribed. Which of the following enzyme should the drug inhibit?
questions.solution:
Allopurinol is a purine antimetabolite and an inhibitor of the enzyme xanthine oxidase.



It is utilized to treat hyperuricemia in patients with gout and also to prevent the onset of gout in individuals with hematological malignancies undergoing chemotherapy.

Both allopurinol and its primary metabolite, oxypurinol (also known as alloxanthine), decrease urate production by inhibiting xanthine oxidase. This inhibition prevents the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid, leading to lower plasma uric acid levels. Allopurinol itself is also a substrate for xanthine oxidase.

Febuxostat is a nonpurine inhibitor of uric acid synthesis that is not an analogue of hypoxanthine. It works by inhibiting xanthine oxidase and is indicated for the management of gout.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of dicumarol?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of Dicumarol involves the inhibition of vitamin K-dependent clotting factor synthesis in the liver.

Both Dicumarol and warfarin function as anticoagulants by competitively inhibiting the gamma-carboxylation system due to their structural resemblance to vitamin K. This inhibition is essential for the therapeutic use of these medications.

In this process, vitamin K epoxide is converted to its quinone form by the enzyme epoxide reductase, which is particularly sensitive to inhibition by both warfarin and dicumarol. This inhibition ultimately leads to a reduction in the synthesis of functional clotting factors that depend on vitamin K for their activity.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Dabigatran?
questions.solution:
Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor. It is the only oral direct thrombin inhibitor available.
Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors:
• Bivalirudin
• Argatroban
• Desirudin
Direct factor Xa inhibitors:
• Rivaroxaban
• Apixaban
• Edoxaban
• Betrixaban
Ref- Goodman and Gillman 13th edition Page 600-602

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for gastrointestinal stromal tumour?
questions.solution:
Imatinib a tyrosine kinase inhibitor is the drug of choice for gastrointestinal stromal tumor. It is also used in the chronic phase of CML. Adverse effects include • Gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Dabigatran ?
questions.solution:
clasification of anticoagulants
(1) Vitamin K antagonist - Warfarin (2) direct thrombin inhibitors
Oral - Dabigatran.
Parenteral - Argatroban, Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin.
(3) indirect thrombin inhibitor - unfractionated heparin , low molecular weight heparin ( enoxaparin, Dalteparin), Fondaparinux.
(4) direct oral factor Xa inhibitors : Rivaroxaban, Apixaban, Endoxaban. Ref- Goodman and Gillman 13th edition Page 594

questions.text: A 35-year-old female, a known case of sickle disease came with complaints of unprovoked pain in the extremities and torso. A thromboembolic episode was suspected. What is the first drug to be started for prophylaxis of thromboembolic events in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Patients with sickle cell disease are at increased risk of venous thromboembolism due to hypercoagulable state.

  • In an acute setting with suspected thromboembolic event, heparin (unfractionated or low-molecular-weight) is preferred as initial prophylaxis or treatment because:

    • Rapid onset of action

    • Can be used safely while confirming diagnosis

    • Easily reversible if needed

Other options:

  • Warfarin: Oral anticoagulant, slow onset, used for long-term prophylaxis after stabilization; not first-line in acute suspected VTE.

  • Aspirin: Antiplatelet, not effective for venous thromboembolism prophylaxis in sickle cell disease.

  • Apixaban: Direct oral anticoagulant, used for treatment or long-term prophylaxis; not the first drug in acute suspected thromboembolism.



Reference
1. Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 14th Edition - Page 713
2. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition - Page no. 2098

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman undergoes hip arthroplasty. The consultant advises starting the patient on dabigatran to prevent venous thromboembolism. How does this drug prevent thrombosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor (DOAC).

  • It binds directly to thrombin (factor IIa) and prevents the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin, thereby inhibiting clot formation.

  • Used for prevention and treatment of venous thromboembolism (VTE), atrial fibrillation-related stroke prevention, and after orthopedic surgeries like hip or knee arthroplasty.

Other options:

  • 2. Activation of antithrombin III → Mechanism of heparin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), not dabigatran.

  • 3. Direct factor Xa inhibition → Mechanism of rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban, not dabigatran.

  • 4. Inhibition of vitamin K epoxide reductase → Mechanism of warfarin, not dabigatran.


Reference
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition - Page no. 592, 594

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of alteplase a tissue plasminogen activator(tPA)?
questions.solution:
Alteplase is a recombinant form of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA).
Its mechanism of action is:

  • It binds to fibrin in a thrombus and converts plasminogen to plasmin.

  • Plasmin is an enzyme that breaks down fibrin, which is the structural framework of blood clots.

  • This promotes fibrinolysis, leading to clot dissolution.

    Why not the others?

  • Option 2 (Inhibits Vit K dependent factors): This is the mechanism of warfarin, not alteplase.

  • Option 3 (Inhibits factor X): This is the mechanism of rivaroxaban, apixaban, and fondaparinux.

  • Option 4 (Activation of thrombin): This is not the mechanism of alteplase. Activating thrombin would promote clot formation, the opposite of alteplase's function.


Reference:Goodman and gillmans The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics 13th edition page no 601

questions.text: In patients with indications for warfarin usage, what is the recommended range of INR in a patient with mechanical heart valves ?
questions.solution:
In patients with mechanical heart valves, anticoagulation with warfarin is essential to prevent thromboembolic complications. The target INR depends on the type and position of the valve:

  • Mechanical mitral valve or older generation valves (e.g., caged-ball or tilting-disc):
    INR target: 2.5–3.5

  • Mechanical aortic valve with low thromboembolic risk (e.g., bileaflet valve, in sinus rhythm, no other risk factors):
    INR target: 2.0–3.0

But in general, and especially in high-risk patients, the most commonly recommended INR target is 2.5–3.5.

Other options: 

  • 2.0–3.0 is appropriate for most venous thromboembolism cases or bioprosthetic valves, not mechanical valves at higher risk.

  • 3.5–4.5 increases bleeding risk and is not routinely recommended.

  • 1.0–1.5 is subtherapeutic and ineffective for anticoagulation.


Reference:Goodman and gillmans The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics 13th edition page no 593

questions.text: Which of the following are not side effects of salbutamol?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hypoglycemia

  • Salbutamol, a beta-2 agonist, enhances glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis while also raising plasma glucose levels.
  • They also boost insulin release while lowering blood sugar levels. However, the first consequence, which causes hyperglycemia, predominates

Trick to memorise side effects of salbutamol: -
Tremor
Tachycardia
Tolerance
T-wave changes(Hypokalemia)

questions.text:
An abrupt aggravation of bronchial asthma was evident in the patient. The patient's condition did not get any better after inhaling salbutamol.
The condition improved after intravenous corticosteroids and aminophylline were introduced. What is the corticosteroid's mode of action in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) They increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol
 
  • Corticosteroids increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol.
  • The need for corticosteroids to be administered as soon as is practical during an acute asthma attack is further emphazised by the fact that they have a dual effect in acute asthma, with an early facilitator effect on airway beta-2 adrenoreceptor sensitivity and a later effect on airway inflammation.
  • They benefit by inhibiting inflammatory cytokine production and eosinophilic, lymphocytic infiltration of lungs. They also reduce bronchial hyperreactivity, mucosal edema and suppress inflammatory response to AG: AB reaction or to other trigger stimuli.
  • They improve airflow, reduce asthma exacerbations and may influence airway remodeling, retarding disease progression. They also increase airway smooth muscle responsiveness to β2 agonists and reverse refractoriness to these drugs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 250.

questions.text: Inhalers with a metering system are used to treat asthma. It is advised that you shake the MDI thoroughly before using it, exhale, bring the inhaler to your mouth, start to breathe in slowly, press the top of the inhaler once, and keep breathing in slowly until you have taken a full breath. After that, hold your breath for 10 seconds. A second MDI puff may be necessary for some patients to experience symptomatic relief. Which one of the following directions for using the MDI again is incorrect?

It is recommended to wait for 15-30 seconds between 2 puffs.

Other options: -

  • MDI should be shaken well so that particles that are settled down also form uniform concentration.
  • Mouth should be rinsed to prevent oral mucocutaneous candidiasis.
  • Inhaler should be cleaned before use as it is exposed to oral mucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a side effect of salbutamol?

questions.text: Pick from the option the  antimicrobial which shouldn't be given to a c/c asthmatic patient being managed on theophylline therapy.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Erythromycin

  • Erythromycin and theophylline should not be given together because they can cause serious drug interactions.
  • Erythromycin is a strong inhibitor of cytochrome P450-3A4 enzyme, which is responsible for the metabolism of theophylline.
  • When taken together, erythromycin will inhibit the action of cytochrome P450-3A4 and cause an elevation of theophylline levels in the blood, leading to the risk of theophylline toxicity.

questions.text: What causes ipratropium's paradoxical bronchoconstriction mechanism

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with asthma arrives in respiratory distress at the emergency room. Epinephrine is administered by the attending physician to cause bronchodilation. questions.text:
A more recent monoclonal antibody used to treat rheumatoid arthritis is tocilizumab.
It is effective against:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) IL-6
 
  • A new monoclonal antibody called tocilizumab blocks interleukin-6 (IL-6) from binding to its receptor in a competitive manner (IL-6R).
  • To stop IL-6 signal transduction to inflammatory mediators that call for B and T cells, the complete receptor complex must be inhibited. A nonlinear pharmacokinetic profile characterises tocilizumab.
  • Those with RA who do not react to methotrexate or other disease-modifying antirheumatic medications may find it helpful.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 782.

questions.text: Which enzyme does aminophylline inhibit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Phosphodiesterase
 
  • Aminophylline group of drugs does Inhibition of phosphodiesterase (PDE) which degrades cyclic nucleotides intracellularly.
  • Consequently, the concentration of cyclic nucleotides is increased. Bronchodilatation, cardiac stimulation and vasodilatation occur and mediator release is inhibited when cAMP level rises in the bronchial/cardiac/vascular smooth muscle and in inflammatory cells, respectively.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 245.

questions.text: With which of the following receptors does theophylline interact antagonistically?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Adenosine receptors
 
  • Theophylline is a medication used as a bronchodilator to treat respiratory conditions such as asthma and COPD.
  • Theophylline, a medication used as a bronchodilator, acts as a non-selective adenosine receptor antagonist.
  • Adenosine receptors are G protein-coupled receptors that bind to the endogenous neurotransmitter adenosine.
  • By antagonizing adenosine receptors, theophylline inhibits their activity and produces various effects, including bronchodilation.

mechanism of action (MOA) of theophylline:

Action Effect
Phosphodiesterase (PDE) inhibition Increases cAMP, causing bronchodilation and reducing inflammation.
Adenosine receptor antagonism Prevents bronchoconstriction and reduces airway reactivity.
Enhances histone deacetylase activity Decreases release of inflammatory mediators.

Outcome: Promotes bronchodilation and anti-inflammatory effects, used in asthma and COPD management.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 245.

questions.text: A known case of COPD was started on I/V theophylline after which he developed diuresis. Such an action of theophylline is mediated through which receptors?
questions.solution:
Increased urine output after administering theophylline is due to antagonism of A1 receptors. 

These receptors are normally preset in afferent arteriole of glomerulus. On activation, they cause vasoconstriction which reduces GFR and decreases urine output. Antagonism of this action will result in increase in GFR and RBF causing increased urine output. 



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 733-735.

questions.text: A pregnant female with a history of asthma presented in the 3rd stage of labor. Which drug is contraindicated in this patient?

questions.text: A male patient with a history of HIV infection was initiated on Anti Retroviral Therapy consisting of Tenofovir 150mg, Lamivudine 300mg, and Dolutegravir 50mg once daily at night, and now he is subsequently diagnosed with TB and started on antitubercular therapy. What is the required dose adjustment in this patient?
questions.solution:
• In this scenario, a patient on Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) with the TLD regimen (Tenofovir, Lamivudine, Dolutegravir) is newly diagnosed with tuberculosis (TB) and requires a dose adjustment of dolutegravir due to the interaction with rifampicin.

• Rifampicin: This drug is a potent inducer of CYP3A4, which can lower the plasma concentration of dolutegravir, necessitating an increase in its dose to maintain efficacy. Thus, dolutegravir is adjusted by adding 50 mg in the morning.

• Other Drugs: Lamivudine and Tenofovir are not affected by rifampicin's CYP3A4 induction, so no dose modification is required for these medications.

• Dolutegravir: This is an integrase inhibitor effective against HIV-1 and HIV-2. It works by preventing the integration of viral DNA into the host genome.

• Preferred ART Regimen: For patients aged >10 years and weighing >30 kg with coexistent HIV and TB, the recommended first-line ART regimen is Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir, ideally administered as a fixed-dose combination (FDC) in a single pill once daily.

• Timing of Treatment: In HIV-TB co-infection, it's preferable to start TB treatment before initiating ART, ideally within 2 weeks and before 2 months of starting ART, to optimize outcomes and minimize complications.

choices.text: Dextromethorphan as it does not have addiction potenital like codeine

questions.text: 70y old known case of bronchiectasis came with history of worsening of cough. Which of the following statement is true about the drugs that could have been prescribed
questions.solution:
• Bromhexine belongs to Mucolytics.
  • It should be used in patients with productive cough as it liquifies the sputum by depolarising the Mucopolysacharides.
  • Other Mucolytics are Ambroxol, N Acteyl Cysteine. Codeine and Dextromethorphan are Anti Tussives used in dry cough.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page No 238-239.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with increased cough, increased breathlessness, and decreased exercise capacity. Chest X-ray shows pulmonary fibrosis. Which drug can be administered in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, Pirfenidone is indicated for the treatment of pulmonary fibrosis.

Pirfenidone is a novel anti-fibrotic medication that has been approved for managing Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) in patients with mild to moderate disease. It works by inhibiting the progression of fibrosis and the decline in lung function associated with IPF, leveraging its anti-fibrotic, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant properties.

Additionally, Pirfenidone inhibits growth factors that play a role in connective tissue proliferation and is also approved for treating acute exacerbations of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

questions.text: A male develops tightness in the chest, associated with breathlessness and altered sensorium during his trek towards a mountain peak. Which of the following can be given for symptomatic relief?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of acute mountain sickness (AMS) or early high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE):

    • Chest tightness, breathlessness, altered sensorium at high altitude.

  • Acetazolamide is used for symptomatic relief and prophylaxis of AMS:

    • Mechanism: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor → causes mild metabolic acidosis → stimulates ventilation, improving oxygenation.

    • Also helps prevent high-altitude cerebral edema (HACE).

Other options:

  • Digoxin: Used for heart failure/arrhythmias; no role in AMS or HAPE.

  • Diltiazem: Calcium channel blocker; sometimes used in HAPE prophylaxis in specific cases, but not first-line for general AMS symptom relief.

  • Mannitol: Osmotic diuretic; used for cerebral edema in intracranial hypertension, not AMS.


Reference:
1. goodman & gillman's the pharmacological basis of therapeutics - 13th edition - page no 451
2. k.d tripathi - essentials of medical pharmacology 8th edition - page no. 634

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty with a chronic dry cough with no fever or other associated symptoms. He had recently been started on an antihypertensive for hypertension. Which among the following is most likely responsible to cause these symptoms?
questions.solution:
This is a classic presentation of ACE inhibitor-induced dry cough, a common side effect of medications like enalapril, lisinopril, and ramipril, which are used for hypertension.

Mechanism:

  • ACE inhibitors block the Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE).

  • ACE normally degrades bradykinin, a vasodilator.

  • When ACE is inhibited, bradykinin accumulates, leading to:

    • Stimulation of sensory nerves in the airway

    • Resulting in persistent dry (non-productive) cough

      Why others are incorrect:

  • 2. Angiotensin II and bradykinin:

    • Angiotensin II is decreased by ACE inhibitors, not increased. It is not responsible for cough.

  • 3. Bradykinin and renin:

    • Renin is not directly related to the cough. Its levels may rise due to compensatory feedback, but it doesn’t cause the cough.

  • 4. Histamine:

    • Histamine can cause cough in allergies or anaphylaxis but is not involved in ACE inhibitor-induced cough.

      Clinical Pearl:

    • Switching to an ARB (Angiotensin Receptor Blocker, e.g., losartan or telmisartan) is advised if cough becomes intolerable, as ARBs do not affect bradykinin metabolism.


Reference:Goodman and gillmans The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics 13th edition page no 483-484

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease who is on inhaled salmeterol therapy presents to the outpatient department with complaints that there is no improvement. Which of the following drugs can be added to his regime?
questions.solution:
This patient is on salmeterol, a long-acting beta-2 agonist (LABA). If symptoms persist despite LABA monotherapy, step-up therapy is appropriate based on GOLD (Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease) guidelines.

Ipratropium:

  • It is a short-acting muscarinic antagonist (SAMA).

  • When combined with a beta-agonist, it provides synergistic bronchodilation by targeting different pathways.

  • Particularly helpful in moderate to severe COPD when LABA alone is insufficient.

  • Safe, inhaled, and effective as an add-on therapy.

    Why the other options are incorrect:

  • 1. Oral glucocorticoids:

    • Not used routinely in stable COPD due to long-term systemic side effects.

    • Reserved for acute exacerbations or very severe disease refractory to other treatments.

  • 3. Azithromycin:

    • Used in selected cases to prevent frequent exacerbations, especially in patients with ≥2 exacerbations/year.

    • Not the first add-on for symptom control.

  • 4. Theophylline:

    • An oral bronchodilator with narrow therapeutic window and significant side effects (arrhythmias, seizures).

    • Rarely used now due to better alternatives.

    • Only considered in resource-limited settings or as a last resort.

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1997

questions.text: A 30-year-old man joins a pilgrimage to a shrine at a mountain peak. At the summit, he develops tightness in the chest, associated with breathlessness and altered sensorium. Which of the following can be given for symptomatic relief?
questions.solution:
This is a classical case of Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS), potentially progressing to High Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE) or High Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE) — both of which can present with:

  • Chest tightness, breathlessness (suggests HAPE)

  • Altered sensorium (suggests HACE)

    Role of Acetazolamide:

  • It is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor.

  • Induces metabolic acidosis, which stimulates ventilation.

  • Improves oxygenation and helps in acclimatization.

  • Used for both prevention and symptomatic relief of AMS and early HACE.

    Why others are incorrect:

  • 2. Mannitol
    – Used to lower intracranial pressure (e.g., trauma, edema), but not useful in high-altitude illness.
    – It may worsen dehydration at high altitudes.

  • 3. Digoxin
    – Used in heart failure and atrial fibrillation, has no role in high-altitude illness.

  • 4. Diltiazem
    – A calcium channel blocker used for angina and hypertension, not effective in AMS or HAPE.


Reference:Goodman and gillmans The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics 13th edition page no 451

questions.text: Pick the option that is not a side effect of long-term use of PPI.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hypothyroidism

Proton Pump Inhibitors have not yet been found to cause hypothyroidism.

They inhibit acid secretion - their long-term use increases the chances of infections like Community-acquired pneumonia
and Clostridium difficile. They can also lead to hypocalcemia leading to osteoporosis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 700.

choices.text: Causes irreversible inhibition of proton pump. Acid secretion suppressed till new pumps are generated
Prodrugs and needs generation of active metabolites

questions.text: Why does PPI act longer despite having a short half-life?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Causes irreversible inhibition of proton pump. Acid secretion suppressed till new pumps are generated
 
  • Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs) are a type of pharmaceutical drug used to reduce the production of stomach acid. Despite their relatively short half-lives of around two hours, they can still cause prolonged suppression of acid secretion for up to 48 hours, due to their effect on the proton pumps which produce the acid.
  • The PPIs bind to and irreversibly inhibit the proton pump molecules, meaning that for acid secretion to occur again, new proton pumps need to be synthesized. Therefore, although the PPIs are short-lived, their effects can be prolonged due to the time taken for new proton pumps to be made.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 700.

choices.text: Change atenolol and thiazide to calcium channel blocker and ACE inhibitor and add bisacodyl for constipation
Change imipramine and haloperidol to fluoxetine and risperidone and add bisacodyl for constipation
Only add bisacodyl for constipation and continue rest of the medications
Discontinue all her medications and start her on steroids

questions.text: A 86-year-old woman arrived at the clinic with acute constipation. She had been taking medicine for five years as a recognised hypertension. Her blood pressure was  157/98 mm Hg in the clinic. A supine blood pressure reading revealed a reading of 90/60 mm Hg. She has just experienced depression. She is taking docusate, imipramine, haloperidol, atenolol, thiazide as medications. What is the management's best course of action going forward?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Change imipramine and haloperidol to fluoxetine and risperidone and add bisacodyl for constipation

Considering the symptoms given in the problem, imipramine and haloperidol must be changed to fluoxetine and risperidone and add bisacodyl for constipation.
 
  • This patient's postural hypotension is most likely caused by imipramine's alpha blocking and its interactions with thiazides.
  • She also has Imipramine's anticholinergic side effects (constipation). Imipramine, a TCA, must thus be stopped, and Fluoxetine, an SSRI, together with a laxative to treat any existing constipation, should be begun.  
  • Additionally, because Haloperidol and other conventional antipsychotics have anticholinergic adverse effects, she should begin taking the atypical antipsychotic Risperidone(with lesser anticholinergic side effects).
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 485.

questions.text: Which of these inhibits CYP450 the least?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Rabeprazole

  • Rabeprazole is exclusively metabolized by CYP2C19 and does not cause any inhibition of CYP450.
  • Among the PPIs, only omeprazole inhibits CYP2C19 (thereby decreasing the clearance of disulfiram, phenytoin, and other drugs) and induces the expression of CYP1A2 (thereby increasing the clearance of imipramine, several antipsychotic drugs, tacrolimus, and theophylline).


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 701.

questions.text: What aspect of metoclopramide causes its antiemetic effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) D2 antagonist

  • Metoclopramide is a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist and is also a mixed 5-HT3 receptor antagonist & 5-HT4 receptor agonist.
  • The antiemetic action of metoclopramide is due to its antagonist activity at D2 receptors in the chemoreceptor trigger zone in the central nervous system-this action prevents nausea & vomiting triggered by most stimuli.
  • At higher doses, 5-HT3 antagonists' activity may also contribute to the antiemetic effect.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 713.

questions.text: What are the effects of laxative abuse?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hypokalemia

* Following are the complications of Chronic Laxative Abuse:

  • c. Secondary hyperaldosteronism
  • d. Hypermagnesemia - magnesium containing preparations
  • e. Acute phosphate nephropathy
  • f. Metabolic alkalosis
  • g. Pancreatic damage (but no changes in glucose levels)
  • h. Ileocecal sphincter dilatation
  • i. Colonic inflammation
  • j. Urolithiasis

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 1128.

questions.text: The intern administered an antiemetic medicine to a patient who had a history of a few episodes of vomiting. A few hours later, the patient's posture began to change. Which of the following medication administrations is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Metoclopramide
 
  • Metoclopramide has a central anti-dopaminergic (D2) action on the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ), which is the primary cause of its antiemetic property.
  • This action of metoclopramide also leads to certain major side effects such as extrapyramidal effects like dystonias, akathisia and parkinsonian features that are observed in individuals who take the drug to control vomiting.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 713.

questions.text: A patient on phenytoin for seizure disorder was prescribed sucralfate 4 times a day for peptic ulcer. What should be the minimum duration between consumption of two drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) 120 min

  • Sucralfate is a gastroprotective agent used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease, oesophageal ulcers and as prophylaxis in radiation proctitis and stress ulcers. It acts by increasing prostaglandin secretion and also increases gastric pH.
  • Phenytoin is a weakly acidic drug and is absorbed from the stomach. Sucralfate raises the gastric pH, hence phenytoin will be in ionised form and can’t be absorbed normally.

So, a minimum gap of 2 hours must be present between consumption of phenytoin and sucralfate for phenytoin to be effective.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 21.

questions.text: Which statement regarding octreotide is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Used in secretory diarrhea

Octreotide is used in secretory diarrhea. Octreotide is an octapeptide analog of somatostatin, effective in inhibiting the severe secretory diarrhea brought about by hormone-secreting tumors of the pancreas and the GI tract. It is preferentially administered subcutaneously.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 928.

choices.text: Ranitidine combines with sucralfate and prevents its action
Combination produces serious side effects like agranulocytosis
Ranitidine increases the gastric pH so sucralfate is not able to act

questions.text: Why is it wrong to combine ranitidine and sucralfate in a patient with a peptic ulcer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Ranitidine increases the gastric pH so sucralfate is not able to act
  • Ranitidine reduces gastric acid secretion (Increasing the gastric pH) by blocking the H2 receptors on the parietal cells in the stomach.
  • Polymerisation of Sucralfate only occurs at acidic pH - this polymer forms a protective coating over the ulcerated or damaged areas in the stomach preventng ulcer from coming in contact with HCl.
  • When ranitidine and sucralfate are taken together, sucralfate polymerisation is affected due to higher pH - this reduces the efficacy of Sucralfate.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 21.

questions.text: A female suffering from carcinoma of ovary was started on Cisplatin. Later on, she presented to the Emergency department with the complaints of several episodes of vomiting.
