questions.text: A 36-year-old chronic alcoholic male was diagnosed with amoebiasis and was started on anti-amoebic drugs. The patient later developed hypotension along with flushing, nausea, and vomiting. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The patient is a chronic alcoholic and developed hypotension, flushing, nausea, and vomiting after starting anti-amoebic therapy (commonly metronidazole).

Key points:

  • Metronidazole can cause a disulfiram-like reaction when taken with alcohol:

    • Accumulation of acetaldehyde due to inhibition of aldehyde dehydrogenase

    • Symptoms: flushing, headache, nausea, vomiting, hypotension, palpitations

  • Differentiation:

    • Delirium tremens: Severe alcohol withdrawal with agitation, hallucinations, tremors

    • Hallucinosis: Isolated hallucinations, usually without autonomic instability

    • Alcohol withdrawal: General symptoms like tremors, anxiety, not typically hypotension

questions.text: Which of these drugs stimulates PPAR- alpha? PPAR alpha-Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha
questions.solution:
Gemfibrozil is a fibrate that works by stimulating the PPAR-alpha (Peroxisome Proliferator-Activated Receptor alpha), leading to several important effects on lipid metabolism:

Mechanism of Action:
PPAR-alpha activation increases the synthesis of lipoprotein lipase (LPL), an enzyme crucial for the degradation of VLDL (Very Low-Density Lipoproteins). This results in:
• Enhanced clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins.
• Reduction in circulating triglyceride levels.
It also promotes fatty acid oxidation and decreases the expression of apo C-III, a key inhibitor of lipolysis.

Clinical Use:
Gemfibrozil is particularly effective in lowering triglycerides and is used as a first-line drug for patients with markedly elevated triglyceride levels, especially in conditions such as:
• Chylomicronemia and severe hypertriglyceridemia to prevent episodes of acute pancreatitis.
• Type III hyperlipoproteinemia, where it is most effective.

Other Options:

Option A: Colestipol is a Bile acid resin. It binds to the bile acids in gut and promote their excretion, which in turn results in increased conversion of hepatic cholesterol to bile acids, thus reducing the hepatic cholesterol content.

Option C: Simvastatin is a statin, which reduces serum cholesterol levels by inhibiting the HMG CoA reductase enzyme, which is the rate limiting step for cholesterol synthesis.

Option D: Ezetimibe is a lipid lowering drug which works by inhibiting the absorption of cholesterol from the small intestine, leading to a decrease in blood cholesterol levels.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in GERD
questions.solution: In GERD, the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) weakens or relaxes, allowing stomach acid to flow back into the esophagus, causing irritation and symptoms like heartburn and regurgitation. Metoclopramide is useful in this condition because it increases LES tone, preventing acid reflux, and enhances gastric emptying by promoting gastrointestinal motility. Additionally, it reduces nausea and vomiting by blocking dopamine D2 receptors in the CNS. Ref-Katzung Basic and Clinical Pharmacology 14th Edition • Page no: 1097-1098

questions.text: Pick the Antibiotic that is characterized by time-dependent killing and post-antibiotic effect(PAE)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Clindamycin

β-lactams, glycopeptides and macrolides produce ‘time dependent killing’, i.e. antimicrobial action depends on the length of time the concentration remains above the MIC; division of daily dose improves the effect.

Drugs having TDK with post antibiotic effect: -
  • Clindamycin
  • Clarithromycin
  • Linezolid
  • Tetracyclines
  • Azoles
Killing Type Key Drugs Mechanism
Time-Dependent Killing - Beta-lactams (e.g., Penicillins, Cephalosporins 1st and 2nd gen), Vancomycin- Clindamycin - Effectiveness depends on time above MIC.
Concentration-Dependent Killing - Aminoglycosides- Daptomycin- 3rd & 4th Gen Cephalosporins , Azithromycin, Doxycycline - Effectiveness increases with higher drug concentration.
Both - Fluoroquinolones- Clarithromycin - Needs both time above MIC and high concentration for maximum effect.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 748.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about H1N1 influenza is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Pregnant woman with sore throat can be started immediately on oseltamivir without diagnostic testing under category B

Regarding H1N1 Influenza, a pregnant woman with a sore throat can be started immediately on oseltamivir without diagnostic testing under category B.

* Category A Patient Of H1N1 Influenza:
Patients with mild fever (less than 380 C) plus cough / sore throat with or without bodyache, headache, diarrhoea and vomitting will be categorized as Category-A. They do not require Oseltamivir and should be treated for the symptoms mentioned above. The patients should be monitored for their progress and reassessed at 24 to 48 hours by the doctor.

* Category B Patient of H1N1 Influenza:
In addition to all the signs and symptoms mentioned under Category-A, if the patient has high grade fever (Above 380 C) and severe sore throat, may require home isolation and Oseltamivir.
In addition to all the signs and symptoms mentioned under Category-A, individuals having one or more of the following high-risk conditions shall be treated with Oseltamivir:
 Children with mild illness but with predisposing risk factors.
 Pregnant women;
 Persons aged 65 years or older;
 Patients with lung diseases, heart disease, liver disease, Kidney disease, blood disorders, diabetes, neurological disorders, cancer and HIV/AIDS;
Patients on long term cortisone therapy.
 No test for Influenza is required for Category-B (i) and (ii).
 All patients of Category-B (i) and (ii) should confine themselves at home and avoid mixing with public and high risk members in the family.
 Broad Spectrum antibiotics as per the Guideline for Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) may be prescribed.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 853.
Online Reference: Guidelines on categorization of Influenza A H1N1 cases during screening for home isolation, testing treatment, and hospitalization (Revised on 05.10.09) https://mohfw.gov.in/sites/default/files/224678457.pdf

* Second line drugs – Ofloxacin, Moxifloxacin, Clarithromycin, Minocycline

Regimen suggested by NLEP


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 763.

choices.text: Inhibition of conversion of RNA to DNA

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of protease inhibitors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Inhibition of assembly of viral proteins

The action of protease inhibitors is to prevent the cleavage of viral polyprotein precursors into mature functional proteins which are necessary for replication.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 864.

questions.text: Which of the following carbamazepine side effects are not idiosyncratic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Blurred vision

Idiosyncratic reactions are adverse effects that cannot be explained by the known mechanisms of the drug, usually mediated by cytotoxic or immunologic effects triggered by the drug in an individual.

* Examples of idiosyncratic reactions by carbamazepine: -
  • DRESS
  • Skin rashes/SJS/TEN
  • Pseudolymphoma
  • Agranulocytosis, Aplastic anemia
  • Liver toxicity

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 442.

questions.text: Choose the antibiotic that can be used in the treatment of fungal keratomycosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Silver sulfadiazine

Silver sulfadiazine is a broad-spectrum antibiotic which acts on gram positive and negative organisms and certain yeasts like C. Albicans. It has been found to be more effective than Miconazole in Ocular keratomycosis according to some trials.

* Mechanism of action – inhibits dihydropteroate synthase

Easy Trick to conclude answer, all other drugs are antibiotics used in bacterial infection, so they won't be the answer.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 757.

questions.text: Select the most effective treatment of severe malaria.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Artesunate

Artesunate (Artemisinin based combination therapy) is the best treatment for severe/complicated cases of Malaria.

Option 1: Doxycycline is the DOC in malaria prophylaxis if the duration of travel is <6 weeks and in treatment if ACT is not available.

Option 2: Primaquine kills hypnozoites and thus provides radical cure by preventing relapse.

Option 3: Chloroquine is used for treatment of uncomplicated malaria caused by P. Vivax, uncomplicated malaria in pregnancy and in case of ACT resistance

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 887.

questions.text:
Some gram-negative bacteria develop an enzyme that prevents beta lactam antibiotics from acting in the periplasm.
Which arrow in the Penicillin G structural diagram represents the site of action of this enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) B
 
  • Beta-lactam is an amide bond found in the structure of Penicillin G, as represented by 'B' above.
  • Beta-lactamases are the enzymes produced by some bacteria which provide resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics like penicillins, cephamycins, and carbapenems by breaking the antibiotics' structure. 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 766.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below is not used to treat bird flu?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ribavirin 

  • There are specific antiviral medications for influenza, including amantadine and rimantadine for influenza A as well as the neuraminidase inhibitors zanamivir, oseltamivir, and peramivir for both influenza A and influenza B.
  • A nucleoside analogue ribavirin has action in vitro against influenza A and B viruses.
  • When given as an aerosol, it has been reported to be varyingly effective against influenza but ineffective when given orally.
  • Its effectiveness in treating influenza A or B has not been shown.
  • Hepatitis C, viral hemorrhagic fevers, and RSV are the main conditions that ribavirin is used to treat.
* Audio Explanation:


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 856.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs absorbs most readily after a fatty meal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Griseofulvin
 
  • Griseofulvin inhibits microtubule formation and thereby disrupts the assembly of the mitotic spindle.
  • Improved absorption when the drug is taken with a fatty meal. 
* [Extra Edge]: Griseofulvin
  1. Griseofulvin interferes with mitosis—multi­ nucleated and stunted fungal hyphae are produced under its action. Metaphase arrest does not occur, but daughter nuclei fail to move apart or move only a short distance. It binds to polymerized microtubules and interferes with their function.
  2. The absorption of griseofulvin from g.i.t. is incomplete because of very low water solubility. Absorption is improved by taking it with fats and by microfining the drug particles. Griseofulvin is keratophilic; gets deposited in keratin forming cells of skin, hair and nails.
  3. Griseofulvin is used orally only for dermatophytosis. On getting deposited in the skin through circulation, it prevents fungal invasion of keratin. Because it is fungistatic and not cidal, the newly formed keratin is not invaded by the fungus, but the fungus persists in already infected keratin, till it is shed off.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 77.

questions.text: Which of the following has recently been approved as a treatment for multidrug resistant tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Bedaquiline
 
  • The FDA granted bedaquiline approval on December 28, 2012. It is specially approved to treat multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis and was the first novel treatment to treat TB in more than 40 years.
  • The ATP synthase proton pump is impacted by bedaquiline. All other quinolone antibiotics target DNA gyrase; this method does not.
  • Recently BPaLM regime is recommended for treatment of drug-resistant TB by Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.

  • BPaLM regimen consisting of four-drug combination – Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, Linezolid and Moxifloxacin, has been proven to be safe, more effective and a quicker treatment option than the previous MDR-TB treatment procedure.
     

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 822.
Recent Update: https://www.mohfw.gov.in/?q=/press-info/7673

questions.text: Which one of these is a new oral medication used to treat chronic Hepatitis C?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ledipasvir

Ledipasvir is an Inhibitor of NS5A protein. 
Commonly used in combination with sofosbuvir for treatment in chronic hepatitis C genotype I patients. 
Standard treatment regimen for Hep C - Sofosbuvir + Velpatasvir x 12 weeks
Other options: -
  • Interferon alpha and Lamivudine are used in the treatment of chronic Hepatitis B 
  • Oseltamivir is used in the treatment of Influenza
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 859.

questions.text: Which of the following medications kills gametes of all Plasmodium species?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Primaquine

Primaquine is gametocidal for all species of Plasmodium.
 
  • Primaquine is effective against all human malaria parasites in their hepatic stages.
  • It is the sole treatment on the market that is effective against P vivax and P. ovale's dormant hypnozoite stages.
  • Moreover, the medication shows modest efficacy against parasites in the erythrocytic stage and is gametocidal against all four human malaria species.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 878.

questions.text: Which of the given options is an antitubercular medicine that causes ophthalmic toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Ethambutol

Ethambutol can cause ophthalmic toxicity in the form of optic neuritis and red green colorblindness.

* Ethambutol:
  • Retrobulbar neuritis, which causes a loss of visual acuity and red-green colorblindness, is the most frequent major adverse effect.
  • When dosages of 25 mg/kg/d are sustained for several months, this dose-related adverse effect is more likely to develop.
  • Specialists advise baseline and recurring assessments of color perception and visual acuity, paying particular attention to those who are taking higher doses or who have other conditions.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 820.

questions.text:
A patient is being treated with indinavir, zidovudine, lamivudine, and ketoconazole. Which drug is responsible for his development of central obesity,
nephrolithiasis, hyperlipidemia, and breast hypertrophy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Indinavir 

Protease inhibitors like indinavir can cause nephrolithiasis.
 
  • Protease inhibitors frequently cause gynecomastia/breast enlargement, dyslipidemia, and obesity.
  • Gynecomastia and breast enlargement are possible adverse effects of Ketoconazole, although none of the others are observed. Zidovudine and stavudine, two NRTIs, produce lipodystrophy and not obesity.

ART Side effects- 

Drug Class Common Drugs Most Common Side Effects
NRTIs - Abacavir- Tenofovir- Lamivudine - Lactic acidosis- Renal toxicity (Tenofovir)- Hypersensitivity (Abacavir)
NNRTIs - Efavirenz - Rash- CNS effects (Efavirenz)- Hepatotoxicity
PIs - Atazanavir- Darunavir - Hyperlipidemia- GI upset- Fat redistribution
Integrase Inhibitors - Dolutegravir - GI upset- Insomnia
Entry Inhibitors - Maraviroc - Hepatotoxicity- Muscle/joint pain
Pharmacokinetic Enhancers - Ritonavir- Cobicistat - GI upset- Liver enzyme elevation

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 865.

choices.text: Inhibition of sterol of the cell wall
Competes with PABA in folic acid synthesis

questions.text: Dapsone is employed as an immunomodulator, antifungal, and antibacterial. What process underlies each of these actions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Competes with PABA in folic acid synthesis

Dapsone Competes with PABA in folic acid synthesis.
 
  • Dapsone is a competitive inhibitor of dihydropteroate synthase (folP1/P2) in the folate pathway and a structural analogue of para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA).
  • Dapsone's impact on this evolutionarily conserved route also explains why it has antibacterial, anti-protozoal, and antifungal properties.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 831.

questions.text: A pediatrician attended an infant who had an unconjugated serum bilirubin level of 33 mg/dL. What medications could the mother have taken during the third trimester?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Cotrimoxazole
 
  • Cotrimoxazole if given near term may cause neonatal hemolysis and methemoglobinemia.
  • Cotrimoxazole is not clearly proven to be hazardous during pregnancy, especially if the dosage is decreased early on to diminish the minor risk of fetal hemolysis and methemoglobinemia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 758.

questions.text: Which of the following dose reductions is not required in renal failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Doxycycline 
 
  • Doxycycline is safe in renal failure dose reduction is not required.
  • In contrast to tigecycline, which is primarily excreted intact along with a minor quantity of glucuronidated metabolites, and minocycline, which is significantly processed by the liver prior to excretion, doxycycline is largely excreted unchanged in both the bile and urine.
  • The dosages of these drugs don't need to be adjusted for people with renal failure.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 79.

questions.text: What is the vancomycin's mode of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Cell wall synthesis inhibition
 
  • Vancomycin inhibits cell wall synthesis.
  • Vancomycin and teicoplanin bind with a high affinity to the D-alanyl-D-alanine terminal of cell wall precursor units to prevent sensitive bacteria from synthesizing cell walls.
  • They cannot pierce the gram-negative bacteria's outer membrane due to their huge molecular size.
  • Vancomycin infusion is associated with red man syndrome due to degranulation of mast cells. 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 806.

questions.text: A patient on antitubercular medication experienced tingling in his lower limb. Which of the following, when substituted, can result in symptom improvement?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Pyridoxine
 
  • Pyridoxine can be given for improvement of symptoms.
  • Pyridoxine can be used as a preventative measure to halt ATT-induced neuropathy. Peripheral neuritis, which most frequently manifests as paresthesia of the hands and feet in patients taking isoniazid 5 mg/kg daily, can develop if pyridoxine is not administered concurrently.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 829.

questions.text: Which is the preferred medicine for scrub typhus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Doxycycline

Scrub typhus is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. The drug of choice for scrub typhus is doxycycline.



Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1182.

questions.text: Which of the following single agent can provide adequate antimicrobial cover to a patient with gonococcal as well as non-gonococcal urethritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Azithromycin 2 gm oral single dose.
 
  • Treatment of choice for a patient with gonococcal as well as non-gonococcal urethritis is Azithromycin 2gm oral single dose.
  • A single 1-g dose of azithromycin has an unacceptable low cure rate (93%) for gonococcal infections and should not be administered by itself while it has a successful treatment for uncomplicated chlamydial infections.
  • A single 2-g dose of azithromycin, especially in the extended-release microsphere formulation, is more tolerable since it is delivered to the lower gastrointestinal tract.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 804.

questions.text: Drug induced colitis is most frequently associated with?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Clindamycin
 
  • Drug-induced colitis is an inflammation of the lining of the intestine that is caused by allergens, irritants, toxins, or medications.
  • Clindamycin is one of the medications most commonly associated with this condition.
  • The risk of colitis is increased when higher doses of clindamycin are used over a long period of time. Symptoms of drug-induced colitis include abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, fever, and blood in the stool. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 805.

choices.text: Rifabutin has the longer half-life than rifampicin
Rifabutin is more efficacious against MAC as compared to rifampicin
Rifabutin is more efficacious for pulmonary TB as compared to rifampicin

questions.text: Select the statement that is not true about rifabutin as compared to rifampicin.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Rifabutin is more efficacious for pulmonary TB as compared to rifampicin

Rifabutin is more effective than Rifampicin against Mycobacterium avium but not against Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

All of the other statements are true in case of Rifabutin.

Characteristic Rifabutin Rifampicin
Indications - TB (Tuberculosis)- MAC (Mycobacterium avium complex) - TB (Tuberculosis)- Leprosy- Meningococcal carriers
Drug Interactions Fewer interactions with other drugs compared to Rifampicin Strong enzyme inducer (CYP450), many drug interactions
Side Effects - Less hepatotoxicity- Uveitis (eye inflammation) - Hepatotoxicity- Orange-red discoloration of body fluids
Half-Life Longer half-life than Rifampicin Shorter half-life than Rifabutin
Usage Often used in HIV patients or those on ART due to fewer interactions Typically used in standard TB treatment regimens
Dosage Lower dosage compared to Rifampicin Higher dosage required compared to Rifabutin
Effectiveness More effective against MAC than Rifampicin More effective against TB than Rifabutin
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 822.

questions.text: What causes delayed post-antibiotic effects and time-dependent killing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Clindamycin 
 
  • Time dependent killing and post antibiotic effects are seen in clindamycin out of the following options.
  • Killing effect of these drugs depends on the length of time the concentration remains above MIC and also there is inhibitory effect of antibiotics even when their concentration is below MIC.
* Drugs having time-dependent killing and post antibiotic effect are : -
  • Clindamycin
  • Clarithromycin
  • Linezolid
  • Streptogramins 
  • Tetracyclines
  • Azoles
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 805.

questions.text: Which of the following does not include non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NN-RTIs)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Lamivudine

Lamivudine is a Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors (NRIT) and not Non - Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors (NNRIT)

Trick to memorize NNRTI: - END RT
Efavirenz, Etravirine
Nevirapine
Delaviridine

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 863.

questions.text: Which among the following antitubercular medications is linked to hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Ethionamide
 
  • It has been observed that ethionamide, which belongs to the second line of anti-tubercular drugs, may induce hypothyroidism, possibly because its structure is similar to methimazole, a known inhibitor of thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • This hypothyroidism caused by ethionamide is at least partly reversible upon cessation of the drug.
  • Additionally, para-amino salicylate (PAS) has also been shown to lead to hypothyroidism.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 821.

questions.text: A humanized monoclonal antibody is called palivizumab. Which of the ensuing circumstances has it been authorised for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Respiratory syncytial virus
 
  • Infections with the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) can be prevented and treated using the monoclonal antibody palivizumab.
  • It is advised for infants who are at high risk due to preterm or other health issues, such as congenital heart disease.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 802.

questions.text: A patient receiving amphotericin B develops 2.3 mEq/l of hypokalemia. How much K + supplementation is required?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) 120-160 mEq over 24 hours
 
  • Here we need to correct potassium from 2.3mEq/L to 3mEq/L, therefore the difference is of 0.7mEq/L For every 1mEq/L increase in K+, KCl required is 200meq So the amount of KCl will be 0.7 x 200 = 140 mEq
  • Thus, the correct answer is 120-160 mEq over 24 hrs.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 531.

questions.text: All of the following medications metabolism is inhibited by Ritonavir with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Phenytoin 
 
  • All protease inhibitors inhibit the metabolism of drugs by CYP3A4 - Hence, Ritonavir Inhibits the metabolism of Amiodarone, Cisapride, and Midazolam, but not Phenytoin.
  • This is because majority (95%) of phenytoin is metabolized principally in the hepatic endoplasmic reticulum by CYP2C9/10. 
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1255.

questions.text: In which of the following can you observe time-dependent killing and prolonged post- antibiotic effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Clindamycin 
 
  • Time dependent killing and prolonged post-antibiotic effect is seen with Clindamycin. 
  • Time dependent killing with short post-antibiotic effect is seen with b-lactam antibiotics, vancomycin and flucytosine. They require continuous IV infusion or multiple dosing. 
  • Time dependent killing with prolonged post antibiotic effect- Protein synthesis inhibitors (except aminoglycosides and azithromycin) and azoles. 
  • Concentration dependent killing with prolonged post-antibiotic effect- Aminoglycosides, FQs, Metronidazole, Rifampicin and Amphotericin B. 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 748.

questions.text: After receiving a sulfa medication, a 16-year-old girl complained of stomach pain. She had a seizure and was incoherent. Which of the following is the more likely scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Acute intermittent porphyria
 
  • Acute Intermittent Porphyria is a autosomal dominant condition resulting from half-normal level of HMB synthase activity.
  • Its Precipitating factors: Endogenous & exogenous steroids, porphyrinogenic drugs, alcohol ingestion, low-calorie diets.
  • It is seen more commonly in women.
  • It presents with pain abdomen.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 34.

questions.text: An appetite loss and abdominal distention have been present for the last week in a 50-year-old male with fever. Antibiotics and malaria medications are having no effect on it. RK39 dipstick test is positive but Widal test is negative. Which medications are appropriate for the patient mentioned above?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Liposomal amphotericin B
 
  • The rK39 dipstick test is an immunochromatographic method commonly employed to diagnose visceral leishmaniasis.
  • The recommended course of therapy for this condition is liposomal amphotericin B, considered to be first line treatment since resistance to sodium stibogluconate has increased in some regions.
  • Doses of 3-4 mg/kg daily are known to be effective for treating visceral leishmaniasis with L-AMB.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 903.

choices.text: Azoles (fluconazole, itraconazole, miconazole): Inhibit lanosterol alpha demethylase thereby preventing ergosterol synthesis
Flucytosine: Inhibit microtubules synthesis thus preventing mitosis
Echinocandins (Caspofungin): act by inhibiting beta 1,3 glucan synthesis
Amphotericin B binds with ergosterol resulting in disruption of cell membrane causing micropores and leakage of ions and cell death

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the mechanism of action of anti-fungal medications is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Flucytosine: Inhibit microtubules synthesis thus preventing mitosis 
 
  • The uptake of flucytosine by fungal cells is facilitated by cytosine permease.
  • It is then transformed through various steps into 5-FU, 5-fluorodeoxyuridine monophosphate (FdUMP), and fluorouridine triphosphate (FUTP), which prevent DNA and RNA synthesis respectively.
  • This conversion is not able to happen in human cells, so flucytosine has selective toxicity which does not impede microtubule synthesis.

 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 843.

questions.text: Which antifungal medication, which has not been used for Tinea corporis and Tinea cruris over the past two years, is developing drug resistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Griseofulvin 
 
  • Griseofulvin is an oral medication used for the treatment of tinea infection.
  • Unfortunately, its efficacy has been diminishing in recent years due to an increase in resistant strains, leading to its replacement by more effective antifungal agents, such as terbinafine and itraconazole, as the go-to medication.
  • Topical application is not effective with this drug.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1204.

questions.text: Ceftriaxone 180 mg is required for a patient. There are 10 divisions per millilitre in your 2 ml syringe. 500 mg/5 ml of ceftriaxone are present in the vial. To administer 180 mg of ceftriaxone, how many divisions in a 2 ml syringe should you fill?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 18

To give the patient 180 mg of ceftriaxone, 1.8 mL of drug solution is required in a 2 mL syringe. This holds 10 divisions per mL, equalling 18 divisions being filled in the syringe.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 24.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below is not used to treat typhoid fever?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Amikacin 
 
  • Amikacin, a widely used aminoglycoside, does not have Salmonella in its antimicrobial spectrum, but is often employed for treating gentamicin and tobramycin resistant diseases, as well as MDR-TB.
  • It also works efficiently against Pseudomonas, Proteus and Serratia.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 762.

questions.text: It was determined that a patient from the northeastern states had P. falciparum malaria. What medication is best for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Artemether plus lumefantrine
 
  • The most effective medication for a patient with a Plasmodium falciparum malaria infection is a combination of artemether and lumefantrine.
  • This combination is specifically designed to treat acute, uncomplicated cases of falciparum malaria acquired in areas in which P. falciparum is resistant to chloroquine and antifolate drugs. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 889.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Doxycycline

Orientia tsutsugamushi is the bacteria that causes scrub typhus, which is transmitted by tiny mites or chiggers.
Doxycycline is the recommended medication to treat scrub typhus.



Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1182.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below is frequently prescribed for community-acquired pneumonia in the OPD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Azithromycin

Azithromycin, as a 500-mg loading dose, followed by a 250-mg single daily dose for the next 4 days, is commonly used alone or in combination with a beta-lactam antibiotic to treat community-acquired pneumonia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 804.

questions.text: A young person reports penicillin allergy and meningococcal meningitis. Which medication is best for them:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Chloramphenicol
 
  • Among the given options, Chloramphenicol is the best answer.
  • Management of bacterial meningitis Empirical treatment should be started within 60 minutes of hospitalisation.
  • Give penicillin to penicillin sensitive pneumococci and meningococci cases Cefriaxone + Vancomycin in penicillin resistant cases Chloramphenicol is used as third line.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 790.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions in a patient taking linezolid therapy needs to be watched over?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Platelet count

Linezolid causes bone marrow suppression leading to anemia, thrombocytopenia and leukemia.

* Some points about Linezolid
  • Group – Oxazolidinones
  • MOA – block translocation
  • 100% oral bioavailability
  • S/E – Bone marrow suppression, Serotonin syndrome, Lactic acidosis, Peripheral neuropathy
  • Use – MRSA and VRSA infections

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 807.

questions.text: Pancreatitis occurs in tandem with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Didanosine

Didanosine is not used anymore because it causes pancreatitis.

* Anti-retro viral drugs and their side effects


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 862.

questions.text: Which of these can lower Amphotericin B toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Using Liposomal Delivery systems
 
  • Liposomal delivery systems lower the nephrotoxicity of amphotericin B.
  • Another way is to pre-load the patient with 1-2 liters of NS
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 839.

choices.text: More potent than penicillamine and orally absorbed
Not given with iron within two hours of ingestion

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Trientine is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) More potent than penicillamine and orally absorbed
 
  • Penicillamine is more potent among the two.
  • Trientine is an alternative to penicillamine and is preferred in cases where penicillamine is not well tolerated or shows adverse reactions.
  • It is used in Wilson’s disease. It forms stable complexes with copper and prevents is absorption in GIT, thus excess copper is excreted.
  • As it has the ability of forming stable complexes with metal ions, it decreases iron absorption and thus may cause IDA.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1523.

questions.text: Amphotericin B acts at the following sites:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Plasma membrane
 
  • Amphotericin B acts on ergosterol present in cell membrane. Answer is Cell/plasma membrane.
  • Cholesterol, present in host cell membranes, closely resembles ergosterol; the polyenes bind to cholesterol as well, though with lesser affinity.
  • Thus, the selectivity of action of polyenes is low, and AMB is one of the most toxic systemically used antibiotics, though it is the least toxic polyene. Bacteria do not have sterols and are unaffected by polyenes.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 839.

questions.text: Which antiviral(HIV) medication also has hepatitis-fighting properties?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Tenofovir

Amongst the given options - Tenofovir exhibits activity against both HIV and Hepatitis B.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 855.

questions.text: Which medicine regimen is prescribed to an HIV-infected pregnant woman?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) All 
 
  • Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutigravir (TLD Regimen)is the 1st line agents, but all of the given options can be used.
  • Health care workers exposed to blood by needle stick injury are to be protected by TLD
  • The offspring of HIV positive pregnant woman can be protected by treating the woman with TLD
  • After delivery the neonate should be given syrup nevirapine for 6 weeks.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 751.

choices.text: Beta lactamase production is the most common mechanism of resistance
Alteration in target PBPs is an important resistance mechanism in gram negative bacteria
Alteration in permeability/penetration of antibiotic causes resistance only in gram negative bacteria
Beta lactamase production causes resistance in both gram positive and gram negative bacteria

questions.text: The following statements about penicillin resistance are all accurate, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Alteration in target PBPs is an important resistance mechanism in gram negative bacteria

* A FEW IMPORTANT POINTS ON ANTIMICROBIAL RESISTANCE FREQUENTLY ASKED: -
 
  • Beta lactamase production is the most common mechanism of resistance. This causes resistance in gram positive organisms like (Streptococcus, Actinomyces); gram negative organisms like (Neisseria, spirochetes)
  • Alteration in Penicillin binding proteins lead to resistance against drugs like Methicillin (MRSA)—Staphylococcus aureus is gram positive organism
  • Cephalosporin resistance – Presence of enzyme like cephalosporinase
  • Carbapenem resistance – Presence of Carbapenems
  • Vancomycin resistance – Amino acid modification of D-ALA, D-ALA
  • Aminoglycoside resistance – Bacterial Transferase enzyme
  • Chloramphenicol resistance – Plasmid coded acetyltransferase
  • Tetracycline resistance – Changes in uptake/ efflux by plasmid coded transport pumps
  • Linezolid resistance – Point mutation of rRNA
  • Sulphonamide resistance – Alteration of enzymes Bacterial Dihydropteroate synthase
  • Fluroquinolone resistance – Chromosome coded mutation in DNA gyrase, plasmid mediated resistance, efflux pumps
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 767.

questions.text: Anaerobes are inherently resistant to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Aminoglycosides
 
  • Aminoglycosides are bactericidal drugs which cause irreversible inhibition of Initiation complex by binding with 30S subunit of ribosome.
  • This leads to misreading of mRNA thereby blocking the process of Transcription. However Aminoglycosides always require oxygen for their uptake and thus is ineffective against Anaerobes.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 794.

questions.text: Which antibiotic is not bacteriostatic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Vancomycin

*Mechanism of Action:
  • Vancomycin acts by inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis.
  • It binds to the terminal dipeptide ‘D-ala-D-ala’ sequence of peptidoglycan units—prevents its release from the bactoprenol lipid carrier so that assembly of the units at the cell membrane and their cross linking to form the cell wall cannot take place.
Other options: -
  • Tetracyclines and Clindamycin are protein synthesis inhibitors hence are bacteriostatic
  • Cephalosporins also act as bactericidal, but Vancomycin is a better answer

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 741.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics will be prescribed to a bedridden patient with pneumonia and a catheter-related UTI?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Beta Lactam antibiotics with beta lactamase

Beta lactam antibiotics with beta lactamase antibiotic will have greater coverage and will be effective in beta lactamase producing organisms.
They are mostly involved in bedridden patient with pneumonia and a catheter-related UTI.

Beta-lactamase-producing organisms are bacteria that produce an enzyme called beta-lactamase. This enzyme can break down and destroy commonly used antibiotics such as penicillin and cephalosporins, making them ineffective in treatment. Examples of such organisms include:
  • Gram-positive organisms (such as Staphylococcus aureus and Staphylococcus epidermidis).
  • Gram-negative organisms (such as Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Moraxella catarrhalis, Escherichia coli, and Proteus, Serratia, Pseudomonas, and Klebsiella species).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 747.

questions.text: What is Mycoplasma resistant to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ceftriaxone
 
  • Like all microorganisms that lack cell wall, M. pneumoniae is intrinsically resistant to beta-lactams and to all antimicrobials targeting the cell wall, such as glycopeptides and Fosfomycin.  Ceftriaxone is a 3rd generation cephalosporin and hence, a beta lactam and mycoplasma would be resitant to ceftriazxone. 
  • M. pneumoniae is also resistant to polymixins, sulfonamides, trimethoprim, rifampicin and linezolid.
  • Antibiotics with potential activity against M. pneumoniae that are used in clinical practice include macrolides, lincosamides, streptogramin combinations and ketolides (MLSK), tetracyclines and fluoroquinolones.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 778.

questions.text: What amongst the following is not the mechanism of resistance to penicillin ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Alteration in 50S ribosome structure

The three main mechanisms of bacterial resistance to the β-lactam antibiotics are
(i) enzymatic degradation by β-lactamases,
(ii) target modification of the PBPs resulting in a lack of β-lactam binding, and
(iii) regulation of β-lactam entry and efflux.

Penicillin is a bacterial cell wall synthesis inhibitor so it is not related to 50S ribosome.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 767.

questions.text: Pick the drug which acts by inhibiting DNA transcription.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Actinomycin D
 
  • Actinomycin D is an antibacterial agent and a type of antibiotic that inhibits the transcription of DNA into RNA.
  • It does this by binding to the double-stranded DNA helix and blocking the enzyme RNA polymerase from transcribing the genes for protein synthesis.
  • This prevents the cell from being able to translate the DNA into proteins, which halts the growth and replication of the cell. In this way, Actinomycin D is used to stop DNA replication and to inhibit the expression of certain genes.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 926

questions.text: Mention the drug used as nail lacquer for fungal infections.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Ciclopirox
 
  • Ciclopirox is an antifungal medication used to treat fungal infections of the skin and nails.
  • It is often used to treat onychomycosis, which is a fungal infection of the toenails or fingernails.
  • Ciclopirox works by stopping the growth of the fungi and preventing it from spreading.
  • Additionally, it helps to restore the natural color and texture of the affected nails. This can reduce the discoloration and thickness of fungal-infected nails, allowing for them to grow normally.
  • Another antifungal used as nail laquer is Amrolfine. 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 848.

questions.text: Choose the fluoroquinolone that shouldn't be used in liver d/s.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Pefloxacin
 
  • Pefloxacin is contraindicated in liver disease because it is metabolized in the liver and can cause function to decrease further, causing serious health issues.
  • This includes increased levels of toxicity and a risk of liver failure. Taking Pefloxacin in this instance can increase the likelihood of serious adverse reactions and, in some cases, death.
  • Moxifloxacin & Pefloxacin are the FQs metabolised in Liver (MoPed by Liver)
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 746.

questions.text: Select the drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Voriconazole

  • Invasive aspergillosis is an infection caused by the fungi sinus Aspergillus. It can cause severe respiratory problems, especially in those with weakened immune systems or whose lungs have already been damaged.
  • Symptoms of the disease include fever, coughing, chest pain, difficulty breathing and a decreased appetite. The spreading fungal infection can cause more serious health complications, such as organ damage, pulmonary embolism and even death.
  • Management for invasive aspergillosis depends upon how severe the infection is. Preventive measures can be taken for those at a higher risk, such as administering antifungal prophylaxis, avoiding immunosuppression when possible, and resolving any risk factors, such as smoking cessation, good hygiene, and prompt removal of any organic material that could encourage fungal growth.
    When the infection has become invasive and severe, the typical treatment is intravenous administration of the antifungal drug, voriconazole.
  • This drug is preferred due to its efficacy and relatively low cost, making it the drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis. It is also available in oral, breathing treatments and intrathecal forms for those who cannot tolerate intravenous medication. Amphotericin B is usually used as a secondary therapy when the infection does not respond to voriconazole.
  • Other drugs, such as caspofungin, posaconazole, and itraconazole, are also available as second-line treatments. It is advised that multiple drugs are used in combination therapy to increase the efficacy of treatment.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 846.

questions.text: Select the drug which acts by preventing the transcription of DNA to RNA slowly.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Rifampicin
 
  • Rifampicin binds to the beta subunit of the DNA- dependent RNA polymerase and inhibits RNA synthesis in the bacteria. It is bactericidal.
  • In therapeutic concentrations, rifampicin cannot bind human RNA polymerase and it, therefore, selectively destroys the bacteria.
  • Moreover, it reaches the cavities, caseous material and penetrates macrophages.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 818.

questions.text: Paucibacillary leprosy treatment includes which of the following options
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Dapsone + Rifampicin x 6 months 

The question was before the recent WHO recommended guideline but now :-
  • Rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine are the first line medications used to treat paucibacillary and multibacillary leprosy.
  • However, paucibacillary leprosy requires a 6-month course of treatment, while multibacillary leprosy requires a 12-month course.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 836.

choices.text: It causes peripheral neuropathy as an adverse effect
It is active against gram positive organisms

questions.text: Choose the statement that stands true to tedizolid.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) It is active against gram positive organisms
 
  • Oxazolidinidiones, such as linezolid and tedizolid, show good anti-gram-positive spectrum activity against staphylococcus, streptococcus, enterococcus, etc.

  • The oral absorption and bioavailability of linezolid and tedizolid are both good at 100% and 80%, respectively. Tedizolid is more effective against gram positive bacteria and has a longer half-life than linezolid.  Thus, linezolid is administered via the oral or intravenous route with a BD dose and tedizolid with an OD dose.

  • Linezolid is excreted primarily by kidney, whereas tedizolid by liver.
  • Because linezolid can decrease bone marrow (predominantly resulting in thrombocytopenia), it is important to monitor platelet count. Linezolid also induces mitochondrial toxicity, which manifests as peripheral neuropathy, visual neuritis, and lactic acidosis. Tedizolid causes less bone marrow suppression and does not have these negative effects.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 808.

questions.text: Name the active drug with inhibition of DNA to RNA transcription
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Rifampicin
 
  • Rifampicin binds to the beta subunit of the DNA- dependent RNA polymerase and inhibits RNA synthesis in the bacteria.
  • It is bactericidal. In therapeutic concentrations, rifampicin cannot bind human RNA polymerase and it, therefore, selectively destroys the bacteria.
  • Moreover, it reaches the cavities, caseous material and penetrates macrophages.
Other options: -
  • Novobiocin and Ciprofloxacin are DNA Gyrase inhibitors
  • Nitrofurantoin inhibits DNA and RNA synthesis.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 818.

questions.text: The CA Breast patient receiving paclitaxel experienced a fever and a decline in total count. Except for____, all of the subsequent antibiotics are usable.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Erythromycin
 
  • Paclitaxel can interact with several other medications.
  • The essential details on the drug-drug interactions associated with paclitaxel are mentioned below.
  • Cytochrome P450 enzymes: Paclitaxel undergoes primary metabolism through the cytochrome P450 (CYP) enzyme system, specifically CYP2C8 and CYP3A4.
  • Drugs that either inhibit or induce these enzymes can alter the metabolism and clearance of paclitaxel. Inhibitors of CYP2C8 and CYP3A4: Drugs such as ketoconazole, erythromycin, clarithromycin, fluoxetine, and grapefruit juice can inhibit CYP2C8 and CYP3A4.
  • This inhibition can result in elevated plasma concentrations, potentially increasing the risk of paclitaxel-related toxicities. Inducers of CYP2C8 and CYP3A4: Drugs such as rifampin, phenytoin, carbamazepine, and St John's wort can induce CYP2C8 and CYP3A4. This induction can lead to diminished paclitaxel plasma concentrations, potentially compromising its efficacy.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 160.

questions.text: What medication, as depicted, works via the following mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Vancomycin

* Mechanisms of action and Resistance Factors:
  • By tightly adhering to the d-Ala-d-Ala terminus of developing peptidoglycan pentapeptide, vancomycin prevents the formation of cell walls. 
  • The peptidoglycan is weakened as a result of this inhibition of transglycosylase, which prevents further elongation and cross-linking of the peptidoglycan and makes the cell more vulnerable to lysis. 
  • Resistance to vancomycin in enterococci is caused by change of the d-Ala-d-Ala binding site of the peptidoglycan building block in which the terminal d-Ala is replaced by d-lactate.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 806.

questions.text: In which of the following situations is combination therapy not usually considered
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Gonorrhea
 
  • Single agent Ceftriaxone is considered sufficient for the management of Gonorrhea.
  • Treatment of Malaria - ACT (Artemisinin Combination therapy) Treatment of TB - HRZE (Combination) Intrabdominal Infections - Metronidazole + Cephalosporin/Levofloxacin
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 772.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in severe COVID treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Is (Option 3) Favipiravir

Favipiravir is not given in severe COVID, it is given in cases of moderate COVID infection.
In June 2020, favipiravir received the DCGI approval in India for mild and moderate COVID-19 infections.
* Drugs given in sever COVID infection include:
  • i. LMWH
  • ii. Steroids
  • iii. Remdesivir
  • iv. Tocilizumab
Online Reference: 
Agrawal U, Raju R, Udwadia ZF. Favipiravir: A new and emerging antiviral option in COVID-19. Med J Armed Forces India. 2020 Oct;76(4):370-376. doi: 10.1016/j.mjafi.2020.08.004. Epub 2020 Sep 2. PMID: 32895599; PMCID: PMC7467067.

questions.text: An antibiotic was prescribed for a patient who had a fever and a sore throat. Two days later, he appeared with the rash as seen in the picture. Which of the following substances could have caused this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Amoxicillin

Amoxicillin is the antibiotic (β-lactam) causing the presented rash.
Most common side effects of penicillins include allergic reactions in the form of-
  1. Anaphylactic shock
  2. Urticaria, fever, swelling of joints
  3. Skin rashes.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1154.

choices.text: TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects
TDM is done for penicillin as it causes severe anaphylactic reaction

questions.text: Which of the following assertions about a patient receiving a high dose of penicillin and gentamicin is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index

TDM is done with gentamicin because of the narrow therapeutic index.
A narrow therapeutic index suggests the chances of drug toxicity on even increasing the drug dose slightly is very high, therefore it requires therapeutic drug monitoring for maintaining safety.

* Drugs requiring TDM are- 
  • Digoxin
  • Anti-arrhythmics
  • Theophylline
  • Lithium
  • Aminoglycosides
  • Anti-epileptics
  • TCAs 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 797.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations of saquinavir will improve its bioavailability?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ritonavir

  • Saquinavir is a protease inhibitor used in anti - retroviral therapy.
  • They are metabolized by CYP3A4 and hence act as inhibitors of CYP3A4.
  • Ritonavir is the most potent inhibitor of CYP3A4 and is used in combination with other protease inhibitors to boost their action and bioavailability.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 33.

questions.text: What is Remdesivir's mode of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 4) Inhibits RNA dependent RNA polymerase

  • Remdsivir is a nucleotide analogue that stops COVID - 19 viral replication by inhibiting RNA dependent RNA polymerase.
  • It is the only FDA approved drug used in the treatment of COVID - 19 infection. It is used only in moderate and severe COVID - 19 cases that require hospitalisation and has to be used within 10 days of disease onset.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1223.

questions.text: Which of the following cephalosporins can make warfarin work more effectively, causing an elevated INR and a higher risk of bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Cefoperazone

Cephalosporins that contain methylthiotetrazole can cause hypothrombinemia leading to bleeding manifestations as it interferes with vitamin K metabolism. Eg. Cefoperazone.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 670.

questions.text:
Match the bacteria to the appropriate drug.
A. Bacteroides 1. Vancomycin
B. MRSA 2. Metronidazole
C. Hemophilus 3. Meropenem
D. Klebsiella 4. Penicillin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 806.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs is associated with a lower risk of death in COVID-19 patients?
A. Dexamethasone
B. Remdesivir
C. Favipiravir
D. HCQ
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Only A
 
  • Dexamethasone is the drug that reduces mortality in COVID- 19 patients.
  • Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used in a wide range of conditions for its anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects.
  • It was tested in hospitalized patients with COVID-19 and was found to have benefits for critically ill patients.
  • According to preliminary findings shared with WHO (and now available as a preprint), for patients on ventilators, the treatment was shown to reduce mortality by about one third, and for patients requiring only oxygen, mortality was cut by about one fifth.
  • Dexamethasone treatment was associated with reduced risk of in-hospital mortality for n = 1,263 treated, matched 1:3 to untreated, patients not receiving remdesivir and for n = 804 treated, matched 1:1 to untreated, patients receiving remdesivir.
Online Reference: Zhou R, Johnson KE, Rousseau JF, Rathouz PJ; N3C Consortium. Comparative effectiveness of dexamethasone in treatment of hospitalized COVID-19 patients in the United States during the first year of the pandemic: Findings from the National COVID Cohort Collaborative (N3C) data repository. PLoS One. 2024 Mar 21;19(3):e0294892. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0294892. PMID: 38512832; PMCID: PMC10956822.

questions.text: A neck lump that was firm but not painful was present in the patient. Upon inspection, it felt warm to the touch and moveable with ease. After a biopsy, molar tooth colonies developed in anaerobic culture in two to three days and revealed gram-positive branching rods when stained. Which medication is ideal for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Penicillin

The most likely diagnosis based on given clinical scenario is Actinomyces.

* Actinomyces features:
  • Strict anaerobes
  • Cause Actinomycosis
  •  Gram-positive and acid-fast negative branching rods
  • Molar tooth colonies on blood agar 
  • Usually presents with painless hard nodule in the neck-seen in most common variety ie cervicofacial. 
  • Drug of choice: Penicillin
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 768.

questions.text: Identify the 2nd line anti-tubercular drug.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ethionamide

Among the following ethionamide is the 2nd line anti-tubercular drug.

streptomycin was previously used as a first-line anti-tubercular drug but now is not used due to it's ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity.

* Following is the second line antitubercular drugs:
  • Ciprofloxacin
  • Amikacin
  • Kanamycin
  • Clarithromycin
  • Cycloserine
  • Ethionamide
  • Para-amino salicylic acid
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 821

questions.text: All of the following medications are bactericidal for Mycobacterium, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Thioacetazone
 
  • Thioacetazone is a thiosemicarbazone prodrug with antitubercular activity. Although the exact mechanism by which thioacetazone exerts its effect has yet to be fully elucidated, this agent, upon activation by bacterial monooxygenase EtaA, appears to target and inhibit cyclopropane mycolic acid synthases (CMASs), a family of S-adenosyl-methionine-dependent methyl transferases responsible for cyclopropanation of mycolic acid.
  • By inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis, the bacterial cell wall becomes more permeable and less resistant to injury which eventually leads to cell lysis.
  • Mycolic acids, long-chain fatty acids, are essential mycobacterial cell wall components and play a key role in resistance to cell injury and mycobacterial virulence.



Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1267.

questions.text:
While obtaining a blood sample from a patient who had HIV +ve symptoms, a resident doctor had a needle prick injury. Which of the following regimens is the most effective for this doctor's post-exposure HIV prophylaxis?
1. Zidovudine + Lamivudine
2. Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
3. Zidovudine + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
4. Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Nevirapine
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir

PEP acc. 2021 guidelines (NACO) is TLD (Tenofovir, Lamivudine and Dolutegravir).
Zidovudine + Lamivudine + Indinavir is the best regimen for post exposure prophylaxis is HIV.

PEP (Post-Exposure Prophylaxis) means taking medicine to prevent HIV after a possible exposure. PEP should be used only in emergency situations and must be started ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours after a recent possible exposure to HIV.

It is taken daily for 28 days/4 weeks. 

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1594.

questions.text: Identify the drug that possesses additional anti-inflammatory and antipruritic activity.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Sertaconazole

Sertaconazole among following antifungal drugs possess additional anti-inflammatory and antipruritic activity.

* Sertaconazole is believed to have following actions
  • Fungistatic
  • Fungicidal
  • Antibacterial
  • Anti inflammatory
  • Anti trichomonal
  • Antipruritic
Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 1072.

questions.text: Which of the following should not be administered concurrently to a patient who is taking metronidazole?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Alcohol

  • Metronidazole cannot be given because it produces disulfiram like reaction.
  • Oxidation of acetaldehyde is inhibited by disulfiram, a drug that has been used to deter drinking by patients with alcohol dependence.
  • When ethanol is consumed in the presence of disulfiram, acetaldehyde accumulates and causes an unpleasant reaction of facial flushing, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and headache.
Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 398.

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin 7.2 million units in three divided doses

questions.text: The preferred course of treatment for late cardiovascular syphilis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Benzathine penicillin 7.2 million units in three divided doses
 
  • The recommended treatment for Late Latent Syphilis or Syphilis of Unknown Duration, assuming no CSF abnormalities, is penicillin G benzathine administered in 3 divided doses with a total dosage of 7.2 million units. 2.4 million IU weekly deep IM after proper skin testing. 
  • However, if any CSF abnormalities are present, the patient should be treated for neurosyphilis.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1152.

questions.text:
A teenage girl using sulfonamides reported having stomach ache and seizures.
The most likely reason is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Acute intermittent porphyria

The given clinical vignette describes the condition called Acute Intermittent Porphyria.

* CLINICAL FEATURES: - [ MNEMONIC – 5P]
  • Pain in abdomen
  • Port wine colored Pee
  • Polyneuropathy
  • Psychological Disturbance
* PRECIPITATING FACTORS: -
It is precipitated by factors which increase the activity of ALA Synthase enzyme (Eg : CYP450 inducers, alcohol, starvation)
Sulfonamide is an example of CYP450 inducer drug.



* MNEMONIC: - 
GRABS Priyanka Chopra for a QUICK VEG Dinner
-GRABS Priyanka Chopra – INDUCERS
-QUICK VEG Dinner – INHIBITORS 

*CONGENITAL ERYTHROPOETIC PORPHYRIA: - Characterized by blisters. Also known as Gunther Disease / Erythrodontia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 757.

questions.text: A woman was on OCP. Later, she developed TB, for which she was given ATT in accordance with NTEP and counselled to use extra contraceptives. This is due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Rifampicin induces metabolism of OCPs
 
  • Rifampicin speeds up the pace at which OCPs are metabolized, which leads to unacceptably high rates of breakthrough bleeding and pregnancy. The hormone metabolising enzyme inducer rifampin reduces the efficacy of OCPs.
  • Anticonvulsants like carbamazepine, phenytoin, topiramate, and some antibiotics like azithromycin, erythromycin, ketoconazole, penicillin (and derivatives), rifabutin, and tetracycline antibiotics are other medications that reduce the effectiveness of OCPs.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 818.

questions.text:
A patient's right upper limb has linear wheals in addition to having pain and edoema in the finger.
Which of the following antibiotics is best for treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Amoxiclav

The given clinical vignette describes skin and soft tissue infection characterized by linear wheals along with pain and oedema of finger for which Amoxiclav is the best drug.

AMOXYCLAV= AMOXICILLIN + CLAVULINIC ACID

Amoxicillin (penicillinase sensitive penicillin) destroys the bacteria and clavulanic acid being a Beta lactamase inhibitor prevents the destruction of Amoxicillin.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 774.

questions.text:
An infection at the location of a wound occurred in a patient who underwent abdominal surgery. MRSA was identified by culture of a wound swab.
Except for__________ all of the other antibiotics may be used for this treatment.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Cefaclor

Cefaclor is a second generation cephalosporin. Only fifth generation cephalosporins like ceftaroline and ceftobiprole are effective against MRSA.

*Drugs used for treatment of MRSA infection-
•​Vancomycin (DOC)
•​Teicoplanin
•​Linezolid
•​Daptomycin
•​Mupirocin
•​Quinupristin/dalfepristin
•​Cotrimoxazole
•​Ciprofloxacin

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 777.

questions.text: In which of the following chloroquine-related eye disease risks is not considered to be high?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Duration of use > 2 years
 
  • Duration of use > 5 years is considered a high-risk factor for development of CQ -Related eye disease.
  • The pathogenesis of hydroxychloroquine-induced retinal toxicity is poorly understood. As chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine are known inhibitors of autophagy, these drugs alkalinize lysosomes, thereby, inhibiting lysosomal enzymes and arresting autophagy—although these mechanisms may be dose-dependent.
  • There is an insignificant risk in the first 5 years of therapy, although, in the highest dose group (>5 mg/kg/day), the risks at 10, 15, and 20 years were approximately 10%, 20%, and 40%, respectively.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 879.
Online Reference: Yusuf IH, Charbel Issa P, Ahn SJ. Hydroxychloroquine-induced Retinal Toxicity. Front Pharmacol. 2023 May 30;14:1196783. doi: 10.3389/fphar.2023.1196783. PMID: 37324471; PMCID: PMC10267834.

questions.text: What does the medication efavirenz inhibit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) HIV reverse transcriptase
 
  • Efavirenz is in a class of medications called non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs).
  • NNRTIs primarily block HIV-1 replication by preventing reverse transcriptase from completing reverse transcription of the viral single-stranded RNA genome into DNA.
  • They are well absorbed from GIT; bioavailability increased with a high fat meal. It is metabolized by oxidation by CYP2D6 and CYP3A4.
NNRTI memorizing trick: - END RTI
Efavirenz
Nevirapine
Delavirdine

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 863.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is used to prevent HIV from being passed from a mother to her child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Nevirapine
 
  • Nevirapine is used to prevent the mother-to-child transmission of HIV.
  • A single oral intrapartum dose of 200 mg nevirapine followed by a single dose given to the newborn reduced neonatal infection by 13%.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 872.

questions.text: What is a side effect of HAART therapy that affects the eyes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Uveitis
 
  • Uveitis is one of the ocular side effects of the HAART therapy.
  • A study conducted in Indian children infected with HIV found a high prevalence of ocular and systemic lesions most commonly anterior uveitis followed by CMV retinitis.
  • An enhancement of immune function and a resultant decrease in systemic and ocular complications of HIV is the desired action of HAART. This improved immune function may result in intraocular inflammation, called “immune recovery uveitis” (IRU), leading to vision-limiting complications.
Online Reference: Dash S, Mohanty SK, Mohanty G. Ocular Complications in Patients on Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy: A Case Report. Cureus. 2023 Oct 18;15(10):e47242. doi: 10.7759/cureus.47242. PMID: 38022310; PMCID: PMC10654452.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for extended-spectrum beta-lactamase-producing enterococci?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Piperacillin-Tazobactam
 
  • Treatment of choice for extended spectrum beta-lactamase producing enterococci is piperacillin tazobactam.
  • Piperacillin-tazobactam is one of the most frequently utilized antibiotic agents for empirical Gram-negative bacterial coverage and remains active against a large proportion of extended spectrum beta-lactamase.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 774.

choices.text: Probenecid given along with PnG decrease its duration of action

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about Penicillin G?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Used for treatment rat bite fever
 
  • True about penicillin G is that it is used for treatment of rat bite fever.
  • ￲Penicillin being acid labile is not given by oral route.
  • It is not a broad-spectrum antibiotic and is used in treatment of bacterial infections caused by susceptible, usually gram positive, organisms.
  • Probenecid given along with penicillin G increase its action because it has affinity for tubular OATP, so it increases its efficiency by blocking the transport of penicillin.￲
  • Leptospirosis or Rat Bite fever: PnG 1.5 MU injected i.v. 6hourly for 7 days is curative.
     
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 768.

questions.text: What is the antibiotic of choice for treatment of wound infection after human bite?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Amoxicillin/clavulanic acid

The empirical treatment for human bite as well as wound infection following human bite is Amoxicillin /Clavulanic Acid OR Ampicillin / sulbactam. 

Human bite is polymicrobial in nature, amoxicillin/clavulanic acid is a broad spectrum antibiotic effective against gram positive organism like staph aureus and also anaerobes like bacteroides and fusibacterium.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 774.

questions.text: Which is the most important antibiotic with the phenomenon of "MIC creep"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Vancomycin
 
  • Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) is defined as the lowest concentration of an antimicrobial that will inhibit the visible growth of a microorganism
  • “MIC creep” is a phenomenon that describes an increase of an organism MICs over time.
  • Vancomycin is an example of antibiotic with the ‘MIC creep’ phenomenon.
Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 808.

choices.text: Follow-up for Paucibacillary leprosy is for 2 years
Two drugs are used for Paucibacillary leprosy

questions.text: The following statement is false regarding treatment of leprosy:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Clofazimine is given for paucibacillary leprosy

But according to recent WHO guideline clofazimine is given in pauci-bacillary leprosy, the question was framed before the update hence the answer is incorrect according to recent guideline.

* TABLE TO SUMMARISE TREATMENT OF LEPROSY: -

 
  • MULTIBACILLARY – 12 months within 18 months has to get completed
  • PAUCIBACILLARY – 6 months within 9 months has to get completed
  • FOLLOW UP: -
    • PAUCIBACILLARY –More than/equal to 5 years
    • MULTIBACILLARY – More than/equal to 10 years
  • DRUGS USED: -
    • PAUCIBACILLARY – Dapsone, Rifampicin
    • MULTIBACILLARY -Dapsone, Rifampicin, Clofazimine

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 834.

questions.text: Which of these nanoparticles has antibacterial properties against candida?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) All the above
 

Various types of nanoparticles have been studied for their antibacterial properties against Candida, including:

  • Silver Nanoparticles: Silver nanoparticles are particularly well-known for their broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity, including against Candida species.
  • Metal Oxide Nanoparticles: Nanoparticles of metals such as zinc oxide, titanium dioxide, and copper oxide have also shown antibacterial effects against Candida.
  • Polymeric Nanoparticles: Nanoparticles made from biocompatible polymers can be functionalized with antimicrobial agents or designed to disrupt microbial membranes effectively.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 952.

questions.text: Select the option that is a second-line antiretroviral drug according NACO.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ritonavir

Ritonavir is the best answer among the 4 given options.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 871.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not associated with causes of peripheral neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Rifampicin
 
  • Rifampicin is not typically associated with causing peripheral neuropathy.
  • Peripheral neuropathy refers to damage or dysfunction of the peripheral nerves, leading to symptoms such as numbness, tingling, and weakness in the extremities.
  • The drugs commonly associated with peripheral neuropathy include certain chemotherapeutic agents and medications used to treat infections.
  • Peripheral neuropathy is not a commonly reported side effect of rifampicin.
* [Extra Edge]: Drugs known to be associated with peripheral neuropathy
  • Vincristine
  • Paclitaxel
  • Cisplatin
  • Platinum-based drugs
  • Didanosine
  • Stavudine
  • Zalcitabine
  • Isoniazid
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 818.

questions.text: Which anti-retroviral medication among the following inhibits both C-C chemokine receptor type 2 (CCR2) and type 5 (CCR5) activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option is 2) Cenicriviroc
 
  • Cenicriviroc is an anti-retroviral medication that inhibits both C-C chemokine receptor type 2 (CCR2) and C-C chemokine receptor type 5 (CCR5) activity.
  • CCR2 and CCR5 are chemokine receptors that play a role in the entry of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) into host cells.
  • By blocking these receptors, cenicriviroc interferes with the entry of HIV into host cells and helps to control viral replication.

  • Cenicriviroc for the treatment of liver fibrosis in adults with nonalcoholic steatohepatiti



Online Reference: 
Anstee QM, Neuschwander-Tetri BA, Wong VW, Abdelmalek MF, Younossi ZM, Yuan J, Pecoraro ML, Seyedkazemi S, Fischer L, Bedossa P, Goodman Z, Alkhouri N, Tacke F, Sanyal A. Cenicriviroc for the treatment of liver fibrosis in adults with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis: AURORA Phase 3 study design. Contemp Clin Trials. 2020 Feb;89:105922. doi: 10.1016/j.cct.2019.105922. Epub 2019 Dec 24. PMID: 31881392.

questions.text: The following cephalosporin has an antipseudomonal activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Cefepime
 
  • Antipseudomonal cephalosporins are a class of antibiotics that are effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a common and often antibiotic-resistant bacterium that can cause severe infections, especially in hospitalized patients and those with compromised immune systems.
  • These cephalosporins have enhanced activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa compared to other cephalosporins. 

  1. Ceftazidime:

    • Ceftazidime is a third-generation cephalosporin that exhibits potent activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is commonly used for severe infections caused by this bacterium, including respiratory tract infections, urinary tract infections, and bloodstream infections. Ceftazidime is often used in combination with other antibiotics for more comprehensive coverage.

  2. Cefepime:

    • Cefepime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin that also has excellent activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is structurally similar to third-generation cephalosporins but has broader coverage against Gram-negative bacteria, including extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL)-producing organisms. Cefepime is frequently used in hospitals for serious infections, including nosocomial pneumonia, complicated urinary tract infections, and septicemia.
    • Cefepime has enhanced activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa compared to earlier generation cephalosporins.

  3. Ceftolozane/Tazobactam:

    • Ceftolozane/tazobactam is a novel antipseudomonal cephalosporin/beta-lactamase inhibitor combination. It was specifically developed to combat multidrug-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa strains. Tazobactam, a beta-lactamase inhibitor, enhances the activity of ceftolozane against beta-lactamase-producing bacteria, including some strains of Pseudomonas aeruginosa resistant to other cephalosporins.
