* [Extra Edge]: Drugs useful in Pseudomonas infection



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 779.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics blocks protein synthesis by interfering with the translocation step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Erythromycin
 
  • Aminoglycosides, such as gentamicin and streptomycin, are a class of antibiotics that work by binding to the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome.
  • By binding to the ribosome, aminoglycosides interfere with the accurate reading of the mRNA codons during protein synthesis.
  • This interference disrupts the translocation step, which is the movement of the ribosome along the mRNA strand during protein synthesis.
  • Ultimately, the disruption of translocation leads to the inhibition of bacterial protein synthesis.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 801.

questions.text: Which of the following is the only antimalarial medication used to treat malaria effectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Primaquine

Primaquine is gametocidal to all species of Plasmodia, while artemisinins have weak lethal action on early stage but not mature gametes.
A single dose of primaquine is employed immediately after clinical cure of falciparum malaria to kill the gametes and cut down transmission to mosquito.
  • Primaquine is an antimalarial medication that is primarily used for the prevention and treatment of relapse in certain types of malaria caused by Plasmodium vivax or Plasmodium ovale.
  • It is the only medication effective against the dormant liver stage of these malaria parasites, preventing the reemergence of the infection.
  •  By eliminating these hypnozoites, primaquine significantly reduces the reservoir of malaria parasites in the population and decreases the transmission of P. falciparum.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 878.

questions.text: Which one of the aforementioned Fifth Generation Cephalosporins is active against MRSA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ceftaroline
 
  • Ceftaroline is a fifth-generation cephalosporin antibiotic that exhibits activity against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) bacteria.
  • It possesses a unique mechanism of action, targeting penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) that are involved in cell wall synthesis.
  • The spectrum of activity of ceftaroline includes not only MRSA but also other gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 779.

questions.text: Which antimalarial drug among the following has the greatest impact in lowering P. falciparum transmission?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Primaquine
 
  • Primaquine is an antimalarial medication that is primarily used for the prevention and treatment of relapse in certain types of malaria caused by Plasmodium vivax or Plasmodium ovale.
  • It is the only medication effective against the dormant liver stage of these malaria parasites, preventing the reemergence of the infection.
  •  By eliminating these hypnozoites, primaquine significantly reduces the reservoir of malaria parasites in the population.
  • It is also effective against gametocyte hence decreases the transmission of P. falciparum.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 878.

questions.text: Except for ______, all of the following sulfonamide are used topically.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Sulfadiazine
 
  • Sulfonamides are a class of antimicrobial medications that inhibit the growth and reproduction of bacteria by interfering with the synthesis of folate.
  • When it comes to topical use, sulfonamides are commonly used in the treatment of various skin and eye infections.
  • Sulfadiazine is not typically used topically due to poor skin penetration. It has limited ability to effectively reach deeper layers of the skin where the infection may be present.
  • Systemic absorption of sulfadiazine can occur when applied topically, increasing the risk of adverse effects and systemic side effects.
  • Sulfadiazine is primarily administered orally or intravenously for the treatment of systemic infections
* Other options:
  • Sulfacetamide is a topical sulfonamide commonly used in the treatment of eye infections, such as conjunctivitis.
  • Silver sulfadiazine is a topical antimicrobial agent that is used for the prevention and treatment of burn wound infections.
  • Mafenide is a topical sulfonamide used as an antibacterial agent in the treatment of burns.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 757.

questions.text: What is most frequently linked to pill induced esophagitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Doxycycline
 
  • Pill-induced esophagitis is caused when the pill lodges within the lumen of the esophagus. This pill causes direct damage to the mucosa. The risk factors for pill-induced esophagitis include poor pill-taking habits, consuming inadequate liquids, and lying down immediately after consuming the pill.
  • Among the options provided, doxycycline is most frequently associated with causing pill-induced esophagitis.
  • The mechanism behind doxycycline-induced esophagitis is thought to be related to its direct irritant effect on the esophageal lining and the potential for local tissue damage.
* [Extra Edge]: Drugs causing esophagitis 
  • Doxycycline
  • Quinidine
  • Phenytoin
  • NSAIDs
  • Bisphosphonates
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1182.

questions.text: Which of the following carbapenems should not be used to treat nosocomial infections?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ertapenem
 
  • Ertapenem is a carbapenem antibiotic that has a narrower spectrum of activity compared to other carbapenems.
  • While it is effective against many common community-acquired pathogens, it may not provide adequate coverage for multidrug-resistant organisms commonly found in nosocomial (hospital-acquired) infections.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium known for its intrinsic resistance to many antibiotics, including ertapenem.
  • Therefore, when treating infections caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, other carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem, or doripenem would be more suitable due to their broader spectrum of activity and better efficacy against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 782.

questions.text: Ertapenem does not work well against:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Pseudomonas
 
  • Ertapenem is a carbapenem antibiotic that has a narrower spectrum of activity compared to other carbapenems.
  • While it is effective against many common community-acquired pathogens, it may not provide adequate coverage for multidrug-resistant organisms commonly found in nosocomial (hospital-acquired) infections.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium known for its intrinsic resistance to many antibiotics, including ertapenem.
  • Therefore, when treating infections caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, other carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem, or doripenem would be more suitable due to their broader spectrum of activity and better efficacy against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 782.

questions.text: When compared to vestibular toxicity, which aminoglycoside is more toxic to the cochlea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Kanamycin
 
  • Aminoglycoside antibiotics are known to have the potential for both vestibular and cochlear toxicity, which can result in balance and hearing disturbances, respectively.
  • Among the given options, kanamycin (option C) is generally considered to have a higher risk of cochlear toxicity compared to vestibular toxicity.
  • Cochlear toxicity refers to damage to the structures of the inner ear responsible for hearing, while vestibular toxicity refers to damage to the structures responsible for balance and spatial orientation.
  • The decreasing order of potency for neuromuscular blockade: Neomycin -> Kanamycin -> Amikacin -> Gentamicin -> Tobramycin
Cochleotoxic drugs- KAN ( meaning ear)
Kanamycin 
Amikacin 
Neomycin- most toxic 

Vestibulo-toxic drugs-
Streptomycin
Gentamycin 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 795.

questions.text: What is Gramicidin S?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Cyclic Decapeptide 
 
  • Gramicidin S is an antibiotic peptide composed of 10 amino acid residues, making it a cyclic decapeptide.
  • It is produced by the soil bacterium Bacillus brevis and has potent antimicrobial activity against a wide range of bacteria.
  • Gramicidin S is known for its ability to form ion channels in cell membranes, disrupting the normal functioning of bacterial cells.
  • Due to its mode of action, gramicidin S is primarily used as a topical antibiotic and is not typically administered systemically.
  • A group of peptide antibiotics from BACILLUS brevis. Gramicidin C or S is a cyclic, ten-amino acid polypeptide and gramicidins A, B, D are linear. Gramicidin is one of the two principal components of TYROTHRICIN.
Online Reference: 
PubChem [Internet]. Bethesda (MD): National Library of Medicine (US), National Center for Biotechnology Information; 2004-. PubChem Compound Summary for CID 73357, Gramicidin S; [cited 2024 Sept. 14]. Available from: https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Gramicidin-S

questions.text: Which anti-tubercular drug among the following has the highest sterilising effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Rifampicin
 
  • Rifampicin is known for its potent bactericidal activity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis (TB).
  • It is a key component of the standard first-line drug regimen for treating TB.
  • Rifampicin has a high sterilizing effect, meaning it is effective in killing both replicating and non-replicating bacteria, including those in the dormant or persistent state.
  • It targets bacterial RNA polymerase, inhibiting RNA synthesis and thus preventing bacterial replication.
  • This unique mechanism of action contributes to its high sterilizing effect, reducing the bacterial load in TB infection and facilitating the eradication of the disease.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 818.

questions.text: Which antitubercular drug among the following has the best chance of halting the development of isoniazid resistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Rifampicin
 
  • Rifampicin is known for its potent bactericidal activity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis (TB).
  • It is a key component of the standard first-line drug regimen for treating TB.
  • It targets bacterial RNA polymerase, inhibiting RNA synthesis and thus preventing bacterial replication.
  • When used in combination with isoniazid, rifampicin has been shown to reduce the risk of the development of isoniazid resistance.
  • The combination of rifampicin and isoniazid is often recommended as a frontline therapy to prevent the emergence of drug resistance and improve treatment outcomes.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 818.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for tuberculosis during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) HRZE for 2 months followed by HRE for 4 months according to NTEP
 
  • The preferred treatment regimen for tuberculosis (TB) during pregnancy follows the same principles as non-pregnant individuals, aiming to provide effective treatment while considering the safety of the mother and fetus
  • This treatment regimen provides adequate drug coverage to effectively treat TB while reducing potential risks to the mother and fetus.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 827.

questions.text: Rifampicin is being used to treat a patient. In the first-line HAART regimen for Rifampicin-based tuberculosis treatment, which of the following medicines is not preferred?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Nevirapine
 
  • Rifampicin, a key component of tuberculosis (TB) treatment, can significantly affect the metabolism of certain antiretroviral drugs used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS.
  • Rifampin, phenytoin, and nevirapine are microsomal enzyme inducers. Nevirapine, a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI), is known to have a significant interaction with rifampicin.
  • Rifampicin can enhance the metabolism of nevirapine, leading to decreased plasma levels and potential loss of efficacy.
  • Due to this drug-drug interaction, nevirapine is not preferred in the first-line HAART regimen for Rifampicin-based TB treatment.
  • Rifampicin is a medication commonly used to treat tuberculosis, and it is also a potent inducer of certain liver enzymes. These enzymes can increase the metabolism and decrease the effectiveness of other medications that are metabolized by the same enzymes. In the case of HIV treatment, Rifampicin can reduce the effectiveness of certain antiretroviral drugs, including Nevirapine. As a result, Nevirapine is not preferred in the first-line HAART regimen for Rifampicin-based tuberculosis treatment.
  • Instead, other antiretroviral drugs that are less affected by Rifampicin-induced liver enzyme induction are preferred, such as Efavirenz. Therefore, option 2 is the correct answer. Zidovudine and Lamivudine are both nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), which are not affected by Rifampicin-induced liver enzyme induction. These drugs are commonly used in HIV treatment and are not contraindicated in Rifampicin-based tuberculosis treatment.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 864.

choices.text: Treatment should be initiated within 48 hours of symptom onset
Should not be co-administered with the vaccine
Orally active with a Bioavailability of >60 percent

questions.text: Each of the following statements concerning oseltamivir is correct except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Should not be co-administered with the vaccine 
 
  • Oseltamivir is a neuraminidase inhibitor (option A) and is commonly used for the treatment and prophylaxis of influenza virus infection.
  • It is most effective when initiated within 48 hours of symptom onset (option B), as early treatment can help reduce the severity and duration of symptoms.
  • Oseltamivir can be co-administered with the influenza vaccine (option C), and there are no significant interactions between oseltamivir and the vaccine. In fact, it is often recommended to receive the influenza vaccine even while taking oseltamivir for treatment or prophylaxis.
  • Oseltamivir is orally active, meaning it can be taken by mouth, and it has a bioavailability of over 60 percent (option D). This indicates that a significant portion of the drug is absorbed and available for therapeutic effect when taken orally.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 853.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis in case of a patient who was given primaquine develops dark coloured urine one day after administration of the drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency
 
  • Primaquine is an antimalarial medication commonly used for the treatment and prevention of malaria.
  • It is known to cause hemolytic anemia in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.
  • G6PD deficiency is an inherited enzyme deficiency that affects red blood cells, making them more susceptible to oxidative damage.
  • When individuals with G6PD deficiency are exposed to certain triggers, such as certain medications or infections, their red blood cells can undergo hemolysis, resulting in the release of hemoglobin.
  • The breakdown products of hemoglobin can give urine a dark or reddish color, known as hemoglobinuria.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 76.

questions.text: Which deficiency is caused by the Prolonged treatment with INH ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Pyridoxine 
 
  • Isoniazid (INH) is an antitubercular medication commonly used for the treatment of tuberculosis (TB).
  • Prolonged use of INH can lead to a deficiency of pyridoxine (vitamin B6).
  • INH inhibits the conversion of pyridoxine to its active form, pyridoxal phosphate, which is required for various enzymatic reactions in the body.
* Side effects of isoniazid include:
  • Peripheral neuritis due to interference with the production of active coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine. Therefore, pyridoxine 10mg/day (vitamin B6) is given prophylactically along with isoniazid to prevent neurotoxicity.
  • Hepatitis - isoniazid must be stopped at the first sign of hepatotoxicity.
  • Rashes
  • Anaemia
  • Arthralgia
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 818.

questions.text:
Which of the following electrolytes is mandatorily monitored during Amphotericin B treatment?
1. \(Na^+\)
2. \(Ca^{2+}\)
3. \(K^+\)
4. \(Mg^{2+}\)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) \(K^+\)
 
  • Amphotericin B can cause renal toxicity, leading to renal tubular dysfunction and electrolyte imbalances.
  • One of the most significant electrolyte imbalances associated with Amphotericin B is hypokalemia (low potassium levels).
  • Hypokalemia can occur due to increased renal potassium excretion caused by the medication.
  • Therefore, regular monitoring of potassium (K+) levels is essential during Amphotericin B treatment to ensure appropriate management and prevention of complications.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 839.

questions.text: Which of the following Integrase inhibitors is approved for HIV1 and HIV 2 ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Raltegravir 
 
  • Raltegravir is an integrase inhibitor and is active against both HIV-1 and HIV-2. It can be used in adults and children >1 month old.
  • Integrase inhibitors block the action of the enzyme integrase, which is responsible for integrating the viral DNA into the host cell's DNA during the replication of the HIV virus.
  • By inhibiting integrase, Raltegravir prevents the integration of viral DNA into the host cell's DNA, thereby inhibiting viral replication.
  • Raltegravir is commonly used as part of combination antiretroviral therapy (ART) for the management of HIV infection.
  • Elvitegravir is effective against hiv-1 but it's efficacy against hiv-2 is not proven yet.
  • Lopinavir and Indinavir are protease inhibitors.
* [Extra Edge]: Lifecycle of HIV



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 866.

questions.text: MDR-TB is defined as resistance to:
questions.solution:
MDR TB is defined as resistance to both isoniazid and rifampicin. 


Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 961, 1359, 1372, 1376.

questions.text:
A 50 years old male who was recently diagnosed as pulmonary TB, was started on ATT. Later on, he presented with the complaints of tingling and numbness over fingers. He is also a chronic alcoholic. This patient should be managed by starting: 
1. Vitamin B1 
2. Vitamin B3
3. Vitamin B6 
4. Vitamin B12
questions.solution:
The features of tingling and numbness over fingers in a patient on anti-tubercular treatment is an adverse effect of isoniazid. 

It occurs due to peripheral neuritis which results from interference with the production of active coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine. Therefore, pyridoxine 10 mg/day- Vitamin B6 is given prophylactically with isoniazid in order to prevent this adverse effect. 



Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 775, 2526.

choices.text: Inhibition of synthesis of mycolic acid in bacterial cell wall

questions.text: A young male with urinary tract infection was given some antimicrobial agent. This agent has the tendency of causing arthropathy in children and causing tendon repture. What is the mechanism of this antimicrobial drug given to the patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the male has been given fluoroquinolone which has an adverse effect profile of causing tendon rupture and arthropathy. 

It works by inhibiting DNA gyrase. 



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 760, 761, 766, 784.

Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 1015, 1017.

questions.text: A patient on ART after 6 months develops hyperpigmentation of hand and foot. The drug responsible for this condition is?
questions.solution:
Pigmentation of sun exposed areas is one of the side effects of emtricitabine.
 
  • Emtricitabine, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used in antiretroviral therapy (ART), is associated with hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles, especially in individuals with darker skin tones.
 
  • This side effect is generally benign and does not require discontinuation of the drug unless cosmetically distressing.


Other options:
 

  1. Zidovudine:

    • May cause anemia, neutropenia, and myopathy but is not commonly linked to hyperpigmentation.

  2. Nevirapine:

    • A non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) associated with hypersensitivity reactions, including rash and hepatotoxicity, but not hyperpigmentation.

  3. Ritonavir:

    • A protease inhibitor, primarily associated with gastrointestinal side effects, lipid abnormalities, and fat redistribution (lipodystrophy).



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 1140, 1143, 1144, 1151.

questions.text: Name the drug acting on point (5)?
questions.solution:
Point 5 shows the action of Integrase

Raltegravir and Dolutegravir acts as Integrase inhibitor.





Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 1139, 1140, 1143.

questions.text: Peripheral blood smear showing sporozoite of plasmodium falciparum in RBC. Patient has seizures. Which is the preferred treatment?
questions.solution:
Parenteral artesunate is the drug of choice for cerebral malaria and this clinical scenario is indicative of cerebral malaria.
 
  • Plasmodium falciparum is the most serious species of malaria, and its infection can lead to cerebral malaria, which is often associated with seizures.
  • The preferred treatment for severe falciparum malaria (including cerebral malaria) is IV artesunate, a fast-acting artemisinin derivative.
    • Inj. Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg is given initially, followed by additional doses as per the protocol for severe malaria.
  • Artesunate is considered more effective than quinine, especially in severe cases, due to its rapid action and better safety profile.


Other options:
 

  1. Tab. Chloroquine:

    • Not effective against Plasmodium falciparum in regions with resistance. It is typically used for non-severe, sensitive malaria caused by other Plasmodium species.

  2. Tab. Doxycycline:

    • Doxycycline is used for prophylaxis and treatment of uncomplicated malaria, particularly for Plasmodium vivax, but not recommended in severe cases of falciparum malaria.

  3. Tab. Quinine:

    • Quinine is another treatment for severe malaria but is less preferred than artesunate for severe falciparum malaria, especially with cerebral involvement.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1730-1733.

questions.text: A pregnant female who was a known case of leprosy developed type 2 lepra reaction. Best treatment for her would be?
questions.solution:
• Type 2 lepra reaction, also known as erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL), is an acute inflammatory complication of leprosy. It is characterized by painful skin nodules, fever, malaise, and inflammation in various organs.
 
  • MDT is NOT stopped in Lepra reactions as stopping drug may cause treatment failure. MDT is safe in Pregnancy.
 
  • Thalidomide should not be given to pregnant females due to its known teratogenic effects, which can cause severe birth defects. Hence, in a pregnant female - the option would be to add steroids (option 1).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1387, 1390.

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology- Volume II, 9th edition, Page no 28.16.

questions.text: Which antimicrobial agent act by inhibiting transpeptidase enzyme?
questions.solution:
Beta-Lactam antibiotics inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) and inhibiting the transpeptidation step of peptidoglycan synthesis, leading to cell lysis and death. 


 
Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 1148,1146,1147 .

questions.text: Which among the following Anti tubercular drug acts inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis and needs catalase enzyme for activation?
questions.solution:
INH acts by inhibiting the mycolic acid synthesis and needs catalase enzyme for activation. 



 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 1068,1071-1074 .

questions.text: In a patient planned for a cardiac surgical procedure. Which of the following is preferred antibiotic for prophylaxis:
questions.solution:
• The most common pathogens infecting incision sites after clean surgery are Staphylococci, specifically S. aureus, and coagulase-negative staphylococci.
  • Cephalosporins (first and second generation) are the best-studied antimicrobial agents for Surgical site infections (SSI) prevention in cardiac procedures, out of which cefazolin is the most extensively studied, and has shown better results than cefuroxime, which theoretically has broader gram-negative coverage, but increased resistance. 
  • The timing of antibiotic administration is crucial, with the first dose typically given within 60 minutes before the incision.
  • It is the preferred antibiotic for prophylaxis in such a case.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 209.

questions.text: An asthmatic patient was being managed on inhaler therapy. The patient complained of whitish oral thrush on buccal mucosa and tongue. Which is the drug used for this condition?
questions.solution:
Inhaled corticosteroids which are used for maintenance therapy result in the deposition of steroids in the oropharyngeal space, which can cause oropharyngeal candidiasis.
For oral candidiasis, 10 mg troche(lozenge) of clotrimazole is allowed to be dissolved in the mouth 3-4 times a day. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 842, 843.

questions.text: 35y old female patient diagnosed to have MDR TB and was initated on treatment, During her regular follow up the doctor noticed to have enlarged neck swelling. TSH -10.08, Which of the following drugs is implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Hypothyoidism. Among the given drugs Ethionamide is known to cause Hypothyroidism. It acts by inhibiting Mycolic acid Synthesis. It has structurally similarities with Thionamide group of anti thyroid drugs, hence its known to cause hypothyoidism.
PAS also is known to cause hypothyroidism.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 821.

questions.text: 15y old boy with history of sore throat on Amoxcillin for the past one week , now came with multiple episodes of watery loose stools with fever. His TC was elevated. Which od the following is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Clostridium difficile infection.
The treatment for non severe disease of CD infection is Fidaxomycin 200mg BD for 10 days or Oral Vancomycin 125mg 4 times a day for ten days.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 20st Edition, Page No: 965, 966.

questions.text: 20y old male known case of hemophilia also on ART. Patient now presents to the ED with Sudden onset Severe headache, vomiting and altered sensorium. Which among the following ART drug could be the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given scenario in a Hemophilia patient with headache and altered sensorium is suggestive of Intra Cranial hemorrhage. Among the given options, Tipranavir is a Protease Inhibitor used in patients who are resistant to other PI ,It is often combined with ritonavir .
It should be avoided in patients with bleeding diathesis as it is asscociated with increased risk of Intra Cranial Hemorrhage

Reference: Katzung Basic and Clinical pharmacology, 14th Edition, Page No: 880, 881.

questions.text: Which of the following Antibiotics act by inhibiting the 50s ribosome?
questions.solution:
Linezolid binds to the P site of 50s ribosomal units and inhibits bacterial Protein Synthesis.
It is used in treatment of infections caused by Gram Positive Bacteria including MRSA and VRSA.
SE- Thrombocytopenia, precipitates Serotonin syndrome, Peripheral Neuropathy.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No: 807.

questions.text: A female in her second month of pregnancy visited the OPD with Plasmodium vivax malaria. Which of the following is the appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
In pregnancy, treatment of malaria must consider both efficacy and fetal safety.

For Plasmodium vivax infection:

  • Drug of choice: Chloroquine (safe and effective in all trimesters)

  • Dose: 25 mg base/kg over 3 days (10 mg/kg on Day 1 and 2, 5 mg/kg on Day 3)

  • Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy, because it can cause hemolysis in the fetus (due to unknown G6PD status).

  • ACT (Artemisinin Combination Therapy) is reserved for chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum and should be avoided in the first trimester unless no alternative is available.

  • Quinine is used for severe malaria or chloroquine-resistant falciparum, not for uncomplicated vivax infection.

Summary:

  • Drug of choice for P. vivax in pregnancy → Chloroquine

  • Primaquine (for hypnozoite eradication) is deferred until after delivery.

questions.text: What is the antibiotic of choice in a patient with enterococcal endocarditis with penicillin resistance ?
questions.solution:
Enterococci is a hospital-acquired pathogens, producing infections like:
● Urinary tract infections
● Bacteremia and mitral valve endocarditis (in intravenous drug abusers)
● Intrabdominal, pelvic and soft tissue infections
● Late-onset neonatal meningitis and sepsis.
  • Frequently Strains resistant to penicillin and other antibiotics are seen. In case of high-level resistance, the choice of drug is vancomycin.
  • In case of vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) linezolid, streptogramins (active against E.faecium, but not to E.faecalis) and daptomycin are used
In infections caused due to E. faecalis ampicillin is used as a first-line antibiotic and resistance is rare.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1201.

questions.text: Which of drugs used in the treatment of leprosy causes skin pigmentation
questions.solution:
• Clofazamine is a component of mutidrug treatment in management of leprosy. It a drug with leprostatic and antiinflammatory properties.
  • The mechanism of antimicrobial activity of clofazimine against mycobacteria appears to be multifactorial and includes membrane disruption, inhibition of mycobacterial phospholipase A2, inhibition of microbial K+ transport, generation of hydrogen peroxide, interference with the bacterial electron transport chain, and efflux pump inhibition.
  • Adverse effects include
  • Gastrointestinal disturbances-Clofazimine can cause nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. These side effects can be severe and may require a change in dose or stopping the drug.
  • Skin discoloration-A reddish-orange color from the drug can cause skin and bodily fluids to turn pinkish-brown. This discoloration can affect the face, eyes, sweat, urine, tears, and stools. It can be especially noticeable in fair-skinned patients who are exposed to light. The discoloration may fade after stopping the drug.
  • Arrhythmia : Clofazimine can cause an irregular heartbeat, dizziness, or fainting. 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page No 833.

questions.text: Which of the following sexually transmitted diseases is associated with drug resistance?
questions.solution:
• Gonorrhoea is caused by Neisseria gonnorrhea. These gonococci have the ability to develop complete resistance to antibiotics either by chromosomal mutation or by acquiring R factors.
Mechanism of resistance:
  • B-Lactamase producing Gonococci and tetracycline-resistant strains occur together. Hence Penicillin, ampicillin, and tetracycline are no longer effective against Neisseria Gonnorrhoea.
  • Changes in DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV cause fluoroquinolone resistance.
  • Drug efflux pump and reduced drug influx also contribute to resistance against cephalosporins.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1124,1128.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs causes optic neuritis?
questions.solution:
Retrobulbar optic neuropathy (normal appearing optic disc on presentation) is the most common form of EON. The exact mechanism of the neurotoxic effect of EMB on the optic nerve is unknown. One theory is that the chelation of copper disrupts oxidative phosphorylation, as there is less copper available in human mitochondria. Another theory is that the chelation of zinc inhibits lysosomal activation. Ref- Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition •
Page no 1074, 1083

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not have dual activity against hepatitis B and HIV?
questions.solution:
Tenofovir, a Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) is affective against both HIV and Hepatitis B. The WHO recommends that people coinfected with HIV and HBV start an antiretroviral therapy (ART) regimen that contains Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate.
Lamivudine (3TC)
A nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that can be used in combination with other drugs to treat HIV-1. It can also be used as a monotherapy for hepatitis B.
Emtricitabine (FTC)
A nucleoside agent that is similar to lamivudine in terms of activity, safety, and convenience. It is often used in combination with tenofovir for patients coinfected with HIV and Hep B. Nevirapine is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor
(NNRTI). Nevirapine PLUS twice-daily zidovudine for six weeks, followed by an additional six weeks of the same combination regimen or nevirapine alone is recommended for High-risk infants with mothers who are:
• HIV positive not on ART
• Mother diagnosed with HIV 72 hours after delivery.
• On ART with viral load > 1000 copies/mL
• With unknown viral load, hasn't been on ART for >4 consecutive weeks. Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition • Page no. 1143, 1144, 1151, 1152 .

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. Which of the following cannot be used to treat her condition?
questions.solution:
• Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is caused by an overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria (e.g., Gardnerella vaginalis) and reduction of normal lactobacilli.

  • Effective treatments target anaerobic bacteria:

    • Metronidazole (oral or topical)

    • Clindamycin (oral or vaginal cream)

    • Tinidazole (oral, similar to metronidazole)

  • Erythromycin: Primarily effective against Gram-positive aerobes and some Gram-negative bacteria, not effective against anaerobes causing BV.


Reference
Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology 16th Edition - Page no.163-164

questions.text: What is the treatment protocol for pulmonary tuberculosis in children?
questions.solution:
The treatment of pulmonary tuberculosis in children follows the WHO-recommended first-line anti-TB regimen:

  1. Intensive phase (2 months):

    • H – Isoniazid

    • R – Rifampicin

    • Z – Pyrazinamide

    • E – Ethambutol

  2. Continuation phase (4 months):

    • H – Isoniazid

    • R – Rifampicin

    • E – Ethambutol (often included depending on guidelines and drug resistance risk)

  • Steroids are added only in complicated TB cases (e.g., TB meningitis, pericardial TB), not in uncomplicated pulmonary TB.

  • The total duration is usually 6 months for uncomplicated pulmonary TB.

Remarks on other options:

  • 4HRZE + 2HRE: Longer than recommended in children for uncomplicated TB.

  • 4HRZE + 2HRE + Steroids / 2HRZE + 4HRE + Steroids: Steroids not indicated in uncomplicated pulmonary TB.




Reference
1.Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 14th Edition - Page 1279,1280
2.Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 27th Edition - Page 221

questions.text: A tuberculosis patient on treatment is non-compliant with initial therapy. Drug susceptibility showed resistance to rifampicin and isoniazid. He was started with the next-line drug that inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthesis. Which of the following can be the newly given drug?
questions.solution:
• The patient has multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), resistant to rifampicin and isoniazid.

  • Bedaquiline is a newer anti-TB drug used for MDR-TB.

    • Mechanism: Inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthase, leading to energy depletion and bacterial death.

    • Important for cases where first-line drugs cannot be used due to resistance.

Other options:

  • Cycloserine: Inhibits cell wall synthesis (D-alanine pathway); used in MDR-TB but not ATP synthase inhibitor.

  • Ethionamide: Inhibits mycolic acid synthesis; second-line drug, not ATP synthase inhibitor.

  • Pretomanid: Used in XDR-TB or MDR-TB regimens, inhibits mycolic acid and causes respiratory poisoning of bacteria, but not direct ATP synthase inhibition.


Reference
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition - Page no. 1075-1078

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of doxycycline?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline is a broad-spectrum tetracycline antibiotic.

Mechanism of Action:

  • It binds to the 30S ribosomal subunit of bacteria.

  • This prevents the attachment of aminoacyl-tRNA to the A site of the ribosome.

  • As a result, bacterial protein synthesis is inhibited, stopping bacterial growth (bacteriostatic effect).

    Why the other options are incorrect:

  • 1. DNA gyrase inhibitor:
    This is the mechanism of fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin), which inhibit DNA replication, not protein synthesis.

  • 3. Leucyl-tRNA synthetase inhibitor:
    This is the mechanism of novel drugs like tavaborole, not doxycycline.

  • 4. Cell wall synthesis inhibitor:
    This is the mechanism of β-lactams (penicillins, cephalosporins) and vancomycin, which affect peptidoglycan cell wall formation.

    Clinical Note:

  • Doxycycline is effective against atypical organisms like Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Rickettsia, and some protozoa (Plasmodium, in malaria prophylaxis).

  • It should not be given to children under 8 years or pregnant women, due to risk of tooth discoloration and bone growth inhibition.



Reference:Goodman and Gillmans The pharmacological basis of Therapeutics 13th edition page no 1051

questions.text: A pregnant lady was diagnosed with Extensively Drug-Resistant TB. Which of the following drugs is unsafe in this lady?
questions.solution:
A pregnant woman with Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis (XDR-TB) must be treated cautiously to balance maternal cure and fetal safety.

Among the options:

Kanamycin

  • Class: Aminoglycoside

  • Risk: Crosses the placenta and is ototoxic to the fetus

  • Adverse effects: Can cause congenital deafness (sensorineural hearing loss) due to damage to the 8th cranial nerve (vestibulocochlear nerve)

  • Conclusion: Contraindicated in pregnancy unless no safer alternatives

Clofazimine

  • Used in: Leprosy and MDR/XDR-TB

  • Pregnancy category C, but no teratogenicity seen in humans

  • Conclusion: Can be used when necessary under specialist care

Linezolid

  • Pregnancy Category C

  • Limited human data, but no known major teratogenicity

  • Conclusion: May be used in XDR-TB under expert supervision

Amoxicillin

  • Beta-lactam antibiotic

  • Pregnancy Category B – considered safe in pregnancy

  • Often used in combination regimens for TB (e.g., with clavulanic acid)


Reference:Williams Obstetrics 25th edition page no 1247

choices.text: Used in ovarian, cervix and breast cancer

questions.text: Which of these is not true about paclitaxel?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) 
 
  • Paclitaxel stabilizes microtubule and prevent polymerization.
  • It binds to β-tubulin and enhances its polymerization to form excess of microtubules: a mechanism opposite to that of vinca alkaloids.
  • The microtubules are stabilized and their depolymerization is prevented. This stability disrupts the normal dynamic reorganization of the microtubule network that is essential for interphase and mitotic functions.
  • Abnormal arrays or ‘bundles’ of microtubules are produced throughout the cell cycle.
  • It is a complex diterpin taxane obtained from bark of the Western yew tree not E.coli.
  • The approved indications of paclitaxel are metastatic ovarian and breast carcinoma after failure of first line chemotherapy and relapse cases. It has also shown efficacy in advanced cases of head and neck cancer, small cell lung cancer, esophageal adenocarcinoma, urinary and hormone refractory prostate cancer. AIDS related Kaposi’s sarcoma also responds.
  • The major toxicity is reversible myelosuppression (mainly granulocytopenia) and ‘stocking and glove’ neuropathy. Nausea, chest pain, arthralgia, myalgia, mucositis and edema can be troublesome.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 925.

choices.text: Chimeric monoclonal antibody against CD-20 B cell antigen
Most common side effect is infusion reaction
First FDA drug approved for resistant lymphomas

questions.text: Which of these is not true for rituximab?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Dose independent pharmacokinetics:

Malignant cells express certain antigens against whom antibodies can be developed. CD20 is such antigen.

Option 1 : Rituximab is one such Monoclonal antibody that binds to CD20 B-cell antigen expressed on the surface of lymphocytes, plasma cells and B-cell lymphomas.

Option 2 : Infusion reactions consisting of chills, rigor, fever, urticarial rashes are the most common adverse effects. Pretreatment with corticosteroids and antihistaminics is done to prevent infusion reactions.

Option 3 : Rituximab was the first MAb used for the treatment of lymphomas. Follicular lymphoma was the first cancer to be treated.

Option 4 : It follows Non-linear PK at low doses and Linear PK at high doses after saturation of target

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 932.

questions.text: Which of these cancers cannot be treated with steroids?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Kaposi sarcoma
 
  • Steroids are often included in the treatment of certain cancers as combination chemotherapy.
  • These include both acute and chronic lymphocytic leukemias, Hodgkin as well as non-Hodgkin lymphoma, multiple myeloma, breast cancer and medulloblastoma.
  • In HIV-infected individuals, the use of glucocorticoids is a risk factor for KS-IRIS and Kaposi's sarcoma-associated mortality. In addition, KS-IRIS is a risk factor for mortality.
  • Therefore, glucocorticoid administration in this population requires careful consideration based on individualized risk–benefit analysis.
Online Reference: 
Fernández-Sánchez M, Iglesias MC, Ablanedo-Terrazas Y, Ormsby CE, Alvarado-de la Barrera C, Reyes-Terán G. Steroids are a risk factor for Kaposi's sarcoma-immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome and mortality in HIV infection. AIDS. 2016 Mar 27;30(6):909-14. doi: 10.1097/QAD.0000000000000993. PMID: 26636923; PMCID: PMC4794188.

questions.text: In estrogen receptor positive breast cancer, the correct anti-estrogen drug to be used is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Tamoxifen
 
  • The drug of choice for estrogen positive breast carcinoma is tamoxifen which is a selective estrogen receptor modulator. 
  • Side effects- Tamoxifen increases the risk of postmenopausal bleeding, endometrial polyps, hyperplasia, and endometrial cancer. 
  • It is also approved by the FDA for the prevention of breast cancer in women at high risk of developing the disease. It has been further approved for the reduction of contralateral (in the opposite breast) cancer.
  • The use of tamoxifen is recommended for 10 years.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 337.

questions.text: What exactly is amifostine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Radio-protector
 
  • Amifostine is a radioprotectant, which is a compound that protects tissue from the damaging effects of radiation.
  • It works by temporarily binding to radiation and preventing it from entering cells and damaging them.
  • When taken before radiation treatment, Amifostine reduces the chances of radiation-induced damage to healthy cells.
  • It is most commonly used to protect the salivary glands and other areas of the head and neck from radiation exposure during radiation therapy for cancer.
Radio-sensitiser examples- oxygen, 5FU, gemcitabine.
Radio-protector examples- amifostine, vitamin A/C/E.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 936.

questions.text: Nausea, with or without vomiting, is the most typical adverse effect of cancer chemotherapy. The likelihood of nausea and vomiting is different among anti-cancer medications. Which of the following anti-cancer medications has the lowest risk of producing nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Chlorambucil 
 
  • Least emetogenic drug out of the following can be concluded as Chlorambucil based on their classification based on risk.
  • Chlorambucil can cause nausea and vomiting which is known as an emetogenic effect.
  • This occurs due to the destruction of rapidly dividing cells in the body, which is how chemotherapy works, but can also be found in the cells in the digestive system or stomach that would normally help prevent the feeling of nausea.
  • If these cells are destroyed, it can lead to nausea and other digestive symptoms.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 918.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs is necessary to lessen the toxicity of pemetrexed?
1. Folic acid and vitamin B6 
2. Folic acid and vitamin B12 
3. Vitamin B6 and Vitamin B12 
4. Folic acid and dexamethasone
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Folic acid and vitamin B12
 
  • Pemetrexed is a drug used alone or with other drugs to treat certain types of non-small cell lung cancer and malignant pleural mesothelioma.
  • Pemetrexed disodium stops cells from using folic acid to make DNA and may kill cancer cells. It is a type of antimetabolite and a type of antifolate. 
  • Patients are administered intramuscular vitamin B12 (1 mg) and folic acid tablets with the first dose of pemetrexed to correct possible B12, deficiency. These small doses of folate and B12, do not compromise the therapeutic effect.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 921.

questions.text: Which of these is not a G2 phase blocker?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Paclitaxel

  • Paclitaxel (PTX) is a taxane. It is an M-phase blocker.
  • PTX binds to microtubules instead of tubulin dimers and stabilizes microtubules (polymerization) by promoting the assembly of alpha and beta tubulin subunits, the building blocks of microtubules.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 925.

questions.text: What is L-asparaginase used to treat?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) ALL

L-asparaginase is used in the treatment of ALL (Acute lymphoblastic leukemia).

Mechanism of Action
L asparaginase depletes asparagine in lymphoblasts and lower levels of cellular asparagine cause reduced RNA, DNA, and protein synthesis. This leads to the inhibition of cell growth and later cell death. 

Drugs used in the treatment of ALL
 
Phase of Treatment Drugs used
Induction Steroids, Vincristine, L-asparaginase, Daunorubicin
Consolidation Cyclophosphamide, Cytosine Arabinoside
CNS Directed Therapy Intrathecal Methotrexate/CNS irradiation
Maintenance Oral 6MP/Methotrexate

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 928.

questions.text: Which medication among the following results in flagellate skin pigmentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Bleomycin
 
  • Bleomycin can cause a flagellate dermatitis consisting of bands of pruritic erythema on the arms, back, scalp and hands, which can be treated with topical corticosteroids.
  • The most serious adverse reaction to bleomycin is pulmonary toxicity, with signs such as dry cough, fine rales, and diffuse basilar infiltrates on X-ray.
  • This can progress to life-threatening pulmonary fibrosis and radiological changes which may be indistinguishable from interstitial infection or tumor, showing strong PET-positivity and ranging from patchy infiltrates to dense fibrosis, cavitation and pneumothorax, atelectasis, or lobar collapse.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1370.

choices.text: It has been re-introduced for its activity in ENL.(Erythema nodusum leprosy)
Developed as antiemetic in pregnancy but withdrawn because of phocomelia
Used for new and relapsed cases of multiple myeloma
Most common side effects are diarrhea and euphoria

questions.text: Incorrect statement about thalidomide:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Most common side effects are diarrhea and euphoria

Thalidomide causes Somnolence and Constipation. Other side effects are fatigue, peripheral neuropathy and skin rashes.

*[Extra Edge]: Thalidomide
 
  • Thalidomide is an anti-inflammatory, cytokine (TNFα, ILs, interferon) modulating drug with anxiolytic, antiemetic property.
  • Thalidomide can be used in ENL as an alternative to prednisolone.
  • It was introduced in 1958 for morning sickness was found to be highly teratogenic and withdrawn in 1961.
  • It has been reintroduced for ENL as well as a variety of other conditions in which cytokines play an important role like cancer-associated cachexia; also used in multiple myeloma.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 837, 936.

questions.text: Which one of the aforementioned medications is advised for the treatment of gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GlST)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Imatinib
 
  • Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor advised for management of metastatic GIST.
  • In case of resistance to Imatinib – Sunitinib and Sorafenib are used.
  • Imatinib is also used for management of CML
  • Sunitinib and Sorafenib are used in management of RCC and HCC.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 929.

questions.text: Which of the following more recent medications is active against both the HER 1 and HER 2 novel receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Lapatinib

Lapatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor shown to be active against both HER1 and HER2 novel receptors. It has shown remission in tumours resistant to Trastuzumab.

Option 1: Erlotinib – Non small cell lung cancer, Pancreatic cancer

Option 2: Gefitinib – Non small cell lung cancer in patients with abnormal EGFR gene

Option 3: Canertinib – Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 930.

questions.text: Tyrosine kinase inhibitors can be used to treat:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GlST)

Tyrosine Kinase inhibitors are effective in the following diseases: HER2 positive breast cancer, CLL, GIST, Waldenström Macroglobulinemia, Non-small cell lung cancer Melanoma

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 929.

questions.text: What is nivolumab used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hodgkin’s lymphoma
 
  • A fully human monoclonal IgG4 antibody called nivolumab disrupts the interaction between PD-1 and its ligands. 
  • Clinical Use of ADME: an intravenous infusion of the medication is administered every two weeks until the condition progresses or there is unacceptable toxicity.
  • recommended for the management of a number of cancers: Advancement of melanoma, Advanced head and neck cancer, previously treated NSCLC, RCC, relapsed/refractory classical Hodgkin lymphoma.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1423.

questions.text: What is Cyclosporine's mode of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Calcineurin inhibitor

  • Cyclosporine is a calcineurin inhibitor.
  • It is used as an immunosuppressant medication.
  • It works by decreasing the function of lymphocytes by forming a complex with cyclophilin to block the phosphatase activity of Calcineurin which in turn decreases the production of inflammatory cytokines by T - lymphocytes.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 937.

questions.text: Identify the drug responsible for the side effect in the given picture:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Bleomycin
 
  • The side effect given in picture is caused due to bleomycin.
  • The side effect that is shown in the image is FLAGELLATED DERMATITIS and it is caused due to consumption of bleomycin.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1370.

questions.text: Identify the best drug for the treatment of hairy cell leukemia:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Cladribine
 
  • DOC for the treatment of hairy cell leukemia is Cladribine.
  • Both pentostatin and cladribine can be used for the treatment of hairy cell leukemia, but cladribine is the drug of choice.


Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1362.

questions.text: The way that methotrexate works to treat osteosarcoma is as follows:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Competitive inhibitor of DHFR

Drug Class Mechanism of Action (MOA)
Methotrexate Antimetabolite Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), blocking the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate. This disrupts DNA synthesis and cell division, especially in rapidly dividing cells like cancer or immune cells.
 This principle is thus used in the management of carcinoma like Osteosarcoma.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 214.

questions.text: In which of the following condition is the drug in the picture used topically?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Subglottic stenosis

EXPLANATIONS:-
  • Subglottic stenosis is defined as the narrowing of the upper airway, which lies between the vocal folds and the lower border of the cricoid cartilage.  
  • CAUSES: -
    • Congenital
    • Trauma
    • Infection   
  • MANAGEMENT: - Mitomycin is the drug of choice in post Subglottic Stenosis operation to prevent regrowth of fibroblasts and prevents restenosis.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 927.

questions.text: Identify the PD-1 inhibitor from the following antineoplastic drugs.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Pembrolizumab

Examples of PD1 inhibitors which act as Anti neoplastic drugs are:-
 
  • PEMBROLIZUMAB
  • NIVOLUMAB
  • CEMIPLIMAB
*Other options:
  • Belimumab inhibits B cell activating factor
  • Ofatumumab is an antibody to CD 20.
  • Alefacept inhibiting the interaction between CD2 and its ligand, LFA-3.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1421.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is treated with telotristat?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Diarrhea induced by carcinoid tumor
 
  • Telotristat is indicated for the treatment of diarrhea associated with carcinoid syndrome.
  • Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that can produce excessive amounts of serotonin, leading to symptoms such as diarrhea.
  • Telotristat works by inhibiting the enzyme tryptophan hydroxylase, which is responsible for serotonin production.
  • By reducing serotonin levels, telotristat helps to alleviate the diarrhea symptoms associated with carcinoid tumors.
* Other options:
  • Pheochromocytoma-induced hypertensive crisis (A) is typically managed with alpha-blockers and other medications to control blood pressure.
  • Galactorrhea in pituitary tumor (C) is often treated with medication such as dopamine agonists to reduce the production of prolactin, a hormone responsible for galactorrhea.
  • Myxedema of Hypothyroidism (D) is treated with thyroid hormone replacement therapy to restore the levels of thyroid hormones in the body.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1098.

questions.text: Which of the following cancer treatments targets the M-phase only?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Docetaxel
 
  • Docetaxel is a chemotherapy medication that belongs to a class of drugs called taxanes.
  • Taxanes primarily target the M-phase (mitotic phase) of the cell cycle, which is the phase when cells divide and replicate their DNA.
  • Docetaxel works by inhibiting microtubule disassembly during cell division, leading to cell cycle arrest and preventing further cell division.
  • By specifically targeting the M-phase, docetaxel can disrupt the growth and proliferation of cancer cells.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 925.

choices.text: Used in Non small cell lung carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the statements is not true about Erlotinib?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Food decreases its absorption 
 
  • Erlotinib is a reversible EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor used for advanced non-small cell lung cancer(NSCLC) with mutant EGFR and advanced pancreatic cancer in combination with gemcitabine.
  • It works by inhibiting the activity of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase, which plays a role in cancer cell growth and survival.
  • One of the common side effects of Erlotinib is the development of skin rashes, which can range from mild to severe.
  • Erlotinib can be taken with or without food, as food does not significantly affect its absorption.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 930.

questions.text: Which is an exception to adverse effects of thalidomide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Diarrhea  
 
  • Thalidomide is a medication known for its history of causing severe birth defects in children, including phocomelia ( abnormally short or absent limbs) when taken by pregnant women.
  • Thalidomide can have several adverse effects, including neuropathy, somnolence, dizziness, constipation, and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
  • However, diarrhea is not commonly associated with thalidomide use, unlike the other mentioned side effects.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 936.

questions.text: Which of the following chemotherapeutic drugs is used for the Alkalinization of urine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Methotrexate
 
  • The chemotherapeutic drug that is used for the alkalinization of urine is Methotrexate.
  • Methotrexate is a chemotherapy drug that is used to treat cancer, autoimmune diseases, and ectopic pregnancies.
  • It works by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, which is responsible for the synthesis of folic acid. This inhibition leads to a decrease in the production of DNA and RNA, which results in the death of rapidly dividing cells, including cancer cells.
  • In addition to its use in cancer treatment, Methotrexate is also used to alkalinize urine.
  • This is because Methotrexate is a weak organic acid that is excreted in the urine. When the urine is acidic, Methotrexate can precipitate out of solution and form crystals, which can cause kidney damage.
  • However, when the urine is alkalinized, Methotrexate remains in solution and is more easily excreted from the body, reducing the risk of kidney damage.
Therefore, Methotrexate is the correct option for the chemotherapeutic drug used for the alkalinization of urine.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 921.

questions.text: Specify the classification of Temozolomide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Alkylating Agent
 
  • Temozolomide is an oral chemotherapy drug used in the treatment of certain types of brain tumors, such as glioblastoma multiforme and anaplastic astrocytoma.
  • Mechanism of action -  deposit Methyl groups on DNA guanine bases - hence - it works similar to alkylating agents.
Therefore, Temozolomide is classified as an Alkylating Agent

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 920.

questions.text:
Match the following 
a. Imatinib (i) Mtor inhibitor
b. Sirolimus (ii) BCR-ABL kinase
c. Trastuzumab (iii) TNF alpha inhibitor
d. Infliximab (iv) HER2 neu inhitor
questions.solution:
• a. Imatinib – (ii) BCR-ABL kinase inhibitor

    • Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor specifically targeting the BCR-ABL fusion protein found in chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).

  • b. Sirolimus – (i) mTOR inhibitor

    • Sirolimus is an immunosuppressive drug that inhibits the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR), used in preventing organ rejection in transplant patients.

  • c. Trastuzumab – (iv) HER2 neu inhibitor

    • Trastuzumab (Herceptin) is a monoclonal antibody that targets the HER2/neu receptor, used in the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer.

  • d. Infliximab – (iii) TNF-alpha inhibitor

    • Infliximab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), used in the treatment of inflammatory conditions like rheumatoid arthritis and Crohn's disease.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 775, 776, 781, 1339.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a check point inhibitor ?
questions.solution:
The checkpoint inhibitor that is not among the options provided is "Cetuximab" (option 3).

Cetuximab is not a checkpoint inhibitor; it is a monoclonal antibody that targets the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR). It is used in the treatment of colorectal/head and neck cancer.

Options 1, 2, and 4 are all checkpoint inhibitors.
Nivolumab (option 1) and pembrolizumab (option 2) are both monoclonal antibodies that target and block the programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) receptor.
Avelumab (option 4) is a monoclonal antibody that targets and blocks the programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1).
 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 1417,1423,1432,1401,801,759 .

questions.text: Which is the active metabolite of Cyclophosphamide?
questions.solution:
• The active metabolite of Cyclophosphamide is: 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide.
  • Cyclophosphamide is a prodrug that undergoes metabolic activation in the liver. One of its primary metabolites is 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide, which is responsible for the cytotoxic effects of the drug (along with aldophosphamide).
  • 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide can further metabolize into other active species, including phosphoramide mustard, which is the ultimate cytotoxic compound responsible for the anticancer activity of Cyclophosphamide.
 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 1170 .

questions.text: Half life of Letrozole is?
questions.solution:
The half-life of Letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor used in the treatment of breast cancer, is approximately 45 hours (option 1).

The half-life of letrozole is 45 hours.

Letrozole is a reversible aromatase inhibitor.It is a non-steroidal compound that inhibits the aromatization of estrogen thereby causing estrogen depletion.Letrozole is rapidly absorbed with 99.9% oral bioavailability and has a t½ of around 41 hours.Letrozole is used as the first-line drug for estrogen-positive breast cancer following mastectomy in post-menopausal women.

Adverse effects of letrozole are due to the depletion of estrogen. The commonly seen adverse effects are hot flashes, vaginal dryness, nausea, diarrhea, dyspepsia, accelerated bone loss, and thinning of hair.



 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 1443 .

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used to treat doxorubicin induced cardiotoxicity?
questions.solution:
Dexrazoxane is used to treat Doxorubicin induced cardiomyopathy.
* Extra edge: 

Dexrazoxane, an FDA-approved cardioprotective drug, has been successfully used to ameliorate cardiac toxicity seen in anthracycline-based (e.g., doxorubicin, daunorubicin, epirubicin) chemotherapy recipients for cancer, mainly in advanced breast cancer patients, adult patients with soft tissue sarcomas, or small-cell lung cancer. It is used intravenously in conjunction with the anthracycline of choice to decrease the incidence of cardiomyopathy and congestive heart failure.

Dexrazoxane has also shown an indication in the prevention of surrounding tissue damage caused by extravasation of anthracyclines, which can occur upon administration of these chemotherapeutic drugs.

However, dexrazoxane treatment does not completely eliminate the risk of cardiac toxicity induced by anthracyclines, so it is necessary to check on the patient’s cardiac function before and consistently during therapy to analyze the left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF).

Reference: 
Eneh C, Lekkala MR. Dexrazoxane. [Updated 2023 Jul 17]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560559/

questions.text: Which of the following is a Her-2 inhibitor monoclonal antibody?
questions.solution:
• Pertuzumab is a humanized IgG1 monoclonal antibody directed against HER2.
  • It approved for the treatment of patients with HER2-positive, locally advanced, inflammatory, or early-stage breast cancer in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel.
  • Its adverse effect includes cardiotoxicity.
  • Cetuximab, Panitumumab, Necitumumab act against epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR)/ HER-1.
Reference: Katzung basic and clinical Pharmacology, 14th Edition, Page No 972.

questions.text: Drug used for trastuzumab-resistant her 2 positive breast cancer Is:
questions.solution:
Lapatinib is a small-molecule, orally bioavailable inhibitor of the EGFR and HER2 tyrosine kinases, and is metabolized by CYP3A4. It is approved for treating metastatic HER2-positive breast cancer that is resistant to trastuzumab when used in combination with capecitabine. Additionally, lapatinib, in combination with the aromatase inhibitor letrozole, is used to treat hormone receptor-positive, metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2 in postmenopausal women. Common side effects include acneiform rash, diarrhea, cramping, and worsening of gastroesophageal reflux. While cardiac toxicity is generally less severe compared to trastuzumab, lapatinib should be used cautiously with other cardiotoxic drugs. It has been associated with a dose-dependent prolongation of the QT interval, so careful monitoring is necessary for patients with heart conditions. Severe hepatotoxicity has also been reported. Trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody that targets the HER2 receptor, is used to treat HER2-positive breast cancer.



 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 956,1340,1378,1389 .

questions.text: Nomogram used for vancomycin dosing is:
questions.solution:
• The Matzke nomogram is utilized for determining vancomycin dosing.
  • It provides dosing intervals from 0.5 to 12 days, depending on creatinine clearance (CL) values ranging from 0 to 120 mL/min. This tool helps establish the initial empiric dose and interval for intravenous (IV) vancomycin in hospitalized adults who are not undergoing hemodialysis.
 
  • However, it is not suitable for patients with highly variable vancomycin pharmacokinetics, including critically ill individuals, those with severe burn injuries (over 20% of body surface), patients with rapidly changing renal function, pregnant women, individuals with liver failure or ascites, those at extreme weights, recent transplant recipients, and cystic fibrosis patients.
  • The Rumack-Matthew nomogram evaluates potential hepatotoxicity based on serum acetaminophen concentration relative to the time elapsed since ingestion, after a single acute dose of acetaminophen.



Reference: Rybak, M J, and S C Boike. “Individualized adjustment of vancomycin dosage: comparison with two dosage nomograms.” Drug intelligence & clinical pharmacy vol. 20,1 (1986): 64-8. doi:10.1177/106002808602000112. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3943460/

questions.text: Osimertinib is used in NSCLC with which of the following mutations?
questions.solution:
The T790M mutation in the EGFR gene is known to confer resistance to first and second-generation EGFR inhibitors. Osimertinib, a third-generation EGFR inhibitor, is effective against this resistance and is commonly used for patients with the T790M mutation who have progressed on earlier EGFR inhibitors.

Osimertinib is a kinase inhibitor approved for:

Treating patients with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) that has progressed after prior EGFR TKI treatment and is positive for the EGFR T790M mutation.

Serving as a first-line treatment for metastatic NSCLC and as adjuvant therapy following resection of NSCLC with EGFR exon 19 deletions or exon 21 L858R mutations.


Although osimertinib is used for both the L858R and T790M mutations, it is particularly noted for its efficacy against the T790M mutation due to its ability to overcome resistance associated with earlier EGFR inhibitors.

Osimertinib is taken orally, is a substrate of CYP3A, and is primarily excreted through feces with some excretion in urine. Concurrent use of CYP3A4 inducers may require dose adjustments
Common adverse effects include leukopenia,
diarrhea, skin rash, interstitial lung disease, QTcprolongation, and left ventricular dysfunction.


 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 1385,1386 .

questions.text: What is true about KEYNOTE-189 trial?
questions.solution:
• The KEYNOTE-189 trial is a study designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of pembrolizumab (MK-3475) in combination with pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy, compared to pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy alone.
  • This trial focuses on patients with advanced or metastatic non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) who have not had prior systemic treatment for their advanced disease.
  • Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either pembrolizumab with pemetrexed/platinum or pemetrexed/platinum alone.






Reference: Pembrolizumab plus Chemotherapy in Metastatic Non-small Cell Lung Cancer (NEJM article), Leena Gandhi et al., Published in 2018, DOI: 10.1056/NEJMoa1801005. URL: https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1801005

questions.text: Cyclosporine-induced cholestasis is due to which receptor?
questions.solution:
Cyclosporine-induced cholestasis is linked to the MDR1 transporter.

ABC transporters such as MRP2, MDR1, BCRP, BSEP, and MDR3, located in the bile canalicular membrane of hepatocytes, facilitate the efflux of drugs, their metabolites, bile salts, and phospholipids from the liver into bile, against a steep concentration gradient. This process, driven by ATP hydrolysis, involves primary active transport.

Cyclosporine, which is a substrate for MDR1, can lead to cholestatic liver injury through several mechanisms:

It competitively inhibits ATP-dependent transporters.

It impairs intrahepatic vesicle transport and disrupts the targeting of ATP-dependent transporters to the canalicular membrane.

It affects bile secretion by increasing canalicular membrane fluidity without altering the expression of canalicular transporters.


Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressive drug that works by inhibiting calcineurin activity. It forms a complex with cyclophilin, a cytoplasmic receptor protein, resulting in the cyclosporine-cyclophilin complex. Calcineurin is a calcium/calmodulin-dependent phosphatase essential for T cell lymphokine production and proliferation. The drug-receptor complex binds to and inhibits calcineurin, which, in turn, prevents the translocation of a group of transcription factors (NF-AT). This leads to decreased transcriptional activation of cytokine genes such as interleukin (IL)-2, tumor necrosis factor (TNF)alpha, IL-3, IL-4, CD40L, granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor, and interferon-gamma, ultimately reducing T lymphocyte proliferation and providing immunomodulation.

Cyclosporine is used for:

Preventing organ rejection in solid organ transplants (kidney, liver, and heart).

Treating rheumatoid arthritis when methotrexate is insufficient.

Managing conditions like Behcet‘s disease, acute ocular syndrome, endogenous uveitis, atopic dermatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, and nephrotic syndrome.


Adverse effects of cyclosporine include decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR), metabolic disturbances such as hypomagnesemia, hyperkalemia, dyslipidemia, gynecomastia, and hypertrichosis, as well as neurotoxicity like convulsions. Additionally, patients with psoriasis treated with cyclosporine have an increased risk of skin and lymphoproliferative malignancies.


 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 92,773-775 .

choices.text: Release of reactive oxygen species and free radicals

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mechanism for thalidomide teratogenicity?
questions.solution:
Thalidomide does not cause teratogenic effects by inhibiting IL2, IL4, or IL5. Instead, its teratogenicity is linked to mechanisms such as oxidative stress, anti-angiogenesis, and its binding to the protein cereblon (CRBN), which is involved in cerebral tissue development and plays a role in memory and learning processes. Exposure to thalidomide during fetal development leads to phocomelia, a condition characterized by underdeveloped limbs, absent pelvic bones, and anomalies such as fused fingers and missing thumbs. Thalidomide was initially used to treat morning sickness during pregnancy but was withdrawn due to these severe effects. It is now prescribed for erythema nodosumleprosum.

Thalidomide functions as an immunomodulator. It is absorbed slowly and variably from the gastrointestinal tract, distributes widely in tissues and organs with minimal plasma protein binding, and is excreted in the urine and, in its non-absorbed form, in the feces.

Common side effects of thalidomide include sedation and constipation. A serious adverse effect is peripheral sensory neuropathy, which presents as asymmetric, painful peripheral paresthesia and sensory loss. Symptoms typically include numbness in the toes and feet, muscle cramps, weakness, signs of pyramidal tract involvement, and carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 1404,1405 .

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are used to treat chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) is managed by combination antiemetic therapy, especially in moderate to highly emetogenic chemotherapy. The most effective regimen includes agents that target different emetic pathways.

Standard Antiemetic Regimen for CINV:
 

  • Highly emetogenic chemo: 5-HT₃ antagonist + NK₁ antagonist + Dexamethasone ± Olanzapine

  • Moderately emetogenic: 5-HT₃ antagonist + Dexamethasone ± NK₁ antagonist ± Olanzapine

  • Low emetogenic: Single agent (Dexamethasone OR 5-HT₃ antagonist OR Dopamine antagonist)

  • Minimal emetogenic: No routine prophylaxis


Mechanism of emesis:


Mechanism of action of anti-emetic drugs:

questions.text: A patient on anti-cancer therapy developed an infection Blood analysis revealed neutropenia. Which of the following drug is likely to be effective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Filgrastim is a medication used to treat chemotherapy-induced neutropenia.

It is a recombinant human granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) that stimulates colony-forming unit-granulocyte (CFU-G) to enhance neutrophil production. Filgrastim can be administered either subcutaneously or via slow intravenous infusion. Its indications include:

Treatment of severe neutropenia following autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation and high-dose cancer chemotherapy.
Treatment of severe congenital neutropenias.
Treatment of neutropenia in patients with AIDS receiving zidovudine.
Notable adverse reactions associated with filgrastim include bone pain, local skin reactions, and cutaneous necrotizing vasculitis.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is most appropriate to be used for the treatment of diarrhea in a patient who was treated for colorectal carcinoma with 5-fluorouracil?
questions.solution:
Loperamide is used to treat diarrhea in patients undergoing treatment for colorectal carcinoma with 5-fluorouracil (5-FU).

Loperamide is an antidiarrheal drug that acts on μ-opioid receptors and is highly potent compared to morphine in this context. However, it penetrates the central nervous system (CNS) poorly, which minimizes its CNS-related side effects. It is particularly effective in managing 5-fluorouracil-induced diarrhea, making it the treatment of choice for this condition. Additionally, loperamide is useful in treating traveler's diarrhea, either alone or in combination with other treatments.

If there is no clinical improvement in acute diarrhea within 48 hours, loperamide should be discontinued. Overdose of loperamide can result in constipation, CNS depression (especially in children), and paralytic ileus.
 

Other options:

  • Atropine: Used for acute cholinergic diarrhea due to irinotecan, not 5-FU.

  • Ornidazole: Antiprotozoal/antibiotic, used for amoebic or giardial diarrhea.
