  • Ciprofloxacin: Used for bacterial infectious diarrhea (traveler’s diarrhea, enteric fever), not chemotherapy-related.

questions.text: Bendamustine falls under which group of anti cancer agents ?
questions.solution:
Bendamustine is an example of nitrogen mustard which falls under the group of alkylating agents.
Example of other nitrogen mustard drugs include
• Cyclophosphamide
• Ifosfamide
• Mechlorethamine
• Melphalan
• Chlorambucil
• Bendamustine. Ref- Goodman and Gillman 14th edition Page 1419, 1370

questions.text: A female patient diagnosed with cervical cancer presented for chemotherapy. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
• Cisplatin is the drug of choice for cervical cancer chemotherapy, particularly in locally advanced or metastatic cases.

  • It is often used as concurrent chemoradiation in combination with radiotherapy for better outcomes.

  • Mechanism: Platinum-based alkylating agent → forms DNA crosslinks → inhibits DNA replication and transcription → induces apoptosis.

Other options:

  • Doxorubicin: Used in some gynecological cancers but not first-line for cervical cancer.

  • Bleomycin: Used mainly for germ cell tumors, Hodgkin lymphoma, not cervical cancer.

  • Trastuzumab: Monoclonal antibody for HER2-positive breast or gastric cancers, not cervical cancer.



Reference: Williams Gynecology, 4th edition - Page 665

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with renal tubular damage caused by one of his chemotherapeutic drugs. Which drug could it be?
questions.solution:
• Cisplatin is a platinum-based chemotherapeutic agent commonly used for solid tumors.

  • Major dose-limiting toxicity: Nephrotoxicity, especially proximal tubular damage, leading to:

    • Electrolyte disturbances (hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia)

    • Reduced renal function (elevated serum creatinine, BUN)

    • Rarely Fanconi-like syndrome

  • Mechanism: Direct tubular epithelial cell injury via reactive oxygen species and DNA crosslinking.

Other options:

  • Streptozocin: Mainly causes pancreatic beta-cell toxicity; rarely nephrotoxic.

  • Methysergide: Serotonin antagonist, rarely causes retroperitoneal fibrosis; not tubular damage.

  • Cyclophosphamide: Causes hemorrhagic cystitis, not tubular injury.



Reference
Katzung's Basic and Clinical Pharmacology 12/E (Lange Basic Science) - Page no 956

questions.text: Which of the following drugs restrict the availability of thymidylate?
questions.solution:
• Thymidylate synthase is the key enzyme that converts dUMP → dTMP (needed for DNA synthesis).

  • 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) is metabolized to FdUMP, which forms a stable complex with thymidylate synthase and folate cofactor → blocks thymidylate formation → DNA synthesis inhibited.

  • Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, thereby indirectly reducing folate availability for thymidylate synthesis, but the direct drug that restricts thymidylate availability is 5-FU.

  • Rituximab is an anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody (lymphoma, CLL).

  • Cisplatin forms DNA crosslinks, does not affect thymidylate.


Reference
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 12th Edition - Page no 1209

questions.text: A patient undergoing chemotherapy was given an antiemetic, after which he developed symptoms like acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. Which of the following drugs would have caused these symptoms?
questions.solution:
• The patient developed acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors after receiving an antiemetic, which are features of extrapyramidal side effects (EPS).

  • Metoclopramide, a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist, can cause:

    • Acute dystonia (early onset)

    • Parkinsonian symptoms (bradykinesia, tremors)

    • Tardive dyskinesia (long-term use)

Other options:

  • Scopolamine: Muscarinic antagonist; causes dry mouth, blurred vision, sedation, not EPS.

  • Meclizine: Antihistamine; may cause sedation or anticholinergic effects, not EPS.

  • Ondansetron: 5-HT3 antagonist; generally well-tolerated, does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms.


Reference
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition - Page no: 923, 18,

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with lung adenocarcinoma comes for her chemotherapy treatment. She has had multiple complaints of nausea and vomiting during her previous treatment visits. Which of the following is used to prevent chemotherapy-induced emesis and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) is a common and distressing side effect of many cytotoxic regimens, especially platinum-based agents (like cisplatin, commonly used in lung cancer).

Palonosetron:

  • It is a second-generation 5-HT₃ receptor antagonist.

  • It has a long half-life (~40 hours) and higher binding affinity compared to older agents like ondansetron and granisetron.

  • It is highly effective in both acute and delayed phases of CINV.

  • It is often used in combination with corticosteroids (e.g., dexamethasone) and NK1 receptor antagonists (e.g., aprepitant) for highly emetogenic chemotherapy.

    Other Options:

  • Metoclopramide: A dopamine antagonist and prokinetic. Used for gastroparesis or mild nausea, but less effective for CINV, especially with highly emetogenic agents.

  • Ropinirole: A dopamine agonist used in Parkinson’s disease and restless leg syndrome, not for nausea or vomiting.

  • Domperidone: Another peripheral dopamine antagonist. It may help with nausea, but again, it is not the drug of choice for CINV.


Reference:Goodman and gillmans The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics 13th edition page no 936-937

questions.text: A 53-year-old female was diagnosed with breast cancer. She was managed appropriately and was advised to start chemotherapy. Further investigations were done that revealed she had heart failure as well. Which of the following drugs would you avoid in this patent?
questions.solution:
• Patient: 53-year-old woman with breast cancer

  • Plan: Chemotherapy

  • Comorbidity: Heart failure

In this case, the choice of chemotherapeutic agent must consider cardiac toxicity.

Why Epirubicin Should Be Avoided:

Epirubicin is an anthracycline, similar to doxorubicin.

Cardiotoxicity is its hallmark adverse effect:

  • It causes dose-dependent, cumulative, and irreversible cardiomyopathy, which may manifest as congestive heart failure (CHF).

  • Mechanism: Generation of free radicals and oxidative stress in cardiac myocytes → leads to myocyte apoptosis and fibrosis.

  • The risk of heart failure increases especially in older patients or those with preexisting cardiac dysfunction.

In patients with heart failure, epirubicin (or any anthracycline) should be avoided or used with extreme caution. Baseline and serial LVEF (left ventricular ejection fraction) monitoring is required if used.

Other Options:

  1. Methotrexate

    • Antimetabolite.

    • No direct cardiotoxicity.

    • Can cause myelosuppression, hepatotoxicity, pulmonary fibrosis—but not heart failure.

  2. Cyclophosphamide

    • Alkylating agent.

    • Can rarely cause hemorrhagic myocarditis and pericarditis, but this is usually acute and high-dose related.

    • Not a contraindication in stable chronic heart failure at standard doses.

  3. Cisplatin

    • Platinum-based drug.

    • Nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity, and electrolyte disturbances (especially hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia).

    • No significant cardiotoxicity, though electrolyte disturbances can exacerbate cardiac problems if severe.


Reference: Goodman and gillmans The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics 13th edition page no 1192-1193
